question: How must an Authorised Person align its obligation to identify conflicts of interest across its managers, Employees and Clients with its separate obligation to maintain adequate procedures and controls when it prepares or publishes Investment Research?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must comply with Principle 7 by taking all reasonable steps to identify conflicts of interest that arise or may arise while it provides any Regulated Activities, including conflicts involving the Authorised Person and its managers, Employees and Clients (and persons linked by control), as well as conflicts between one Client and another Client [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319]. Separately, the Authorised Person must have adequate procedures and controls when it prepares or publishes Investment Research [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]. Read together, the Authorised Person should ensure that its Investment Research procedures and controls are designed and operated in a way that supports, and does not undermine, the reasonable-steps obligation to identify conflicts—because the Source makes clear that the rule’s requirements apply in addition to other requirements under FSMR and any rules made thereunder [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]. The Source also indicates that, after identifying actual or potential conflicts, the Authorised Person is required to prevent or manage them, which should be reflected in how research-related controls are implemented [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759].
source_text: The requirements in this Rule ‎6.4.2 apply to an Authorised Person in addition to other requirements under FSMR and any rules made thereunder. For example, an Authorised Person is required to take reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest and then prevent or manage them under GEN 3.3.21-3.3.24. An Authorised Person must also have adequate procedures and controls when it prepares or publishes Investment Research.
target_text:
Conflicts of Interest: An Authorised Person must comply with Principle 7 as outlined in Rule ‎2.2.7, taking all reasonable steps to identify conflicts of interest between:
(1)	the Authorised Person, including its managers, Employees and Clients, or any person directly or indirectly linked to them by control; or
(2)	one Client of the Authorised Person and another Client,
that arises or may arise in the course of the Authorised Person providing any Regulated Activities.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity wants to publish Exploration Results or Mineral Resources/Ore Reserves estimates, what do they need to do first with the Competent Person(s), and what exact Competent Person details must be written into the disclosure (name, job relationship/employer, and professional organisation)?
gold_answer: Before publishing the disclosure, the Mining Reporting Entity must obtain prior written consent from the Competent Person(s) that covers the form and context in which the Exploration Results or the Mineral Resources/Ore Reserves estimates (and the supporting information) will be presented. [#SRC:c30b96f6-edff-4774-b206-68a20fe00ba8] That consent requirement operates alongside the content requirements for the disclosure itself, so the disclosure must also include specific statements about the Competent Person(s). [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] In the disclosure text, the entity must: (1) identify a named Competent Person(s) and state that the disclosure is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by that person(s). [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] (2) For each Competent Person, state whether the person is an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party; if the person is neither, the disclosure must give the name of the Competent Person’s employer. [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] (3) For each Competent Person, include the name of the professional organisation of which the person is a member. [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] These disclosure statements should be consistent with the form and context that the Competent Person(s) consented to in writing. [#SRC:c30b96f6-edff-4774-b206-68a20fe00ba8]
source_text: Competent Persons . The disclosure made in Rule 11.12.1 must only be made with the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) as to the form and context in which the Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, as the case may be, and the supporting information is presented in the disclosure.
target_text:
Competent Persons . Subject to Rule 11.12.2, a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity containing Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves must state:
(1)	that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s);
(2)	in each case, whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer; and
(3)	in each case, the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.

question: Where an Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business has a Financial Service Permission that entitles it to hold Client Money, what must it do to ensure a Client Money Auditor's Report is submitted to the Regulator annually, and what specific confirmations must it ensure an Auditor includes in that report as at the date of the audited statement of financial position?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business whose Financial Service Permission entitles it to hold Client Money must arrange for a Client Money Auditor's Report to be submitted to the Regulator on an annual basis [#SRC:c42abaa9-4c93-4d5b-b989-aa4ec57cf600]. In addition, when procuring the production of that Client Money Auditor's Report, the Authorised Person must ensure that an Auditor states, as at the date of which the Authorised Person’s audited statement of financial position was prepared, the amount of Client Money the Authorised Person was holding and controlling in accordance with COBS Chapter 14 [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17]. The Authorised Person must also ensure the Auditor addresses whether the Authorised Person maintained throughout the year systems and controls to comply with the relevant provisions of COBS Chapter 14, whether controls ensure Client Money is identifiable and secure at all times, and whether any COBS Chapter 14 requirements were not met. The report must further cover whether Client Money was pooled in a single client Account or segregated in Client Accounts for individual Clients, whether (if applicable) the appropriate amount of Client Money was held and controlled as at the statement date, whether the Auditor received all necessary information and explanations, and whether (if applicable) there were any material reconciliation discrepancies [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17].
source_text: An Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business whose Financial Service Permission entitles them to hold Client Money must also arrange for a Client Money Auditor's Report to be submitted to the Regulator on an annual basis in accordance with GEN 6.6.6.

question: Where a trader rapidly accumulates control of more than 90% of the physical inventory underlying a crude oil contract on a Commodity Derivative Exchange and then exits the position in the final settlement window at escalating prices, how should this conduct be assessed against the definition of Behaviour that involves effecting transactions or orders to trade other than for legitimate reasons and not in conformity with Accepted Market Practices, particularly in relation to creating a misleading impression of supply/demand or securing an abnormal or artificial price level?
gold_answer: The scenario describes an “abusive squeeze” in which a trader rapidly builds a dominant position in the physical inventory underlying a crude oil contract, does not offer to lend the crude oil back at a reasonable commercial rate, and then unwinds the position in the Exchange’s final settlement window at rapidly increasing prices, with the stated effect of cornering/squeezing the market and causing an abnormal movement in forward-month crude oil contract prices [#SRC:350b6237-da6f-47c6-b04c-10caf56bf9d7]. Under the definition, the relevant assessment is whether the trader’s conduct constitutes “Behaviour” consisting of effecting transactions or orders to trade otherwise than for legitimate reasons and not in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market, and whether those transactions/orders (a) give or are likely to give a false or misleading impression as to supply, demand, or price, or (b) secure the price at an abnormal or artificial level [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f]. The described withholding of inventory from lending and the subsequent unwind at escalating prices, coupled with the abnormal price movement, are the key factual elements to map to the definition’s “misleading impression” and “abnormal/artificial level” limbs.
source_text:
Abusive squeezes. The following are specific examples of an abusive squeeze that, in the Regulator's view, may contravene section 92 (4)(b):
(a)	during the course of a trading day on a Commodity Derivative Exchange, a trader rapidly builds up a position of more than 90% of the physical inventory underlying a crude oil contract.  The trader fails to Offer to lend the crude oil back to other market participants at a reasonable commercial rate.  The trader then unwinds his position in the Exchange's final settlement window  at rapidly increasing prices, thereby cornering/squeezing the crude oil market.  His conduct causes an abnormal movement in the price of crude oil contracts for forward month delivery; and
(b)	a trader with a long position in bond futures, buys or borrows a large amount of the bonds and either refuses to re-lend these bonds or will only lend them to parties he believes will not re-lend to the market.  His purpose is to position the price at which persons with short positions have to deliver to satisfy their obligations at a materially higher level, making him a profit on his position.
target_text:
The third is where the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade (otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market) which—
(a)	give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to the supply of, or demand for, or as to the price of, one or more Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; or
(b)	secure the price of one or more such instruments at an abnormal or artificial level.

question: When a law enforcement agency seeks a person’s interview answers taken under section 206(1)(a) for use in criminal proceedings against that same person, how do the Regulator’s notification practice and the Investigator’s disclosure prohibition operate together, including the consent pathway and the law/court-order exception?
gold_answer: In this scenario, disclosure to a law enforcement agency for criminal proceedings against the person is generally blocked unless a specific condition is met, and the person is typically given a chance to respond before disclosure occurs. The Investigator is prohibited from disclosing the person’s statement (i.e., answers to questions asked under a section 206(1)(a) requirement) to any law enforcement agency for that purpose unless the person consents or the Regulator must disclose due to law or a court order. [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff] When the Regulator receives such a request from a law enforcement agency, the Regulator will generally notify the person concerned so the person has an opportunity either to consent to the disclosure or to challenge the request. [#SRC:1e42ed63-f4af-4b44-9cb5-90fa843a8951] This notification practice aligns with the consent-based disclosure route described for the Investigator, because the person’s consent is one of the two stated gateways for disclosure. [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff] However, the notification is not expected where disclosure is compelled: the Regulator may be required by law or court order to disclose the statement, and in that case the Regulator may disclose without following the general notification approach. [#SRC:1e42ed63-f4af-4b44-9cb5-90fa843a8951] The same law/court-order compulsion is also an express exception to the Investigator’s non-disclosure rule. [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff]
source_text: If the Regulator receives a request from a law enforcement agency for a person's answers in an interview conducted under section 206(1)(a) of the FSMR for the purpose of criminal proceedings against the person, the Regulator will, in accordance with section 207(2) of the FSMR, generally notify the person concerned of such request (so that the person has an opportunity to either consent to the disclosure or challenge the request), unless the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose the statement.
target_text:
The Investigator shall not disclose a statement made by a person in answer to any question asked pursuant to a requirement made of the person under section ‎206‎(1)‎(a) to any law enforcement agency for the purpose of criminal proceedings against the person unless—
(a)	the person consents to the disclosure; or
(b)	the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose the statement.

question: For a Third Party Provider entering into a Governing Contract with a Customer, what information must be included in the Governing Contract (absent a written agreement otherwise), and by what point must that Rule 20.2.2 information be provided so the Customer is not bound before receiving it?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider must ensure the Customer receives the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 before the Customer becomes bound by the Governing Contract. [#SRC:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8] Unless the Third Party Provider and their Customer have otherwise agreed in writing, that Rule 20.2.2 information is the set of items that the Governing Contract itself is required to contain. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] In practice, this means the contract must include, at a minimum, identifying and regulatory details about the Third Party Provider (including its name, ADGM office contact details, and the name of its Regulator and Financial Service Permission details), and operational details about the Third Party Services (including service characteristics, what customer information/identifier is needed for a Third Party Transaction, consent process, time of receipt of a Third Party Transaction, maximum service time, and any usage limits). [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] It must also cover charges and (where relevant) exchange rates and Reference Exchange Rates mechanics, agreed communication methods and frequencies (including what Customer information is transferred to the Customer’s Financial Institution), safeguards/corrective measures (including notification periods for unauthorised or incorrect Third Party Transactions and relevant liability/refund conditions), change/termination terms, and redress provisions. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] The timing requirement is that this information must be provided before the Customer is bound, even if information may also be provided during the period of the Governing Contract. [#SRC:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8]
source_text:
A Third Party Provider must provide a Customer the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 before the Customer is bound by the Governing Contract.
Information provision during period of the Governing Contract

question: For a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity preparing its quarterly report, what information must the report contain (including any consolidated-basis requirement and the 12‑month reserves/resources disclosure cross-reference), and by when after quarter-end must the report required by Rule 12.13.1 be disclosed?
gold_answer: A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity must both (i) include specified content in its quarterly report for each quarter of its financial year and (ii) disclose the Rule 12.13.1 report within a defined post‑quarter deadline. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] [#SRC:380ff25a-7805-4020-9f40-da991f91eab1] The quarterly report must cover the Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity and all controlled entities, prepared on a consolidated basis where applicable. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] It must include: details of Petroleum-related activities for Exploration (or a statement of no Exploration activity) and for production and development (or a statement of no mining production and development activity); a summary of expenditure incurred for Exploration and for production and development; Petroleum Tenements held at quarter-end with location and percentage interest (including beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements); and Petroleum Tenements (including those beneficial interests) acquired or disposed of during the quarter with their location. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] In addition, at least once every 12 months the report must address the Summary of Reserves and Resources required by Rule 12.14.1 unless that summary is included in the annual report, and it must state when the previous and upcoming disclosures of that summary were and are to be made. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] The Rule 12.13.1 quarterly report must be disclosed no later than one month after the end of the quarter. [#SRC:380ff25a-7805-4020-9f40-da991f91eab1]
source_text: Quarterly Reports – Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entities. A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity must disclose the report required by Rule 12.13.1 no later than one month after the end of the quarter.

question: For a Listed Entity preparing its annual financial report under the annual reporting on compliance section, how should the Directors’ statement about the effectiveness of the Corporate Governance framework be framed so that it also aligns with the annual report statement required under Rule 9.2.10, including the specific outcome reference and the required supporting material?
gold_answer: The Directors should provide an effectiveness statement that simultaneously (i) addresses the Listed Entity annual financial report requirement to opine on whether the Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, and (ii) satisfies the annual report requirement under Rule 9.2.10 by also stating whether the framework is effective in achieving the outcome required by section 73 of the FSMR. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] [#SRC:2d67e3e8-d385-4fc8-aff1-487611d02cca] The statement must be made by Directors/Board and must be supported by information and assumptions, and include qualifications where needed. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] [#SRC:2d67e3e8-d385-4fc8-aff1-487611d02cca] In addition, because the annual financial report must state whether the best practice standards in APP 4 have been adopted, the effectiveness statement should be consistent with (and informed by) that adoption disclosure and any explanation of partial/non-adoption and actions taken to achieve compliance. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] Finally, the Board should treat how the Principles are applied as the central focus when determining how the Reporting Entity conducts its affairs in line with the applicable requirements, so the supporting information should address application of the Principles in practice. [#SRC:2d67e3e8-d385-4fc8-aff1-487611d02cca]
source_text: General. The annual report required under Rule 9.2.10 must include a statement by the Board of Directors (the "Board"), stating whether or not, in its opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Reporting Entity is effective in achieving the outcome required by section 73 of the FSMR and promoting compliance with the Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary. As the Principles are the core of the Corporate Governance framework, the way in which they are applied should be the central question for the Board as it determines how the Reporting Entity conducts its affairs under its directorship in accordance with the letter and spirit of the applicable requirements including the Principles and the standards.
target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: Before a Customer becomes bound by the Governing Contract, what information must a Third Party Provider provide, and how does that obligation align with the requirement that the Governing Contract itself include specified content unless the parties agree otherwise in writing?
gold_answer: A Third Party Provider must ensure that, before the Customer is bound by the Governing Contract, the Customer is provided with the information that is required to be given at that pre‑contract stage [#SRC:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8]. In parallel, unless the Third Party Provider and their Customer otherwise agree in writing, the Governing Contract between the Third Party Provider and their Customers must itself contain specified information covering: details about the Third Party Provider (including identity, ADGM office contact details, and regulator/FSP details); the Third Party Services (including key characteristics, required Customer identifiers, consent process, receipt timing, service timeframes, and usage limits); charges and exchange rates; agreed communications and information delivery arrangements; safeguards and corrective measures (including notification periods for unauthorised/incorrectly executed Third Party Transactions, fraud/security contact procedures, stopping conditions, and liability/refund-related terms); changes and termination terms; and redress mechanisms (including applicable law/courts and any alternative dispute resolution) [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]. Taken together, the Third Party Provider must both provide the required information before the Customer is bound and, absent a written variation, embed the required disclosures and operational terms within the Governing Contract itself.
source_text:
A Third Party Provider must provide a Customer the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 before the Customer is bound by the Governing Contract.
Information provision during period of the Governing Contract

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure that includes Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, what must it do to ensure the disclosure is both properly attributed to named Competent Person(s) and is issued only with the necessary prior written consent regarding how the information is presented?
gold_answer: For a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity that contains Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, the disclosure must include specific Competent Person attribution statements and also be controlled by the Competent Person(s) through prior written consent on presentation. First, the disclosure must state that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s). It must also state, for each Competent Person, whether the person is an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party; if not, it must identify the Competent Person’s employer. In addition, it must state the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203]. Separately, where the disclosure involves Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves and supporting information, it must only be made with the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) as to the form and context in which that information is presented [#SRC:c30b96f6-edff-4774-b206-68a20fe00ba8].
source_text: Competent Persons . The disclosure made in Rule 11.12.1 must only be made with the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) as to the form and context in which the Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, as the case may be, and the supporting information is presented in the disclosure.
target_text:
Competent Persons . Subject to Rule 11.12.2, a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity containing Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves must state:
(1)	that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s);
(2)	in each case, whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer; and
(3)	in each case, the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.

question: If you have precise information that isn’t public and it’s about a Reporting Entity or Issuer, how do you decide whether it counts as “Inside Information” for products that are not Commodity Derivatives, especially when it might move the price of a Related Instrument?
gold_answer: You treat it as “Inside Information” only if it meets the full definition for products that are not Commodity Derivatives, including the part about likely price impact. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] First, the information must be of a Precise nature and not generally available. [#SRC:ba7db39b-8edf-4a95-94c3-14bd0ddb9c18] Second, it must relate directly or indirectly either to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers of the Financial Instruments, or to one or more of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, or Accepted Spot Commodities. [#SRC:ba7db39b-8edf-4a95-94c3-14bd0ddb9c18] Third, you must consider whether making it public would be likely to have a significant effect on price. [#SRC:ba7db39b-8edf-4a95-94c3-14bd0ddb9c18] In doing that price test, you do not stop at the main product mentioned: the definition also covers a likely significant effect on the price of Related Instruments (as well as Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, and Accepted Spot Commodities) within the non-Commodity Derivatives scope. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] If any of these elements is missing, the information does not meet the definition. [#SRC:ba7db39b-8edf-4a95-94c3-14bd0ddb9c18]
source_text:
Definition. "Inside Information" is defined in section 95(2) as meaning information of a Precise nature which, in relation to Financial Instruments, Related Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities which are not Commodity Derivatives:
(a)	is not generally available;
(b)	relates, directly or indirectly, to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers of the Financial Instruments or to one or more of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; and
(c)	would, if generally available, be likely to have a significant effect on the price of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities or on the price of Related Instruments.
target_text:
In relation to Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments which are not Commodity Derivatives, Inside Information is information of a Precise nature which—
(a)	is not generally available;
(b)	relates, directly or indirectly, to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers of the Financial Instruments or to one or more of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; and
(c)	would, if generally available, be likely to have a significant effect on the price of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments.

question: If a Listed Entity plans an issue of Securities and wants to rely on approval from holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.5.3, what does it have to do when the Related Party Transaction is below the 5% net-assets threshold, and what extra step applies if a series of unapproved transactions with the same Related Party reaches 5% within 12 months?
gold_answer: Where the issue of Securities is being made using approval from holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.5.3 (Related Party Transaction), the Listed Entity must apply the Related Party Transaction procedures that distinguish between transactions below and at/above the 5% net-assets threshold. [#SRC:0e803fa7-08d6-46fa-802d-ed7fe0c0cfd4] [#TGT:4671ca00-05bb-4d71-86bf-d345d30630de] If the value of the proposed Related Party Transaction is less than 5% of the value of the net assets of the Listed Entity (as stated in its most recent financial reports), the Reporting Entity must, as soon as possible after entering the transaction, notify the Regulator of the relevant terms and explain the basis on which those terms are considered fair and reasonable, supported by written confirmation from an independent third party. [#TGT:4671ca00-05bb-4d71-86bf-d345d30630de] It must also disclose the Related Party Transaction in accordance with Rule 7.7.1. [#TGT:4671ca00-05bb-4d71-86bf-d345d30630de] Separately, if there is a series of Related Party Transactions with the same Related Party that have not received Shareholder approval and their cumulative value reaches the 5% threshold in any 12 month period, the Listed Entity must not enter into the last transaction in that series unless it is put to Shareholder approval and receives approval by a majority of the Shareholders in voting. [#TGT:4671ca00-05bb-4d71-86bf-d345d30630de] This ties back to the securities issuance being undertaken in the Rule 9.5.3 approval context. [#SRC:0e803fa7-08d6-46fa-802d-ed7fe0c0cfd4]
source_text: An issue of Securities made with the approval of the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.5.3 (Related Party Transaction).

question: If an Authorised Person has private sector credit exposures in different jurisdictions, what do they have to do to work out the Countercyclical Capital Buffer and how does that connect to the rule that says they must keep the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must both (1) compute a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital using a jurisdiction-based formula and (2) continuously hold the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital. [#TGT:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] For the calculation, the Countercyclical Capital Buffer must equal the Authorised Person’s Total Risk Exposure Amount multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where its private sector credit exposures are located. [#TGT:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] The Total Risk Exposure Amount used in that multiplication must be calculated under Rule 3.5.7, and the weighted average of the jurisdictional buffer rates must be calculated under Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8. [#TGT:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] Separately, the Authorised Person must maintain the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times, and that required buffer amount is determined using the calculation approach in Rule 3.18.4. [#SRC:97faadb3-289b-44a9-9f5c-3ea5c35e39cf] Taken together, the rules mean the Authorised Person cannot treat the buffer as a one-off computation; it must be held continuously in CET1 Capital while being calculated using the specified rule-based methods. [#SRC:97faadb3-289b-44a9-9f5c-3ea5c35e39cf]
source_text: An Authorised Person must maintain the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times, as calculated in accordance with Rule 3.18.4.
target_text: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital equal to its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures are located, calculated in accordance with Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8.

question: When an Authorised Person takes out and maintains professional indemnity insurance cover that is appropriate to its nature, size, complexity and risk profile, what specific features should the insurance contract include regarding the Insurer and the scope of claims and legal costs, and how do the annual submission and notification duties to the Regulator apply to that cover?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must maintain professional indemnity insurance that fits the nature, size, complexity and risk profile of its business, and that same cover should be structured as a contract placed with a reputable and well capitalised Insurer and drafted to address the Authorised Person’s potential liabilities and related legal costs. [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b] [#SRC:3c5ec7af-6f4a-41d7-988c-13494992bc71] In practical terms, the contract should include cover for claims where the Authorised Person may be liable due to the conduct of itself and its Employees, and it should also provide appropriate cover for legal costs that arise from a claim. [#SRC:3c5ec7af-6f4a-41d7-988c-13494992bc71] In addition to maintaining the cover, the Authorised Person must, at least once each year, give the Regulator a copy of the insurance cover for the next 12 months and be able to show that the cover is adequate against the same nature/size/complexity/risk-profile benchmark. [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b] The Authorised Person must also notify the Regulator of any material changes to that cover, including changes to the level of cover and events such as renewal or termination. [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b]
source_text: In complying with Rule 6.12.2, an Authorised Person should take out and maintain a contract for professional indemnity insurance (PII) from a reputable and well capitalised Insurer and such contract should include cover in respect of claims for which the Authorised Person may be liable as a result of the conduct of itself and its Employees and appropriate cover in respect of legal costs arising from a claim.
target_text:
An Authorised Person must:
(a)	subject to Rule 6.12A, take out and maintain professional indemnity insurance cover appropriate to the nature, size, complexity and risk profile of the Authorised Person's business;
(b)	at least annually, provide the Regulator with a copy of the professional indemnity insurance cover in (a) covering the following 12 month period and be able to demonstrate its adequacy in relation to the nature, size, complexity and risk profile of the Authorised Person’s business; and
(c)	notify the Regulator of any material changes to the cover in (a), including the level of cover, its renewal or termination.

question: If an Authorised Person is allowed to hold Client Money, what must it do each year about the Client Money Auditor's Report, and what must it make sure the Auditor says in the report about Client Money and controls as at the audited statement of financial position date?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business has a Financial Service Permission that entitles it to hold Client Money, it must arrange for a Client Money Auditor’s Report to be submitted to the Regulator every year [#SRC:c42abaa9-4c93-4d5b-b989-aa4ec57cf600]. When it is procuring the production of that report, the Authorised Person must also ensure an Auditor includes specific statements tied to the date the Authorised Person’s audited statement of financial position was prepared [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17]. These include the amount of Client Money the Authorised Person was holding and controlling in accordance with COBS Chapter 14, and whether the Authorised Person maintained systems and controls throughout the year to comply with the relevant COBS Chapter 14 provisions. The Auditor must also state whether controls keep Client Money identifiable and secure at all times, whether any COBS Chapter 14 requirements were not met, and whether Client Money was pooled in a single client Account or segregated in Client Accounts for individual Clients. If applicable, the Auditor must address whether the appropriate amount of Client Money was held and controlled at the statement date, whether the Auditor received all necessary information and explanations, and whether there were any material discrepancies in Client Money reconciliation [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17].
source_text: An Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business whose Financial Service Permission entitles them to hold Client Money must also arrange for a Client Money Auditor's Report to be submitted to the Regulator on an annual basis in accordance with GEN 6.6.6.

question: When the Prospectus for a Passported Fund is amended or replaced and the Regulator must be notified, what must be sent with the notification, and what is the latest deadline for sending it once the relevant party knows about the change?
gold_answer: If the Prospectus relating to a Passported Fund is amended or replaced, this is one of the events that triggers a requirement to notify the Regulator as soon as practicable and, in any case, no later than seven days after it becomes aware of the event [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898]. The notification must also meet minimum submission and information standards. It must be made in the prescribed form that the Regulator may direct from time to time, and it must be accompanied by reasonable detail of the event—here, the nature of the Prospectus change—so the Regulator has an adequate description of what occurred [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f]. In addition, because the Prospectus has been amended or replaced, the notification must include a copy of the new Prospectus, ensuring the Regulator receives the updated disclosure document together with the notice and supporting detail [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f].
source_text: The notification referred to in Rule 6.6.2 must be in such prescribed form as the Regulator may direct from time to time.  At a minimum, the notification must be accompanied by reasonable detail of the event and (where the Prospectus has been amended or replaced) a copy of the new Prospectus.

question: If someone plans to buy or increase control in a Domestic Firm and also needs the Regulator’s prior written approval, what notice do they have to send, and who decides the required format?
gold_answer: In the control-change scenario, a person who proposes either to acquire or increase the level of control in a Domestic Firm must give us written notice, and it must be submitted in the form we set [#SRC:4068f5d7-33d4-473c-b314-4ee227d051bd]. Separately, if a Person is required to obtain the prior written approval of the Regulator, that Person must provide written notice to the Regulator, and the format must follow what the Regulator prescribes [#TGT:9b45a767-f8c2-493b-b0ae-d9f349767787]. So, the sender must prepare a written notice and ensure it matches the required form specified by the relevant authority. The Source also explains what can happen after submission: we may approve, object, or impose conditions, and if the application is incomplete or unclear we may request clarification in writing at any time during processing; the decision period does not start until the additional information is provided to our satisfaction [#SRC:4068f5d7-33d4-473c-b314-4ee227d051bd].
source_text: Controllers - Our approval. Under GEN 8.8.5(1), a person who proposes either to acquire or increase the level of control in a Domestic Firm must provide written notice to us in such form as we shall set. We may approve of, object to or impose conditions relating to the proposed acquisition or the proposed increase in the level of control of the firm. If the information in the written application lodged with us is incomplete or unclear, we may in writing request further clarification or information. We may do so at any time during the processing of such an application. The period of 90 days within which we will make a decision will not commence until such clarification or additional information is provided to our satisfaction. We may, in our absolute discretion, agree to a shorter period for processing an application where an applicant requests for such a period, provided all the information required is available to us.
target_text: A Person who is required to obtain the prior written approval of the Regulator pursuant to Rule ‎8.8.4(1) must provide written notice to the Regulator in such form as the Regulator shall prescribe.

question: When an Authorised Person is calculating RWA for all its securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures), how must it treat Early Amortisation Exposures within that overall calculation, including (i) the formula and risk-weight basis used for Early Amortisation Exposures and (ii) how those results are combined with the RWA for other SE Exposures?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must compute RWA for its SE Exposures by calculating RWA for each SE Exposure (other than those required to be deducted from any component of Capital Resources) and then combining those amounts with the separately calculated RWA for its Early Amortisation Exposures. [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] For each SE Exposure that is not deducted from Capital Resources, it must first determine the Exposure value under the Section 4.9 exposure measurement methodology while recognising applicable CRM, assign a Credit Quality Grade under Section 4.11, and then apply the formula RWA(SE) = SE × CRW, where CRW is the risk weight determined from that Credit Quality Grade. [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] In parallel, for each Early Amortisation Exposure it must calculate the Exposure value (EAE) under Section 4.9 while recognising applicable CRM and then compute RWA(EAE) = EAE × CRW, where CRW is the risk weight for the underlying Exposure type as if the Exposure had not been securitised. [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e] Finally, it must add together (i) the RWA(SE) amounts across all relevant SE Exposures and (ii) the aggregated RWA(EAE) amounts across all Early Amortisation Exposures to arrive at the combined RWA total for these securitisation-related positions. [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e]
target_text:
Calculation of RWA for securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures). To calculate its RWA for Early Amortisation Exposures, an Authorised Person must:
(a)	calculate the value of the Exposure (EAE) for each of its Early Amortisation Exposures in accordance with Exposure measurement methodology specified in Section 4.9 and recognising the effects of any applicable CRM;
(b)	calculate the risk weighted Exposure amount for each Early Amortisation Exposure using the following formula: RWA(EAE) = EAE x CRW
where:
(i)	"RWA(EAE)" refers to the risk weighted Exposure amount for that Early Amortisation Exposure;
(ii)	"EAE" refers to the Exposure value or amount, for that Early Amortisation Exposure calculated in accordance with (a); and
(iii)	"CRW" refers to the applicable risk weight for the underlying Exposure type as if the Exposure had not been securitised; and
(c)	add the RWA amounts calculated in accordance with (b) for all its Early Amortisation Exposures.

question: If you are working out E for a reverse repurchase agreement, what numbers do you subtract and, when you need the MV of the Securities and the value of Collateral for Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6, where do you get the method for calculating those values?
gold_answer: To calculate E for a reverse repurchase agreement, you start with the amount paid (or the Collateral given) and then subtract the MV of the Securities received. [#TGT:4262e773-aad2-4422-b6b3-fea38fd9d619] However, you cannot choose any ad hoc approach for those MV and collateral figures when the calculation is being done under Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6. [#SRC:379a83c2-96da-4b2a-acea-f8779444878d] Instead, the MV of Securities and the value of Collateral that feed into the reverse repo E formula must be calculated using the CRM provisions in Section 4.13, because Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6 specify that those values should be calculated in accordance with that Section 4.13 CRM framework. [#SRC:379a83c2-96da-4b2a-acea-f8779444878d] Put together, the steps are: (1) identify the amount paid or Collateral given and the Securities received for the reverse repurchase agreement, (2) calculate the MV of the Securities and the value of any Collateral using Section 4.13’s CRM provisions, and (3) plug those results into the E equation by subtracting the MV of the Securities received from the amount paid or Collateral given. [#TGT:4262e773-aad2-4422-b6b3-fea38fd9d619]
source_text: The MV of Securities and the value of Collateral under Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6 should be calculated in accordance with the CRM provisions set out in Section 4.13.
target_text:
For reverse repurchase agreements:
E = Amount paid or Collateral given   MV of the Securities received.

question: Where an Authorised Person is authorised for custody or trustee services connected to a Fund or Investment Trust, what additional permission-based conditions would prevent it from being treated as Category 3B and instead place it in Category 1?
gold_answer: Category 3B is only available if the Authorised Person’s Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on Providing Custody (where it does so for a Fund) or Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust, and it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5; accordingly, if the firm meets Category 1 criteria, it is excluded from Category 3B by the express “does not meet” condition [#SRC:c1ffeb55-d01d-48f4-b82b-88eb654acbbe]. Category 1 is met where the Financial Services Permission authorises the firm to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, and the firm does not meet the criteria of Category 5; the guidance clarifies that this authorisation is determinative even if other Regulated Activities are also authorised [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. Therefore, a custody/trustee-authorised firm would be prevented from being treated as Category 3B, and instead be treated as Category 1, if its permission also includes Accepting Deposits or Managing a PSIAu and it is not within Category 5, because that would cause it to meet Category 1 and fail the Category 3B exclusion test.
source_text:
Category 3B
An Authorised Person is in Category 3B if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of:
(i)	Providing Custody (where it does so for a Fund); or
(ii)	Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust; and
(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5.
Guidance
A Category 3B Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Providing Custody for a Fund or Acting as Trustee of a Fund, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1, 1.3.2 and 1.3.3 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3B.
target_text:
Category 1
An Authorised Person is in Category 1 if:
(a)		(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu; and
(b)		(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Category 5.
Guidance
A Category 1 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu that is determinative of its belonging to Category 1.
Category 2
Guidance
1.	A Category 2 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1, that are determinative of its belonging to Category 2.
2.	Where the dealing activities of a firm are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the activities fall in the scope of Category 3A in accordance with Rule 1.3.3(1). A definition of "Matched Principal" is in Rule 1.3.3(2).

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information under Rule 11.9.1 that is derived from a Production Target, what specific Production Target-related content must be carried into the Rule 11.9.1 disclosure, and what additional Production Target disclosure elements are required under Rule 11.8.2 (including any required statements where forecast commodity prices or Inferred Mineral Resources are involved)?
gold_answer: A Rule 11.9.1 disclosure of forecast financial information must incorporate the underlying Production Target and, specifically, must include that Production Target together with all the information that Rule 11.8.3 requires for the Production Target. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In addition, the Production Target disclosure framework in Rule 11.8.2 requires detailed content about how the Production Target was determined, which becomes relevant because the forecast financial information is expressly derived from that Production Target. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] In practice, the Production Target disclosure must cover the assumptions used to determine the Production Target, including all material economic assumptions, or (if treated as commercially sensitive) a sensitivity statement plus an explanation of the methodology used to determine those economic assumptions, and all other material assumptions. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] If forecast commodity prices were used to determine the Production Target, the disclosure must also state that the forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] Where the Production Target is wholly or partly based on Inferred Mineral Resources (or partly on an Exploration Target), the disclosure must include the specified prominent, proximate cautionary statements and, for a wholly Inferred basis, additional explanation and a Technical Study prepared by or under the supervision of a named independent Competent Person(s). [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity already made a full Rule 11.8.2 Production Target disclosure, when can it make a later update without repeating all the details (like the assumptions and the split between Ore Reserves/Mineral Resources/Exploration Target), and what must it still say if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or partly based on an Exploration Target?
gold_answer: A later disclosure about a Production Target does not have to repeat all the detailed Rule 11.8.2 information (for example, the material economic assumptions and other material assumptions, whether forecast commodity prices were used on reasonable grounds, and the proportions sourced from Ore Reserves, Mineral Resources, Inferred Mineral Resources, and any Exploration Target) if it properly relies on an earlier Rule 11.8.2 disclosure that already included those items and was compliant. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] To do that, the later disclosure must refer back to the earlier compliant disclosure and must also confirm that the material assumptions from the initial disclosure still apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] Even when the later disclosure is streamlined, it still needs to include specific prominent warnings in certain cases: if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the later disclosure must include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement matching the required Inferred Mineral Resources warning for that scenario. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] If the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, the later disclosure must include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement matching the required Exploration Target warning. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]

question: Where a person is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, and an investor who acquired Securities suffers loss from an untrue or misleading statement or a material omission in that Prospectus, what publication-related steps (and timing relative to acquisition) can prevent that person from incurring liability for the loss, including the case where the issue is that an Expert was not competent or did not consent?
gold_answer: A person who is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus can be liable to pay compensation to an acquirer of the relevant Securities for loss or damage caused by an untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus, or by omitting a material matter that was required to be included. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] However, that person does not incur liability for loss in respect of the Securities if, before the Securities were acquired, either (i) a correction was published in a way intended to reach persons likely to acquire those Securities, or (ii) where the statement is of the type attributed to an Expert, the fact that the Expert was not competent or had not consented to inclusion of the attributed statement was published in that same attention-getting manner. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] Alternatively, liability is avoided if the person took all steps that it was reasonable to take to secure that publication and, on reasonable grounds, believed the publication had occurred before the Securities were acquired. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] The key linkage is that the compensation exposure tied to untrue/misleading statements or material omissions is addressed by timely, appropriately targeted publication (or reasonable efforts and belief of publication) occurring before acquisition. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b]
source_text:
Without prejudice to (2) and (3), a Person does not incur any liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR for any loss in respect of any Securities caused by any statement or omission as is mentioned in that Article if:
(a)	before the Securities were acquired by any Person, a correction or, where the statement was such as is mentioned in (2)(c), the fact that the Expert was not competent or had not consented to the inclusion of the statement attributed to that Expert in the Prospectus had been published in a manner designed to bring to the attention of Persons likely to acquire the Securities in question; or
(b)	he took all such steps as it was reasonable for him to take to secure such publication and believed on reasonable grounds that such a publication had taken place before the Securities were acquired.
target_text: Any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to another person who has acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and who has suffered loss or damage arising from any untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission from it of any material matter required to have been included in the Prospectus by or under these Regulations.

question: Where a person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator is liable to pay compensation for loss suffered by an acquirer of Securities due to an untrue or misleading statement, or a missing material matter required to be included, what specific showings can that person rely on to avoid incurring civil liability, including any steps that must be taken before the Securities are acquired in reliance on the Prospectus?
gold_answer: A person who is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus can face an obligation to pay compensation to someone who acquired the relevant Securities and suffered loss or damage because the Prospectus contained an untrue or misleading statement or omitted a material matter that was required to be included. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] However, that person does not incur civil liability if they can establish one of the specified defenses tied to the accuracy of the Prospectus, the reasonableness of their diligence, or timely corrective action. [#SRC:4ce33793-6bb5-4bc3-a65f-675a4ac19554] To avoid civil liability in this compensation context, the person must be able to show at least one of the following: (i) the relevant statement was true (and not false, misleading, or deceptive) or that the matter whose omission caused the loss was properly omitted; (ii) they made all enquiries that were reasonable in the circumstances and believed there was no false, misleading, or deceptive statement or omission in the Prospectus; or (iii) before any person acquired the Securities in reliance on the Prospectus, they took all steps that were reasonable for them to take to ensure a correction was promptly made and brought to the attention of persons likely to acquire the Securities. [#SRC:4ce33793-6bb5-4bc3-a65f-675a4ac19554]
source_text:
A Person does not incur civil liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR if that Person can show that:
(a)	the statement was true and not false, misleading, or deceptive or that the matter the omission of which caused the loss was properly omitted;
(b)	he made all enquiries that were reasonable in the circumstances and believed that there was no false, misleading, or deceptive statement or omission in the Prospectus; or
(c)	before the Securities were acquired by any Person in reliance on the Prospectus, he had taken all such steps as were reasonable for him to have taken to secure that a correction was promptly made and brought to the attention of the Persons likely to acquire the Securities in question.
target_text: Any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to another person who has acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and who has suffered loss or damage arising from any untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission from it of any material matter required to have been included in the Prospectus by or under these Regulations.

question: If an Authorised Person is allowed (by its Financial Service Permission) to hold Client Money while doing Investment Business, what report has to go to the Regulator every year, and what does the Auditor have to say in it at the date of the audited statement of financial position?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business has a Financial Service Permission that allows it to hold Client Money, it must arrange for a Client Money Auditor’s Report to be submitted to the Regulator each year. [#SRC:c42abaa9-4c93-4d5b-b989-aa4ec57cf600] When the Authorised Person procures that report, it must ensure the Auditor includes specific statements measured as at the date the Authorised Person’s audited statement of financial position was prepared. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] At that financial-position date, the Auditor must state the amount of Client Money the Authorised Person was holding and controlling in line with COBS Chapter 14. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] The Auditor must also state whether the Authorised Person maintained systems and controls throughout the year to comply with COBS Chapter 14, and whether those controls keep Client Money identifiable and secure at all times. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] In addition, the Auditor must address whether any COBS Chapter 14 requirements were not met and whether Client Money was pooled in a single client Account or segregated into Client Accounts for individual Clients in accordance with COBS Chapter 14. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] Finally, the Auditor must confirm receiving necessary information and explanations for the report to the Regulator and, if applicable, note any material reconciliation discrepancies. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17]
source_text: An Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business whose Financial Service Permission entitles them to hold Client Money must also arrange for a Client Money Auditor's Report to be submitted to the Regulator on an annual basis in accordance with GEN 6.6.6.

question: If an Authorised Person wants to change its existing Financial Services Permission so it can do several new Regulated Activities in one go, what fee does it pay, and how do the “highest fee” and “extra activity” fee rules work together with the Rule 3.2.1 fee list?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person applies to amend an existing Financial Services Permission so it can undertake additional Regulated Activities, it must pay the Regulator the application fees that apply to those additional Regulated Activities as set out in Rule 3.2.1. [#SRC:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0] When the same amendment application includes multiple additional Regulated Activities at the same time, the total is not simply a single flat amount; instead, the Authorised Person must pay the highest of the relevant application fees for the Regulated Activities included in that application. [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2] On top of that highest fee, each additional Regulated Activity included in that same application triggers an extra application fee, and that extra fee is capped: it is the lesser of $10,000 or the application fee specified in these Rules for that Regulated Activity. [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2] In other words, Rule 3.2.1 provides the underlying fee amounts for the activities being requested, and the multi-activity rule tells you to start with the highest applicable fee and then add a capped incremental fee for each other activity requested at the same time. [#SRC:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0] [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2]
source_text:
Amendment of a Financial Services Permission other than the addition of a Regulated Activity
(a)	Subject to Rule 2.1(c), an Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Service Permission to enable it to undertake additional Regulated Activities must pay to the Regulator such application fees as set out in Rule 3.2.1.
(b)	An Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission to enable it to serve Retail Clients, other than pursuant to Rule 3.20.1, must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $5,000.
(c)	An Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission to enable it to conduct Islamic Financial Business must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $5,000.
(d)	An Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission through the amendment or removal of a condition, other than in accordance with (b) or (c), must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $5,000.
target_text:
In respect of:
(a)	an Applicant seeking to obtain a Financial Service Permission enabling the Applicant to undertake multiple Regulated Activities; or
(b)	an Authorised Person seeking to amend a Financial Service Permission to enable it to undertake one or more additional Regulated Activities.
the Applicant or Authorised Person, as the case may be, must pay the highest of the relevant application fees associated with the Regulated Activities being applied for at that time.  Each additional Regulated Activity applied for at that time shall incur an additional application fee of the lesser of $10,000 or the application fee specified in these Rules.

question: Where an MTF Operator lists Securities offered by an Exempt Offer on its MTF, what trading-participant limits and systems-and-controls measures must the MTF have in place, including any platform-origin restriction and information-access requirement?
gold_answer: An MTF Operator may list Exempt Offer Securities on the MTF so they can be traded among an unlimited number of Professional Clients, but trading by non-Professional Clients must be capped and controlled. [#SRC:1afc74c9-338e-44c8-8b6b-bba509c5946f] Specifically, the MTF must restrict trading of the Securities to no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients; in the SOURCE framing, this corresponds to permitting no more than 200 Retail Clients, and only where the MTF Operator has assessed those Retail Clients as having appropriate knowledge and experience of the relevant risks. [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] [#SRC:1afc74c9-338e-44c8-8b6b-bba509c5946f] In addition, the MTF must have effective systems and controls that (i) admit only Securities of Exempt Offers made on its own platform and (ii) identify the Persons to whom the Exempt Offer was made. [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] The MTF must also ensure its systems and controls support compliance with MIR rule 3.9.1 on admission to trading, as applicable to the relevant Securities. [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] Finally, users must be able to obtain Inside Information, including any Offer documents relevant to the Securities, and the MTF Operator should look to the systems-and-controls description referenced in COBS Rule 8.2.2 when seeking to admit Exempt Offer Securities to trading. [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] [#SRC:1afc74c9-338e-44c8-8b6b-bba509c5946f]
source_text: In respect of Securities offered by Exempt Offer, whether previously offered through a PFP or not, an MTF Operator may list Exempt Offer Securities on the MTF, enabling such Securities to be traded amongst an unlimited number of Professional Clients and not more than 200 Retail Clients which have been assessed by the MTF Operator to possess appropriate knowledge and experience of the relevant risks, in accordance with Market Infrastructure Rules (MIR) Rule 2.8.3. A description of the systems and controls required to be employed by a MTF Operator that seeks to admit Exempt Offer Securities to trading is set out in Conduct of Business Rules (COBS) Rule 8.2.2.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 about a Production Target, what information must be included about material assumptions and related matters, and in what circumstances may a later Production Target disclosure omit that otherwise-required information provided it cross-references the earlier compliant disclosure and includes the required confirmations and prominent cautionary statements?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity’s initial disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include, among other items, all material economic assumptions employed (or, if commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect plus an explanation of the methodology used to determine them) and all other material assumptions utilised; it must also address forecast commodity pricing (if used), disclose the proportions of the Production Target attributable to specified resource/reserve categories (including any Inferred Mineral Resources and any Exploration Target), and include the required statements about the role of Inferred Mineral Resources and any Exploration Target in viability and the early mine plan, together with additional prominent, proximate cautionary statements where the Production Target is wholly or partly based on Inferred Mineral Resources and/or partly based on an Exploration Target [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. After a Mining Reporting Entity has made an earlier disclosure under Rule 11.8.2 that complied with the information requirements, a subsequent disclosure in relation to the Production Target is permitted to omit the information otherwise required, but only if it references the earlier compliant disclosure, confirms that all material assumptions in the initial disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed, and (where applicable) includes at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statements for a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources and/or based in part on an Exploration Target [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef].
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: If an Authorised Person is a clearing member acting between a client and a CCP, what must it do to calculate Credit RWA for its Trade Exposure to the client, and what must it do to calculate EAD for derivatives and long settlement transactions unless it has permission to use an internal model?
