gold_answer: If an Authorised Person acts as a clearing member and, in that role, is an intermediary between a client and a CCP, it must calculate Credit RWA for its Trade Exposure to the client using the required approach, and it must also take into account the relevant provisions for any Collateral posted by the client, where applicable [#SRC:57fed3b7-e493-4c49-9c2d-c8c8194bbac8]. Separately, for Derivative transactions (both OTC and exchange-traded) and for long settlement transactions, it must calculate the exposure at default (EAD) in accordance with the section that sets out the Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR) [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff]. The only stated exception is where the Authorised Person has been granted permission by the Regulator to use an internal model; in that case, the requirement to calculate EAD under that standardised section does not apply [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff]. Read together, the clearing-member obligation to calculate Credit RWA for client Trade Exposure relies on having an EAD calculation for the relevant derivatives and long settlement transactions, while also reflecting any client-posted collateral where applicable [#SRC:57fed3b7-e493-4c49-9c2d-c8c8194bbac8].
source_text: Trade Exposure of a clearing member to a client. Where an Authorised Person acts as a clearing member, and in that capacity, acts as an intermediary between a client and a CCP, it must calculate Credit RWA in respect of its Trade Exposure to the client in accordance with Rule A4.6.14, together with App5 and relevant provisions of Section 4.13 in respect of any Collateral posted by the client, if applicable.
target_text: Derivatives and long settlement transactions – Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR). The exposure at default (EAD) of Derivative transactions (OTC and exchange-traded) and long settlement transactions must be calculated in accordance with this Section unless the Authorised Person has been granted permission by the Regulator to use an internal model.

question: If a Listed Entity has issued or plans to issue Restricted Securities, does it always have to apply the APP 7 restriction, or are there cases where some APP 7 restriction categories do not apply unless the Regulator says they do?
gold_answer: When a Listed Entity has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities, it must apply the restriction in APP 7, or follow other restrictions the Regulator chooses to impose in its discretion [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f]. But the Target text narrows when certain APP 7 restrictions apply: unless the Regulator decides otherwise, the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply in relation to a Listed Entity that meets at least one of three criteria [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]. Those criteria are: the Listed Entity qualifies for admission to the Official List under the stated admission route; it has a profitability or revenue track record that is acceptable to the Regulator; or, in the Regulator’s opinion, it has tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value that make up a substantial proportion of its total asset value [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]. So, the general “must apply” obligation exists, but whether particular APP 7 categories apply depends on these conditions and on whether the Regulator decides otherwise.
source_text: Entry into Restriction Agreements and Application of Restriction. Subject to Rule 9.6.2, a Listed Entity which has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities, must apply the restriction in APP 7 or such other restrictions as the Regulator, in its discretion, decides.
target_text:
Entry into Restriction Agreements and Application of Restriction. Unless the Regulator decides otherwise, the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply in relation to a Listed Entity that:
(1)	qualifies for admission to the Official List pursuant to Rule 2.3.15;
(2)	has a track record of profitability or revenue acceptable to the Regulator; or
(3)	in the opinion of the Regulator, has tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value which constitute a substantial proportion of the total value of its assets.

question: What does a Listed Entity have to do within two Business Days after issuing Restricted Securities to ensure a holding lock is put in place, and what must it (and any Security Holder or Controller under a Restriction Agreement) not do during the Restriction Period about releasing that lock?
gold_answer: Within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, the Listed Entity must obtain an undertaking from a suitable entity (such as a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD, or another entity the Regulator considers suitable) and submit that undertaking to the Regulator [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76]. The undertaking must cover two key points: the entity will place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities it holds, and it will not release that holding lock unless it first has the Regulator’s prior written consent. At the same time, during the Restriction Period, the Listed Entity, Security Holder, or Controller that is subject to a Restriction Agreement is prohibited from trying to change the restriction framework by amending an executed Restriction Agreement, and is also prohibited from asking for or agreeing to the release of a holding lock that has been imposed under the relevant mechanism [#SRC:344f9898-63f7-4bec-afdc-2c9984f6502d]. Together, these requirements mean the lock must be promptly documented and filed, and no party covered by the Restriction Agreement should initiate or consent to a release during the Restriction Period.
source_text:
Entry into Restriction Agreements and Application of Restriction. During a Restriction Period, a Listed Entity, Security Holder or Controller subject to a Restriction Agreement must not:
(1)	amend an executed Restriction Agreement; or
(2)	ask for or agree to the release of a holding lock that has been imposed in accordance with Rule 9.6.9.
target_text: Timing and Enforcement. A Listed Entity must obtain, and submit to the Regulator, within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD or other entity deemed suitable by the Regulator, to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities held by it, and not to release the holding lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent.

question: Where Restricted Securities are issued and then become subject to a Takeover offer, how do the undertaking and holding-lock requirements interact with the Regulator’s ability to permit release of the holding lock so holders can accept the offer or transfer/cancel Securities?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity must ensure that Restricted Securities are placed under a holding lock backed by an undertaking, and any later release of that lock—such as to facilitate a Takeover—requires the Regulator’s prior written consent. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] The initial control is implemented by obtaining an undertaking from an eligible lock-holding entity (for example, a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD, or another entity the Regulator considers suitable) and submitting that undertaking to the Regulator within two Business Days after the issue of the Restricted Securities. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] Once the holding lock is in place, it must not be released unless the Regulator has given prior written consent, which is the same consent mechanism that enables a party managing the holding lock to release it in a Takeover context. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] In particular, the Regulator may consent to the party managing the holding lock releasing it to allow holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer, or to transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover. [#SRC:12178c65-d1b6-440a-91e1-c670c7d9ab67] Accordingly, the Listed Entity’s timely undertaking submission supports enforceable lock placement, while the Takeover-related release is only permissible when the Regulator affirmatively consents to that release. [#SRC:12178c65-d1b6-440a-91e1-c670c7d9ab67] [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76]
source_text: Regulator’s consent to sale of Restricted Securities in a Takeover or Merger. The Regulator may consent to a party that is managing a holding lock in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 releasing the holding lock, to enable holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer, or transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover.
target_text: Timing and Enforcement. A Listed Entity must obtain, and submit to the Regulator, within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD or other entity deemed suitable by the Regulator, to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities held by it, and not to release the holding lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent.

question: When an Authorised Person is calculating CET1 Capital and must deduct defined benefit pension fund assets, in what circumstances may the amount of that deduction be reduced, and what additional treatment applies to any assets used to reduce the deduction?
gold_answer: In calculating CET1 Capital, an Authorised Person is required to deduct its defined benefit pension fund assets from CET1 Capital, but the amount of that specific deduction may be reduced in limited, specified cases. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] For the defined benefit pension fund asset deduction, the Authorised Person may reduce the deduction by (i) any associated deferred tax liability that could be eliminated if the pension assets were impaired or derecognised under the International Financial Reporting Standards, and (ii) the amount of pension fund assets that the Authorised Person has an unrestricted ability to use, provided it has given adequate advance notification to the Regulator of its intention to use those assets. [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada] Any pension fund assets used to reduce the amount deducted are not ignored for prudential purposes; instead, those assets must be assigned a risk weight in accordance with Chapter 4 of these Rules. [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada] This reduction mechanism operates within the broader CET1 deduction framework that includes, among other items, goodwill and other intangible assets and certain deferred tax assets, but the reduction described here is specific to the defined benefit pension fund asset deduction. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]
source_text:
CET1 Deductions - defined benefit pension fund assets. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(d), the amount of defined benefit pension fund assets to be deducted from CET1 Capital must be reduced by the following:
(a)	the amount of any associated deferred tax liability which could be extinguished if the assets became impaired or were derecognised under the International Financial Reporting Standards; and
(b)	the amount of assets in the defined benefit pension fund which the Authorised Person has an unrestricted ability to use where the Authorised Person has provided adequate advance notification of its intention to use those assets to the Regulator. Those assets used to reduce the amount to be deducted must receive a risk weight in accordance with Chapter 4 of these Rules.

question: If an Authorised Person is using the FCSA and the Collateral’s risk weight would come out below 20%, what do they do with the Exposure split (collateralised vs uncollateralised) and when can they use 0% or 10% instead of 20% for the collateralised part?
gold_answer: Under the FCSA approach, the Authorised Person must first split the CR Exposure into a collateralised portion and an uncollateralised portion, and then apply risk weights to each portion based on what each portion represents. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] The collateralised portion is measured as the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and the uncollateralised portion is the CR Exposure amount minus that latest fair value. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] For Credit RWA purposes, the collateralised portion uses the CRW that applies to the Collateral as if it were a direct Exposure to that Collateral, while the uncollateralised portion uses the CRW that applies to the obligor. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] If the CRW for the collateralised portion (based on the Collateral) would be less than 20%, the default outcome is that the Authorised Person must apply a 20% CRW to the collateralised portion. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438] The Authorised Person may instead apply 0% or 10% only in the listed cases, including qualifying SFTs depending on whether the Counterparty is a core market participant, and certain daily mark-to-market OTC Derivative transactions with no currency mismatch depending on whether the Collateral is cash or specified 0%-risk-weight government/central bank/PSE exposures. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438] A further 0% option exists for certain no-currency-mismatch transactions where the Collateral is specified cash on Deposit or specified 0%-risk-weight government/central bank/PSE exposures and the latest fair value used in the collateralised portion has been discounted by 20%. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438]
source_text:
Recognition of eligible financial Collateral under FCSA. Subject to A4.3.28, an Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA may recognise the effects of CRM of the eligible financial Collateral as follows:
(a) 	break down the Exposure into -
(i) 	a collateralised portion with E equal to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral; and
(ii) 	an uncollateralised portion with E equal to the E of the CR Exposure less the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral;
and
(b) 	for the purposes of calculating the Credit RWA amount pursuant to Rule 4.8.3, use:
(i) 	for the collateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the eligible financial Collateral as though the Authorised Person had a direct Exposure to that Collateral; and
(ii) 	for the uncollateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the obligor.

question: Under what conditions may a Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund also perform fund administration for the Fund, and what risk-management considerations must the Fund Manager ensure are addressed in that scenario, taking into account the role of Fund Administrators and Eligible Custodians (and, where appointed, prime brokers)?
gold_answer: A Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund may be able to carry out fund administration for the Fund only where the Fund’s risk management and portfolio functions are adequately separated. [#SRC:5cba2a1e-1340-4401-a5c7-23c937abe4fc] In that same operating model, the Fund Manager must still ensure that the risks inherent in the operation of the Fund are adequately addressed, and must do so with due regard to the nature of the strategies and investment process it employs and to the role of Fund Administrators and Eligible Custodians and, where appointed, prime brokers. [#TGT:b6eb6967-279e-4da2-9b77-1f703f2597f7] Practically, this means the Fund Manager should (i) confirm and maintain the separation between risk management and portfolio functions as the condition that enables it to perform administration, and (ii) structure its risk-management approach so it reflects both how the Fund is managed (strategies and investment process) and how key service providers contribute to the Fund’s operation. [#SRC:5cba2a1e-1340-4401-a5c7-23c937abe4fc] [#TGT:b6eb6967-279e-4da2-9b77-1f703f2597f7] The requirement to address operational risks applies even if the Fund Manager itself is acting as the Fund Administrator, so the Fund Manager must explicitly consider that role alongside Eligible Custodians and any appointed prime brokers when ensuring risks are adequately addressed. [#TGT:b6eb6967-279e-4da2-9b77-1f703f2597f7]
source_text: A Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund may be able to perform fund administration for the Fund in circumstances where risk management and portfolio functions are adequately separated (Rule 12.3.10).
target_text: Risk management. A Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund must ensure that the risks inherent in the operation of a Fund are adequately addressed, with due regard to the nature of the strategies and investment process employed by the Fund Manager and the role of Fund Administrators and Eligible Custodians and where appointed, prime brokers.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information that is derived from a Production Target in relation to either its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s), what specific content must be included about (i) the assumptions used and (ii) the Production Target itself?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity that discloses forecast financial information derived from a Production Target—whether the disclosure is made in relation to its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s)—must include both assumption-related content and Production Target-related content in the disclosure. [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d] For the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, the disclosure must cover all material economic assumptions employed and also include all other material assumptions utilised. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, it must state that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In addition, because the forecast financial information is derived from a Production Target, the disclosure must include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, and it must include all the information that is required to be contained in that Production Target under Rule 11.8.3. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] This combined content expectation applies regardless of whether the Production Target-based forecast is presented against holdings or against material project(s). [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d]
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text:
Forecast financial information derived from a Production Target may be disclosed in relation to either a Mining Reporting Entity’s:
(1)	Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings; or
(2)	material Mining Project(s).

question: For a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity, what is the latest time by which it must disclose the quarterly report, and what minimum subject-matter must that quarterly report cover for the entity and all controlled entities on a consolidated basis (if applicable)?
gold_answer: A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity must disclose its quarterly report no later than one month after the end of the relevant quarter [#SRC:380ff25a-7805-4020-9f40-da991f91eab1]. The report that must be disclosed is a report for each quarter of its financial year and must cover, in respect of the Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity and all controlled entities (on a consolidated basis, if applicable), specified information about Petroleum-related activities and positions [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62]. At a minimum, the quarterly report must include: details of activities relating to Petroleum (Exploration, and production and development, or statements that there were no such activities); a summary of expenditure incurred relating to Petroleum (Exploration activities, and production and development); the Petroleum Tenements held at quarter end (including location, percentage interest held, and beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements); and Petroleum Tenements acquired or disposed of during the quarter (including location and beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements) [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62]. In addition, at least once every 12 months the report must address the Summary of Reserves and Resources requirement (unless included in the annual report) and state when the previous and upcoming disclosures of that summary were and are to be made [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62].
source_text: Quarterly Reports – Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entities. A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity must disclose the report required by Rule 12.13.1 no later than one month after the end of the quarter.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity publishes forecast financial information and also reports Ore Reserves based on a Technical Study, what does it have to say about the economic assumptions it used, and what extra explanation is required if it says those assumptions are commercially sensitive?
gold_answer: The Mining Reporting Entity has to cover two connected disclosure areas: the assumptions behind its forecast financial information and the assumptions/outcomes behind the Technical Study used to support an Ore Reserves estimate. For the forecast financial information, it must include all material economic assumptions employed, and it must also include all other material assumptions utilised [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. If it believes the material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it cannot simply withhold them; it must state that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. Separately, to reach the required level of confidence in the modifying factors used to determine an estimate of Ore Reserves, it will need to have carried out a relevant Technical Study (preliminary feasibility study or feasibility study), and it must disclose the key underlying assumptions and outcomes of that Technical Study [#TGT:30cf9cda-951e-48ba-9be2-61a889a87464]. These requirements work together to make the economic basis and study basis transparent.
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text: ORE RESERVES . Pursuant to Rule 11.6.1(1)(a), in order to achieve the required level of confidence in the modifying factors to determine an estimate of Ore Reserves, a Mining Reporting Entity will need to have carried out a relevant Technical Study (preliminary feasibility study or feasibility study ).  The key underlying assumptions and outcomes of the Technical Study are also to be disclosed.

question: When a Petroleum Reporting Entity makes a disclosure containing Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves, what must it do to ensure the disclosure is both properly attributed to named Competent Person(s) and not released without the Competent Person(s)’ prior written consent as to the form and context of the presentation?
gold_answer: A Petroleum Reporting Entity must satisfy two linked requirements when it discloses Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves. First, the disclosure must include specific attribution statements: it must state that the disclosure is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s); it must also state whether each Competent Person is an employee of the Petroleum Reporting Entity or a Related Party (and if not, identify the Competent Person’s employer); and it must state the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member [#TGT:6f4cc15d-24f2-4ffc-a2ad-dff5dce98f79]. Second, the statement referred to in the relevant framework must only be disclosed with the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) as to the form and context in which the estimated resources/reserves and supporting information are presented in the disclosure [#SRC:9c4480c6-f416-4989-b1c9-ad5cf7c5d72e]. Together, these obligations mean the Petroleum Reporting Entity must both obtain the required written consent for the presentation and include the required identification and status details for the named Competent Person(s) in the disclosure.
source_text:
Competent Persons . The statement referred to in Rule 12.15.2:
(1)	must only be disclosed with the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) as to the form and context in which the estimated Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Prospective Resources, as the case may be, and the supporting information is presented in the disclosure; and
(2)	only applies the first time a Petroleum Reporting Entity discloses original or updated estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves where:
(a)	any subsequent disclosure that refers to the estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves references the earlier disclosure containing the statements and consent referred to in Rules 12.15.2 and 12.15.3(1); and
(b)	the Petroleum Reporting Entity confirms in the subsequent disclosure that it is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects the information included in the earlier disclosure, and that all material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the estimates in the earlier disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed.
target_text:
Competent Persons . A disclosure by a Petroleum Reporting Entity containing Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves must state:
(1)	that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s);
(2)	whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Petroleum Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer; and
(3)	the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.

question: When calculating Exposure value for Derivatives (including written credit protection) that fall within the SA-CCR framework, what steps must be followed to ensure the Exposure value is computed as a sum of the IFRS on-balance sheet amount and a potential future exposure add-on, and how must this be aligned with the requirement to calculate EAD separately for each netting set using the SA-CCR components?
gold_answer: For Derivatives (including written credit protection), the firm must calculate the Exposure value as a sum of two elements: (i) the on-balance sheet value determined in accordance with IFRS, and (ii) an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated under the specified App 4 rules for derivatives add-ons [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007]. Where the derivative is within the SA-CCR scope, the procedure for quantifying the counterparty credit risk measure requires calculating EAD separately for each netting set and determining it using the SA-CCR formula EAD = alpha * (RC + PFE), with alpha fixed at 1.4, RC computed under the referenced replacement cost rules, and PFE computed under the referenced potential future exposure rule [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918]. Operationally, this means the IFRS on-balance sheet value provides the accounting-based component of Exposure value, while the add-on/PFE component must be produced using the SA-CCR methodology on a netting-set basis, ensuring the “sum” requirement for Exposure value is met consistently with the SA-CCR decomposition into RC and PFE.
source_text:
In relation to on-balance sheet items:
a.	for SFTs, the Exposure value should be calculated in accordance with IFRS and the Netting requirements referred to in Rule 4.9.14;
b.	for Derivatives, including written credit protection, the Exposure value should be calculated as the sum of the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated in accordance with Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4; and
c.	for other on-balance sheet items, the Exposure value should be calculated based on their balance sheet values in accordance with Rule 4.9.3.
target_text:
Derivatives and long settlement transactions – Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR). EAD is to be calculated separately for each netting set. It is determined as follows:
EAD = alpha* (RC + PFE)
where:
alpha = 1.4
RC = the replacement cost calculated according to Rules A4.6.19 to A4.6.24
PFE = the amount for potential future exposure calculated according to Rule A4.6.26

question: If someone is making an Offer of a Unit, do the rules in this Chapter apply to them, and does the Rulebook’s usual prospectus content and structure chapter apply to Prospectuses for Units of Funds?
gold_answer: For a person making an Offer of a Unit, the provisions in the Chapter and the Rules made for the purposes of that Chapter are stated not to apply to that person in relation to making that offer [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a]. Separately, the Rulebook explains that its prospectus requirements on content and structure in chapter 4 do not apply to Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94]. Instead of relying on those general chapter 4 prospectus requirements, the Rulebook points to a different source for what does apply: prospectus requirements that apply to an Offer of Units of Funds are found in the Fund Rules [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94]. Taken together, these two scope statements mean that Unit-related offers are carved out from the Chapter-based framework for the act of making the offer, and Fund Prospectuses are carved out from the general chapter 4 content and structure requirements, with the applicable prospectus obligations for Offers of Units of Funds being addressed through the Fund Rules rather than the general prospectus chapter [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] while the Chapter itself is disapplied for the person making the Offer of a Unit [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a].
source_text: The Prospectus requirements including content and structure in chapter 4 of this Rulebook do not apply to Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds. Prospectus requirements that apply to an Offer of Units of Funds are found in the Fund Rules. Section 57(1) of FSMR disapplies chapter 4 of this Rulebook to Fund Prospectuses.
target_text: The provisions in this Chapter and the Rules made for the purposes of this Chapter shall not apply to a person in relation to making an Offer of a Unit.

question: Where an Applicant has less than three years of audited financial statements and the Regulator generally expects quarterly cash reporting in that circumstance, what audited accounts must the Applicant have published or filed, and what minimum content and assurance characteristics must those accounts meet, including any Regulator discretion to accept a shorter period?
gold_answer: When an Applicant has less than three years of audited financial statements, the Regulator may generally require quarterly cash reporting from the relevant Reporting Entity in that circumstance, including where the Listed Entity is admitted under the assets eligibility test or where the Regulator considers quarterly cash reports necessary for other reasons such as a cash-box admission [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8]. In parallel, the Applicant must still have published or filed audited accounts that cover a prior period of three years, unless the Regulator accepts a shorter period, which provides a mechanism to address situations where a full three-year history is not available [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1]. Those audited accounts must be consolidated for the Applicant and any of its subsidiary undertakings, prepared in accordance with IFRS or other standards acceptable to the Regulator, and audited and reported on by auditors using IAASB auditing standards or other standards acceptable to the Regulator [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1]. Accordingly, even if the Regulator accepts a shorter audited period, the Applicant must ensure the accounts meet the specified consolidation, accounting framework, and audit-standard requirements while also anticipating the Regulator’s expectation of quarterly cash reporting in the identified circumstances [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8].
source_text: The Regulator will generally require a Reporting Entity to comply with Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i) in circumstances where the Listed Entity with Securities being admitted to the Official List is admitted under the assets eligibility test (see Rule 2.3.16), has less than three years of audited financial statements as prescribed in Rule 2.3.2(1), or is considered by the Regulator, for other reasons, to require quarterly cash reports, such as the admission of a cash-box.

question: In meeting the MIR rulebook requirements that an MTF Operator or OTF Operator must follow (as if it were a Recognised Body or Recognised Investment Exchange), what specific term-mapping must be applied where the applicable COBS Chapter 8 materials (including any MIR content incorporated into COBS) use “Investment(s)” or “Financial Instrument(s)”?
gold_answer: The obligation on an Authorised Person acting as an MTF Operator or an OTF Operator is to comply with the enumerated MIR rulebook requirements applicable to a Recognised Body or Recognised Investment Exchange, while reading references to those entities in the relevant MIR rules as references to the MTF Operator or OTF Operator [#TGT:180edda8-db12-4969-97d5-182435bdf094]. For the purposes of applying the related COBS Chapter 8 references in that same compliance exercise, the firm must apply a defined interpretive approach to key product terms: references to “Investment” or “Investments” must be read as references to “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets,” and references to “Financial Instrument” or “Financial Instruments” (including those appearing in MIR as incorporated into COBS via COBS Rule 8.2.1) must also be read as references to “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets,” as applicable [#SRC:a3736367-db02-465d-809f-1bc6cfd7bbcd]. Practically, this mapping ensures that when the MTF Operator/OTF Operator is implementing the imported MIR requirements (e.g., around systems and controls, transparency, disclosure, or other listed areas), any COBS Chapter 8 terminology that would otherwise point to Investments or Financial Instruments is treated as referring to Virtual Assets.
source_text:
For the purposes of Rule 17.7.2, the following references in COBS, Chapter 8 should be read as follows:
(a)	references to “Investment” or “Investments” shall be read as references to “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets”, as applicable; and
(b)	references to “Financial Instrument” or “Financial Instruments” (including those in MIR as incorporated by virtue of COBS Rule 8.2.1) shall be read as references to “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets”, as applicable.

question: For an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, what must be done to ensure reconciliations of Client Accounts are performed with the required frequency and accuracy, and what reconciliation evidence must be retained within the Resolution Pack regarding Client Money and Client Investments?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must operate adequate systems and controls that ensure reconciliations of Client Accounts are accurate and performed as often as necessary, with a minimum frequency of at least every calendar month [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b]. In addition to meeting that operational requirement, the Authorised Person must also ensure that the Resolution Pack includes the most recent reconciliations relating specifically to Client Money and Client Investments, so that there is readily available documentary evidence of the latest reconciliation activity for those client asset categories [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. Taken together, these obligations mean the firm should both (i) run a reconciliation process on a schedule that cannot fall below monthly and that is designed to produce accurate outcomes, and (ii) retain and file the latest completed reconciliation outputs for Client Money and Client Investments in the Resolution Pack, so the most current reconciliation records are captured and accessible.
target_text: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must maintain adequate systems and controls to ensure that accurate reconciliations of Client Accounts are carried out as regularly as necessary but at least every calendar month.

question: When is an Authorised Person prohibited from offering OTC Leveraged Products to a Retail Client or providing related advice/arrangements, and how does that prohibition interact with the requirement to reassess the relevant client assessment annually or upon a material change in the Retail Client’s financial situation or risk tolerance?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is prohibited from offering OTC Leveraged Products to a Retail Client, or from providing advice or making arrangements on behalf of a Retail Client relating to OTC Leveraged Products, unless it has first completed an assessment of the Retail Client’s skill, experience, knowledge, financial resources and risk tolerance and can reasonably conclude that the Retail Client has adequate experience and skill to understand the potential risk of loss and has liquid financial resources sufficient to absorb potential losses [#TGT:be7639eb-37d0-4a64-80e4-a7694dd68cc0]. In addition, the assessment that underpins this gatekeeping must be kept current through reassessment by the Authorised Person on an annual basis, and also earlier where there is any material change in the Retail Client’s financial situation or risk tolerance before the annual reassessment [#SRC:98b97356-14ec-44f8-9af4-96ffa1211a76]. Read together, the prohibition means the Authorised Person should not rely on an outdated assessment when engaging in the restricted activities; instead, it must ensure the prerequisite assessment has been completed and, where required, reassessed so that the reasonable conclusions about experience, risk understanding, and liquid resources remain valid at the time of offering, advising, or arranging.
source_text:
The assessment required by Rule 23.5.1 must be reassessed by an Authorised Person:
(a)	on an annual basis; or
(b)	where there is any material change in the financial situation or risk tolerance of the Retail Client, if that change occurs prior to the annual reassessment.
target_text:
An Authorised Person must not offer OTC Leveraged Products to a Retail Client, or provide any advice or make arrangements on behalf of a Retail Client relating to OTC Leveraged Products unless it has first completed an assessment of the skill, experience, knowledge, financial resources and risk tolerance of the Retail Client, such that the Authorised Person may reasonably conclude that the Retail Client has:
(a)	adequate experience and skill enabling them to understand the potential risk of loss involved in investing in OTC Leveraged Products; and
(b)	liquid financial resources sufficient to absorb potential losses resulting from trading in OTC Leveraged Products.

question: If a Fund Manager is arranging for a Fund Auditor’s Report, what are the two main things it must do: one about the audit itself and one about what the report must cover?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager has two connected duties: one is to make sure the audit is carried out properly, and the other is to make sure the report contains the required conclusions. On the audit side, the Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to conduct an audit of the Fund’s financial statements in accordance with the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB), and to produce a Fund Auditor’s Report on the audited financial statements [#SRC:8949f938-33e5-4393-a256-021917125579]. On the report side, when procuring the production of the Fund Auditor’s Report, the Fund Manager must ensure that an Auditor states whether the financial statements were properly prepared under the financial reporting standards adopted by the Fund, and whether they give a true and fair view of the Fund’s (or Sub-Fund’s) financial position and results for the annual accounting period and at the end of that period [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce]. It must also ensure the report addresses whether proper accounting records have not been kept or the statements do not agree with records/returns or do not comply with applicable standards, whether the Auditor received all necessary information and explanations, whether the Directors’ report or the Fund Manager’s report is consistent with the financial statements, and any other matter required by FUNDS [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce].
source_text:
Function of the Auditor. A Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to:
(a)	conduct an audit of the Fund's financial statements in accordance with the requirements of the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB); and
(b)	produce a Fund Auditor's Report on the audited financial statements in accordance with GEN Rule 6.6.8.

question: Can the Regulator make Rules that tell a Reporting Entity what Corporate Governance standards it must follow (including for the board of Directors, Controllers, and employees), and how should the Reporting Entity use its annual report explanation to show it meets the long‑term, prudent management goal for the Reporting Entity and its Shareholders?
gold_answer: Yes. Read together, the passages indicate that the Regulator has permission to set detailed Corporate Governance requirements by Rules and that those requirements are aimed at ensuring a Reporting Entity’s governance supports prudent and sound management over the long term in the interests of the Reporting Entity and its Shareholders. The SOURCE states that the Regulator is entitled to enact rules requiring a Reporting Entity to have an adequate Corporate Governance framework to promote prudent and sound long‑term management, and it adds that, in the annual report explanation, a Reporting Entity should aim to illustrate how its actual practices achieve compliance with the outcomes intended by the relevant framework and Principles, thereby contributing to prudent and sound management [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1]. The TARGET then clarifies what the Regulator may prescribe by Rules for that requirement: Corporate Governance principles and standards applying to a Reporting Entity, including requirements for its board of Directors and individual members, Controllers, employees, or any other person as appropriate, plus requirements on fair treatment of Shareholders and provisions to address conflicts of interests [#TGT:d0183f42-1701-4885-9dcb-cb96c2d62d6d].
source_text: General. Section 73(2) of the FSMR provides that the Regulator is entitled to enact rules requiring a Reporting Entity to have a Corporate Governance framework which is adequate to promote prudent and sound management of the Reporting Entity in the long term interest of the Reporting Entity and its Shareholders. Accordingly, in providing its explanation in the annual report as noted in 2, a Reporting Entity should aim to illustrate how its actual practices achieve compliance with the outcomes intended by section 73 of the FSMR and the Principles, and thereby contribute to prudent and sound management of the Reporting Entity.
target_text:
For the purposes of the requirement in subsection ‎(1), the Regulator may by Rules prescribe—
(a)	Corporate Governance principles and standards that apply to a Reporting Entity, including any requirements applicable to its board of Directors and individual members, Controllers, employees or any other person as appropriate;
(b)	requirements relating to fair treatment of Shareholders; and
(c)	provisions to address conflicts of interests.

question: For an Authorised Person’s Credit Risk policy addressing conflicts of interest in Related Person transactions, when may the policy permit Providing Credit to a Related Person on more favourable terms than those offered to Persons who are not Related Persons, and what governance, procedural, and monitoring conditions must be met to keep that exception within scope?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person’s Credit Risk policy must include adequate procedures for handling conflicts of interest relating to the provision and management of credit, including measures to prevent any Person who directly or indirectly benefits from the credit from being involved in granting or managing it, and it must also exclude such beneficiaries from any approval process for relevant Exposures and write-offs [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496]. While the policy generally prohibits Exposures to Related Persons on more favourable terms than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons, that prohibition is out of scope where the more favourable terms arise under an Employee credit policy that is widely available to Employees of the Authorised Person and is approved by the Authorised Person’s Governing Body or the Governing Body’s delegate [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91]. To rely on this exception, the credit policy must clearly set out the terms, conditions, and limits (individual and aggregate) for providing such credit, and it must require adequate mechanisms for ongoing compliance, including immediate reporting to the Governing Body or its delegate upon any deviation or breach for timely and appropriate action [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91].
source_text:
Credit Risk policy. In relation to conflicts of interest and Related Person transactions, the policy must:
(a)	set out adequate procedures for handling conflicts of interest relating to the provision and management of credit, including measures to prevent any Person directly or indirectly benefiting from the credit being part of the process of granting or managing the credit;
(b)	subject to Rule 4.4.5, prohibit Exposures to Related Persons on terms that are more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons; and
(c)	if Exposures to Related Persons are allowed on terms which are no more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons, set out procedures that:
(i)	require such Exposures, and any write off of such Exposures, exceeding specific amounts or otherwise posing special risks to the Authorised Person, to be made subject to the prior written approval of the firm's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate; and
(ii)	exclude Persons directly or indirectly benefiting from the grant or write off of such Exposures being part of the approval process.

question: When an Authorised Person must determine its Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital based on its Total Risk Exposure Amount and the jurisdictions of its private sector credit exposures, what calculation steps must it follow to derive the weighted average Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate that is then applied in the buffer amount?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must calculate its Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by taking its Total Risk Exposure Amount and multiplying it by a weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates applicable to the jurisdictions where its private sector credit exposures are located [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]. To obtain that weighted average rate, it must follow a jurisdiction-by-jurisdiction procedure: first, identify each jurisdiction in which it has private sector credit exposures and determine the portion of Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to those private sector credit exposures in that jurisdiction. Next, divide that jurisdiction-specific amount by the Total Risk Exposure Amount relating to the Authorised Person’s private sector credit exposures across all jurisdictions, and multiply the resulting fraction by the applicable Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate for that jurisdiction. Finally, sum the resulting contributions across all jurisdictions to produce the single weighted average rate that is used as the multiplier in the CET1 buffer calculation [#TGT:e71f9d6c-0033-443d-9ce0-aa873bdd8124].
source_text: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital equal to its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures are located, calculated in accordance with Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8.
target_text:
Weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates. The weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates shall be calculated by:
(a)	for each jurisdiction in which the Authorised Person has private sector credit exposures, dividing the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the private sector credit exposures in that jurisdiction by the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures across all jurisdictions and multiplying it by the applicable Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate in that jurisdiction; and
(b)	summing those contributions across all jurisdictions.

question: When putting together the Resolution Pack, what information has to be on the master list of all Client Accounts that the Authorised Person must keep?
gold_answer: The Resolution Pack must include the master list (or master lists) of all Client Accounts, and that list must be kept with the specific details required for each account. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d] The Resolution Pack requirement applies to an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business and explicitly calls for master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments, so the pack should contain the maintained master list covering those Client Accounts. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] The master list itself must include, for every Client Account, the account’s name and number and where the account is held (its location). [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d] It also has to identify the bank and provide the bank’s address and contact details, and it must capture the account’s terms and conditions. [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d] In addition, the list must show whether the account is open or closed and record the opening date or closure date, so the Resolution Pack includes an up-to-date view of each Client Account’s status. [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d]

question: If an Authorised Person’s Financial Services Permission lets it do Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal, but it is also authorised for things like Managing Assets or Providing Custody (other than for a Fund), how do you decide whether it is Category 2 or Category 3C? What role do the “not limited in scope” dealing condition and the “must not meet other Categories” tests play?
gold_answer: You decide by matching the Authorised Person’s Financial Services Permission to the category tests and then applying the “must not meet other Categories” exclusions. Category 2 is triggered when the permission authorises Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal), the firm’s dealing activities are not limited in scope in the specified way, and it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5 [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f]. Category 3C is triggered when the permission authorises one or more of the listed activities (such as Managing Assets, Managing a Collective Investment Fund, Providing Custody other than for a Fund, managing a PSIAr, Providing Trust Services as trustee of at least one express trust, or Providing Money Services) and the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B or 5 [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0]. So, if the firm meets Category 2 (including the “not limited in scope” condition), it cannot be Category 3C because Category 3C excludes firms that meet Category 2. If it does not meet Category 2, then Category 3C remains possible, but only if it meets the listed-activity requirement and none of the excluded categories apply.
target_text:
An Authorised Person is in Category 2 if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal);
(b)	its dealing activities are not limited in scope as provided in Rule 1.3.3(1)(a)(i); and
(c)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5.
Category 3A
Guidance
A Category 3A Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Agent and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1 and 1.3.2 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3A. Provided that an Authorised Person carries out the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Agent in a manner that is wholly incidental to the activity of Managing an Investment Fund or Managing Assets, the Authorised Person shall be regarded as falling within Category 3C.

question: When a Petroleum Reporting Entity must immediately disclose a new material estimate of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves that has not previously been disclosed, what must it ensure the disclosure includes regarding the permits or licences connected to those estimates?
gold_answer: Where a Petroleum Reporting Entity has a new material estimate of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves that has not previously been disclosed, it must make an immediate disclosure of that estimate [#TGT:1d41da19-7d47-42e7-baf3-28af0f6c1c12]. When making that disclosure, the Petroleum Reporting Entity must also ensure the disclosure contains specific supporting content, including the types of permits or licences it holds that relate to the estimates being disclosed [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704]. In practice, this means the immediate disclosure obligation is not satisfied by stating the new estimate alone; the disclosure must identify the relevant permit or licence types held by the Petroleum Reporting Entity in connection with the estimate. The same disclosure package must also include an explanation of the new data and information, an explanation of how that new data and information affected the estimates, and any changes or additions to previously disclosed information relating to Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources, or Petroleum Reserves, as applicable [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704].
target_text: A Petroleum Reporting Entity must immediately disclose any new material estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves that have not previously been disclosed.

question: If an MTF Operator lists Exempt Offer Securities on the MTF so they can be traded by Professional Clients and up to 200 assessed Retail Clients, what systems and controls must the MTF have to admit the Securities and limit who can trade them?
gold_answer: The source allows an MTF Operator to list Exempt Offer Securities on the MTF (whether or not they were previously offered through a PFP) and describes the intended trading limits: trading may occur among an unlimited number of Professional Clients, but only up to 200 Retail Clients, and only where those Retail Clients have been assessed by the MTF Operator as having appropriate knowledge and experience of the relevant risks [#SRC:1afc74c9-338e-44c8-8b6b-bba509c5946f]. If the MTF admits these Securities to trading, the target requires the MTF to back that listing decision with effective systems and controls. Specifically, the MTF must ensure it admits only Securities of Exempt Offers that are made on its own platform, and it must be able to identify the Persons to whom the Exempt Offer was made [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66]. It must also restrict trading so that no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients can trade, which supports the source’s cap on non-professional participation [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66]. In addition, the MTF must have controls to meet applicable admission-to-trading requirements and to allow users to obtain Inside Information, including relevant offer documents, so that trading happens with appropriate information access [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66].
source_text: In respect of Securities offered by Exempt Offer, whether previously offered through a PFP or not, an MTF Operator may list Exempt Offer Securities on the MTF, enabling such Securities to be traded amongst an unlimited number of Professional Clients and not more than 200 Retail Clients which have been assessed by the MTF Operator to possess appropriate knowledge and experience of the relevant risks, in accordance with Market Infrastructure Rules (MIR) Rule 2.8.3. A description of the systems and controls required to be employed by a MTF Operator that seeks to admit Exempt Offer Securities to trading is set out in Conduct of Business Rules (COBS) Rule 8.2.2.

question: Where the Regulator considers a name issue under Section 117 of FSMR, how does the Regulator’s power to make a direction apply across (i) a Fund, (ii) a Sub-Fund, and (iii) a class of Units in a Fund, and what specific action may the Regulator require and from whom when the name is undesirable, misleading, or conflicts with another name?
gold_answer: If the Regulator forms the view that a relevant name is undesirable, misleading, or conflicts with a name used by another product, the Regulator has power to issue a direction under Section 117 of FSMR covering not only a Fund and a Sub-Fund but also a class of Units in a Fund. [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295] When exercising that power in relation to a Fund or a Sub Fund, the Regulator may require a concrete remedial step: it may direct the Fund Manager to change the name of the Fund or the Sub Fund. [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff] The triggering conditions align across both passages: the Regulator’s assessment (including where the name conflicts with another Fund/Sub-Fund name, or is undesirable or misleading) is the basis for intervention. [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff] The scope of what can be assessed for undesirability, misleading character, or conflict is broader in that it expressly includes a class of Units in a Fund in addition to Funds and Sub-Funds. [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295] Accordingly, compliance planning should treat the Fund Manager as the directed party for Fund/Sub Fund name changes, while recognizing that the Regulator’s naming-direction power extends to class-of-Units naming issues as well. [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff] [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295]
source_text: Pursuant to Section 117 of FSMR, the Regulator has the power to make a direction if a name of a Fund, Sub-Fund or class of Units in a Fund is undesirable, misleading or conflicts with a name used by another Fund, Sub-Fund or class of Units of a Fund.
target_text:
Power to make a Direction
If, in the opinion of the Regulator, the name of a Fund or of a Sub Fund conflicts with the name of another Fund or Sub-Fund or is undesirable or misleading, it may direct the Fund Manager to change the name of the Fund or the Sub Fund.

question: For a Designated Non-Financial Business or Profession that files late, how do the texts connect the $500 late payment fee to the specific type of Regulatory Filing referenced in Rule 1.2.7, and what additional consequence may follow from the late submission?
gold_answer: A Designated Non-Financial Business or Profession that submits a Regulatory Filing after the due date must pay a $500 late payment fee to the Regulator, and the late submission also constitutes a breach with potential further regulatory action beyond the fee. [#TGT:44e2c477-1fbd-46c4-9391-046045a5b105] [#SRC:2932ae57-5946-46b4-8ac2-e41d4d145bcc] The linkage to Rule 1.2.7 is that, for Designated Non-Financial Businesses or Professions, Rule 1.2.7 is specifically tied to the AML Return, which is required by Rule 4.6.1 in the Anti-Money Laundering and Sanctions Rules and Guidance Rulebook. [#SRC:2932ae57-5946-46b4-8ac2-e41d4d145bcc] Accordingly, when the late-filed Regulatory Filing is the AML Return in that context, the $500 fee described for late Regulatory Filings applies, and it is imposed in addition to the breach outcome. [#TGT:44e2c477-1fbd-46c4-9391-046045a5b105] [#SRC:2932ae57-5946-46b4-8ac2-e41d4d145bcc] Beyond paying the fee, the Regulator may take further action following the late submission. [#SRC:2932ae57-5946-46b4-8ac2-e41d4d145bcc]
source_text:
Where a Regulatory Filing is submitted after the date on which it becomes due, the Authorised Person, Designated Non-Financial Business or Profession or a Recognised Body is in breach of a Rule. In addition to the imposition of a fee under Rule 1.2.7, the Regulator may take further action.
For Designated Non-Financial Businesses or Professions, Rule 1.2.7 relates to the AML Return, as required by Rule 4.6.1 in the Anti-Money Laundering and Sanctions Rules and Guidance Rulebook.
target_text:
Late Payment Fees relating to Regulatory Filings
An Authorised Person, a Designated Non-Financial Business or Profession or a Recognised Body that submits a Regulatory Filing after the due date must pay to the Regulator a fee of $500.

question: How do you decide whether an Authorised Person is Category 1 or Category 3B based on what its Financial Services Permission lets it do, and what categories must it not fall into for each label?
gold_answer: You classify the Authorised Person by looking at which Regulated Activities its Financial Services Permission authorises and then checking the stated “must not meet” category exclusions. Category 1 applies if the permission authorises the firm to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, and the firm does not meet the criteria of Category 5; the guidance adds that this specific authorisation is what determines Category 1 even if the firm can do other Regulated Activities [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. Category 3B applies if the permission authorises the firm to carry on Providing Custody (where it does so for a Fund) or Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust, and the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5; the guidance similarly says the custody-for-a-Fund or trustee authorisation is determinative, alongside the absence of certain other authorisations, even if other activities are also authorised [#SRC:c1ffeb55-d01d-48f4-b82b-88eb654acbbe].
source_text:
Category 3B
An Authorised Person is in Category 3B if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of:
(i)	Providing Custody (where it does so for a Fund); or
(ii)	Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust; and
(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5.
Guidance
A Category 3B Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Providing Custody for a Fund or Acting as Trustee of a Fund, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1, 1.3.2 and 1.3.3 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3B.
target_text:
Category 1
An Authorised Person is in Category 1 if:
(a)		(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu; and
(b)		(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Category 5.
Guidance
A Category 1 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu that is determinative of its belonging to Category 1.
Category 2
Guidance
1.	A Category 2 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1, that are determinative of its belonging to Category 2.
2.	Where the dealing activities of a firm are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the activities fall in the scope of Category 3A in accordance with Rule 1.3.3(1). A definition of "Matched Principal" is in Rule 1.3.3(2).

question: When an Appointed auditor becomes aware of information suggesting a potentially significant contravention, loss of going-concern status, or an inability to give an unqualified accounts-related statement, what must the Appointed auditor communicate to the Regulator, and how does this interact with the broader duty on each Authorised Person, Recognised Body and its Auditors to disclose matters indicating a breach or likely breach or non-compliance and to maintain notification systems and procedures?
gold_answer: An Appointed auditor must communicate to the Regulator information on, or the auditor’s opinion on, the relevant matters when the auditor reasonably believes there is or may have been a contravention applicable to the person concerned that may be materially significant to the Regulator’s exercise of powers; when the information or opinion may be materially significant to whether the person concerned satisfies and will continue to satisfy the Threshold Conditions (or, for a Recognised Body, the Recognition Requirements); when the person concerned is not, may not be, or may cease to be a going concern; or when the auditor is precluded from stating in the auditor’s report that the annual accounts or other required financial reports have been properly prepared, conform with applicable Rules, or include required statements of facts. This auditor-to-Regulator reporting obligation sits alongside the broader requirement that each Authorised Person, Recognised Body and its Auditors disclose to the Regulator any matter indicating a breach or likely breach, or a failure or likely failure to comply with, Regulations or Rules, and that each Authorised Person and Recognised Body establish and implement systems and procedures enabling compliance with those notification requirements, including by its Auditors [#TGT:46098015-5ac3-4e30-a252-1dc40ab3f6d6] [#SRC:80eb597d-32ee-446e-a416-b5777f98698b].
source_text: Each Authorised Person, Recognised Body and its Auditors is also required under Part 16 and section 193 of the FSMR respectively, to disclose to the Regulator any matter which may indicate a breach or likely breach of, or a failure or likely failure to comply with, Regulations or Rules. Each Authorised Person and Recognised Body is also required to establish and implement systems and procedures to enable its compliance and compliance by its Auditors with notification requirements.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity is updating the market again about the same Non-Equivalent Estimates, when can it avoid repeating the long list of details (like the source and date, reliability, and what work is needed to verify them), and what must it say and do instead?
gold_answer: The Mining Reporting Entity can avoid repeating the full set of detailed disclosure items for material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation only when the new announcement is clearly tied to an earlier announcement that already included those items. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] In that situation, the later disclosure must refer readers to the earlier compliant disclosure and must include the Mining Reporting Entity’s confirmation that (a) the earlier information still applies and (b) there is no new material information or data that changes the reliability/interpretation of the Non-Equivalent Estimates or affects the Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard. [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] The later disclosure still needs a prominent and nearby warning statement about the Non-Equivalent Estimates, and it must be at least as prominent and proximate as the earlier required warning. [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] That warning must cover the key points that the estimates are Non-Equivalent Estimates not disclosed under a Mining Reporting Standard, that a Competent Person has not done enough work to classify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, and that it is uncertain they will ever be reportable as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves after further work. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]
source_text:
If a Mining Reporting Entity has disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates that comply with the requirements of Rule 11.7.3, then any subsequent disclosure made in respect of the Non-Equivalent Estimates does not need to include the information in that Rule if the subsequent disclosure:
(1)	references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with that Rule;
(2)	contains a confirmation from the Mining Reporting Entity that:
(a)	the information provided in the earlier disclosure in compliance with that Rule continues to apply; and
(b)	there is no new material information or data relating to the Non-Equivalent Estimates that impacts on the:
(i)	reliability or interpretation of the Non-Equivalent Estimates; or
(ii)	Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify the Non-Equivalent Estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard; and
(3)	includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates addressing the matters contained in Rule 11.7.3(1).

question: For a Public Listed Company that is also a Reporting Entity, what written instructions must it give to its auditor regarding (i) the audit standards to be applied to its financial statements and (ii) the type of report to be produced, including how the IAASB standards and the FSMR/GEN reporting framework fit together?
gold_answer: A Public Listed Company that is also a Reporting Entity must (in writing) require its auditor to both perform the audit using the specified audit standards and to deliver the required auditor reporting tied to the FSMR and GEN framework. [#TGT:0d030b22-5322-4118-b712-56967f99b2ce] In particular, the company must instruct the auditor to audit the company’s financial statements in accordance with the relevant IAASB-issued International Standards on Auditing for its financial business, unless another standard is acceptable to the Regulator. [#SRC:ad712be8-a953-4486-a76d-484a73126c91] The written requirement must also cover the reporting output: the auditor is to produce the applicable audit report on the audited financial statements in the form contemplated by the FSMR and GEN (i.e., a Reporting Entity auditor’s Report under that framework). [#TGT:0d030b22-5322-4118-b712-56967f99b2ce] This aligns with the Public Listed Company obligation to have its auditor produce audit reports as specified in GEN, while ensuring the report is expressly linked to the FSMR and GEN requirements for a Reporting Entity. [#SRC:ad712be8-a953-4486-a76d-484a73126c91] Separately, the Public Listed Company must appoint an auditor under section 82 of the FSMR, which is the prerequisite for giving these instructions. [#SRC:ad712be8-a953-4486-a76d-484a73126c91]
source_text: A Public Listed Company is required under section 82 of the FSMR to appoint an auditor. Under Rule 10.2.7 a Public Listed Company must require its auditor to conduct an audit of its financial statements in accordance with the requirements of the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB) in respect of its financial business or other standards acceptable to the Regulator and produce audit reports as specified in GEN.
target_text:
Function of the auditor. A Reporting Entity, must in writing require its auditor to:
(1)	conduct an audit of the Reporting Entity's financial statements in accordance with the International Standards on Auditing as issued by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB) in respect of its financial business or other standards acceptable to the Regulator; and
(2)	produce a Reporting Entity auditor's Report on the audited financial statements in accordance with the FSMR and GEN.

question: If the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, and the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider have a written deal saying Rule 19.21.5 (liability for charges) does not apply, who is responsible for charges and interest when a Payment Transaction is not executed, is executed badly, or is executed late?
gold_answer: For a Payment Service User that is not a Natural Person, the SOURCE text allows the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider to agree in writing that certain specified Rules do not apply, including Rule 19.21.5 on liability for charges. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] Separately, the TARGET text sets out a liability position tied to execution problems: it says the Payment Service Provider is liable to its Payment Service User for any charges the Payment Service User is responsible for, and any interest the Payment Service User must pay, when those amounts arise because the Payment Service Provider did not execute the Payment Transaction, executed it defectively, or executed it late. [#TGT:7a0dd0a5-6eb8-41ba-8900-b4048ce180fa] To answer “who pays” in your scenario, you must use both passages: the SOURCE establishes that (because the user is not a Natural Person) the parties can contractually switch off Rule 19.21.5, while the TARGET provides the concrete statement that, in non-execution/defective/late execution cases, the Payment Service Provider bears liability to the Payment Service User for the relevant charges and interest consequences. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] [#TGT:7a0dd0a5-6eb8-41ba-8900-b4048ce180fa] In practice, you would confirm whether the written agreement actually disapplies Rule 19.21.5 (as permitted by SOURCE) and then apply the TARGET liability statement to the execution-failure facts described. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] [#TGT:7a0dd0a5-6eb8-41ba-8900-b4048ce180fa]
target_text: A Payment Service Provider is liable to its Payment Service User for any charges for which the Payment Service User is responsible and any interest which the Payment Service User must pay as a consequence of the non-execution, defective or late execution of a Payment Transaction by the Payment Service Provider.

question: When designing controls to mitigate misuse of Virtual Assets by determining the origin of incoming transactions and the destination of outgoing transactions, what additional technology governance elements must an Authorised Person address regarding security of data transmission/storage and business continuity planning for outages?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must implement systems and controls that explain how the origin of Virtual Assets is determined for incoming transactions and how the destination is determined for outgoing transactions, and those controls must be supported by technology governance measures that protect data and maintain service resilience. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] [#SRC:a5118140-500d-49f4-85a9-6a18ef85d7f2] In practice, the transaction-origin/destination controls should be designed alongside security measures and procedures for the safe storage and transmission of data, because determining origin/destination depends on handling transaction and related information in a way that is protected in transit and at rest. [#SRC:a5118140-500d-49f4-85a9-6a18ef85d7f2] The Authorised Person must also have a security plan describing arrangements for privacy of sensitive data, networks and systems, cloud-based services, physical facilities, and documents/document storage, which provides a structured baseline for safeguarding the information used in these determinations. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] Additionally, the technology governance expectations include business continuity and Client engagement planning for both planned and unplanned system outages; this is relevant because origin/destination determinations must remain operationally manageable even when systems are disrupted. [#SRC:a5118140-500d-49f4-85a9-6a18ef85d7f2] Taken together, the misuse-mitigation controls should be implemented with secure data handling and outage planning so the control objective is maintained under normal and disrupted conditions. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] [#SRC:a5118140-500d-49f4-85a9-6a18ef85d7f2]

question: What does an Authorised Person have to do to stop and report suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes, and can it use secure authentication, biometrics, and customer behaviour monitoring to help meet that requirement?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must put in place and keep effective systems and controls that deter and prevent suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes against the Authorised Person and its Customers, and it must also report suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes to the relevant authorities [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596].
