gold_answer: For an initial disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, a Mining Reporting Entity must include the required content for a disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1, including all material economic assumptions employed, any commercially sensitive treatment (a statement that the material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive and an explanation of the methodology used to determine them), all other material assumptions utilised, and the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3) [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. After the Mining Reporting Entity has made that compliant disclosure, a subsequent disclosure in relation to the same type of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target is permitted to omit the information otherwise required by Rule 11.9.2, but only if it references the earlier compliant disclosure and confirms that all material assumptions in the initial disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]. Additional prominent, proximate cautionary statements are also required in the subsequent disclosure where the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or is based in part on an Exploration Target [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4].
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: What must a Payment Service Provider tell a Payment Service User before the user is bound, and what must also be written into a Framework Contract—especially for charges, exchange rates, and the information needed to start or execute a Payment Order?
gold_answer: Before a Payment Service User is bound by a Single Payment Service Contract, a Payment Service Provider must provide or make available important details about the Payment Service. This includes what information or unique identifier the Payment Service User must give so a Payment Order can be properly initiated or executed, the maximum time for the Payment Service to be executed, the charges payable (and a breakdown where applicable), and (where applicable) the actual or Reference Exchange Rate for the Payment Transaction [#SRC:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55]. In addition, a Framework Contract between a Payment Service Provider and a Payment Service User must include a broader set of information, unless the parties otherwise agree in writing where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person. The Framework Contract must cover, among other things, the same core items (identifiers needed for Payment Orders, maximum execution time, and charges and exchange-rate details), and it must also include extra specifics such as charges connected to information being provided or made available, how exchange rates are determined, and how and how often information under the chapter will be provided or made available [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b].

question: If an Authorised Person is working out its Countercyclical Capital Buffer, what does it have to treat as the “jurisdiction” for each private sector credit exposure, and how is that used in the final buffer calculation?
gold_answer: For the Countercyclical Capital Buffer calculation, the Authorised Person must treat the jurisdiction of a private sector credit exposure as the place where the underlying credit risk ultimately originates, based on the best identification it can make. [#TGT:ffc672ed-a781-4a71-bb0d-7fc38a2e0c7c] That jurisdiction identification matters because the buffer is calculated by taking the Authorised Person’s Total Risk Exposure Amount and multiplying it by a weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where those private sector credit exposures are located. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] In other words, the “location” step determines which jurisdictional buffer rates are considered “applicable” for the weighted average, and the weighted average then directly drives the size of the buffer when applied to the Total Risk Exposure Amount. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] The Authorised Person must therefore link each exposure to a jurisdiction by tracing the ultimate origin of the credit risk, and then use those jurisdictions’ rates in the weighted-average component of the buffer formula. [#TGT:ffc672ed-a781-4a71-bb0d-7fc38a2e0c7c]
source_text: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital equal to its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures are located, calculated in accordance with Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8.
target_text: Geographical location. For the purposes of the calculation of the weighted average of the applicable Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates an Authorised Person must identify, to the best of its ability, the geographical location of its private sector credit exposures as the jurisdiction where the underlying credit risk ultimately originates.

question: Where an MTF admits to trading Securities offered by way of an Exempt Offer under MKT Rule 4.3.1 (13), how should the operator align its platform-specific systems and controls (including identifying offerees and limiting non-Professional Client participation) with the broader Rule 3.9.1 admission-to-trading framework that requires clear, transparent Business Rules and fair, orderly and efficient trading?
gold_answer: An MTF admitting Securities from an Exempt Offer under MKT Rule 4.3.1 (13) must implement platform-level systems and controls that both (i) enforce the Exempt Offer-specific constraints and (ii) support compliance with the admission-to-trading requirements referenced through Rule 3.9.1. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] Concretely, the MTF must ensure it admits only Securities from Exempt Offers made on its own platform, can identify the Persons to whom the Exempt Offer was made, and restrict trading so that no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients can trade those Securities. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] In parallel, because the MTF must comply with MIR rule 3.9.1 (Admission to trading) as applicable for the relevant Securities, the admission approach should be reflected in clear and transparent Business Rules and should ensure the admitted instruments are capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner. [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215] Operationally, this means the Exempt Offer gating (platform-only admission, offeree identification, and the 200-person non-Professional Client cap) should be embedded into the admission process and rule set used to meet Rule 3.9.1 expectations on transparency and orderly trading. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215]
target_text:
Admission to trading
In order to admit Financial Instruments to trading, a Recognised Investment Exchange must satisfy the following requirements, save and except for Recognised Investment Exchanges which only admit to trading Derivatives, in which case only (a), (b), (c) and (i) apply:
(a)	A Recognised Investment Exchange’s Business Rules must be clear and transparent in relation to the admission of Financial Instruments to trading on any market operated by it.
(b)	The Business Rules must ensure that all Financial Instruments admitted to trading on any market operated by the Recognised Investment Exchange are capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner.
(c)	The Business Rules must ensure that:
(i)	all Financial Instruments other than Derivatives admitted to trading on a market operated by the Recognised Investment Exchange are freely negotiable; and
(ii)	all contracts for Derivatives admitted to trading on a regulated market operated by the Recognised Investment Exchange are designed so as to allow for their orderly pricing as well as for the existence of effective settlement conditions.
(d)	For the purposes of meeting the requirements in Rule 3.9.1(c)(ii), a Recognised Investment Exchange must include in its Business Rules, or its Business Rule procedures, contract design specifications relating to Derivative contracts traded on its market which, at a minimum, include:
(i)	minimum price fluctuations (price ticks);
(ii)	maximum price fluctuations (daily price limits), if any;
(iii)	last trading day;
(iv)	settlement or delivery procedures as applicable;
(v)	trading months;
(vi)	position limits, if any;
(vii)	reportable levels; and
(viii)	trading hours.
(e)	The Recognised Investment Exchange must maintain effective arrangements to verify that Issuers of Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a market operated by it comply with its disclosure obligations.
(f)	The Recognised Investment Exchange must maintain arrangements to assist users of a market operated by it to obtain access to information made public under its disclosure obligations.
(g)	The Recognised Investment Exchange must maintain arrangements regularly to review whether the Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a market operated by it comply with the admission requirements for those Financial Instruments.
(h)	The Business Rules must provide that where a Recognised Investment Exchange, without obtaining the consent of the Issuer, admits to trading on a market operated by it a Financial Instrument which has been admitted to trading on another market, the Recognised Investment Exchange:
(i)	must inform the Issuer of that Financial Instrument as soon as is reasonably practicable; and
(ii)	may not require the Issuer of that Financial Instrument to demonstrate compliance with its disclosure obligations.
(i)	The Business Rules must provide that where a Recognised Investment Exchange, without obtaining the consent of the Issuer, admits to trading on an MTF operated by it a Financial Instrument which has been admitted to trading on a market, it may not require the Issuer of that Financial Instrument to demonstrate compliance with its disclosure obligations.
(j)	A Recognised Investment Exchange must comply with the requirements of Rule 3.11 where it admits to trading on a market operated by it a Financial Instrument, the value of which is determined by reference to an underlying benchmark or index provided by a Price Reporting Agency.

question: If a Listed Entity/Reporting Entity has to report each year on compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, what does the Listed Entity have to say in its annual financial report about whether it adopted the APP 4 standards, what it did if it did not fully adopt them, and what the Directors think about the effectiveness of its governance framework?
gold_answer: Listed Entities/Reporting Entities are required to provide annual reporting on their compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles [#SRC:88ccc385-cfe8-4e4e-afd3-80026e74b4dd]. When the annual financial report obligations apply, the Listed Entity must use its annual financial report to cover three core points: first, it must state whether it has adopted the best practice standards in APP 4 (the Corporate Governance Principles). Second, if those standards were not fully adopted or were only partially adopted, it must explain why that happened and describe what actions, if any, it has taken to achieve compliance to the extent the relevant standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted. Third, the annual financial report must include a statement by Directors on whether, in their opinion, the Listed Entity’s Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, and that statement must be supported by information and assumptions, with qualifications included if necessary [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e]. These requirements ensure the annual compliance report is not just a declaration, but also explains gaps and governance oversight.
source_text: Note that Listed Entities/Reporting Entities are also required to comply with Rule 9.2.10 on annual reporting of their compliance with Corporate Governance Principles.
target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: If a firm’s dealing is only as Matched Principal, but it also has permission for Providing Credit, how do you decide whether it fits Category 2 or instead falls into Category 3A, and what extra Category 2 conditions must you check?
gold_answer: You must treat “only as Matched Principal” dealing as pointing away from Category 2 and toward Category 3A, and then separately verify whether the firm can satisfy the specific Category 2 conditions tied to Providing Credit/Principal dealing and the category exclusions. [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] The Category 2 criteria require that the Financial Services Permission authorises Providing Credit and/or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal), that the firm’s dealing activities are not limited in scope as described in Rule 1.3.3(1)(a)(i), and that it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5. [#SRC:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] In contrast, where dealing activities are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, those activities are treated as falling within Category 3A under Rule 1.3.3(1), rather than being determinative for Category 2. [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] This means that even if the firm has Providing Credit permission, it cannot rely on “Matched Principal only” dealing to meet the “Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal)” element for Category 2. [#SRC:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] The practical outcome is that you classify the dealing activity as Category 3A when it is only Matched Principal, and you only classify as Category 2 if the firm independently meets the Category 2 tests (including the scope limitation and category exclusions). [#SRC:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]
source_text:
An Authorised Person is in Category 2 if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal);
(b)	its dealing activities are not limited in scope as provided in Rule 1.3.3(1)(a)(i); and
(c)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5.
Category 3A
Guidance
A Category 3A Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Agent and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1 and 1.3.2 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3A. Provided that an Authorised Person carries out the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Agent in a manner that is wholly incidental to the activity of Managing an Investment Fund or Managing Assets, the Authorised Person shall be regarded as falling within Category 3C.
target_text:
Category 1
An Authorised Person is in Category 1 if:
(a)		(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu; and
(b)		(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Category 5.
Guidance
A Category 1 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu that is determinative of its belonging to Category 1.
Category 2
Guidance
1.	A Category 2 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1, that are determinative of its belonging to Category 2.
2.	Where the dealing activities of a firm are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the activities fall in the scope of Category 3A in accordance with Rule 1.3.3(1). A definition of "Matched Principal" is in Rule 1.3.3(2).

question: When an Authorised Person is required to choose between the Financial Collateral Simplified Approach and the Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral, how is the scope of “eligible financial Collateral” defined for an Authorised Person using the FCCA, and how does that definition relate to the treatment adopted under the Simplified Approach?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral by using either the Financial Collateral Simplified Approach (FCSA) or the Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach (FCCA) [#SRC:f161ce59-6314-4980-8eaf-752bb38a5a19]. Where the Authorised Person uses the FCCA, “eligible financial Collateral” is defined to include three categories: (1) any instrument listed in the referenced list; (2) any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and (3) any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund that invests in those traded equity Securities, provided the Unit price is publicly quoted daily and at least 90% of the Fund’s deposited property is invested in instruments covered by the FCCA list and the referenced list [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85]. This FCCA definition is relevant to the required approach selection because the FCSA is described as adopting the treatment under the same referenced list “in relation to the composition of financial Collateral,” while the FCCA adopts a different treatment and then specifies, by definition, what collateral is eligible under that approach [#SRC:f161ce59-6314-4980-8eaf-752bb38a5a19] [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85].
source_text:
An Authorised Person must use either the:
(a)	Financial Collateral Simplified Approach (FCSA) which adopts the treatment under Rule 4.13.5 in relation to the composition of financial Collateral; or
(b)	Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach (FCCA) which adopts the treatment under Rule 4.13.6;
to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral.
target_text:
For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral comprises:
(a)	any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5;
(b)	any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and
(c)	any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund which invests in equity Securities referred to in (b), where:
(i)	a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily; and
(ii)	at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5.

question: If an Authorised Person is going to let a Third Party Agent hold Safe Custody Assets, what must the Third Party Agent confirm in writing, and does that written confirmation need to be kept in the Authorised Person’s Resolution Pack for Client Investments records?
gold_answer: Before an Authorised Person passes, or permits to be passed, Safe Custody Assets to a Third Party Agent, it must first obtain a written acknowledgement from the Third Party Agent that sets out key protections for Client Investments. This includes confirming the account name clearly separates Client holdings from any Investments belonging to the Authorised Person; that Client Investment movements happen only on the Authorised Person’s instructions; that Client Investments are held separately from the Third Party Agent’s own assets; and that there are defined arrangements for recordkeeping/registration, handling dividends and other entitlements, and giving/receiving instructions. The acknowledgement must also cover that the Third Party Agent will provide statements (with an agreed frequency) detailing Client Investments in the account, that the account cannot be combined with other accounts and is not subject to charges, liens, set-off, or counterclaims for sums owed on other accounts, and the Third Party Agent’s liability if it defaults [#TGT:57e8f079-f256-41f4-b1d3-fcbba0690a98]. Separately, the Resolution Pack for an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must include specified records, including those relating to Third Party Agent acknowledgements for Client Investments, so this written acknowledgement must be kept as part of the Resolution Pack records [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5].

question: For a Reporting Entity, how do the section 82 FSMR obligation to appoint an auditor and the requirement that the auditor be appointed in accordance with Part 15 and any Rules made for that Part operate together when making the appointment?
gold_answer: A Reporting Entity must ensure it has an auditor and that the appointment is made through the specific framework referenced for auditor appointments. [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] The baseline obligation is that the Reporting Entity is required to appoint an auditor under section 82 of the FSMR, so the entity cannot omit making an appointment. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] In addition, the appointment is not merely a general designation; it must be carried out in accordance with Part 15 and any Rules made for the purposes of that Part, meaning the Reporting Entity must follow that Part 15/Rules pathway when appointing the auditor. [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] Read together, section 82 establishes the duty to appoint, while the Part 15 and related Rules condition specifies the required method or procedural basis for how the auditor is appointed. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] Accordingly, compliance requires both (i) making an auditor appointment and (ii) ensuring that appointment is made under the Part 15 and Rules framework, rather than outside it. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb]
source_text: A Reporting Entity is required under section 82 of the FSMR to appoint an auditor.
target_text:
Financial reports. Appointment of auditors
A Reporting Entity shall have an auditor Appointed in accordance with ‎Part 15 and any Rules made for the purposes of that Part.

question: When a Recognised Investment Exchange is permitted by the FSRA to operate a separate MTF, OTF and/or MTF using Virtual Assets under its Recognition Order, what additional market operation must it ensure in parallel to satisfy the Recognition Requirements?
gold_answer: If a Recognised Investment Exchange is permitted by the FSRA, and subject to the stated conditions, to operate a separate MTF, OTF and/or an MTF using Virtual Assets under its Recognition Order, that permission does not displace the baseline operational requirement that applies when it is operating an MTF or an OTF. In that case, the Recognised Investment Exchange must also operate a market that complies with the Recognition Requirements, meaning it needs to maintain a compliant market alongside the operation of the MTF or OTF (including where those facilities are operated separately and may involve Virtual Assets). Practically, the permission to add or separate facilities (including an MTF using Virtual Assets) is conditional and scoped, and the obligation is cumulative: operating the MTF or OTF triggers the requirement to also operate a Recognition Requirements-compliant market. This ensures that, even where additional trading facilities are introduced under the Recognition Order, the Recognised Investment Exchange continues to operate a market meeting the Recognition Requirements as required [#TGT:85479490-968f-42f7-baaa-2580214b953d] while relying on the FSRA-permitted ability to operate the separate facilities [#SRC:fa3cde4e-a388-4d88-bb14-8242a2758cc0].
source_text:
MULTILATERAL TRADING FACILITIES AND VIRTUAL ASSETS
Recognised Investment Exchanges Operating an MTF using Virtual Assets
This means that a Recognised Investment Exchange (in addition to operating markets relating to the trading of Financial Instruments (including Digital Securities) can, where permitted by the FSRA and subject to MIR Rule 3.4.2, operate a separate MTF, OTF and/or MTF using Virtual Assets under its Recognition Order.
target_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange operating an MTF or an OTF, must also operate a market that complies with the Recognition Requirements.

question: If an Authorised Person holds CET1 Capital instruments in a Relevant Entity, when does that holding count as a significant investment, and what must the Authorised Person do with that holding when working out its CET1 Capital?
gold_answer: A holding by an Authorised Person in a Relevant Entity must be treated as a significant investment if it meets any of the listed triggers: the Authorised Person owns more than 10% of the CET1 Capital instruments issued by the Relevant Entity; or the Authorised Person both has Close Links with the Relevant Entity and owns its CET1 Capital instruments; or the Authorised Person owns the Relevant Entity’s CET1 Capital instruments and, while the Relevant Entity is not included in consolidation under the Rules, it is included in the same accounting consolidation as the Authorised Person for IFRS financial reporting [#SRC:c9f19d0b-d036-4cfe-88ba-7e2528a70c11]. When the holding meets that definition, the CET1 deduction requirements apply: subject to the other Rules in the Section, the Authorised Person must deduct from the calculation of its CET1 Capital the applicable amount of its direct and indirect holdings of CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where the Authorised Person has a significant investment in those entities [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]. This links the definition of “significant investment” to the required CET1 deduction treatment for those holdings.
source_text:
CET1 Deductions - significant investment in a Relevant Entity. For the purposes of Rules 3.10.7(g) and (h), an investment by an Authorised Person in a Relevant Entity must be considered as a significant investment if it meets any of the following conditions:
(a)	the Authorised Person owns more than 10% of the CET1 Capital instruments issued by that entity;
(b)	the Authorised Person has Close Links with that entity and owns CET1 Capital instruments issued by that entity; or
(c)	the Authorised Person owns CET1 Capital instruments issued by that entity and the entity is not included in consolidation pursuant to Chapter 8 of these Rules but is included in the same accounting consolidation as the Authorised Person for the purposes of financial reporting under the International Financial Reporting Standards.

question: When calculating CET1 Capital deductions for holdings of CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities, how should an Authorised Person determine whether the holding is treated as a “significant investment” (thereby falling under the deduction category for significant investments rather than the category for non-significant investments), and what types of deductions are required to be taken from CET1 Capital in that calculation?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must first classify its holdings of CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities by determining whether the holding constitutes a “significant investment,” because the CET1 deduction category differs depending on that classification. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] A holding is treated as a significant investment if any of the specified conditions are met: the Authorised Person owns more than 10% of the CET1 Capital instruments issued by the Relevant Entity; or the Authorised Person has Close Links with the entity and owns its CET1 Capital instruments; or the Authorised Person owns the entity’s CET1 Capital instruments and the entity is not included in consolidation under Chapter 8 but is included in the same accounting consolidation as the Authorised Person for IFRS financial reporting. [#SRC:c9f19d0b-d036-4cfe-88ba-7e2528a70c11] Once classified, the Authorised Person must deduct from the calculation of its CET1 Capital the applicable amount of direct and indirect holdings in Relevant Entities where it does not have a significant investment, and separately the applicable amount of direct and indirect holdings in Relevant Entities where it does have a significant investment. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] In addition, the CET1 deduction calculation includes other specified items such as current-year losses, IFRS-defined goodwill and other intangible assets, and deferred tax assets that rely on future profitability. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]
source_text:
CET1 Deductions - significant investment in a Relevant Entity. For the purposes of Rules 3.10.7(g) and (h), an investment by an Authorised Person in a Relevant Entity must be considered as a significant investment if it meets any of the following conditions:
(a)	the Authorised Person owns more than 10% of the CET1 Capital instruments issued by that entity;
(b)	the Authorised Person has Close Links with that entity and owns CET1 Capital instruments issued by that entity; or
(c)	the Authorised Person owns CET1 Capital instruments issued by that entity and the entity is not included in consolidation pursuant to Chapter 8 of these Rules but is included in the same accounting consolidation as the Authorised Person for the purposes of financial reporting under the International Financial Reporting Standards.

question: If the Customer is not a Natural Person, what can the Customer and the Third Party Provider agree to change in writing about which Rules apply (and timing for unauthorised/incorrectly executed Payment Transactions), and what does the Third Party Provider still owe the Customer if a Third Party Transaction is not done, done badly, or done late?
gold_answer: When the Customer is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider may make a written agreement that switches off only certain named Rules, and they may also agree a different time period for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 20.10.1. [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] The Rules that can be disapplied by that written agreement are limited to the specific list provided (covering charges for information, withdrawal of consent, revocation of a Payment Order, requests for refund, evidence on authentication and execution, and liability for charges). [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] Even with such an agreement in place, the Third Party Provider remains liable to its Customer for the financial impact described where the Third Party Provider does not execute a Third Party Transaction, or executes it defectively or late. [#TGT:e704735d-e9c8-4326-b79a-28e066317151] That liability is framed as covering any charges for which the Customer is responsible and any interest the Customer must pay, but only where those amounts arise as a consequence of the Third Party Provider’s non-execution, defective execution, or late execution of the Third Party Transaction. [#TGT:e704735d-e9c8-4326-b79a-28e066317151] Accordingly, the written agreement can adjust the listed Rule-based protections and timing, but it does not remove the stated responsibility for charges and interest caused by execution failures. [#TGT:e704735d-e9c8-4326-b79a-28e066317151]
target_text: Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. A Third Party Provider is liable to its Customer for any charges for which the Customer is responsible and any interest which the Customer must pay as a consequence of the non-execution, defective or late execution of a Third Party Transaction by the Third Party Provider.

question: If the Investigator is running an investigation, who can be told to come to an interview and answer questions, and what else can the Investigator ask for in the same written notice (including when and where things must happen)?
gold_answer: In an investigation, the Investigator can require a person (the interviewee) to attend an interview and answer questions for the purposes of that investigation. [#SRC:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf] The Investigator can do this by sending a written notice to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, even if that other person is not connected to the Person Under Investigation, telling them to attend an interview at a specified time and place and answer questions. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] That same written notice can also require additional cooperation steps, such as producing specified documents (or documents of a specified description) at a specified time and place, providing information, and providing assistance. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] It can also require the person to allow the Investigator to enter the person’s business premises during normal business hours so the Investigator can inspect and copy documents kept there. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] Taken together, the investigative interview requirement can be paired with these other notice-based requirements, with the notice setting the relevant specified time/place or the normal-business-hours condition, as applicable. [#SRC:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]
source_text: Power to require a person to attend an interview . Under section 206(1)(a) of FSMR, the Investigator has the power to require a person (the interviewee) to attend an interview and answer questions for the purposes of an investigation.

question: When the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, may the Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User agree in writing that the regime governing charges for information will not apply, and how does that interact with their ability to agree charges for information requested by the Payment Service User that is extra, more frequent, or sent via a different communication method than the Framework Contract specifies?
gold_answer: Yes. Where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider are permitted to agree in writing that the specific Rules dealing with charges for information do not apply, meaning they can contract out of that default rule set for this topic [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]. Separately, the framework also permits the Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User to agree on charges for information provided at the Payment Service User’s request when the information falls into defined categories: it is additional to what must otherwise be provided or made available, it is provided more frequently than specified, or it is transmitted using a means of communication other than those specified in the Framework Contract [#TGT:18f42ca0-235a-47ac-9e8c-47bd6dd631d7]. Read together, the parties can (i) rely on the permission to agree charges for these types of requested information, and (ii) if the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, additionally agree in writing that the default Rules on charges for information are disapplied, leaving the charging approach to their written agreement within the overall contractual arrangement.
target_text:
The Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User may agree on charges for any information which is provided at the request of the Payment Service User where such information is:
(a)	additional to the information required to be provided or made available by Section 19.2;
(b)	provided more frequently than is specified in Section 19.2; or
(c)	transmitted by means of communication other than those specified in the Framework Contract.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity’s Production Target for an operating mine is built only from Ore Reserves (or Ore Reserves plus Measured Mineral Resources, and any Indicated Mineral Resources are not what makes the project viable), can it skip the required information about the assumptions behind the Production Target, like material economic assumptions and other material assumptions?
gold_answer: In the operating-mine scenarios described—where the Production Target is wholly based on Ore Reserves, or on Ore Reserves together with Measured Mineral Resources, or on Ore Reserves with Measured and/or Indicated Mineral Resources provided the Indicated Mineral Resources are not the determining factor in project viability—the Mining Reporting Entity has a specific permission that its disclosure is not required to comply with the identified compliance requirement referenced in the SOURCE [#SRC:1d86427d-4a34-4179-bd16-1f64e7ef8560]. However, when the Mining Reporting Entity is making a disclosure pursuant to the TARGET obligation, it still has to include the required assumption-related content: it must address the assumptions used to determine the Production Target by providing all material economic assumptions, or (if it considers them commercially sensitive) a statement that they are commercially sensitive along with an explanation of the methodology used to determine them, and it must also include all other material assumptions utilised [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. So, the SOURCE creates a conditional carve-out from one compliance requirement, but the TARGET still imposes mandatory assumption disclosures for disclosures made under that obligation.
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure is not required to comply with Rule 11.8.3 where a Production Target relating to an operating mine(s) is wholly based upon:
(1)	Ore Reserves;
(2)	a combination of Ore Reserves and Measured Mineral Resources; or
(3)	a combination of Ore Reserves; and
(a)	Measured Mineral Resources; and/or
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources, provided that the Indicated Mineral Resources are not the determining factor in project viability.
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: Before an Authorised Person establishes a business relationship with a Retail Client and also intends to offer OTC Leveraged Products (or provide advice or make arrangements relating to them), what combined pre-engagement assessment must the Authorised Person perform, and what conclusions must it be able to reach about the Retail Client?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person must complete a pre-engagement evaluation that both (i) considers the Retail Client’s understanding of risk and potential loss magnitude before establishing the business relationship and (ii) satisfies the specific OTC Leveraged Products gating test before offering, advising on, or arranging those products. [#SRC:e79e3adf-b4c6-4c32-81c3-6440c56574a6] [#TGT:be7639eb-37d0-4a64-80e4-a7694dd68cc0] Practically, this means the Authorised Person should, prior to establishing the relationship, consider whether the Retail Client demonstrates an understanding of the risks and the potential magnitude of losses they may be exposed to. [#SRC:e79e3adf-b4c6-4c32-81c3-6440c56574a6] In addition, the Authorised Person is prohibited from offering OTC Leveraged Products, or providing advice or making arrangements on behalf of the Retail Client relating to OTC Leveraged Products, unless it has first assessed the Retail Client’s skill, experience, knowledge, financial resources, and risk tolerance. [#TGT:be7639eb-37d0-4a64-80e4-a7694dd68cc0] The assessment must be completed to a level that allows the Authorised Person to reasonably conclude that the Retail Client has adequate experience and skill to understand the potential risk of loss involved in investing in OTC Leveraged Products and has liquid financial resources sufficient to absorb potential losses from trading in those products. [#TGT:be7639eb-37d0-4a64-80e4-a7694dd68cc0]
source_text: In order to satisfy the requirements imposed by Rule 23.5.1, the Authorised Person should, prior to establishing a business relationship with a Retail Client, consider whether such Retail Client demonstrates an understanding of the risks and potential magnitude of losses which they may be exposed to.
target_text:
An Authorised Person must not offer OTC Leveraged Products to a Retail Client, or provide any advice or make arrangements on behalf of a Retail Client relating to OTC Leveraged Products unless it has first completed an assessment of the skill, experience, knowledge, financial resources and risk tolerance of the Retail Client, such that the Authorised Person may reasonably conclude that the Retail Client has:
(a)	adequate experience and skill enabling them to understand the potential risk of loss involved in investing in OTC Leveraged Products; and
(b)	liquid financial resources sufficient to absorb potential losses resulting from trading in OTC Leveraged Products.

question: Where a Listed Entity has issued, or agreed to issue, Securities without prior approval, under what conditions is that issue treated as approved for Rule 9.7.1 purposes, and how does that treatment affect whether those Securities are excluded from “Relevant Issues” when applying the 20% formula restriction on new Issues of Equity Securities?
gold_answer: An unapproved issue (or agreement to issue) Securities can be treated as if it had approval for Rule 9.7.1, but only if three conditions are met: it stayed within the Rule 9.7.1 limit, the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities later approve it, and the Securities are then issued within three months after that approval date. [#SRC:3f609871-988e-4e0c-921f-6e1066c630f6] Once that subsequent approval treatment applies, the issue is treated as having approval “for the purposes of Rule 9.7.1,” which matters when calculating the restriction on new issues because “Relevant Issues” excludes Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the prior 12 months if they were made with approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 (or Rule 9.7.5). [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] In practical terms, if the Securities are Equity Securities and the subsequent-approval conditions are satisfied, the Listed Entity can treat them as approved under Rule 9.7.1 for the exclusion test in the “Relevant Issues” definition, rather than counting them toward the prior-12-month total that reduces the maximum number available under the 20% * Base Amount formula. [#SRC:3f609871-988e-4e0c-921f-6e1066c630f6] [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]
source_text:
Subsequent approval of an issue of Securities. An issue of, or agreement to issue, Securities made without approval under Rule 9.7.1 is treated as having been made with approval for the purposes of Rule 9.7.1 if:
(1)	the issue or agreement did not exceed the limit in Rule 9.7.1;
(2)	the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities subsequently approve it; and
(3)	the Securities are issued within three months of the date of the approval.
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: For an Authorised Person, how should its categorisation be determined where its Financial Services Permission includes authorisation to Accept Deposits or manage a Profit Sharing Investment Account as a PSIAu, but it is also authorised for activities such as Managing Assets, Managing a Collective Investment Fund, Providing Custody other than for a Fund, managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account as a PSIAr, Providing Trust Services as trustee of an express trust, or Providing Money Services? Identify the determinative permissions and the exclusion tests that must be applied to decide whether it falls in Category 1 or Category 3C.
gold_answer: Categorisation turns on which Regulated Activities the Authorised Person is authorised to carry on under its Financial Services Permission and on the relevant exclusion tests. Under the Category 1 definition, an Authorised Person is in Category 1 if its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, and it does not meet the criteria of Category 5; the guidance confirms that this authorisation is determinative even if other Regulated Activities are also authorised [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. By contrast, Category 3C applies where the Financial Services Permission authorises one or more of Managing Assets, Managing a Collective Investment Fund, Providing Custody (other than for a Fund), Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAr, Providing Trust Services (as trustee of at least one express trust), or Providing Money Services, and the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B or 5; the guidance similarly treats those authorisations (and the absence of certain other authorisations) as determinative [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0]. Accordingly, if the firm meets the Category 1 trigger and is not Category 5, it is Category 1; Category 3C is only available if the firm does not meet Category 1 (and the other listed categories) while meeting the Category 3C activity trigger.
target_text:
Category 1
An Authorised Person is in Category 1 if:
(a)		(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu; and
(b)		(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Category 5.
Guidance
A Category 1 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu that is determinative of its belonging to Category 1.
Category 2
Guidance
1.	A Category 2 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1, that are determinative of its belonging to Category 2.
2.	Where the dealing activities of a firm are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the activities fall in the scope of Category 3A in accordance with Rule 1.3.3(1). A definition of "Matched Principal" is in Rule 1.3.3(2).

question: For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, how should eligible financial Collateral be determined when the proposed Collateral is an instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5 but is a T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by an entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person and held as Collateral by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities?
gold_answer: Eligible financial Collateral for an Authorised Person using the FCCA is defined to include instruments listed in Rule 4.13.5, but that inclusion is narrowed by a specific exclusion for certain intra-Group capital instruments. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] In practice, even if the proposed Collateral falls within the category of instruments listed in Rule 4.13.5, it must be treated as ineligible if it is a T1 Capital instrument or a T2 Capital instrument issued by any entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person and it is held as Collateral by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities. [#SRC:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685] Accordingly, the Authorised Person should apply a two-step determination: first confirm the instrument is within the FCCA-eligible set (including Rule 4.13.5 instruments), and then screen out any T1/T2 Capital instruments issued by a Financial Group entity when the Collateral is held within the Authorised Person’s Financial Group. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] [#SRC:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685] This ensures the FCCA eligibility assessment does not inadvertently treat intra-Group capital instruments as eligible merely because they appear on the Rule 4.13.5 list. [#SRC:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685]
source_text: For the purposes of Rule 4.13.5 and 4.13.6, eligible financial Collateral excludes any T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by any entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person, which is held by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities as Collateral.
target_text:
For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral comprises:
(a)	any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5;
(b)	any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and
(c)	any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund which invests in equity Securities referred to in (b), where:
(i)	a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily; and
(ii)	at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information that is derived from a Production Target, what must it include about the Production Target and the assumptions used, including how it must address any commercially sensitive material economic assumptions and the required breakdown and cautionary statements where the Production Target relies on Inferred Mineral Resources or an Exploration Target?
gold_answer: Where a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, it must include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, and it must also include the full set of information required for that Production Target disclosure. This means the disclosure must cover all material economic assumptions and all other material assumptions used, and if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, it must state that and explain the methodology used to determine those assumptions [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] and [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. In addition, the Production Target disclosure must state whether forecast commodity prices were used and, if so, that the pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds, and it must specify the proportions of the Production Target attributable to Ore Reserves, Mineral Resources (including Inferred Mineral Resources), and any Exploration Target. It must also include the required statements addressing that Inferred Mineral Resources and any Exploration Target are not determining factors in viability and do not feature significantly in the early mine plan, plus the prescribed prominent cautionary statements and supporting explanations/technical study requirements where the Production Target is wholly or partly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or partly based on an Exploration Target [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a].
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: If a Petroleum Reporting Entity is re-using earlier estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves in a later announcement, what must it say about the Competent Person, and what extra cross-reference and “no material change” confirmation does it need so it can rely on the earlier consent and statement?
gold_answer: In a later announcement that refers to earlier estimates, the Petroleum Reporting Entity must still include the required Competent Person statements for a disclosure that contains Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves, and it can treat the consent-and-statement requirement as already satisfied only if it links back to the earlier disclosure and makes the required confirmations. [#TGT:6f4cc15d-24f2-4ffc-a2ad-dff5dce98f79] The announcement must identify the named Competent Person(s) whose prepared information and supporting documentation the disclosure is based on and which it fairly represents, state whether each Competent Person is an employee of the Petroleum Reporting Entity or a Related Party (or otherwise give the employer’s name), and name the professional organisation each Competent Person belongs to. [#TGT:6f4cc15d-24f2-4ffc-a2ad-dff5dce98f79] For the consent aspect, the prior written consent about the form and context of presenting the estimates and supporting information is only required the first time the entity discloses original or updated estimates, as long as the later announcement that mentions those estimates points readers to the earlier disclosure that included the statement and consent. [#SRC:9c4480c6-f416-4989-b1c9-ad5cf7c5d72e] The later announcement must also confirm there is no new information or data that materially affects what was in the earlier disclosure and that the key assumptions and technical parameters behind the estimates have not materially changed. [#SRC:9c4480c6-f416-4989-b1c9-ad5cf7c5d72e]
source_text:
Competent Persons . The statement referred to in Rule 12.15.2:
(1)	must only be disclosed with the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) as to the form and context in which the estimated Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Prospective Resources, as the case may be, and the supporting information is presented in the disclosure; and
(2)	only applies the first time a Petroleum Reporting Entity discloses original or updated estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves where:
(a)	any subsequent disclosure that refers to the estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves references the earlier disclosure containing the statements and consent referred to in Rules 12.15.2 and 12.15.3(1); and
(b)	the Petroleum Reporting Entity confirms in the subsequent disclosure that it is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects the information included in the earlier disclosure, and that all material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the estimates in the earlier disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed.
target_text:
Competent Persons . A disclosure by a Petroleum Reporting Entity containing Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves must state:
(1)	that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s);
(2)	whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Petroleum Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer; and
(3)	the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.

question: For an Authorised Person, what conditions must be satisfied to be treated as Category 2, and how does that classification differ from Category 1 where the Financial Services Permission covers deposit-taking or managing a PSIAu?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is in Category 2 where its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (and not merely acting as Matched Principal), its dealing activities are not limited in scope in the way contemplated for certain limited dealing permissions, and it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5 [#SRC:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f]. The Target text reinforces that Category 2 status is determinatively driven by authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, together with the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1, and it also clarifies that where dealing is limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the firm’s activities fall within Category 3A rather than Category 2 [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]. By contrast, Category 1 is determinatively based on authorisation to Accept Deposits or to Manage a Profit Sharing Investment Account that is a PSIAu, provided the Authorised Person does not meet Category 5; other authorisations may exist but do not drive the Category 1 classification [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66].
source_text:
An Authorised Person is in Category 2 if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal);
(b)	its dealing activities are not limited in scope as provided in Rule 1.3.3(1)(a)(i); and
(c)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5.
Category 3A
Guidance
A Category 3A Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Agent and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1 and 1.3.2 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3A. Provided that an Authorised Person carries out the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Agent in a manner that is wholly incidental to the activity of Managing an Investment Fund or Managing Assets, the Authorised Person shall be regarded as falling within Category 3C.

Category 1
An Authorised Person is in Category 1 if:
(a)		(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu; and
(b)		(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Category 5.
Guidance
A Category 1 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu that is determinative of its belonging to Category 1.
Category 2
Guidance
1.	A Category 2 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1, that are determinative of its belonging to Category 2.
2.	Where the dealing activities of a firm are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the activities fall in the scope of Category 3A in accordance with Rule 1.3.3(1). A definition of "Matched Principal" is in Rule 1.3.3(2).

question: When calculating CET1 Capital, an Authorised Person must deduct defined benefit pension fund assets; how must the Authorised Person determine the deductible amount where there is an associated deferred tax liability that could be extinguished on impairment or derecognition, and where the Authorised Person has an unrestricted ability to use certain pension fund assets after giving adequate advance notification to the Regulator?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must deduct defined benefit pension fund assets from the calculation of its CET1 Capital as part of the required CET1 deductions framework [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]. However, for purposes of determining the amount of defined benefit pension fund assets to be deducted, the deductible amount must be reduced in two specific ways: first, by the amount of any associated deferred tax liability that could be extinguished if the pension fund assets became impaired or were derecognised under the International Financial Reporting Standards; and second, by the amount of assets in the defined benefit pension fund that the Authorised Person has an unrestricted ability to use, provided the Authorised Person has given the Regulator adequate advance notification of its intention to use those assets [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada]. Where assets are used to reduce the amount to be deducted on this basis, those assets must receive a risk weight in accordance with Chapter 4 of these Rules [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada].
source_text:
CET1 Deductions - defined benefit pension fund assets. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(d), the amount of defined benefit pension fund assets to be deducted from CET1 Capital must be reduced by the following:
(a)	the amount of any associated deferred tax liability which could be extinguished if the assets became impaired or were derecognised under the International Financial Reporting Standards; and
(b)	the amount of assets in the defined benefit pension fund which the Authorised Person has an unrestricted ability to use where the Authorised Person has provided adequate advance notification of its intention to use those assets to the Regulator. Those assets used to reduce the amount to be deducted must receive a risk weight in accordance with Chapter 4 of these Rules.

question: When an Authorised Person is preparing the separate risk disclosure statement to be provided in good time during onboarding (before carrying on any business for a Retail Client) for OTC Leveraged Products, which content elements must be included to support the documented acknowledgement that the Retail Client understands and accepts the risks?
gold_answer: To support obtaining a documented acknowledgement that a Retail Client has received, reviewed, and understands and accepts the risks of trading OTC Leveraged Products, the Authorised Person must ensure the onboarding risk disclosure statement is both timely and substantively complete. [#SRC:3af19a86-294a-44cc-9abc-df79783033e8] Procedurally, the Authorised Person must provide a separate risk disclosure statement as part of onboarding in sufficient time before it carries on any business for the Retail Client, then obtain the documented acknowledgement, provide the Retail Client with a duplicate copy of that acknowledgement, and retain a record of it under applicable record-keeping requirements. [#SRC:3af19a86-294a-44cc-9abc-df79783033e8] Substantively, the risk disclosure statement must contain a prominent warning that the Retail Client can lose substantially more than the initial margin posted. [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955] It must further state that it may not address all risks; that the Retail Client may lose all capital outlay and any profits not redeemed; that losses can arise and accumulate quickly; that leverage and margin trading amplify losses; that stop-loss limits and other controls may be ineffective or fail; that slippage (differences between approved and executed prices) can occur; and that most Retail Clients lose money when transacting in OTC Leveraged Products. [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955] Where relevant, it must also explain stop-loss orders and clarify whether they are guaranteed, and if not, that they may not cap losses in highly volatile conditions. [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955]

question: Where a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a disclosure under Rule 11.8.2 that included the required material assumptions and proportion breakdown for a Production Target, under what conditions may a later disclosure about the same Production Target omit that detailed Rule 11.8.2 information, and what additional proximate statements are still required if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or is based in part on an Exploration Target?
gold_answer: A subsequent disclosure about a Production Target can omit the detailed information that would otherwise be required (such as the material economic and other assumptions and the proportion breakdown across reserves/resources/Exploration Target) only if it is framed as a follow-on to an earlier Rule 11.8.2 disclosure that itself contained those elements. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] To rely on that streamlined approach, the later disclosure must (i) point back to the earlier disclosure that complied with the detailed requirements, and (ii) expressly confirm that the material assumptions used for the Production Target continue to apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] In addition, the later disclosure must still include specific, prominent cautionary statements in certain cases: if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, it must include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement in the form required for that scenario (the statement addressing low geological confidence and uncertainty). [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] If the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, it must likewise include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement in the form required for that scenario (the statement noting the conceptual nature and uncertainty). [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]

question: When a Payment Order for an individual Payment Transaction is transmitted using a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, which post-initiation information must the Payment Service Provider still provide immediately after initiation, and what category of information may it omit because another Payment Service Provider provides it under Section 19.2?
gold_answer: For an individual Payment Transaction sent via a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider must still provide (or make available) the post-initiation, transaction-specific information immediately after the initiation of the Payment Order to the Payer and, where applicable, to the Payee. [#SRC:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622] This includes confirmation that initiation with the Payer’s Payment Service Provider was successful, a reference that lets the Payer and Payee identify the Payment Transaction (including identifying the Payer and Payee and, where appropriate, information transferred with the Payment Order), the transaction amount in the currency used in the Payment Order, any charges payable (and where applicable a breakdown in the Payment Order currency), any exchange-rate details and the post-conversion amount where an exchange rate is used, the date the Payment Service Provider received the Payment Order, and the Credit Value Date. [#SRC:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622] However, in this Framework Contract/Payment Instrument scenario, the Payment Service Provider for that single Payment Transaction does not need to provide the “general information” that would otherwise be required under Rule 19.5.1, to the extent that such general information has been provided or will be provided under Section 19.2 by another Payment Service Provider in respect of the Framework Contract. [#TGT:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2]
