target_text: Where a Payment Order for an individual Payment Transaction is transmitted by way of a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider in respect of that single Payment Transaction need not provide or make available under Rule 19.5.1 the general information which has been provided or will be provided under Section 19.2 by another Payment Service Provider in respect of a Framework Contract.

question: Where an Applicant’s written application must state the address of the Remote Members registered office and head office in its home jurisdiction, how does that information connect to the Remote Member Requirements concerning the Remote Member’s place of business and office location relative to the ADGM?
gold_answer: The written application must include the address of the Remote Members registered office and head office in its home jurisdiction, which is a required data point for the Applicant’s submission and is part of the minimum content that must be provided in writing [#SRC:9820bf55-9b39-42c8-8471-04d83bc34f82]. This information directly supports assessment against the Remote Member Requirements that define the Remote Member’s geographic and establishment criteria: the Remote Member must carry on business in a jurisdiction other than the ADGM and must have its head office and registered office outside the ADGM [#TGT:1c380817-662e-4a9b-ab9d-3bc555c5b20d]. By requiring the applicant to specify the registered office and head office addresses in the home jurisdiction, the application provides the factual basis to evidence that the Remote Member’s offices are not located in the ADGM and that it operates from another jurisdiction, as required by the definition of the Remote Member Requirements [#SRC:9820bf55-9b39-42c8-8471-04d83bc34f82] [#TGT:1c380817-662e-4a9b-ab9d-3bc555c5b20d]. In addition, because the application must also explain how the Applicant will satisfy the Remote Member Requirements, the office-location information is not merely descriptive; it is part of demonstrating compliance with the defined condition that the Remote Member’s business presence and offices remain outside the ADGM while it seeks membership of the specified Recognised Body [#SRC:9820bf55-9b39-42c8-8471-04d83bc34f82] [#TGT:1c380817-662e-4a9b-ab9d-3bc555c5b20d].

question: If an Authorised Person is working out PSIACOMcredit for all its Islamic Contracts, what must it do with any CR Exposure that is not more than 90 days past due, and how does that step fit with valuing the underlying asset and then choosing the risk weighting or capital charge for each contract?
gold_answer: When an Authorised Person calculates PSIACOMcredit across its contracts, it must follow a defined set of steps: identify the Islamic Contracts that are in scope, value each contract’s underlying investment or asset, and reduce that value as required to produce the contract-specific value used in the calculation [#SRC:ad52577a-53d9-469d-ba7a-ae9b4c0a7787]. If the contract involves a CR Exposure that is not past due for more than 90 days, the Authorised Person must categorise that CR Exposure into one of the required asset classes (such as cash items, exposures to central governments/central banks, banks, corporates, regulatory retail, residential mortgages, commercial real estate, or other Exposures) [#TGT:0699660d-a2de-4359-8468-2d993b6a712f]. That categorisation is the classification step that supports selecting the appropriate risk weighting or capital charge (the CRW) for the contract. After the CRW is determined, the Authorised Person applies the relevant PSIACOMcredit formula for each contract and then adds up the PSIACOMcredit results for all contracts to get the total PSIACOMcredit applicable to the Authorised Person [#SRC:ad52577a-53d9-469d-ba7a-ae9b4c0a7787].

question: When is a Recognised Investment Exchange not allowed to let Securities trade on its facilities, and how can the Regulator change chapter requirements to help an Exempt Offeror get its Securities onto the Official List so trading can be sought?
gold_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange must not permit trading of Securities on its facilities unless the Securities are admitted to, and not suspended from, the Official List, except where otherwise prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator [#TGT:76d81d0b-f659-47be-bcb8-a99a24187cac]. The Source explains why this matters for an Exempt Offeror: if the Exempt Offeror wants to voluntarily comply with the Listing Rules so it can include its Securities on the Official List and thereby seek admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, the Regulator may also modify one or more requirements of the chapter to support that outcome [#SRC:46cdf9d3-2ae0-4bc2-8b02-87f68e832ddc]. It also states that, without such a modification, an Exempt Offeror cannot have its Securities included in the Official List [#SRC:46cdf9d3-2ae0-4bc2-8b02-87f68e832ddc]. Putting the two together, the trading restriction means Official List admission (and not being suspended) is the default gateway to trading, and the Regulator’s ability to modify chapter requirements is the lever described for enabling an Exempt Offeror—who is voluntarily following the Listing Rules—to achieve Official List inclusion so that the Recognised Investment Exchange can lawfully permit trading, subject to any prescribed exception [#TGT:76d81d0b-f659-47be-bcb8-a99a24187cac].
source_text: The Regulator may also modify one or more requirements of this chapter for an Exempt Offeror who wishes to voluntarily comply with the Listing Rules in order to include its Securities on the Official List and thereby seek admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange. Without such a modification an Exempt Offeror cannot have its Securities included in the Official List. This is because section 50(3) of the FSMR requires that a Recognised Investment Exchange shall not permit trading of Securities on its facilities unless those Securities are admitted to, and not suspended from, the Official List.
target_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange shall not permit trading of Securities on its facilities unless those Securities are admitted to, and not suspended from, the Official List except where otherwise prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity publishes forecast financial information based on a Production Target and also reports an Ore Reserves estimate, what must it include about (1) the assumptions behind the forecast and (2) the key technical details behind the Ore Reserves estimate?
gold_answer: For forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, a Mining Reporting Entity must include detailed disclosure about the assumptions used to determine that forecast. This includes all material economic assumptions employed, plus all other material assumptions utilised [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. If the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, it must say so and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. It must also disclose the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including the required accompanying information for that Production Target [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. Separately, when the Mining Reporting Entity discloses an estimate of Ore Reserves, it must also include key information relating to mining (recovery/dilution) factors or assumptions, metallurgical factors or assumptions, cut-off parameters, study status, and the relative accuracy/confidence [#TGT:cb1ec09f-a7d3-4c38-ba2e-4e72ed8c3129]. Together, these requirements ensure the forecast is supported by transparent assumptions and the Ore Reserves estimate is supported by key technical and confidence information [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:cb1ec09f-a7d3-4c38-ba2e-4e72ed8c3129].
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text: ORE RESERVES . Rule 11.6 also requires that when a Mining Reporting Entity discloses an estimate of Ore Reserves, the disclosure is also to include key information relating to mining (recovery/dilution) factors or assumptions, metallurgical factors or assumptions, cut-off parameters, study status and the relative accuracy/confidence.

question: When an Authorised Person uses the FCSA to recognise eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure, how must it split the Exposure into collateralised and uncollateralised portions, and what CRW must it apply to the collateralised portion when the CRW applicable to the Collateral would otherwise be below 20%, including the specific exceptions that permit 0% or 10%?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person using the FCSA must treat eligible financial Collateral by separating the CR Exposure into two parts and then applying the appropriate CRW to each part, with a floor on the collateralised portion unless an exception applies. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] The collateralised portion must be set equal to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and the uncollateralised portion must be the CR Exposure amount reduced by that latest fair value. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] For Credit RWA calculation purposes, the collateralised portion generally takes the CRW applicable to the Collateral as if the Authorised Person had a direct Exposure to it, while the uncollateralised portion takes the CRW applicable to the obligor. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] However, if the CRW that would be used for the collateralised portion (i.e., the CRW applicable to the Collateral) is below 20%, the Authorised Person must apply 20% to the collateralised portion unless one of the specified cases applies. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438] The exceptions include qualifying SFTs (0% if the Counterparty is a core market participant; 10% if not), certain daily-marked OTC Derivatives with no currency mismatch (0% if collateralised by cash; 10% if collateralised by specified 0%-risk-weight government/central bank/PSE exposures), and certain no-currency-mismatch transactions where the Collateral is specified cash on Deposit or specified 0%-risk-weight government/central bank/PSE exposures and the latest fair value used for the collateralised portion has been discounted by 20%. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438]
source_text:
Recognition of eligible financial Collateral under FCSA. Subject to A4.3.28, an Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA may recognise the effects of CRM of the eligible financial Collateral as follows:
(a) 	break down the Exposure into -
(i) 	a collateralised portion with E equal to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral; and
(ii) 	an uncollateralised portion with E equal to the E of the CR Exposure less the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral;
and
(b) 	for the purposes of calculating the Credit RWA amount pursuant to Rule 4.8.3, use:
(i) 	for the collateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the eligible financial Collateral as though the Authorised Person had a direct Exposure to that Collateral; and
(ii) 	for the uncollateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the obligor.

question: For an ADGM Green Fund, when does the Fund Manager have to appoint a third party to attest compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement, and how does that obligation change if the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund where the Fund Manager elects to self-attest, or if all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund must generally appoint a third party to attest, on an ongoing basis and at least annually, that it complies with the Green Fund Investment Requirement, but this obligation is limited in scope and can be displaced by specified alternatives. [#SRC:900d63ac-47c0-453a-91f1-79eaee1ab8f1] The third-party appointment requirement applies only to the portion of the Eligible Green Fund Property that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy (i.e., the taxonomy-aligned portion described in connection with Rule 20.2.3(a)). [#SRC:900d63ac-47c0-453a-91f1-79eaee1ab8f1] However, the Fund Manager is not required to appoint a third party if the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund and the Fund Manager elects to provide the attestation itself, in which case the attestation function is performed by the Fund Manager rather than an external party. [#TGT:700ed6a6-3a4a-49b8-8bae-3980c9d36df0] Separately, if all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark (as referenced with Rule 20.2.3(b)), then no attestation is required at all, removing both the third-party and self-attestation pathways for that scenario. [#TGT:700ed6a6-3a4a-49b8-8bae-3980c9d36df0]
source_text: The Green Fund Attestation Requirement. Subject to Rule 20.2.9, the Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund must appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually.  This requirement only applies to that portion of the Eligible Green Fund Property that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy in accordance with Rule ‎20.2.3(a). This is referred to as the “Green Fund Attestation Requirement”.
target_text:
Alternative Attestation Requirement. The Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund is not required to appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement if:
(a)	the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund and the Fund Manager elects to provide the attestation itself; or
(b)	all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark pursuant to Rule ‎20.2.3(b), in which event an attestation is not required.

question: For the purposes of an investigation, how may the Investigator exercise the power to require a person to attend an interview and answer questions, and what additional requirements can be included in the same written notice (including any conditions on time, place, or premises access)?
gold_answer: The Investigator’s power to compel interview attendance is exercised for the purposes of an investigation by requiring a person (the interviewee) to attend an interview and answer questions. [#SRC:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf] In operational terms, the Investigator may implement that power by issuing a written notice to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, including someone not connected to the Person Under Investigation, requiring them to attend an interview at a specified time and place and answer questions. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] The same written notice can also impose additional, distinct requirements that support the investigation, including: producing specified documents (or documents of a specified description) at a specified time and place; providing information; providing assistance; and permitting entry to the person’s business premises during normal business hours so the Investigator can inspect and copy documents located there. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] Accordingly, when the Investigator uses the interview power for investigative purposes, the notice can combine the interview obligation with document, information, assistance, and premises-access obligations, each framed with the timing/place parameters or business-hours condition stated for that requirement. [#SRC:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]
source_text: Power to require a person to attend an interview . Under section 206(1)(a) of FSMR, the Investigator has the power to require a person (the interviewee) to attend an interview and answer questions for the purposes of an investigation.

question: When a Supplementary Prospectus is filed, under what circumstances may the Regulator require payment of a supplementary fee, and how does that align with the broader situations in which the Regulator is permitted to impose a supplementary fee for substantial additional cost or effort?
gold_answer: Across both provisions, the Regulator’s ability to impose a supplementary fee is framed as a conditional permission tied to expected substantial additional cost or effort. In the specific context of filing a Supplementary Prospectus, the default position is that filing alone does not lead to any fee; however, if the review of that Supplementary Prospectus will require the Regulator to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in conducting its review, the Regulator may require payment of a supplementary fee [#SRC:cec237a1-c364-4ed0-9197-dcac6160defb]. The broader permission confirms the same underlying threshold—where the Regulator expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort—and clarifies that this may arise not only in review of a filing but also in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing, or when conducting on-going supervision [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]. Read together, the Supplementary Prospectus scenario is an example of the wider category: a filing that, due to the anticipated burden on the Regulator, can justify a supplementary fee, but only when the substantial-cost/effort condition is met.
source_text: The filing of a Supplementary Prospectus does not trigger the payment of a fee unless the review of the Supplementary Prospectus will require the Regulator to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort when conducting its review, in which event the Regulator may require payment of a supplementary fee in accordance with Rule 1.2.4.
target_text:
Supplementary fees
The Regulator may require a Person to pay to the Regulator a supplementary fee in circumstances where it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing or when conducting on-going supervision.

question: When an Authorised Person carries out a Regulated Activity involving Virtual Assets, do the listed COBS Rules apply to every Transaction, even if other parts of COBS would normally limit them or create exceptions?
gold_answer: Yes. In the Virtual Asset Framework context, the SOURCE states that, for Authorised Persons, the relevant COBS Rules are to apply to all transactions undertaken by an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, and it specifies the exact set: Suitability, Best Execution, Aggregation and Allocation, Confirmation Notes, Periodic Statements, and Key Information and Client Agreement [#SRC:3483a783-5aa5-4a3d-8e88-9c26ba4bed8a]. The TARGET then frames how this should be interpreted for scope: the same COBS Rules should be read as applying to all Transactions undertaken by an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, and this applies irrespective of any restrictions on application or any exception to these Rules elsewhere in COBS [#TGT:60f7507b-7582-4d9b-8e9c-1e5a8ceeaf5e]. Putting both together, the scope is comprehensive for that Virtual Assets regulated-activity scenario: the listed Rules are meant to apply transaction-by-transaction, and the TARGET makes clear that other COBS limitations or exceptions do not narrow that application for these particular Rules.

question: For a decision that may adversely affect a person’s rights, liabilities, or interests, when is it eligible to be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review, and how do the exclusions and examples in FSMR (including operational decisions and certain decisions outside the Part 21 procedure such as exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers) interact with the rule that covers decisions made under these Regulations or Rules made by the Regulator?
gold_answer: A person may refer to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review a decision that meets the adverse-effect threshold, but the availability of referral must be read together with the FSMR carve-out for operational decisions and the FSMR indication that some additional categories of decisions are also referable even though they are not within the Part 21 procedure. [#TGT:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23] [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea] The threshold condition is that the decision may affect the person’s rights or liabilities or otherwise adversely affect the person’s interests, and the referral is made by that affected person. [#TGT:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23] Within that scope, FSMR states that all of our decisions meeting that threshold may be referred, except for operational decisions, which are excluded from referral. [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea] In addition, FSMR explains that certain other decisions—specifically identified as not being subject to the Part 21 procedure—may still be referred for a full merits review, with the exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers given as an example. [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea] Accordingly, for decisions made under these Regulations or Rules made by the Regulator that meet the adverse-effect threshold, referral is available unless the decision is operational, and FSMR also contemplates referral for specified non‑Part 21 decisions such as Own‑Initiative Powers. [#TGT:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23] [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea]
source_text: Section 225(1) of FSMR provides that all of our decisions that may affect the rights or liabilities of a person or otherwise adversely affect the interests of a person (except operational decisions) may be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review. FSMR also specifies that certain other decisions, not subject to the Part 21 procedure, may be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review (e.g., exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers).
target_text: Any decision made under these Regulations by the Regulator or Rules made by the Regulator which may affect the rights or liabilities of a person or otherwise adversely affect the interests of a person, may be referred by that person to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review .

question: When an Authorised Person is permitted to reduce the value of its Exposures using credit risk mitigation techniques, what policy documentation must it maintain regarding the use of exclusions, and how should that documentation align with the discretionary reductions it applies?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may, for the purposes of the Section on recognition of credit risk mitigations, reduce the value of its Exposures at its discretion by applying one or more specified reduction methods, including specific provisions tied to credit loss risk, eligible netting (subject to applicable conditions), qualifying Collateral, eligible guarantees, qualifying Credit Derivatives, and securitisation-based credit risk transfers where the stated conditions are met [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3]. In parallel with exercising that discretion, the Authorised Person must document its policy governing the use of any exclusions referenced for recognition of credit risk mitigations [#SRC:5a4ad383-0e7b-476f-84ee-d6bce45b2270]. Practically, this means the firm’s written policy should clearly describe when and how it will apply exclusions in connection with its chosen exposure-reduction approaches, so that the discretionary use of provisions, netting, Collateral, guarantees, Credit Derivatives, or securitisation is supported by an articulated internal framework. The documentation obligation is not optional and should be maintained as part of the firm’s approach to applying the permitted exposure reductions under the Section.
source_text: Recognition of Credit Risk mitigations. An Authorised Person must document its policy for the use of any of the exclusions in Rule 4.15.12.

question: When checking whether Collateral is eligible financial Collateral under the FCCA, how do you apply the list of allowed instruments and the rules for traded equity Securities and Fund Units, while also making sure you do not include excluded Capital instruments issued by an entity in the Authorised Person’s Financial Group?
gold_answer: To determine eligible financial Collateral under the FCCA for an Authorised Person, first confirm the Collateral fits within the allowed types: it is either an instrument on the relevant rule-based list, an equity Security (including a convertible bond) traded on a regulated exchange, or a Unit in a Collective Investment Fund that invests in those traded equity Securities. If the Collateral is a Fund Unit, it only qualifies if its price is publicly quoted daily and at least 90% of the Fund’s deposited property is invested in instruments that are within the FCCA eligibility rule and the referenced rule-based list. Once the Collateral meets one of these inclusion tests, you must then apply the exclusion that overrides eligibility for certain intra-group capital instruments. Specifically, you must not treat as eligible any T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by any entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person, where it is held by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities as Collateral. This ensures the FCCA eligibility definition is applied with both the inclusion categories and the mandatory carve-out. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] [#SRC:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685]
source_text: For the purposes of Rule 4.13.5 and 4.13.6, eligible financial Collateral excludes any T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by any entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person, which is held by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities as Collateral.
target_text:
For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral comprises:
(a)	any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5;
(b)	any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and
(c)	any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund which invests in equity Securities referred to in (b), where:
(i)	a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily; and
(ii)	at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5.

question: If someone gets written notice to attend an interview and answer questions, are they prohibited from refusing to answer because it could incriminate them or reveal something said in confidence, and does the same “no reasonable excuse” rule also apply to refusing to let documents be inspected/copied or produced under a requirement?
gold_answer: Yes. In the interview setting, a person who is required to attend an interview is first provided written notice requiring their attendance to answer questions, and the interviewee is not entitled to refuse or fail to answer just because the answers may incriminate them, make them liable for a penalty, or might reveal a communication made in confidence (with the stated qualification about confidential communications) [#SRC:4d708250-cc2d-408e-9e2f-d77689864eda]. The related prohibition goes further by stating that, subject to the stated carve-out, it is not a reasonable excuse for a person to refuse or fail to permit inspection and copying of any information or Document, to give or produce (or procure the giving or production of) any information or Document, or to answer questions, when the refusal is based on the ground that the information, Document, or answer might tend to incriminate the person or might reveal a communication made in confidence (again with the stated qualification) [#TGT:4a2d4419-4e18-431a-9f52-59dae76a79ab]. Together, these passages mean a person cannot rely on self-incrimination or confidentiality concerns as the reason to avoid answering questions at interview, and cannot use those grounds as a “reasonable excuse” to avoid inspection/copying or production duties when required.
source_text: Power to require a person to attend an interview . A person required to attend an interview will first be provided with written notice requiring their attendance at the interview to answer questions. Pursuant to section 206(5) of FSMR, an interviewee is not entitled to refuse or fail to answer a question on the basis that their answers may incriminate them, make them liable for a penalty or might reveal a communication made in confidence (subject to section 209(6) of FSMR).
target_text:
Subject to section ‎210‎(3), it is not a reasonable excuse for a person to refuse or fail to—
(a)	permit inspection and copying of any information or Document;
(b)	give or produce, or procure the giving or production of, any information or Document; or
(c)	answer questions;
pursuant to any requirement under sections ‎201, ‎203 and ‎206‎(1)‎(a), ‎(b), ‎(c) and ‎(e) on the grounds that any such information or Document or answer, as the case may be—
(d)	might tend to incriminate the person; or
(e)	is, or contains, or might reveal a communication made in confidence (subject to section ‎209‎(6)).

question: If an Authorised Person has eligible financial Collateral for an SFT, what are the allowed ways to reflect that collateral when measuring E for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure, and how do the rules change depending on whether the SFT is in the Non Trading Book or Trading Book and whether the exposure is determined under Rule 4.9.15?
gold_answer: To reflect eligible financial Collateral in E for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure from an SFT, the Authorised Person must follow both the rule that permits collateral recognition for exposures determined under Rule 4.9.15 and the book-based limits on which approach can be used. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] If the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 and the firm has taken eligible financial Collateral, the firm may recognise the effect of that collateral by applying Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] Separately, for any SFT in the Non Trading Book, the firm must pick either the FCSA or the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral, use that one approach for the entire Non Trading Book, and not combine both approaches. [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412] For a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure from an SFT in the Trading Book, the firm is limited to using only the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral. [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412]
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.
target_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person must use either the FCSA or the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral for any SFT in the Non Trading Book. The Authorised Person must apply the chosen approach consistently to the entire Non Trading Book and must not use a combination of both approaches. For a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from any SFT in the Trading Book, an Authorised Person must only use the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral.

question: When an Authorised Person is using the FCCA, how should eligible financial Collateral be defined by combining the general composition criteria (including instruments listed in the relevant rule, certain traded equity Securities, and qualifying Units in a Collective Investment Fund) with the specific exclusion for certain Capital instruments issued within the Authorised Person’s Financial Group and held as Collateral?
gold_answer: For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral is defined by starting with the categories that are permitted and then applying the stated carve-out. The permitted composition includes (i) any instrument listed in the relevant rule, (ii) any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange, and (iii) any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund that invests in those traded equity Securities, provided a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily and at least 90% of the Fund’s deposited property is invested in instruments listed in the FCCA eligibility rule and the referenced rule. However, even if an instrument would otherwise fall within the “instrument listed” limb, it must be treated as ineligible if it is a T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by any entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person and held by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities as Collateral. This exclusion operates as a limitation on what can be counted as eligible financial Collateral under the FCCA definition. [#SRC:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685] [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85]
source_text: For the purposes of Rule 4.13.5 and 4.13.6, eligible financial Collateral excludes any T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by any entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person, which is held by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities as Collateral.
target_text:
For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral comprises:
(a)	any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5;
(b)	any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and
(c)	any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund which invests in equity Securities referred to in (b), where:
(i)	a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily; and
(ii)	at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5.

question: If an Applicant’s audited accounts don’t cover a full three years (or the Regulator accepts a shorter period), when would the Regulator usually make the Reporting Entity follow Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i), and what other admission situations can trigger that same requirement?
gold_answer: If an Applicant’s audited accounts cover less than three years, that fact aligns with a circumstance in which the Regulator generally requires a Reporting Entity to comply with Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i). [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8] This matters because the Applicant is expected to have published or filed audited accounts covering a prior period of three years, unless the Regulator accepts a shorter period. [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1] Where the audited history is shorter than three years (including where a shorter period is accepted), the Regulator’s general approach is to require Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i) in that scenario. [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8] The same Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i) requirement is also generally triggered when the Listed Entity with Securities being admitted to the Official List is admitted under the assets eligibility test, or when the Regulator considers—on other grounds—that quarterly cash reports are needed, including where the admission is of a cash-box. [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8] Separately, regardless of the period length, the audited accounts must satisfy the consolidation requirement and be prepared and audited under standards acceptable to the Regulator. [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1]
source_text: The Regulator will generally require a Reporting Entity to comply with Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i) in circumstances where the Listed Entity with Securities being admitted to the Official List is admitted under the assets eligibility test (see Rule 2.3.16), has less than three years of audited financial statements as prescribed in Rule 2.3.2(1), or is considered by the Regulator, for other reasons, to require quarterly cash reports, such as the admission of a cash-box.

question: What does a Mining Reporting Entity have to put in its first Rule 11.8.2 Production Target disclosure about assumptions and the make-up of the Production Target, and when can a later Production Target update leave out that detailed information if it points back to the earlier disclosure and confirms the assumptions have not materially changed (including any required prominent warning statements)?
gold_answer: In the first disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2, a Mining Reporting Entity must provide the key assumption and composition information supporting the Production Target. This includes all material economic assumptions used (or, if the Mining Reporting Entity considers them commercially sensitive, saying so and explaining the methodology used to determine them) and all other material assumptions utilised. If forecast commodity prices were used, it must state that the forecast pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds. It must also disclose the proportions of the Production Target based on the specified reserves/resources categories, including any Inferred Mineral Resources and any Exploration Target, and include the required statements about whether Inferred Mineral Resources and any Exploration Target are determining factors in viability and whether they feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan. Additional prominent, proximate cautionary statements (and other supporting items in the wholly-Inferred case) apply depending on whether the Production Target is wholly or partly based on Inferred Mineral Resources and/or partly based on an Exploration Target [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. A later disclosure about the Production Target may omit the otherwise-required detailed information if it references the earlier compliant disclosure, confirms the original material assumptions still apply and have not materially changed, and includes the required prominent cautionary statements where the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources and/or based in part on an Exploration Target [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef].
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: Can the Investigator make someone come to an interview and answer questions during an investigation, and can that include people other than the Person Under Investigation if the Investigator sends a written notice?
gold_answer: Yes, taken together the two texts indicate that the Investigator is permitted to require interview attendance and questioning for investigative purposes, and that this can apply to more than just the Person Under Investigation. The SOURCE states that, for the purposes of an investigation, the Investigator has the power to require a person (the interviewee) to attend an interview and answer questions [#SRC:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf]. The TARGET adds important detail about both process and scope: the Investigator may do this by written notice, and the notice can be directed to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, even if that other person is not connected to the Person Under Investigation [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. The TARGET also makes clear that the notice can specify the time and place for the interview and that the person must answer questions at that interview. Combining these points, the Investigator’s permission covers compelling interviews for investigative purposes and extends to third parties, provided the requirement is issued through written notice.
source_text: Power to require a person to attend an interview . Under section 206(1)(a) of FSMR, the Investigator has the power to require a person (the interviewee) to attend an interview and answer questions for the purposes of an investigation.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure doesn’t follow a non-mandatory part of a Mining Reporting Standard (like something in Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code), what exactly has to be written in the disclosure, and how does that fit with the Regulator’s expectation to comply or explain under Rule 11.2.1(1) and Rule 11.2.2?
gold_answer: If a Mining Reporting Entity does not follow a non-mandatory requirement in a Mining Reporting Standard, it still needs to address that gap directly and clearly in the disclosure. [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124] The disclosure must contain a statement that explains both (1) how the disclosure is different from the non-mandatory requirement and (2) why it is different. [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f] This is consistent with the Regulator’s stated expectation that the Mining Reporting Entity should fully comply with non-mandatory requirements (including examples such as Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code) unless it provides an explanation of non-compliance. [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124] In other words, the “comply or explain” idea is implemented by requiring the explanation to be included inside the disclosure whenever the non-mandatory requirement is not met. [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f] This also matches the reference to explaining non-compliance in accordance with Rule 11.2.2 when the entity does not follow non-mandatory requirements. [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124]
source_text: Rule 11.2.1(1) requires a Mining Reporting Entity to fully comply with all binding requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard. The Regulator also expects a Mining Reporting Entity to fully comply with all non-mandatory requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard, including, for example, Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code, or explain its non-compliance in accordance with Rule 11.2.2.
target_text: Requirements for all disclosures. Where a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity does not meet a non-mandatory requirement contained in a Mining Reporting Standard, the Mining Reporting Entity must provide in its disclosure a statement as to how and why its disclosure differs from the non-mandatory requirement contained in the relevant Mining Reporting Standard.

question: If a Recognised Body cannot follow a direction (like giving access for inspection or suspending an activity), what can the Regulator do, and when does it usually consider revoking the Recognition Order?
gold_answer: The Regulator can give directions to a Recognised Body to take specified steps to secure compliance with the Recognition Requirements, and those steps may include giving the Regulator access to the Recognised Body’s premises to inspect the premises or documents there, as well as suspending the carrying on of any activity for a period set out in the direction [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500]. But the Regulator will usually consider revoking the Recognition Order where it would not be possible for the Recognised Body to comply with a direction, meaning the direction route is not workable in practice [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a]. The Regulator will also usually consider revocation if the Recognised Body is failing or has failed to satisfy one or more Recognition Requirements and that failure has or will have serious consequences, or if for some other reason it would not be appropriate for the Regulator to give a direction under its power to give directions. Separately, revocation is usually considered if the Recognised Body has not carried on the business of a Recognised Body during the 12 months after the Recognition Order took effect, or has not carried on that business at any time during the six months ending with the day the Recognition Order is revoked [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a].
target_text: The Regulator has the power to give directions to a Recognised Body to take specified steps in order to secure its compliance with the Recognition Requirements. Those steps may include granting the Regulator access to the Recognised Body's premises for the purposes of inspecting those premises or any documents on the premises and the suspension of the carrying on of any activity by the Recognised Body for the period specified in the direction.

question: When can the Regulator tell a Recognised Body to take steps like letting the Regulator inspect its premises or stopping an activity for a set time, and when will the Regulator usually think about revoking the Recognition Order instead?
gold_answer: The Regulator has the power to give directions to a Recognised Body to take specified steps to secure compliance with the Recognition Requirements. The steps the Regulator may require can include granting the Regulator access to the Recognised Body’s premises to inspect the premises or documents on the premises, and suspending the carrying on of any activity by the Recognised Body for the period specified in the direction [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500]. Even though those directions are available, the Regulator will usually consider revoking a Recognition Order in several situations: if the Recognised Body is failing or has failed to satisfy one or more Recognition Requirements and that failure has or will have serious consequences; if it would not be possible for the Recognised Body to comply with a direction; or if, for some other reason, it would not be appropriate for the Regulator to give a direction under its power to give directions [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a]. The Regulator will also usually consider revocation if the Recognised Body has not carried on the business of a Recognised Body during the 12 months after the Recognition Order took effect, or has not carried on that business at any time during the six months ending with the day the Recognition Order is revoked [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a].
target_text: The Regulator has the power to give directions to a Recognised Body to take specified steps in order to secure its compliance with the Recognition Requirements. Those steps may include granting the Regulator access to the Recognised Body's premises for the purposes of inspecting those premises or any documents on the premises and the suspension of the carrying on of any activity by the Recognised Body for the period specified in the direction.

question: For an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, what records must be retained to satisfy both the requirement to keep a Resolution Pack (including client classification and client agreement documentation) and the general obligation to maintain sufficient records for each activity and function for at least six years?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must ensure its recordkeeping meets two linked requirements: (1) the Resolution Pack must include specified categories of records, and (2) the Authorised Person must maintain sufficient records for each activity and function for at least six years. Practically, this means the Resolution Pack should contain, at a minimum, records of Client classification and Client agreements, master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments, records and written permissions relating to the use of Client Investments, assessments and acknowledgements relating to Third-Party Agents for both Client Money and Client Investments, and the most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. In parallel, the six-year recordkeeping set must include (where applicable) documents regarding Client classification and a record of each Client Agreement (including amendments), alongside broader records such as Marketing Material, records of Financial Instruments or Regulated Activities for Clients and related advice/recommendations, suitability assessment records, inducements/Soft Dollar Agreement details, financial promotions, and other Client disclosures [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2].

question: In what situations can the Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund skip hiring a third party to attest compliance, even though it normally must get ongoing and at least annual attestation for the part of Eligible Green Fund Property invested in taxonomy-aligned assets?
gold_answer: Normally, the Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund must appoint a third party to attest to compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually, but that requirement is targeted: it applies only to the portion of Eligible Green Fund Property invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy. [#SRC:900d63ac-47c0-453a-91f1-79eaee1ab8f1] The Fund Manager can skip appointing a third party under the Alternative Attestation Requirement in two cases. First, if the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund, the Fund Manager may elect to provide the attestation itself; in that case, the Fund Manager is not required to appoint a third party even though an attestation is still being provided. Second, if all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark, then an attestation is not required at all. These alternatives operate as exceptions to the general third-party appointment approach and determine whether the Fund Manager must engage an external attester or can rely on self-attestation or no attestation, depending on the Fund’s status and asset composition. [#TGT:700ed6a6-3a4a-49b8-8bae-3980c9d36df0]
source_text: The Green Fund Attestation Requirement. Subject to Rule 20.2.9, the Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund must appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually.  This requirement only applies to that portion of the Eligible Green Fund Property that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy in accordance with Rule ‎20.2.3(a). This is referred to as the “Green Fund Attestation Requirement”.
target_text:
Alternative Attestation Requirement. The Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund is not required to appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement if:
(a)	the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund and the Fund Manager elects to provide the attestation itself; or
(b)	all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark pursuant to Rule ‎20.2.3(b), in which event an attestation is not required.

question: When calculating CET1 deductions for investments in CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities under Rule 3.10.7(g) and (h), how should an Authorised Person determine whether to use gross long positions or a net long position approach for Trading Book holdings, and what additional method applies where the Trading Book exposure is indirect via index Securities?
gold_answer: For Rule 3.10.7(g) and (h), an Authorised Person must apply the Trading Book-specific netting methodology described for those holdings, rather than defaulting to a gross-long-only approach for all positions. [#TGT:f6640865-b279-44c1-941f-091a1619258c] The SOURCE establishes that, for Rule 3.10.7(f), (g) and (h), the deductible amount is calculated on the basis of gross long positions (with a stated cross-reference to Rule 3.10.15), which creates the baseline calculation concept that must be reconciled with the TARGET’s Trading Book treatment for (g) and (h). [#SRC:40c66431-d7b0-41ae-bc47-0ae63f4d9454] In practice under (g) and (h), for holdings in the Trading Book, the holdings must be calculated using the net long position in the same underlying Exposure, but only where the short position’s maturity matches the long position’s maturity or the short has a residual maturity of at least one year. [#TGT:f6640865-b279-44c1-941f-091a1619258c] Additionally, where the Trading Book holding is indirect and takes the form of holdings of index Securities, the amount to be deducted must be determined by calculating the underlying Exposure to the capital instruments of the Relevant Entities included in the indices. [#TGT:f6640865-b279-44c1-941f-091a1619258c]
source_text: CET1 Deductions - investments in CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(f), (g) and (h), the amount of holdings of CET1 Capital instruments and other capital instruments of Relevant Entities to be deducted, must be calculated, subject to Rule 3.10.15, on the basis of the gross long positions.
target_text:
CET1 Deductions - investments in CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(g) and (h), an Authorised Person must make the deductions in accordance with the following:
(a)	the holdings in the Trading Book of the capital instruments of Relevant Entities must be calculated on the basis of the net long position in the same underlying Exposure provided the maturity of the short position matches the maturity of the long position or has a residual maturity of at least one year; and
(b)	the amount to be deducted for indirect holdings in the Trading Book of the capital instruments of Relevant Entities that take the form of holdings of index Securities must be determined by calculating the underlying Exposure to the capital instruments of the Relevant Entities in the indices.

question: If an Authorised Person uses the FCSA and wants to recognise the risk-reducing effect of eligible financial Collateral, how should it split the CR Exposure and choose the risk weights, and what must it do if the collateral’s risk weight would come out below 20%?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA may recognise CRM by dividing the Exposure into two parts: a collateralised portion set equal to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and an uncollateralised portion equal to the CR Exposure amount minus that latest fair value [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb]. For risk-weighting, it then uses the CRW applicable to the Collateral for the collateralised portion (as though it had a direct Exposure to that Collateral) and uses the obligor’s CRW for the uncollateralised portion [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb]. But there is a floor: if the CRW produced by that collateral-based approach is below 20%, the Authorised Person must apply a 20% CRW to the collateralised portion [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438]. The only time it can go below that floor is in the listed exception cases, such as certain qualifying SFTs (with different outcomes depending on whether the Counterparty is a core market participant) and certain daily-marked OTC Derivative transactions or other no-currency-mismatch transactions with specified collateral types, where 0% or 10% may be applied if the stated conditions are met.
source_text:
Recognition of eligible financial Collateral under FCSA. Subject to A4.3.28, an Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA may recognise the effects of CRM of the eligible financial Collateral as follows:
(a) 	break down the Exposure into -
(i) 	a collateralised portion with E equal to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral; and
(ii) 	an uncollateralised portion with E equal to the E of the CR Exposure less the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral;
and
(b) 	for the purposes of calculating the Credit RWA amount pursuant to Rule 4.8.3, use:
(i) 	for the collateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the eligible financial Collateral as though the Authorised Person had a direct Exposure to that Collateral; and
(ii) 	for the uncollateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the obligor.

question: Where an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and is determining the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure under the specified measurement basis, how must the Authorised Person recognise the effect of that Collateral across the Non Trading Book and the Trading Book, including any consistency and non-combination requirements?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined under the specified measurement basis, the firm is permitted to recognise the effect of that Collateral (i.e., it may take the Collateral’s effect into account when measuring E) [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778]. However, when it does so, the method it must use depends on whether the SFT sits in the Non Trading Book or the Trading Book. For any SFT in the Non Trading Book, the Authorised Person must use either the FCSA or the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral, must apply the chosen approach consistently to the entire Non Trading Book, and must not combine the two approaches within that book [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412]. For any pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT in the Trading Book, the Authorised Person must only use the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412].
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.
target_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person must use either the FCSA or the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral for any SFT in the Non Trading Book. The Authorised Person must apply the chosen approach consistently to the entire Non Trading Book and must not use a combination of both approaches. For a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from any SFT in the Trading Book, an Authorised Person must only use the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral.

question: During a Restriction Period, how must a Listed Entity comply with its obligation to obtain and submit an undertaking to the Regulator regarding a holding lock on Restricted Securities, while ensuring that neither it nor any Security Holder or Controller subject to a Restriction Agreement seeks or agrees to any release of that holding lock?
gold_answer: The Listed Entity must secure an undertaking from an appropriate third party (a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD, or another entity the Regulator deems suitable) that it will place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities it holds and will not release that holding lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent, and the Listed Entity must obtain and submit that undertaking to the Regulator within two Business Days after the issue of the Restricted Securities [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76]. In parallel, during the Restriction Period, the Listed Entity (and any Security Holder or Controller subject to a Restriction Agreement) must not take steps that would undermine the lock by asking for or agreeing to the release of a holding lock imposed under the relevant framework, and must also refrain from amending an executed Restriction Agreement [#SRC:344f9898-63f7-4bec-afdc-2c9984f6502d]. Practically, this means the Listed Entity should treat any request, consent, or arrangement to lift the lock as prohibited conduct during the Restriction Period, and rely only on the undertaking’s “no release without prior written consent” condition as the control point for any potential release.
source_text:
Entry into Restriction Agreements and Application of Restriction. During a Restriction Period, a Listed Entity, Security Holder or Controller subject to a Restriction Agreement must not:
(1)	amend an executed Restriction Agreement; or
(2)	ask for or agree to the release of a holding lock that has been imposed in accordance with Rule 9.6.9.
target_text: Timing and Enforcement. A Listed Entity must obtain, and submit to the Regulator, within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD or other entity deemed suitable by the Regulator, to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities held by it, and not to release the holding lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent.

question: If an Authorised Person is a Branch, what must it keep in place so there is no significant risk it cannot pay liabilities when they are due, and how can it use the listed liquidity options (cash or marketable assets, matching cashflows, or borrowing) to meet that requirement?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that is a Branch must ensure it has and maintains, at all times, liquid assets and access to financial resources that are adequate for its business in both amount and quality, so that there is no significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due [#TGT:9fbb61f7-59fe-4340-85f8-ab6b9e7fb03c]. The general obligation on an Authorised Person is aligned to the same outcome—avoiding a significant risk of being unable to meet liabilities as they fall due—and it explains practical liquidity ways an Authorised Person may meet its obligations [#SRC:456ed7d2-778d-4597-862e-2c4582c20c87]. In practice for a Branch, this means the Branch should structure its liquid assets and broader financial resources using one or more of the described options: keeping sufficient immediately available cash or readily marketable assets, arranging an appropriate future cashflow profile that matches expected outflows, and, where appropriate, maintaining the ability to borrow further [#SRC:456ed7d2-778d-4597-862e-2c4582c20c87]. The key is that these measures must remain adequate at all times for the Branch’s business profile and must collectively support the stated “no significant risk” standard [#TGT:9fbb61f7-59fe-4340-85f8-ab6b9e7fb03c].
source_text:
In accordance with Rule 3.2.2 or Rule 3.2.4, an Authorised Person is required to ensure that there is no significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due. With specific reference to liquidity, an Authorised Person may meet its obligations in a number of ways, including:
a.	by holding sufficient immediately available cash or readily marketable assets;
b.	by securing an appropriate matching future profile of cashflows; and
c.	by further borrowing.

question: If a Listed Entity signs a deal to issue Equity Securities but says it will only go ahead if holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities approve it under Rule 9.7.1 before the issue happens, what must the Listed Entity do before issuing, and how does that approval affect whether the issue counts in the “Relevant Issues” part of the 20% formula test?
gold_answer: Before issuing under a conditional agreement of this kind, the Listed Entity must first obtain approval from the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1, because relying on that conditional structure means it is not permitted to issue the Equity Securities without that approval. [#SRC:6f5d3058-de98-48a8-a8dc-2e4967c6a437] In addition, the Listed Entity is generally prohibited from issuing or agreeing to issue Equity Securities above the maximum number produced by the formula “(20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues” unless it has holder approval. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] If the holders approve under Rule 9.7.1, that approved issue (or approved agreement to issue) is not counted in “Relevant Issues,” because Relevant Issues exclude Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued with approval under Rule 9.7.1 (or Rule 9.7.5). [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] So the same Rule 9.7.1 approval is both (i) the required green light to proceed with the conditional issuance and (ii) a factor that can reduce the Relevant Issues number used in the 12‑month formula calculation. [#SRC:6f5d3058-de98-48a8-a8dc-2e4967c6a437] [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]
source_text: An agreement to issue Equity Securities that is conditional on the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities approving the issue under Rule 9.7.1 before the issue is made.  If a Listed Entity relies on this exception, it must not issue the Equity Securities without such approval.
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity already made a full Rule 11.8.2 Production Target disclosure, what does it have to put in a later update so it can leave out the long list of Rule 11.8.2 details, and when does it still need to repeat a prominent warning about Inferred Mineral Resources or an Exploration Target?
gold_answer: A later update about a Production Target may avoid repeating the full set of Rule 11.8.2 disclosure items (for example, the required material economic assumptions or the required breakdown of what proportion of the Production Target comes from different resource/reserve categories) only when the update is clearly tied to an earlier Rule 11.8.2 disclosure that already included those items. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] To do this, the update must refer back to the earlier compliant disclosure and must also state that the material assumptions used in the original disclosure still apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] Even when the update is allowed to omit the broader Rule 11.8.2 content, it cannot omit certain cautionary statements in two situations: (1) if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the update must include an at least equally prominent and proximate warning statement of the kind required for that scenario; and (2) if the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, the update must include an at least equally prominent and proximate warning statement of the kind required for that scenario. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] These are exceptions to the general “no need to repeat” approach and link back to the baseline Rule 11.8.2 requirement to include those warnings in the first place. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity can disclose forecast financial information from a Production Target for its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or for material Mining Project(s), what does it have to include about the key assumptions and the Production Target itself, especially if some assumptions are commercially sensitive?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is permitted to disclose forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, but only in relation to either its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s) [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d]. If it chooses to make that disclosure, it must include specific information about how the forecast was determined: it must set out all material economic assumptions used, and it must also include all other material assumptions utilised [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. Where the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, it still has to address them by stating that they are commercially sensitive and explaining the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. The disclosure must also include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, together with the full set of information required to accompany that Production Target [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489].
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
