A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text:
Forecast financial information derived from a Production Target may be disclosed in relation to either a Mining Reporting Entity’s:
(1)	Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings; or
(2)	material Mining Project(s).

question: If a Relevant Person is reviewing risks for NFTF business and especially the use of eKYC Systems, what kinds of risks and weak spots must it look at, and how should it use mitigation measures identified by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, or other relevant bodies so the results affect daily work (like new products or new customers)?
gold_answer: In this scenario, the Relevant Person must run a risk assessment that is broad enough to cover money laundering risk (including related categories) and detailed enough to address NFTF business and the use of eKYC Systems, then make sure the findings drive practical mitigation in daily operations. [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851] The business risk assessment should include evaluating risks linked to carrying on NFTF business, with particular focus on eKYC Systems. [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2] When identifying and assessing risks, it must take steps that consider the nature, size and complexity of its activities, and it must treat money laundering risks as also covering terrorist financing, proliferation financing, the financing of unlawful organisations, and sanctions non-compliance (including Targeted Financial Sanctions). [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851] It must also look (as relevant) at vulnerabilities involving customers, countries/geographic areas, products/services/activity profiles, distribution channels and business partners, transaction complexity and volume, new products and practices, and the use of new or developing technologies—connecting that technology review to eKYC Systems used in NFTF business. [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851] The assessment should consider incorporating mitigation measures identified by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and other relevant bodies, and the Relevant Person must ensure identified risks are taken into account and mitigated in day-to-day operations, including when developing new products, taking on new customers, and responding to changes in its business profile. [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2] [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]
source_text: A business risk assessment under Rule ‎6.1.1(b) should include an assessment of the risks associated with the carrying on of NFTF business, particularly the use of eKYC Systems. The assessment should consider incorporating any relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and any other relevant bodies.

question: What checks must a PFP Operator do on a PFP Prospect before it posts a financing proposal on a Private Financing Platform, and how long must it keep records showing those checks and related disclosures and communications?
gold_answer: Before the PFP Operator publishes a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, it must perform due diligence on the PFP Prospect to meet its disclosure requirements. This due diligence must include reviewing information the PFP Prospect provides about: (1) management details and background, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers; (2) the PFP Prospect’s background, including financial soundness, good standing and (if relevant) regulatory status; and (3) the financing proposal, to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, the proposal is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce]. The PFP Operator must also keep evidence of what it did: for a minimum of six years it must maintain and keep a record of the due diligence it undertook, all disclosures made under the applicable disclosure rules, and all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7].
source_text:
A PFP Operator must, for a minimum of six years, maintain and keep a record of:
(a)	all disclosures made in accordance with Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2;
(b)	all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect; and
(c)	the due diligence undertaken in accordance with Rule 18.4.1.
target_text:
Prior to publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence upon the PFP Prospect, in order to satisfy the disclosure requirements imposed on it by Rule 18.5.1. Such due diligence must include, but not be limited to, a review of the following information to be provided by the PFP Prospect:
(a)	details and background of management, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers;
(b)	background of the PFP Prospect, including its financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status, if relevant; and
(c)	the financing proposal, in order to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, its content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading.

question: When determining the Credit RWA of an Authorised Person as a sum of component RWAs, how should the Authorised Person delineate what is included in the RWA calculation for Credit Risk Exposures (CR Exposures) versus what is carved out because it is treated as securitisation or Trading Book exposure, including any Traditional Securitisation risk-transference recognition condition?
gold_answer: In calculating Credit RWA, an Authorised Person must aggregate three distinct RWA components: (i) RWA for all Credit Risk Exposures (CR Exposures), (ii) RWA for all securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures), and (iii) RWA for Counterparty Risk Exposures, each computed under the specified rule sets for those components. [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020] For the CR Exposure component specifically, the Authorised Person must include both on-balance sheet assets and off-balance sheet items in the CR Exposure RWA calculation. [#TGT:cb5e6ab2-3cae-450b-87c6-acb11128d3f0] However, to keep the CR Exposure component distinct from the other Credit RWA components, the Authorised Person must exclude from CR Exposure RWA: (a) any SE Exposure (which instead belongs in the securitisation RWA component of Credit RWA), (b) any securitised Exposure that qualifies for recognition of risk transference in a Traditional Securitisation under Section 4.14, and (c) any Exposure classified as a position or instrument in the Trading Book under Section A2.1. [#TGT:cb5e6ab2-3cae-450b-87c6-acb11128d3f0] This delineation ensures the CR Exposure RWA is calculated on the intended population while the excluded items are addressed through the separate securitisation and other relevant RWA calculations that together form Credit RWA. [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020]
source_text:
The Credit RWA of an Authorised Person is the sum of:
(a)	its risk weighted assets (RWA) for all its Credit Risk Exposures (referred to in these Rules as "CR Exposures") calculated in accordance with Rules 4.8.2 and 4.8.3;
(b)	its RWA for all its securitisation Exposures (referred to in these Rules as "SE Exposures") calculated in accordance with Rule 4.8.4 and Section 4.14; and
(c)	its RWA for its Counterparty Risk Exposures as calculated in accordance with Sections A4.6 to A4.8.
target_text:
Calculation of RWA for Credit Risk Exposures (CR Exposures). An Authorised Person must include in its calculation of RWA for CR Exposures:
(a)	any on balance sheet asset; and
(b)	any off balance sheet item; but excluding:
(c)	any SE Exposure;
(d)	any securitised Exposure that meets the requirements for the recognition of risk transference in a Traditional Securitisation set out in Section 4.14; and
(e)	any Exposure classified as a position or instrument in the Trading Book in accordance with Section A2.1.

question: For a Mining Production Reporting Entity preparing its quarterly report, how should it satisfy the requirement to provide the Summary of Reserves and Resources at least once every 12 months, and what date constraint applies to the MKT Form 11-1 table included in that Summary when it is disclosed (including when the Summary is instead included in the annual report)?
gold_answer: A Mining Production Reporting Entity must ensure that, across its quarterly reporting cycle, it provides the Summary of Reserves and Resources at least once in every 12-month period, unless that Summary is instead provided in the Mining Reporting Entity’s annual report. [#SRC:a24b4f51-4c48-4846-bd22-d5f98dbad55b] When the Summary of Reserves and Resources is disclosed (whether via a quarterly report to meet the 12‑month cadence or via inclusion in the annual report), the Mining Reporting Entity’s Summary must contain a table in the format of MKT Form 11-1. [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd] The table must be prepared “as of” a date that is not earlier than one month before the disclosure date of the Summary of Reserves and Resources, meaning the table’s effective date must fall within the month leading up to the Summary’s disclosure. [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd] In addition, the quarterly report must state when the prior disclosure of this 12‑monthly Summary occurred and when the next such disclosure is expected to occur, so readers can track the timing of the required Summary disclosures. [#SRC:a24b4f51-4c48-4846-bd22-d5f98dbad55b]
target_text: A Mining Reporting Entity must include in its Summary of Reserves and Resources, a table in the form of MKT Form 11-1, as of a date no earlier than one month prior to the disclosure of the Summary of Reserves and Resources.

question: When assessing potential contravention of section 92(2) (Insider Dealing), how should a firm distinguish between (i) a person merely executing their own pre-formed intention to deal and (ii) dealing on the basis of “Inside Information” for Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, or Accepted Spot Commodities (including Related Instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives)?
gold_answer: A person’s execution of their own pre-formed intention to deal, by itself, is treated as not breaching section 92(2) (Insider Dealing); the compliance focus therefore shifts to whether the dealing is instead connected to “Inside Information” as defined for the relevant instruments. [#SRC:78dea780-e39f-407d-855f-5cb46c1b30d7] For Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities, and Related Instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives, “Inside Information” is limited to information that is precise, not generally available, and that relates (directly or indirectly) to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers or to the instruments themselves, and that would likely move the price significantly if it became generally available. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] In practical terms, the firm should (1) confirm the person formed an intention to deal before dealing and recognize that carrying out that intention alone is not the contravention trigger, [#SRC:78dea780-e39f-407d-855f-5cb46c1b30d7] and (2) separately test whether any information influencing the trade meets all elements of the “Inside Information” definition (precise, non-public, relevant to Reporting Entities/Issuers or the instruments, and price-significant). [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] This linkage matters because the “own intention” concept addresses the act of dealing, while the “Inside Information” definition supplies the characteristics of information that could make dealing problematic under an insider dealing analysis. [#SRC:78dea780-e39f-407d-855f-5cb46c1b30d7] [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977]
source_text: Carrying out of own trading intention. A person will form an intention to deal in a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity before doing so. His carrying out of his own intention will not of itself contravene section 92(2) (Insider Dealing).
target_text:
In relation to Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments which are not Commodity Derivatives, Inside Information is information of a Precise nature which—
(a)	is not generally available;
(b)	relates, directly or indirectly, to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers of the Financial Instruments or to one or more of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; and
(c)	would, if generally available, be likely to have a significant effect on the price of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments.

question: When conducting an investigation, may the Investigator both enter a person’s business premises to inspect and copy documents and also compel that access through a written notice to the Person Under Investigation or any other person, and what limits apply to the timing and relevance of the documents?
gold_answer: Across the two provisions, the Investigator is permitted to enter business premises to inspect and copy documents, but the exercise of that access is framed in two complementary ways: a general investigative permission tied to document relevance, and a notice-based mechanism that can compel a person to allow entry. Under the source, the Investigator may enter business premises for the purpose of inspecting and copying any documents where those documents are relevant for the purposes of the investigation [#SRC:6f288073-515c-4e53-9fa5-16c3700d2767]. Under the target, the Investigator may, by written notice, require the Person Under Investigation or any other person (whether or not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to permit the Investigator to enter that person’s business premises during normal business hours for the purpose of inspecting and copying documents on the premises [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. Read together, the entry/inspection/copying purpose is consistent in both texts, while the target adds procedural and temporal constraints (written notice; normal business hours) and broadens who can be required to grant access, and the source emphasizes that the documents inspected/copied must be relevant to the investigation.
source_text: Power to enter premises and inspect and copy documents . Section 206(1)(e) of FSMR permits the Investigator to enter business premises for the purpose of inspecting and copying any documents where relevant for the purposes of the investigation.

question: Can the Investigator make someone give information during an investigation, and does this apply only to the Person Under Investigation or also to other people? What does “information” cover?
gold_answer: Yes. The Investigator may use a written notice to require the person who is the Person Under Investigation, or any other person (even if not connected to the Person Under Investigation), to provide such information as the Investigator may require [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. This matches the Investigator’s power to require a person to give, or procure the giving of, information [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. The term “information” is meant to be read broadly in its ordinary sense, so it is not limited to formal records. It can include knowledge communicated or received about a matter, fact, or circumstance, and knowledge gained through work, commerce, study, communication, research, or instruction [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. It can also include computer-related data at any stage of processing, including input, output, storage, or transmission data. In addition, “information” can be an explanation or statement about a matter, the identification of a person/matter/thing, or simply a response to a question—consistent with the Investigator’s ability to require a person to answer questions (for example, at an interview) [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32].

question: If someone is making an Offer of a Unit, do the rules in this Chapter apply to them, and if the Offer is for Units of Funds, where do they find the Prospectus requirements instead of chapter 4 of the Rulebook?
gold_answer: A person making an Offer of a Unit is not subject to the provisions in this Chapter or the Rules made for the purposes of this Chapter in relation to that activity. [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a] Separately, when the Prospectus relates to Units of Funds, the Rulebook’s chapter 4 Prospectus requirements—covering content and structure—do not apply to those Prospectuses. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] Putting these together for an Offer that involves Units of Funds, you should not look to chapter 4 of the Rulebook for the Prospectus content/structure requirements, because that chapter is expressly stated not to apply to Fund Prospectuses. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] Instead, the Prospectus requirements that apply to an Offer of Units of Funds are found in the Fund Rules, which are identified as the applicable source for such Offers. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] This approach is consistent with the statement that Section 57(1) of FSMR disapplies chapter 4 of the Rulebook to Fund Prospectuses, reinforcing that chapter 4 is not the governing Prospectus framework for Units of Funds even though the Chapter itself is also stated not to apply to a person in relation to making an Offer of a Unit. [#SRC:254251bf-b846-4357-af1b-961bfa5fff94] [#TGT:07edf917-eba6-4ad8-8173-a8d5bc0ec58a]
source_text: The Prospectus requirements including content and structure in chapter 4 of this Rulebook do not apply to Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds. Prospectus requirements that apply to an Offer of Units of Funds are found in the Fund Rules. Section 57(1) of FSMR disapplies chapter 4 of this Rulebook to Fund Prospectuses.
target_text: The provisions in this Chapter and the Rules made for the purposes of this Chapter shall not apply to a person in relation to making an Offer of a Unit.

question: If the Listing Authority’s enquiry leads it to think the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not exempt, and it believes the information should have been disclosed earlier, what does an ‘aware letter’ usually ask the Reporting Entity to confirm, and when is the Listing Authority allowed to send that letter (instead of only asking for a disclosure)?
gold_answer: If, following an enquiry into complaints or allegations of non-compliance, the Listing Authority forms the view that the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not within an exemption from disclosure, it will ask the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter; and if the information should have been Disclosed earlier, the Listing Authority may issue an ‘aware letter’ (or take other relevant action) [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944]. An ‘aware letter’ generally uses a standard template and typically identifies the information in question and the date it was Disclosed, then asks the Reporting Entity whether it believes the information is Inside Information. If the Reporting Entity says “yes,” it is asked to confirm when it first became aware of the Inside Information (including the time and circumstances) and, if it was aware before the letter date, why it did not Disclose earlier or request a Trading Halt or Suspension, including specific comment on how the disclosure obligation applied. If it says “no,” it must confirm the basis for not treating the information as Inside Information. The letter also asks the Reporting Entity to confirm it is in compliance with the Markets Rules, particularly the disclosure obligation [#TGT:f221a729-4fb2-4eca-bb45-6c892c667a28].
source_text:
SUPERVISION BY LISTING AUTHORITY
Complaints or allegations of non-compliance by Reporting Entities
If, as a result of the enquiry, the Listing Authority forms the view that the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and is not within exemption from Disclosure provided by Rule 7.2.2, the Listing Authority will ask the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter under Rule 7.2.1.  If the information should have been Disclosed earlier, the Listing Authority may issue an ‘aware letter’ (see paragraphs 187 to 189 above), or take other relevant action.
target_text:
SUPERVISION BY LISTING AUTHORITY
Aware Letters
Similar to a MAQ Letter, ‘aware letters’ tend to follow a standard template.  Generally, they will identify the information in question and the relevant date it was Disclosed, and ask the following questions:

(i)	Does the Reporting Entity believe the information identified in the letter to be Inside Information (being information that a reasonable person would expect to have a significant effect on the price of the Listed Entity’s Securities)?

(ii)	If the answer to question i) is “yes”, please confirm the following:

i.	When did the Reporting Entity first become aware of the Inside Information identified in the letter? Please include details of the relevant time and circumstances of the Reporting Entity becoming aware of the [key contents of the Inside Information]?

ii.	If the Reporting Entity was aware of the [key contents of the Inside Information] prior to the date of this letter, please advise why the Reporting Entity did not Disclose the Inside Information or request a Trading Halt or Suspension at an earlier time?  Please comment specifically on the application of Rule 7.2.1.

(iii)	If the answer to question i) is “no”, please confirm the basis on which the Reporting Entity does not consider the information to be Inside Information?

(iv)	Please confirm that the Reporting Entity is in compliance with the Markets Rules and, in particular, Rule 7.2.1.

question: If you must calculate the Exposure value for on-balance sheet derivatives as the IFRS balance sheet amount plus an add-on for potential future exposure, how do you then calculate RC for unmargined transactions, including what goes into V and C and how the netting set and collateral are handled?
gold_answer: For on-balance sheet Derivatives (including written credit protection), you must calculate the Exposure value as the sum of the on-balance sheet value under IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated under the specified App 4 rules, so your process needs to capture both the current IFRS amount and the separate add-on component [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007]. When those derivative transactions are unmargined and you need RC, you follow the stated RC procedure: compute RC as max{V – C; 0}. In that formula, V is the value of the derivative transactions in the netting set, and the netting set must be constituted in accordance with the referenced netting-set rule. C is the haircut value of the net collateral held, and it must be calculated in accordance with the referenced collateral haircut section [#TGT:7925206c-3c2f-45a8-940b-3cbf102d8e84]. Practically, this means you first identify the correct netting set for the derivatives, determine V for that set, determine the haircut-adjusted net collateral amount C, and then apply the max test so RC cannot be negative.
source_text:
In relation to on-balance sheet items:
a.	for SFTs, the Exposure value should be calculated in accordance with IFRS and the Netting requirements referred to in Rule 4.9.14;
b.	for Derivatives, including written credit protection, the Exposure value should be calculated as the sum of the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated in accordance with Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4; and
c.	for other on-balance sheet items, the Exposure value should be calculated based on their balance sheet values in accordance with Rule 4.9.3.
target_text:
Calculation of RC for unmargined transactions. RC for unmargined transactions is calculated in accordance with the following formula:
RC = max{V – C; 0}
where:
V = the value of the derivative transactions in the netting set (constituted in accordance with Rule A4.6.18); and
C = the haircut value of the net collateral held, calculated in accordance with Section A4.3.

question: When an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA, how must it reflect that collateral in the RWA(CR) calculation—specifically, how are E and CRW determined for the collateralised and uncollateralised portions under the general RWA(CR) = E x CRW approach?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA may reflect the collateral as a CRM effect by splitting the CR Exposure into two parts and then applying the standard RWA(CR) computation to each part. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] Under the general approach, the firm calculates RWA for CR Exposures by determining an Exposure value (E), determining the applicable risk weight (CRW), and applying the formula RWA(CR) = E x CRW, then summing across exposures. [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368] For the collateralised portion, E must be set to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and CRW must be the risk weight applicable to that collateral as if the Authorised Person had a direct Exposure to it. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] For the uncollateralised portion, E must be the original E of the CR Exposure reduced by the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and CRW must be the risk weight applicable to the obligor. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] The resulting RWA(CR) amounts for the two portions are calculated using RWA(CR) = E x CRW and then included in the total RWA by adding the RWA amounts across all CR Exposures. [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368]
source_text:
Recognition of eligible financial Collateral under FCSA. Subject to A4.3.28, an Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA may recognise the effects of CRM of the eligible financial Collateral as follows:
(a) 	break down the Exposure into -
(i) 	a collateralised portion with E equal to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral; and
(ii) 	an uncollateralised portion with E equal to the E of the CR Exposure less the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral;
and
(b) 	for the purposes of calculating the Credit RWA amount pursuant to Rule 4.8.3, use:
(i) 	for the collateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the eligible financial Collateral as though the Authorised Person had a direct Exposure to that Collateral; and
(ii) 	for the uncollateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the obligor.

question: When the Regulator determines it must not transmit a notice because it considers the Fund Manager or the Public Fund is not compliant (or may become non-compliant) with applicable legislation, or because refraining is necessary and appropriate to meet its objectives, what immediate notification is the Regulator required to give the Fund Manager about that decision?
gold_answer: Where the Regulator reaches a decision not to transmit a notice, it has an immediate communication duty to the Fund Manager. Specifically, if the Regulator is in a situation where it is prohibited from transmitting a notice because it considers that the Fund Manager or the Public Fund does not comply with applicable legislation (including these Rules), or it has reasonable grounds to determine that the Fund Manager or the Public Fund may in the future not comply, the Regulator must refrain from transmitting the notice and must then promptly inform the Fund Manager of that decision [#TGT:02c6d009-e171-41d6-adac-aaaaf2b66e5a]. The same applies where the Regulator considers it necessary and appropriate to refrain from transmitting a notice in order to meet its objectives: the prohibition on transmitting triggers the requirement to immediately notify the Fund Manager that the Regulator has decided not to transmit the notice [#TGT:02c6d009-e171-41d6-adac-aaaaf2b66e5a]. In all such cases, the required notification is not discretionary; it is an immediate obligation tied to the Regulator’s decision not to transmit the notice [#SRC:de227401-76fb-48e7-90c5-1fe0553a4657].
source_text: The Regulator shall immediately notify the Fund Manager of its decision not to transmit a notice in accordance with Rule 3.2.5.
target_text:
The Regulator shall not transmit a notice under Rule 3.2.4‎(a):
(a)	if it considers that the Fund Manager or the Public Fund does not comply with, or it has reasonable grounds for determining that the Fund Manager or the Public Fund may in the future not comply with, applicable legislation, including these Rules; or
(b)	if it considers that it is necessary and appropriate to refrain from doing so in order to meet its objectives.

question: When considering an Application for Listing, to what extent is the Regulator permitted to attach, later change, or remove conditions or restrictions relating to the admission of Securities to the Official List, and how does that permission align with the Regulator’s power described in the FSMR?
gold_answer: Across both passages, the Regulator is expressly permitted to manage the admission of Securities to the Official List by imposing conditions or restrictions and then subsequently adjusting that regulatory treatment. The SOURCE states that, under the FSMR, the Regulator may impose conditions or restrictions in respect of the admission of Securities to the Official List and may also vary or withdraw those conditions or restrictions, establishing the baseline permission and its ongoing nature [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226]. The TARGET confirms the same permission in the specific context of the Regulator’s decision-making on an Application for Listing, listing as an available action the ability to impose conditions or restrictions (and to vary or withdraw them) in respect of admission to the Official List, and indicating that this is exercisable in the circumstances specified in a further subsection [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b]. Read together, the Regulator’s permission covers (i) initial imposition at admission, and (ii) later variation or withdrawal, with the TARGET situating that permission within the application/decision framework.
source_text: Under section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR, the Regulator may impose conditions or restrictions in respect of the admission of Securities to the Official List, or vary or withdraw such conditions or restrictions.
target_text:
The Regulator may—
(a)	refuse an Application for Listing; or
(b)	impose conditions or restrictions, in respect of the admission of Securities to the Official List, or vary or withdraw such conditions or restrictions;
in the circumstances specified in subsection ‎(2).

question: If an Authorised Person has foreign currency or gold risk under an Islamic Contract, can it skip calculating the Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement, and what limits does it have to stay under?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person is exposed to the risk of foreign currencies and gold under any Islamic Contract, it must calculate its Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement. But it can be allowed not to do that calculation if it meets two specific limits based on Capital Resources. First, its Foreign Currency business—worked out as the larger of (i) total gross long positions and (ii) total gross short positions across all Foreign Currencies—must not be more than 100% of its Capital Resources. Second, its overall net open position must not be more than 2% of its Capital Resources. So, even where the Authorised Person has the type of exposure that would normally trigger the calculation requirement, it may rely on the exemption only if it can show both that its Foreign Currency business stays within the 100% threshold and that its overall net open position stays within the 2% threshold. If either limit is exceeded, the exemption would not apply and the calculation obligation remains relevant. [#SRC:6a51fe1f-d0d3-42f6-b369-4e9345775696] [#TGT:79d3cd2f-93a5-4f25-af68-c67e7fd4cb97]
source_text: Market risk. An Authorised Person which is exposed to the risk of foreign currencies and gold under any Islamic Contract, must calculate its Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement in accordance with PRU Rule 5.6.2.
target_text:
An Authorised Person need not calculate a Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement if:
(a)	its Foreign Currency business, defined as the greater of the sum of its gross long positions and the sum of its gross short positions in all Foreign Currencies, does not exceed 100% of Capital Resources as defined in Chapter 3; and
(b)	its overall net open position as defined in Rule A6.4.4 does not exceed 2% of its Capital Resources as defined in Chapter 3.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity already made an earlier disclosure that met Rule 11.9.2, what does it need to do in a later announcement with forecast financial information from a Production Target so it can skip repeating the Rule 11.9.2 details, and what warning statement must it put next to the forecast financial information when the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources?
gold_answer: The later announcement can avoid repeating the Rule 11.9.2 information only if it clearly refers back to the earlier disclosure that was compliant with Rule 11.9.2 and includes a confirmation that the material assumptions used in that initial disclosure still apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] Even when that “no repetition” approach is used, the later announcement must still add specific cautionary language in certain cases, and it must be placed at least equally prominently and close to the forecast financial information. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] When the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the required warning is the prescribed statement explaining that the geological confidence for inferred mineral resources is low, that further evaluation and/or exploration is required to establish sufficient confidence, and that there is no certainty the work will lead to indicated mineral resources or that the production target will be realised. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] It must also state that the production target reflects current expectations of future results or events and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: For a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company and carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that must be attributed to a Long-Term Insurance Fund under Rule 8.2, how do the Captive Insurer’s options (establishing funds or notifying the Regulator that it is deemed a single fund) interact with the Regulator’s residual discretion to direct the establishment of one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds for that business or any part of it?
gold_answer: A Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company and carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that must be attributed to a Long-Term Insurance Fund under Rule 8.2 has a baseline compliance choice: it must either set up one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds or provide a written notice to the Regulator stating that the Captive Insurer is deemed to be a single Long-Term Insurance Fund. [#TGT:510a1a41-dd30-47bf-b331-893b2b70a469] However, that choice does not eliminate the Regulator’s ability to require fund establishment, because the Regulator retains residual discretion to direct that a Captive Insurer conducting Long-Term Insurance Business establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds for its Long-Term Insurance Business or for any part of that business. [#SRC:f6bf482b-33ba-4cf1-9375-26e6bfeb7ca7] In practice, this means the Captive Insurer can comply initially by notifying the Regulator that it is deemed a single fund, but the Regulator may still direct the Captive Insurer to establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds (including potentially for only part of the Long-Term Insurance Business). [#TGT:510a1a41-dd30-47bf-b331-893b2b70a469] [#SRC:f6bf482b-33ba-4cf1-9375-26e6bfeb7ca7] Accordingly, the Captive Insurer should treat the written-notice route as a permitted default position, while recognizing that the Regulator can override that position by directing the creation of one or more funds for the relevant business scope. [#TGT:510a1a41-dd30-47bf-b331-893b2b70a469] [#SRC:f6bf482b-33ba-4cf1-9375-26e6bfeb7ca7]
source_text:
Residual discretion of the Regulator
Notwithstanding Rule 8.1.1 and 8.1.2, the Regulator may, at its sole discretion, direct that a Captive Insurer which conducts Long-Term Insurance Business establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds in respect of its Long-Term Insurance Business or any part of such business.
target_text:
Captive Insurer not a Cell Company
Where a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that, under the provisions of Rule ‎8.2, must be attributed to a Long-Term Insurance Fund, it must either:
(a)	establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds; or
(b)	notify the Regulator in writing that the Captive Insurer is deemed to constitute a single Long-Term Insurance Fund.

question: If an Authorised Person does not meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, what must it do to work out the maximum distributable amount, and what two inputs must it multiply (profits and a quartile-based factor) before it can move forward with restricted distributions or payments?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must calculate the maximum distributable amount as a required step tied to restrictions on distributions and certain payments [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]. To determine that amount, the method requires multiplying a specified profit total by a factor. The profit total is the total of interim or year-end profits that were not included in CET1 Capital and that accrued after the most recent distribution of profits and after any relevant actions referenced in the calculation framework [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1]. The factor is then chosen based on where the Authorised Person’s CET1 Capital (that is not used to meet the Capital Requirement, including any Individual Capital Requirement) falls within the quartiles of the Combined Buffer Requirement: 0 in the first quartile, 0.2 in the second, 0.4 in the third, and 0.6 in the fourth [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1]. This multiplication-based determination is the required way to compute the maximum distributable amount in the circumstances described [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e].
target_text:
Restrictions on distributions. Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must:
(a)	calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3.19.6; and
(b)	ensure that it does not undertake any of the following actions until such time as it has calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator under Rule 3.19.7:
(i)	make a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital, or create an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, or pay variable remuneration if the obligation to pay was created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement; or
(ii)	make payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments.

question: When calculating the Exposure value for on-balance sheet Derivatives (including written credit protection), how should the firm incorporate the potential future Exposure add-on, and how does that interact with the SA-CCR requirement to calculate RC and PFE differently for margined versus unmargined netting sets, including the cap on EAD for margined netting sets?
gold_answer: For on-balance sheet Derivatives (including written credit protection), the Exposure value is determined by combining two elements: the on-balance sheet value measured under IFRS and an additional amount for potential future Exposure that is calculated under the specified App 4 rules. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] When the derivative exposures are being assessed under SA-CCR, the firm must ensure that the replacement cost (RC) and potential future exposure (PFE) components are computed using different methods depending on whether the relevant netting set is margined or unmargined, so the PFE concept used for the add-on must be aligned to the appropriate margined/unmargined treatment. [#TGT:949c0178-dbd8-44f8-b832-e4c2a327c941] In addition, where the firm determines an exposure at default (EAD) for a margined netting set, it must apply the cap that limits that margined EAD to no more than the EAD that would result if the same netting set were calculated on an unmargined basis. [#TGT:949c0178-dbd8-44f8-b832-e4c2a327c941] Practically, this means the IFRS on-balance sheet value remains part of the Exposure value, while the potential future Exposure add-on is calculated per the referenced rules and then reflected consistently with the SA-CCR margined/unmargined netting set framework and the EAD cap. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:949c0178-dbd8-44f8-b832-e4c2a327c941]
source_text:
In relation to on-balance sheet items:
a.	for SFTs, the Exposure value should be calculated in accordance with IFRS and the Netting requirements referred to in Rule 4.9.14;
b.	for Derivatives, including written credit protection, the Exposure value should be calculated as the sum of the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated in accordance with Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4; and
c.	for other on-balance sheet items, the Exposure value should be calculated based on their balance sheet values in accordance with Rule 4.9.3.
target_text: Derivatives and long settlement transactions – Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR). The replacement cost (RC) and the potential future exposure (PFE) components must be calculated differently for margined and unmargined netting sets. The EAD for a margined netting set is to be capped at the EAD of the same netting set calculated on an unmargined basis.

question: When a Listed Entity proposes to issue Equity Securities under an Employee Incentive Scheme and intends to rely on holder approval to avoid breaching the cap on new issues, what specific information must not be omitted from the notice of meeting, and how does that notice content support the required approval to issue above the calculated maximum?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity is prohibited from issuing, or agreeing to issue, more Equity Securities than the maximum number produced by the prescribed 20% Base Amount formula (net of Relevant Issues) unless it has the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]. Where the proposed issue is under an Employee Incentive Scheme and the Listed Entity is seeking that holder approval as the relevant exception within the prior three-year window, the notice of meeting must include three core disclosures: a summary of the terms of the scheme; the number of Securities issued under the scheme since the Listed Entity’s Securities were admitted to the Official List (or since the date of the last approval under the relevant approval pathway); and the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme following the approval [#SRC:a2108df9-4a76-4d9c-8a4a-7e058e5e8113]. These notice elements are the procedural minimum that enables holders of Ordinary Securities to give the approval that is necessary to permit an issue that would otherwise exceed the calculated maximum under the restriction on new issues.
source_text:
An issue of Securities under an Employee Incentive Scheme if within three years before the issue date:
(a)	in the case of a scheme established before the Listed Entity’s Securities were admitted to the Official List – a summary of the terms of the scheme and the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme were set out in in its Approved Prospectus or documents lodged with the Regulator under Rule 2.4.3; or
(b)	the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities have approved the issue of Equity Securities under the scheme as an exception to Rule 9.7.1.  The notice of meeting must have included:
(i)	a summary of the terms of the scheme;
(ii)	the number of Securities issued under the scheme since the Listed Entity’s Securities were admitted to the Official List, or the date of the last approval under this Rule; and
(iii)	the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme following the approval.
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: How should a PFP Operator evidence compliance when it conducts pre-publication due diligence on a PFP Prospect to ensure the financing proposal is not misleading, and what minimum retention period applies to those due diligence records and associated disclosure and transaction documentation?
gold_answer: To evidence compliance, the PFP Operator should be able to demonstrate that, prior to publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, it performed due diligence on the PFP Prospect aimed at satisfying its disclosure requirements. That due diligence must include reviewing information provided by the PFP Prospect about management (including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers), the PFP Prospect’s background (including financial soundness, good standing and any relevant regulatory status), and the financing proposal itself so that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, the proposal’s content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce]. The PFP Operator must then maintain and keep, for a minimum of six years, a record of the due diligence undertaken, together with records of all disclosures made under the applicable disclosure rules and all documentation exchanged between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7].
source_text:
A PFP Operator must, for a minimum of six years, maintain and keep a record of:
(a)	all disclosures made in accordance with Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2;
(b)	all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect; and
(c)	the due diligence undertaken in accordance with Rule 18.4.1.
target_text:
Prior to publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence upon the PFP Prospect, in order to satisfy the disclosure requirements imposed on it by Rule 18.5.1. Such due diligence must include, but not be limited to, a review of the following information to be provided by the PFP Prospect:
(a)	details and background of management, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers;
(b)	background of the PFP Prospect, including its financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status, if relevant; and
(c)	the financing proposal, in order to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, its content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading.

question: How should a Relevant Person evidence that its regular risk assessments of AML/TFS systems and controls remain comprehensive and proportionate where the business relationship is entirely NFTF and relies on eKYC, including what external mitigation measures the assessment should draw on?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person can evidence this by ensuring its regular risk assessments explicitly cover the distinct risk profile of conducting business entirely in an NFTF manner and using eKYC, and by linking the resulting mitigation actions to the ongoing adequacy of its AML/TFS systems and controls. [#SRC:c24c6dfe-b5fa-4802-81ab-5894795d4362] [#TGT:f0c3d08f-8696-42f8-b449-86c97c8f6d4d] The assessment should recognize that different risks are likely to arise where business is conducted entirely NFTF compared with a mix of face-to-face and NFTF interactions, and it should identify actions to mitigate risks associated with NFTF business generally and eKYC specifically. [#SRC:c24c6dfe-b5fa-4802-81ab-5894795d4362] At the same time, the Relevant Person must ensure that regular risk assessments are carried out on the adequacy of its AML/TFS systems and controls so they continue to enable it to identify, assess, monitor and manage money laundering risk adequately, and so that those systems and controls remain comprehensive and proportionate to the nature, scale and complexity of its activities. [#TGT:f0c3d08f-8696-42c8-b449-86c97c8f6d4d] To support the mitigation component of the NFTF/eKYC assessment, it should make reference to risk mitigation measures recommended by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and other relevant bodies. [#SRC:c24c6dfe-b5fa-4802-81ab-5894795d4362]
source_text: The risk assessment under Rule ‎6.2.1(c) should identify actions to mitigate risks associated with undertaking NFTF business generally, and the use of eKYC specifically. This is because distinct risks are often likely to arise where business is conducted entirely in an NFTF manner, compared to when the business relationship includes a mix of face-to-face and NFTF interactions. The assessment should make reference to risk mitigation measures recommended by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and other relevant bodies.

question: If an Issuer is offering Securities to the public in or from ADGM and has already put out a Prospectus, what should happen if something important changes or a big error is found after the Prospectus is issued, and how does this connect to the original need to publish a Prospectus?
gold_answer: For an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, the Issuer is expected to publish a Prospectus as part of the applicable requirements for such offers. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] After that Prospectus has been issued, the rules then require an additional step if certain events occur: if at any time there is a significant change, or a material mistake or inaccuracy affecting something in the Prospectus, or a significant new matter arises, the Issuer (or the person responsible for issuing the Prospectus) must produce a supplementary prospectus. [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] That supplementary prospectus has two core content/compliance elements: it must describe the relevant change, mistake, inaccuracy, or new matter, and it must comply with the requirements in section 62(1). [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] The link between the two texts is that the supplementary prospectus obligation only makes sense once the Issuer has already met the initial prospectus publication requirement for the public offer in or from ADGM. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] The trigger is explicitly tied to the period after the Prospectus is issued, and it applies whenever the specified kinds of developments occur. [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c]
source_text: Regulatory treatment of tokens deemed to be Securities. The requirements for Offers of Securities fall under Sections 58 to 71 of FSMR and Chapter 4 of the Markets Rules (“MKT”). When an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, these requirements include, for example, the obligation to publish a Prospectus under Section 61 of FSMR.
target_text:
Prospectus requirement. Obligation to issue a supplementary prospectus
If at any time after the issue of a Prospectus there is a significant change in, or a material mistake or inaccuracy affecting any matter contained in the Prospectus or a significant new matter arises, the Issuer or the person responsible for the issue of the Prospectus shall issue a supplementary prospectus which—
(a)	provides details of the change, mistake, inaccuracy or new matter; and
(b)	complies with the requirements in section ‎62‎(1).

question: If a trader quickly takes more than 90% of the physical crude oil inventory behind a contract and then sells out during the final settlement window at rising prices, when does that become the kind of Behaviour defined as trading without legitimate reasons and not following Accepted Market Practices—especially if it makes supply/demand look different or pushes prices to an abnormal level?
gold_answer: In the example, the Regulator describes an abusive squeeze where, during a trading day on a Commodity Derivative Exchange, a trader rapidly builds up more than 90% of the physical inventory underlying a crude oil contract, fails to offer to lend the crude oil back to other market participants at a reasonable commercial rate, and then unwinds the position in the Exchange’s final settlement window at rapidly increasing prices, thereby cornering/squeezing the market and causing an abnormal movement in the price of crude oil contracts for forward month delivery [#SRC:350b6237-da6f-47c6-b04c-10caf56bf9d7]. The definition to apply asks whether the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade other than for legitimate reasons and not in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market, and whether those trades/orders either (a) give or are likely to give a false or misleading impression about supply, demand, or price, or (b) secure the price at an abnormal or artificial level [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f]. Practically, you would connect the inventory dominance, refusal to lend, and settlement-window unwind to the definition’s focus on misleading impressions and abnormal/artificial pricing outcomes.
source_text:
Abusive squeezes. The following are specific examples of an abusive squeeze that, in the Regulator's view, may contravene section 92 (4)(b):
(a)	during the course of a trading day on a Commodity Derivative Exchange, a trader rapidly builds up a position of more than 90% of the physical inventory underlying a crude oil contract.  The trader fails to Offer to lend the crude oil back to other market participants at a reasonable commercial rate.  The trader then unwinds his position in the Exchange's final settlement window  at rapidly increasing prices, thereby cornering/squeezing the crude oil market.  His conduct causes an abnormal movement in the price of crude oil contracts for forward month delivery; and
(b)	a trader with a long position in bond futures, buys or borrows a large amount of the bonds and either refuses to re-lend these bonds or will only lend them to parties he believes will not re-lend to the market.  His purpose is to position the price at which persons with short positions have to deliver to satisfy their obligations at a materially higher level, making him a profit on his position.
target_text:
The third is where the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade (otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market) which—
(a)	give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to the supply of, or demand for, or as to the price of, one or more Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; or
(b)	secure the price of one or more such instruments at an abnormal or artificial level.

question: When the Investigator issues a written notice requiring a Person Under Investigation or another person to produce specified documents at a specified time and place, can the Investigator also require that person to procure the production of those documents (including originals or copies), and may the Investigator retain any original documents for as long as necessary for the purpose for which they were requested?
gold_answer: Yes. The Investigator’s written-notice power to require the Person Under Investigation or any other person (whether or not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to produce specified documents or documents of a specified description at a specified time and place supports compelling document production through that notice mechanism [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. In addition, the Investigator is empowered to require a person not only to produce documents but also to procure the production of specified documents or documents of a specified description, which addresses situations where the recipient must arrange for documents to be produced by another holder or source [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3]. The same empowerment extends to requiring production of original documents or copies, allowing the Investigator to specify the form of production depending on investigative needs [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3]. Where originals are produced, the Investigator may retain possession of any original document for as long as is necessary for the purpose for which it was requested, aligning retention with the investigative purpose rather than a fixed period [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3].
source_text: Power to require documents or information . Section 206(1)(b) of FSMR empowers the Investigator to require a person to produce, or procure the production of, specified documents or documents of a specified description. It empowers the Investigator to require production of original documents or copies. The Investigator may retain possession of any original document for as long as is necessary for the purpose for which it was requested.

question: Where an executed Third Party Transaction was not authorised in accordance with Rule 20.7 and it leads to an unauthorised Payment Transaction, what refunds must the Third Party Provider make (including how amounts are netted between the Primary Financial Institution and the Customer), and by when must the refund be provided once the Third Party Provider has confirmed the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed?
gold_answer: In the scenario where an executed Third Party Transaction was not authorised in accordance with Rule 20.7 and it results in an unauthorised Payment Transaction, the Third Party Provider has a dual refund obligation that allocates amounts between the Primary Financial Institution and the Customer, and it must also meet a specific timing standard once it has confirmed the issue. [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe] Specifically, the Third Party Provider must (a) reimburse the Primary Financial Institution for the amount the Primary Financial Institution may already have repaid to the Customer, and (b) reimburse the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction, reduced by any amount the Third Party Provider has already reimbursed to the Primary Financial Institution (so the Customer is not paid twice for the same loss). [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe] Once the Third Party Provider has confirmed that the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, it must provide the refund as soon as practicable and, at the latest, by the end of the day after the day of that confirmation. [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] This timing requirement applies to the refund obligation described, ensuring prompt remediation after confirmation. [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]
source_text: Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. The Third Party Provider must provide a refund under Rule 20.12.1 as soon as practicable, and in any event no later than the end of the day following the day on which it has confirmed that the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed.
target_text:
Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. Subject to Rules 20.10 and 20.11, where an executed Third Party Transaction was not authorised in accordance with Rule 20.7 and the Third Party Transaction leads to an unauthorised Payment Transaction, the Third Party Provider must:
(a)	refund the Primary Financial Institution for the amount that the Primary Financial Institution may have already refunded to the Customer; and
(b)	refund the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction, less any amount that the Third Party Provider has refunded to the Primary Financial Institution.

question: When an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business is preparing its Resolution Pack, what specific Third Party Agent acknowledgement record must be included if the firm passes, or permits to be passed, Safe Custody Assets to a Third Party Agent, and what minimum content must that acknowledgement cover?
gold_answer: If an Authorised Person passes, or permits to be passed, Safe Custody Assets to a Third Party Agent, it must obtain a written acknowledgement from that Third Party Agent, and the relevant acknowledgement record must be included in the Resolution Pack as part of the required records for Client Investments involving a Third Party Agent. [#TGT:57e8f079-f256-41f4-b1d3-fcbba0690a98] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] The acknowledgement must, at a minimum, address operational and safeguarding points, including: the account title must clearly distinguish the account from any account holding Investments belonging to the Authorised Person and be in the form the Authorised Person requests; Client Investment credits/withdrawals must follow the Authorised Person’s instructions; and Client Investments must be held separately from the Third Party Agent’s own assets. [#TGT:57e8f079-f256-41f4-b1d3-fcbba0690a98] It must also set out arrangements for recording/registering Client Investments and handling dividends/entitlements/interest and instructions, require delivery of statements to the Authorised Person (including frequency) detailing Client Investments deposited, and confirm that Investments in the account are held by the Authorised Person as agent with restrictions on combining accounts or asserting charges, liens, set-off, or counterclaims against those Investments for sums owed on other accounts. [#TGT:57e8f079-f256-41f4-b1d3-fcbba0690a98] Finally, the acknowledgement must state the extent of the Third Party Agent’s liability in the event of default, and that written acknowledgement record is part of the Resolution Pack’s Third Party Agent acknowledgement materials for Client Investments. [#TGT:57e8f079-f256-41f4-b1d3-fcbba0690a98] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity says its key economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, what does it have to put in its forecast financial disclosure, and what else must it tell investors so they can understand how it calculated and reported its Ore Reserves estimates?
gold_answer: For forecast financial information, a Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure must cover the assumptions used to determine that forecast, including all material economic assumptions employed; if the Mining Reporting Entity considers those material economic assumptions commercially sensitive, it must say so and explain the methodology it used to determine the material economic assumptions, and it must also include all other material assumptions utilised [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. When the same Mining Reporting Entity is reporting estimates of Ore Reserves and is relying on the relevant guidance, it must again make a statement that its material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, should explain why the information is considered a trade secret or commercially sensitive, and must still disclose enough information for investors to understand the methodology used to determine the relevant factors and assumptions and the basis on which it is reporting the Ore Reserves estimates [#TGT:6435d936-1f1e-44c9-a788-2a4f4de44b80]. Where the numbers themselves are sensitive, the Ore Reserves disclosure can be narrative rather than numerical, but it must remain sufficient for investor understanding.
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text:
ORE RESERVES. In such cases, however, where a Mining Reporting Entity relies on the guidance set out in Rule 11.6.1(1)(a), it:

a)	must make a statement to the effect that its material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive;

b)	should explain why the information is considered a trade secret or commercially sensitive; and

c)	must disclose sufficient information (possibly in narrative rather than numerical form, where the numbers are commercially sensitive) in order for investors to understand the methodology it has used to determine these factors and assumptions, and the basis on which it is reporting the estimates of Ore Reserves.

question: For investments made using Musharaka or Mudaraba contracts where commodities are the underlying assets, how must an Authorised Person calculate its Commodities Risk Capital Requirement, and how does that calculation method interact with the requirement for Category 1, 2 or 5 firms to calculate the requirement for Trading Book and Non Trading Book commodity positions using either an approved internal Market Risk model or the Section A6.5 rules?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that makes investments using Musharaka or Mudaraba contracts with commodities as the underlying assets must determine its Commodities Risk Capital Requirement by following PRU Rule 5.7.1. [#SRC:bbd0d60b-0179-4756-8de1-848cacc7db4e] Where that same Authorised Person is in Category 1, 2 or 5, it must also ensure that its Commodities Risk Capital Requirement is calculated for both Trading Book and Non Trading Book commodity positions using one of the two permitted approaches: either an internal Market Risk model that has been approved by the Regulator for this specific purpose, or the rules in Section A6.5. [#TGT:e93a335b-caf1-4776-842f-11bd1e28aefe] In practice, this means the firm must (i) identify that the relevant exposures arise from Musharaka or Mudaraba investments with commodity underlyings, triggering the PRU Rule 5.7.1 basis, and (ii) for Category 1, 2 or 5, apply that calculation across both Trading Book and Non Trading Book commodity positions through either the approved internal model route or the Section A6.5 route. [#SRC:bbd0d60b-0179-4756-8de1-848cacc7db4e] [#TGT:e93a335b-caf1-4776-842f-11bd1e28aefe]
source_text: Market risk. Where investments are made using Musharaka or Mudaraba contracts with commodities as the underlying assets, an Authorised Person must calculate its Commodities Risk Capital Requirement in accordance with PRU Rule 5.7.1.
target_text:
An Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5 must calculate its Commodities Risk Capital Requirement in respect of Trading Book and Non Trading Book commodity positions by:
(a)	applying its internal Market Risk model which has been approved by the Regulator for this purpose; or
(b)	applying the Rules set out in Section A6.5.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information derived from a Production Target for an operating mine, in what circumstances is it not required to comply with Rule 11.9.2, and what specific content must still be included in the disclosure under Rule 11.9.1 (including how to handle commercially sensitive material economic assumptions)?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is not required to comply with Rule 11.9.2 for forecast financial information derived from a Production Target relating to an operating mine(s) where that forecast financial information is wholly based on (i) Ore Reserves, (ii) a combination of Ore Reserves and Measured Mineral Resources, or (iii) a combination of Ore Reserves with Measured Mineral Resources and/or Indicated Mineral Resources, provided the Indicated Mineral Resources are not the determining factor in project viability. [#SRC:bf5c6652-b4c7-4b61-8732-68aed56e52a7] Even in that scenario, if the Mining Reporting Entity is making a disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1, the disclosure must include the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, covering all material economic assumptions employed and all other material assumptions utilised. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, it must state that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] The Rule 11.9.1 disclosure must also identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including all information required by Rule 11.8.3. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]
source_text:
A disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity is not required to comply with Rule 11.9.2 where the forecast financial information derived from a Production Target relating to an operating mine(s) is wholly based on:
(1)	Ore Reserves;
(2)	a combination of Ore Reserves and Measured Mineral Resources; or
(3)	a combination of Ore Reserves; and
(a)	Measured Mineral Resources; and/or
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources, provided that the Indicated Mineral Resources are not the determining factor in project viability.
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: If an Authorised Person is applying to change an existing Financial Services Permission so it can do more Regulated Activities, what fees must it pay to the Regulator, and how do you work out the fee when more than one Regulated Activity is included in the same application?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that applies to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission so it can undertake additional Regulated Activities must pay application fees to the Regulator under the applicable fee provisions [#SRC:f02f1e7a-a3ea-47cf-94df-8656a695fbd0]. When the amendment application covers one or more additional Regulated Activities (or otherwise involves multiple Regulated Activities being applied for at the same time), the fee is not calculated by simply adding only one base fee; instead, the Authorised Person must pay the highest of the relevant application fees for the Regulated Activities included in that application at that time [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2]. On top of that highest fee, each additional Regulated Activity included in the same application also attracts an extra application fee, which is the lesser of $10,000 or the specific application fee set out in the Rules for that activity [#TGT:4797c128-c19a-4af6-89ba-59fb6b9ac4d2]. In practice, you identify all Regulated Activities being requested in the amendment, pay the highest applicable fee among them, and then add the required incremental fee for each additional activity requested at the same time.
source_text:
Amendment of a Financial Services Permission other than the addition of a Regulated Activity
