(a)	Subject to Rule 2.1(c), an Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Service Permission to enable it to undertake additional Regulated Activities must pay to the Regulator such application fees as set out in Rule 3.2.1.
(b)	An Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission to enable it to serve Retail Clients, other than pursuant to Rule 3.20.1, must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $5,000.
(c)	An Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission to enable it to conduct Islamic Financial Business must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $5,000.
(d)	An Authorised Person applying to amend the scope of an existing Financial Services Permission through the amendment or removal of a condition, other than in accordance with (b) or (c), must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $5,000.
target_text:
In respect of:
(a)	an Applicant seeking to obtain a Financial Service Permission enabling the Applicant to undertake multiple Regulated Activities; or
(b)	an Authorised Person seeking to amend a Financial Service Permission to enable it to undertake one or more additional Regulated Activities.
the Applicant or Authorised Person, as the case may be, must pay the highest of the relevant application fees associated with the Regulated Activities being applied for at that time.  Each additional Regulated Activity applied for at that time shall incur an additional application fee of the lesser of $10,000 or the application fee specified in these Rules.

question: If the Regulator is thinking about using Resolution Tools or Resolution Powers to support or fully carry out a Recognised Foreign Resolution Action (and section 27 might require ex-ante judicial approval), what are the reasons it can still say no to recognising the Foreign Resolution Action, in full or in part?
gold_answer: Even if the Regulator’s plan would be to support or fully implement a Recognised Foreign Resolution Action by using one or more Resolution Tools or Resolution Powers (with any applicable ex-ante judicial approval requirement under section 27), it can still refuse to recognise the underlying Foreign Resolution Action, either entirely or only for certain elements. [#TGT:5798f720-7021-4b63-9ebe-f1a30aebee29] The refusal decision is available where the Regulator is satisfied that one or more listed grounds exist. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] These grounds include an adverse impact on financial stability in the ADGM. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] They also include situations where the Resolution Conditions are not met for the relevant entity listed in section 2 in relation to the Regulator’s proposed Resolution Action under section 78(5), or where taking Resolution Action under section 78(5) for an ADGM Branch is not needed to meet one or more Resolution Objectives. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] Another basis is unequal treatment: if creditors located or payable in the ADGM would not receive the same treatment and similar legal rights as creditors (including depositors) located or payable in the relevant non-ADGM jurisdiction, merely because they are in the ADGM. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] The Regulator may also refuse if recognition and supportive action would have material fiscal implications for the UAE or the ADGM. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba]
target_text: For the purposes of supporting, or giving full effect to, a Recognised Foreign Resolution Action, the Regulator may exercise one or more Resolution Tools, or one or more Resolution Powers, subject to any requirement for ex-ante judicial approval in compliance with section 27.

question: When an executed Third Party Transaction is later confirmed to have been unauthorised or incorrectly executed and it results in an unauthorised Payment Transaction, what refunds must the Third Party Provider make, to whom, and by what deadline, taking into account any prerequisite conditions and offsets between the Primary Financial Institution and the Customer?
gold_answer: Where the Third Party Provider has confirmed that a Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, it must provide a refund as soon as practicable and, in any event, no later than the end of the day following the day of that confirmation [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]. In the specific scenario where an executed Third Party Transaction was not authorised in accordance with the applicable authorisation requirement and the Third Party Transaction leads to an unauthorised Payment Transaction, the Third Party Provider’s refund obligations are twofold and are expressly subject to the stated conditions: it must refund the Primary Financial Institution for the amount the Primary Financial Institution may have already refunded to the Customer, and it must also refund the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction, reduced by any amount it has refunded to the Primary Financial Institution [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe]. Read together, the timing requirement governs how quickly the Third Party Provider must effect the required refunds, while the allocation and netting mechanics determine the correct payees and prevent double recovery when the Primary Financial Institution has already compensated the Customer.
source_text: Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. The Third Party Provider must provide a refund under Rule 20.12.1 as soon as practicable, and in any event no later than the end of the day following the day on which it has confirmed that the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed.
target_text:
Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. Subject to Rules 20.10 and 20.11, where an executed Third Party Transaction was not authorised in accordance with Rule 20.7 and the Third Party Transaction leads to an unauthorised Payment Transaction, the Third Party Provider must:
(a)	refund the Primary Financial Institution for the amount that the Primary Financial Institution may have already refunded to the Customer; and
(b)	refund the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction, less any amount that the Third Party Provider has refunded to the Primary Financial Institution.

question: When a Relevant Person conducts business in a non-face-to-face manner and uses eKYC, what actions must it take to ensure its risk assessment identifies and mitigates the distinct money laundering risks of that delivery channel, and how must those findings be reflected in its AML/TFS policies, procedures, systems and controls?
gold_answer: Where a Relevant Person undertakes non-face-to-face (NFTF) business, including the use of eKYC, its risk assessment should explicitly identify actions to mitigate the distinct risks that can arise when business is conducted entirely NFTF versus a mix of face-to-face and NFTF interactions, and it should refer to risk mitigation measures recommended by the Regulator, competent U.A.E. authorities, FATF, and other relevant bodies [#SRC:c24c6dfe-b5fa-4802-81ab-5894795d4362]. Those identified mitigation actions must then be operationalised through the Relevant Person’s obligation to establish and maintain effective policies, procedures, systems and controls to prevent opportunities for money laundering in relation to the Relevant Person and its activities [#TGT:f0c3d08f-8696-42f8-b449-86c97c8f6d4d]. In addition, the Relevant Person must ensure that regular risk assessments are carried out on the adequacy of its AML/TFS systems and controls so they continue to enable it to identify, assess, monitor and manage money laundering risk adequately, and remain comprehensive and proportionate to the nature, scale and complexity of its activities [#TGT:f0c3d08f-8696-42f8-b449-86c97c8f6d4d].
source_text: The risk assessment under Rule ‎6.2.1(c) should identify actions to mitigate risks associated with undertaking NFTF business generally, and the use of eKYC specifically. This is because distinct risks are often likely to arise where business is conducted entirely in an NFTF manner, compared to when the business relationship includes a mix of face-to-face and NFTF interactions. The assessment should make reference to risk mitigation measures recommended by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and other relevant bodies.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity shares forecast financial information based on a Production Target, and it’s being shared about either its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s), what details does it have to include about the assumptions and about the Production Target?
gold_answer: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information that comes from a Production Target, it can be presented in relation to either the entity’s Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s), but the disclosure still has to include specific items about assumptions and the Production Target. [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d] On assumptions, the disclosure must include all material economic assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, plus any other material assumptions used. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity thinks the material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it must say they are commercially sensitive and describe the methodology it used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] On the Production Target, the disclosure must identify the Production Target that the forecast financial information is based on, and it must include all the information that Rule 11.8.3 requires to be included with that Production Target. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] These content requirements apply whichever of the two contexts (holdings or material project(s)) the entity uses for the Production Target-based forecast disclosure. [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d]
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text:
Forecast financial information derived from a Production Target may be disclosed in relation to either a Mining Reporting Entity’s:
(1)	Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings; or
(2)	material Mining Project(s).

question: Where an Applicant/Authorised Person will undertake a Regulated Activity involving conventional assets in addition to Virtual Assets and therefore must seek FSRA approval for both asset types, how should the firm assess whether fees for the two categories could be charged cumulatively, and what discretion does the Regulator have to reduce, waive, or refund fees (including supplementary or late payment fees) in that context?
gold_answer: If an Applicant/Authorised Person plans to conduct a Regulated Activity involving conventional assets as well as Virtual Assets, it must obtain FSRA approval to carry on the Regulated Activity in relation to both asset types. [#SRC:743f4b18-44d3-4fe2-ac7a-077cdd333689] In assessing whether fees for the conventional and Virtual Asset-related activities will be cumulative, the firm should treat non-cumulative outcomes as dependent on the FSRA’s exercise of discretion to reduce or waive a fee, rather than as an automatic entitlement. [#SRC:743f4b18-44d3-4fe2-ac7a-077cdd333689] The Regulator’s discretion is broad: it may, at any time, reduce, waive, or refund all or part of any fee, and this expressly includes supplementary or late payment fees, where it considers that doing so would be fair and reasonable in the circumstances of the particular case. [#TGT:0caa9f08-40e5-42b7-9cef-4148ae1dc036] Practically, this means the firm should (i) identify the fee exposure associated with seeking approval for both asset types, and (ii) consider whether there is a case-specific basis to request relief on fairness and reasonableness grounds, recognizing that the decision rests with the Regulator. [#TGT:0caa9f08-40e5-42b7-9cef-4148ae1dc036] The FSRA also recommends raising fee questions with it as early as practicable to clarify expectations and timing around any potential discretionary relief. [#SRC:743f4b18-44d3-4fe2-ac7a-077cdd333689]
source_text:
FEES
Cumulative application of Fees
Noting the above paragraph, if an Applicant/Authorised Person will be undertaking a Regulated Activity involving conventional assets (e.g. securities or derivatives) in addition to Virtual Assets, as noted in paragraphs 20 to 21, it will need to seek approval from the FSRA to carry out its Regulated Activity in relation to both asset types (conventional and Virtual Asset).  The fees attributable to that Authorised Person for its Regulated Activities (conventional and Virtual Asset-related), may not be cumulative should the FSRA apply its discretion to reduce or waive a fee, under FEES 1.2.8 subject to the considerations set out in paragraph 187 below).  The FSRA recommends that Applicants discuss any questions relating to FEES with the FSRA as early as practicable.
target_text:
Relief from Payment
The Regulator may at any time reduce, waive or refund all or part of any fee including any supplementary or late payment fee if it considers that, in the circumstances of a particular case, it would be fair and reasonable to do so.

question: If an Authorised Person must use either the Simplified Approach or the Comprehensive Approach to recognise eligible financial Collateral, what counts as “eligible financial Collateral” when the Authorised Person uses the Comprehensive Approach, and how does that connect to the Simplified Approach’s focus on the composition of financial Collateral?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral by choosing and using either the Financial Collateral Simplified Approach (FCSA) or the Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach (FCCA) [#SRC:f161ce59-6314-4980-8eaf-752bb38a5a19]. If the Authorised Person uses the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral is defined to include: any instrument listed in the referenced list; any equity Security (including a convertible bond) traded on a regulated exchange; and certain Units in a Collective Investment Fund that invests in those traded equity Securities, but only where the Unit price is publicly quoted daily and at least 90% of the Fund’s deposited property is invested in instruments covered by the FCCA list and the referenced list [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85]. This matters for the required choice of approach because the FCSA is described as adopting the treatment under the referenced list specifically “in relation to the composition of financial Collateral,” while the FCCA is the alternative approach and its definition expands and conditions what collateral is eligible under that approach [#SRC:f161ce59-6314-4980-8eaf-752bb38a5a19] [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85].
source_text:
An Authorised Person must use either the:
(a)	Financial Collateral Simplified Approach (FCSA) which adopts the treatment under Rule 4.13.5 in relation to the composition of financial Collateral; or
(b)	Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach (FCCA) which adopts the treatment under Rule 4.13.6;
to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral.
target_text:
For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral comprises:
(a)	any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5;
(b)	any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and
(c)	any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund which invests in equity Securities referred to in (b), where:
(i)	a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily; and
(ii)	at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5.

question: When an Authorised Person calculates PSIACOMcredit contract by contract, what must it do if the CR Exposure is still current (not past due for more than 90 days), and how does that affect the step where it sets the contract’s risk weighting or capital charge before using the PSIACOMcredit formula?
gold_answer: For each Islamic Contract included in PSIACOMcredit, an Authorised Person must run through a contract-level process: identify the relevant Islamic Contracts, value the underlying investment or asset for each one, and reduce that value as required to arrive at the contract-specific value used in the PSIACOMcredit calculation [#SRC:ad52577a-53d9-469d-ba7a-ae9b4c0a7787]. If the contract results in a CR Exposure that is not past due for more than 90 days, the Authorised Person must categorise that exposure into one of the specified asset classes (for example, cash items, central government/central bank, bank, corporate, regulatory retail, residential mortgage, commercial real estate, or other Exposures) [#TGT:0699660d-a2de-4359-8468-2d993b6a712f]. This categorisation is the required classification step that the Authorised Person must have in place when it determines the risk weighting or capital charge (CRW) appropriate to the contract. Once the CRW is determined, the Authorised Person applies the relevant formula to calculate PSIACOMcredit for that contract and then sums the PSIACOMcredit across all contracts to determine the total PSIACOMcredit applicable to the Authorised Person [#SRC:ad52577a-53d9-469d-ba7a-ae9b4c0a7787].

question: In preparing the annual report/annual financial report, what must the Board of Directors/Directors state about the effectiveness of the entity’s Corporate Governance framework, and how must that statement be supported and framed in relation to adoption of the Corporate Governance Principles and any non-adoption or partial adoption of best practice standards?
gold_answer: Both regimes require the annual report package to contain an express Directors-level assessment of the Corporate Governance framework’s effectiveness, supported by appropriate context and evidence. Under the SOURCE obligation, the annual report must include a statement by the Board of Directors stating whether or not, in its opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Reporting Entity is effective in achieving the relevant governance outcome and promoting compliance with the Principles, and that statement must be accompanied by supporting information and assumptions, with qualifications if necessary [#SRC:2d67e3e8-d385-4fc8-aff1-487611d02cca]. Under the TARGET obligation, the annual financial report of a Listed Entity must state whether the Corporate Governance Principles have been adopted; if not fully or only partially adopted, it must explain why and describe what actions, if any, have been taken to achieve compliance to the extent of the gap; and it must also include a statement by Directors on whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance, again with supporting information and assumptions and qualifications if necessary [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e]. Practically, the Directors’ effectiveness statement should be consistent with, and informed by, the adoption/disclosure narrative and any described remediation actions.
source_text: General. The annual report required under Rule 9.2.10 must include a statement by the Board of Directors (the "Board"), stating whether or not, in its opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Reporting Entity is effective in achieving the outcome required by section 73 of the FSMR and promoting compliance with the Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary. As the Principles are the core of the Corporate Governance framework, the way in which they are applied should be the central question for the Board as it determines how the Reporting Entity conducts its affairs under its directorship in accordance with the letter and spirit of the applicable requirements including the Principles and the standards.
target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: If an Authorised Person uses the FCCA and takes eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is not under a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, what number should they use instead of E when working out the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount, and how do they calculate it (including what haircuts and values go into the formula)?
gold_answer: They must use E* instead of E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for the CR Exposure, because the transaction is an SFT with eligible financial Collateral, the FCCA is used, and there is no qualifying bilateral Netting agreement. [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de] E* is the exposure value after risk mitigation and must be calculated using the FCCA haircut method formula for collateralised transactions that are not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement (and, here, the transaction is not described as an OTC Derivative transaction or a long settlement transaction). [#TGT:bfe1d138-bbe5-4cfd-b804-a89cccbf6949] The calculation is: E* = max{0, [E(1+HE) − C(1−HC−HFX)]}. [#TGT:bfe1d138-bbe5-4cfd-b804-a89cccbf6949] In that formula, E is the fair value of the Exposure (calculated under the referenced section), C is the fair value of the eligible financial Collateral received, HE is the haircut for the Exposure, HC is the haircut for the Collateral (or a weighted sum if the Collateral is a basket of assets), and HFX is the haircut for any currency mismatch between the Collateral and the Exposure. [#TGT:bfe1d138-bbe5-4cfd-b804-a89cccbf6949] Once E* is computed, it is substituted for E in the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount calculation for that CR Exposure. [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de]
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT that is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and using the FCCA, must calculate E* in accordance with Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4, and substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for that CR Exposure under Section 4.8.

question: When calculating the Exposure value for on-balance sheet SFTs, how should an Authorised Person reflect the netting approach described for legally valid bilateral netting that substitutes a single payable/receivable amount, and what calculation framework must be used?
gold_answer: For on-balance sheet SFTs, the Exposure value must be calculated using the IFRS-based approach specified for SFTs, and it must incorporate the applicable netting requirements for those SFTs. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] Where the Authorised Person applies a legally valid form of bilateral netting that produces legal substitution—i.e., replacing prior gross obligations with one single payable/receivable amount—this netting concept is the type of netting that may be used to net transactions and should be reflected in how the SFT exposure is determined under the referenced netting requirements. [#TGT:af6814ee-9972-4eb9-996b-eb4446ec5113] In practical terms, the calculation is anchored in IFRS for the on-balance sheet measurement of the SFT exposure, while the netting treatment is constrained to bilateral netting arrangements that are legally valid and achieve legal substitution into a single net amount. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:af6814ee-9972-4eb9-996b-eb4446ec5113] This linkage matters because the SFT exposure rule requires both the IFRS calculation basis and compliance with the netting requirements, and the netting-set concept clarifies the kind of bilateral netting that can be used to arrive at a single net payable/receivable amount rather than gross obligations. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:af6814ee-9972-4eb9-996b-eb4446ec5113]
source_text:
In relation to on-balance sheet items:
a.	for SFTs, the Exposure value should be calculated in accordance with IFRS and the Netting requirements referred to in Rule 4.9.14;
b.	for Derivatives, including written credit protection, the Exposure value should be calculated as the sum of the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated in accordance with Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4; and
c.	for other on-balance sheet items, the Exposure value should be calculated based on their balance sheet values in accordance with Rule 4.9.3.
target_text: Netting Sets . An Authorised Person may net transactions subject to any legally valid form of bilateral netting which results in legal substitution of one single payable/receivable amount for previous gross obligations.

question: When the Regulator is satisfied that action is in the interest(s) of the ADGM/Abu Dhabi Global Market, what directions may it give to a Reporting Entity, and what additional power (beyond directing disclosure or other steps) may it exercise, including how it may frame those requirements?
gold_answer: If the Regulator is satisfied that it is in the interest of the ADGM/Abu Dhabi Global Market, it may issue a direction to a Reporting Entity requiring disclosure of specified information or requiring the Reporting Entity to take other steps the Regulator considers appropriate. [#SRC:b83c251c-65fd-4f1c-9225-20fa42145c35] [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94] The TARGET clarifies that the disclosure direction can be framed as disclosure “to the market,” and it also confirms that the Regulator’s direction power is not limited to disclosure/steps: it may additionally impose extra continuing obligations on the Reporting Entity. [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94] In exercising these powers, the Regulator may set the terms and conditions it determines for the direction or the additional continuing obligations. [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94] The SOURCE provides the statutory basis that the Regulator’s power is triggered by its satisfaction that acting is in the interest of the ADGM and that the direction can require disclosure of specified information or other steps the Regulator considers appropriate. [#SRC:b83c251c-65fd-4f1c-9225-20fa42145c35] Taken together, the passages indicate that, once the Regulator reaches the relevant “interest” satisfaction, it can (i) direct disclosure of specified information (including to the market) or other steps, and (ii) separately impose additional continuing obligations, each potentially subject to Regulator-determined terms and conditions. [#SRC:b83c251c-65fd-4f1c-9225-20fa42145c35] [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94]
source_text: Section 84 of the FSMR gives the Regulator the power to direct a Reporting Entity to Disclose specified information or take such other steps as the Regulator considers appropriate where it is satisfied that it is in the interest of the ADGM to do so.
target_text:
Miscellaneous . Regulator's powers of Direction
The Regulator may, if it is satisfied that it is in the interests of the Abu Dhabi Global Market to do so—
(a)	direct a Reporting Entity to disclose specified information to the market or take such other steps as the Regulator considers appropriate; or
(b)	impose on a Reporting Entity any additional continuing obligations;
on such terms and conditions as determined by the Regulator.

question: If a Home Regulator has already taken steps about a Passported Fund but the Fund Manager (or its Agent or another Licensed Person promoting it) is still causing serious harm in ADGM, what happens next—first with urgent discussions and then if those talks don’t fix the problem in a reasonable time?
gold_answer: When a Passported Fund situation in ADGM remains materially prejudicial even after measures (if any) taken by the Home Regulator, the Regulator can respond by asking for urgent discussions with the Home Regulator that has supervision and enforcement responsibility for the Passported Fund. [#TGT:722d2090-eec8-4ae1-8d98-db9a10f13e55] The prejudice that can trigger this includes harm to Unitholders of the Passported Fund who are situated in ADGM, or harm to ADGM’s financial stability or integrity. [#TGT:722d2090-eec8-4ae1-8d98-db9a10f13e55] If those urgent discussions (the ones referred to in Rule 9.5.2) do not settle the issues to the Regulator’s satisfaction within a period that is reasonable in the circumstances, the Regulator is not limited to continued dialogue and may take all appropriate measures needed to protect Unitholders domiciled in ADGM or to safeguard the financial stability and integrity of the ADGM market. [#SRC:6a79069b-b2b7-4349-9fa6-ae21f98b3a02] In practical terms, the sequence is: persistent material prejudice despite Home Regulator measures leads to urgent discussions, and an unresolved outcome within a reasonable time opens the door to protective measures by the Regulator. [#TGT:722d2090-eec8-4ae1-8d98-db9a10f13e55] [#SRC:6a79069b-b2b7-4349-9fa6-ae21f98b3a02]
source_text: If the urgent discussions referred to in Rule 9.5.2 fail to resolve the issues to the satisfaction of the Regulator within a period that is reasonable in the circumstances, then the Regulator may take all appropriate measures needed in order to protect the interests of Unitholders domiciled in ADGM or the financial stability and integrity of the ADGM market.
target_text:
If, despite the measures (if any) taken by a Home Regulator in relation to a Passported Fund, a Fund Manager's activities (or the activities of its Agent or any other Licensed Person that is Promoting the Passported Fund) in ADGM continue to be materially prejudicial to either:
(a)	the Unitholders of the Passported Fund who are situated in ADGM; or
(b)	the financial stability or the integrity of ADGM,
the Regulator may request urgent discussions with the Home Regulator who has the supervision and enforcement responsibilities in respect of the Passported Fund.

question: In a Takeover or Merger, when may the Regulator consent to the release of a holding lock so that holders of Restricted Securities can accept an offer or otherwise transfer or cancel Securities, and what preconditions must be satisfied before the Regulator will provide that consent (including any requirements about offer scope, acceptance levels by non-restricted holders, and written re-imposition arrangements if the transaction does not proceed or securities are not acquired)?
gold_answer: The Regulator may consent to a party that is managing a holding lock in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 releasing the holding lock to enable holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer, or to transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover [#TGT:12178c65-d1b6-440a-91e1-c670c7d9ab67]. However, the Regulator will not provide its consent unless, to the extent applicable, specified conditions are met [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd]. Where there is an offer for Securities, the offer must cover all of the Ordinary Securities or, if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities, all Securities in the same class as the Restricted Securities; holders of at least half of the Securities that are not Restricted Securities to which the offer relates must have accepted; and if the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder must agree in writing that the holding lock be immediately re-imposed for each Security not bought by the offeror. Where the offer is conducted by way of a scheme, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity in which the Restricted Securities are held must agree in writing that the holding lock be immediately re-imposed if the Takeover does not take effect.
source_text:
Regulator’s consent to sale of Restricted Securities in a Takeover or Merger. The Regulator will not provide its consent under Rule 9.6.11 unless, to the extent to which they are applicable, all the following requirements are met:
(1)	where there is an offer for Securities:
(a)	the offer is for all of the Ordinary Securities or, if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities, all the Securities in the same class as the Restricted Securities;
(b)	holders of at least half of the Securities that are not Restricted Securities, to which the offer relates, have accepted; and
(c)	if the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder agree in writing that the holding lock (imposed under Rule 9.6.9) be immediately re-imposed for each Security that is not bought by the offeror under the offer; and
(2)	where the offer is to be conducted by way of a ‘scheme’, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity in which the Restricted Securities are held agree in writing that the holding lock imposed under Rule 9.6.9 be immediately re-imposed if the Takeover does not take effect.
target_text: Regulator’s consent to sale of Restricted Securities in a Takeover or Merger. The Regulator may consent to a party that is managing a holding lock in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 releasing the holding lock, to enable holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer, or transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover.

question: How does an Authorised Person work out the weighted average Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate across countries, and how is that rate then used to calculate the Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by multiplying its Total Risk Exposure Amount by a weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to the jurisdictions where its private sector credit exposures are located [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]. To compute that weighted average rate, it must break the calculation into steps across all relevant jurisdictions. For each jurisdiction where it has private sector credit exposures, it takes the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to those private sector credit exposures in that jurisdiction and divides it by the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the Authorised Person’s private sector credit exposures across all jurisdictions. It then multiplies that share by the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate that applies in that jurisdiction. After doing this for every jurisdiction, it adds up (sums) all of those jurisdiction-level contributions to arrive at one weighted average rate [#TGT:e71f9d6c-0033-443d-9ce0-aa873bdd8124]. That final weighted average rate is the rate used as the multiplier in the CET1 buffer amount calculation.
source_text: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital equal to its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures are located, calculated in accordance with Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8.
target_text:
Weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates. The weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates shall be calculated by:
(a)	for each jurisdiction in which the Authorised Person has private sector credit exposures, dividing the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the private sector credit exposures in that jurisdiction by the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures across all jurisdictions and multiplying it by the applicable Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate in that jurisdiction; and
(b)	summing those contributions across all jurisdictions.

question: If a Petroleum Reporting Entity publishes Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves, what must it say about the named Competent Person(s), and what consent must it have before it discloses the relevant statement and supporting information?
gold_answer: When a Petroleum Reporting Entity makes a disclosure that includes Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves, it must include clear information about the Competent Person(s) and also ensure the disclosure is authorised in the required way. On content, the disclosure must state that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s). It must also state whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Petroleum Reporting Entity or a Related Party; if the Competent Person is not, it must give the name of the Competent Person’s employer. In addition, it must state the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member [#TGT:6f4cc15d-24f2-4ffc-a2ad-dff5dce98f79]. Separately, the statement referred to in the framework must only be disclosed if the Petroleum Reporting Entity has the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) regarding the form and context in which the estimated resources/reserves and the supporting information are presented in the disclosure [#SRC:9c4480c6-f416-4989-b1c9-ad5cf7c5d72e].
source_text:
Competent Persons . The statement referred to in Rule 12.15.2:
(1)	must only be disclosed with the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) as to the form and context in which the estimated Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Prospective Resources, as the case may be, and the supporting information is presented in the disclosure; and
(2)	only applies the first time a Petroleum Reporting Entity discloses original or updated estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves where:
(a)	any subsequent disclosure that refers to the estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves references the earlier disclosure containing the statements and consent referred to in Rules 12.15.2 and 12.15.3(1); and
(b)	the Petroleum Reporting Entity confirms in the subsequent disclosure that it is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects the information included in the earlier disclosure, and that all material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the estimates in the earlier disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed.
target_text:
Competent Persons . A disclosure by a Petroleum Reporting Entity containing Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves must state:
(1)	that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s);
(2)	whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Petroleum Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer; and
(3)	the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.

question: For a Listed Entity/Reporting Entity preparing its annual financial report, how should it address the separate obligation to comply with Rule 9.2.10 on annual reporting of Corporate Governance Principles compliance, and what specific disclosures must appear in that annual financial report to satisfy the annual reporting on compliance requirements?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity/Reporting Entity should treat its annual financial report as the vehicle that must contain the required annual compliance disclosures, while also recognizing that it has an additional, explicit obligation to comply with Rule 9.2.10 regarding annual reporting of its compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles. [#SRC:88ccc385-cfe8-4e4e-afd3-80026e74b4dd] In the annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which the annual reporting section applies, the report must first state whether the best practice standards in APP 4 (the Corporate Governance Principles) have been adopted. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] If adoption is not full (including partial adoption), the report must explain the reasons for not fully adopting the standards and describe any actions taken to achieve compliance to the extent standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] The annual financial report must also include a statement by Directors on whether, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, supported by information, assumptions, and any necessary qualifications. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] These annual financial report disclosures should be prepared in a way that enables the entity to meet the separate Rule 9.2.10 annual reporting compliance obligation. [#SRC:88ccc385-cfe8-4e4e-afd3-80026e74b4dd]
source_text: Note that Listed Entities/Reporting Entities are also required to comply with Rule 9.2.10 on annual reporting of their compliance with Corporate Governance Principles.
target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: If a person’s trades or orders could mislead the market about supply, demand, or price, or could push the price to an artificial level, must they avoid doing this unless they can show they acted for legitimate reasons and followed an Accepted Market Practice on that market?
gold_answer: The target text describes a prohibited type of Behaviour: effecting transactions or orders to trade in a way that is not for legitimate reasons and not in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market, where the result is (or is likely to be) a false or misleading impression about supply, demand, or price, or where it secures an abnormal or artificial price level [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f]. The source text provides the key condition that can justify the conduct: if a person establishes that they carried out the conduct or practice for legitimate reasons and in conformance with an Accepted Market Practice, then they meet the legitimacy-and-conformity standard referenced in the target [#SRC:277b5e91-5efc-4b1d-a2b2-790aa0039f73]. Put simply, the prohibition is triggered when the trading is done “otherwise than” for legitimate reasons and accepted practice and has the misleading/artificial effects described; the permission concept is that the person can rely on legitimate reasons plus conformity with an Accepted Market Practice, but only if they can establish those points.
source_text: Market Practice. If a person establishes that they carried out the conduct or practice for legitimate reasons and in conformance with an Accepted Market Practice (see section 92(4)).
target_text:
The third is where the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade (otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market) which—
(a)	give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to the supply of, or demand for, or as to the price of, one or more Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; or
(b)	secure the price of one or more such instruments at an abnormal or artificial level.

question: If an Authorised Person has a rated short term corporate CR Exposure that gets a 50% or 100% risk weight, what is the lowest risk weight they can use for an unrated short term CR Exposure to the same corporate, and does that match the table’s unrated corporate risk weight?
gold_answer: When the Authorised Person has a short term CR Exposure in the corporate asset class with an issue-specific external credit assessment that results in a 50% or 100% risk weight, they must apply a risk weight of not lower than 100% to any unrated short term CR Exposure to the same corporate [#SRC:f80ad0a8-f280-43e0-a71b-74b00c8175ad]. The corporate asset class table also sets the risk weight for “Unrated” corporate exposures at 100% (subject to the stated rule cross-references) [#TGT:ee286214-80b1-480f-8be1-055c442795e4]. So, in this situation, the minimum required by the rule for the unrated short term exposure and the table’s unrated corporate risk weight point to the same outcome: 100%. Practically, the Authorised Person should treat the unrated short term exposure to that corporate as 100% and ensure it is not assigned anything lower, even though the related rated short term issue may have received a lower risk weight (50%) or the same risk weight (100%). This approach satisfies both the specific minimum floor tied to the rated short term exposure and the general unrated corporate treatment in the table.
source_text:
Corporate asset class. The risk weight for any CR Exposure in the corporate asset class that does not have an external credit assessment by a recognised external credit rating agency must be the risk weight determined in accordance with the table under Rule 4.12.13 or the risk weight that is applicable to an CR Exposure to the central government of the jurisdiction in which the corporate is incorporated or established, whichever is higher. If a short term CR Exposure in the corporate asset class with an issue specific external credit assessment:
(a)	attracts a risk weight of 50% or 100%, then the Authorised Person must apply a risk weight of not lower than 100% to any unrated short term CR Exposure to the same corporate; or
(b)	attracts a risk weight of 150%, then the Authorised Person must apply a risk weight of 150% to any unrated CR Exposure (whether long term or short term) to the same corporate.
target_text:
Corporate asset class. Subject to Rules 4.12.14 and 4.12.15, an Authorised Person must risk weight any CR Exposure in the corporate asset class in accordance with the following table:
Risk Weights for the corporate asset class
/Table Start

Credit Quality Grade	1	2	3	4	5	6	Unrated
Risk Weight	20%	50%	100%	100%	150%	150%	100%

/Table End

question: If the Regulator is looking at an Application for Listing, what can it do (including refusing the application), and how does section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR fit with the rule that these actions are only available in the circumstances in subsection (2)?
gold_answer: For an Application for Listing, the Regulator can choose to refuse the Application for Listing, or it can allow admission of Securities to the Official List but attach conditions or restrictions to that admission. [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] If conditions or restrictions are used, the Regulator can also later change them or remove them entirely (vary or withdraw them). [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] Section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR provides the underlying authority for the admission-related part of this: it expressly allows the Regulator to impose conditions or restrictions on admission of Securities to the Official List and to vary or withdraw those conditions or restrictions. [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226] The listing provision adds an important boundary: the Regulator’s ability to refuse the application or to impose/vary/withdraw admission conditions is stated to apply in the circumstances specified in subsection (2). [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] Taken together, section 52(1)(b) explains the scope of the admission-condition tools, while the listing provision ties both refusal and those tools to the subsection (2) circumstances. [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226] [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b]
source_text: Under section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR, the Regulator may impose conditions or restrictions in respect of the admission of Securities to the Official List, or vary or withdraw such conditions or restrictions.
target_text:
The Regulator may—
(a)	refuse an Application for Listing; or
(b)	impose conditions or restrictions, in respect of the admission of Securities to the Official List, or vary or withdraw such conditions or restrictions;
in the circumstances specified in subsection ‎(2).

question: If a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company has Long-Term Insurance Business that must sit in a Long-Term Insurance Fund, what does it have to do, and can the Regulator still require it to set up one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds?
gold_answer: If a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that must be attributed to a Long-Term Insurance Fund, it must take one of two required steps: either (a) establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds, or (b) notify the Regulator in writing that the Captive Insurer is deemed to constitute a single Long-Term Insurance Fund [#TGT:510a1a41-dd30-47bf-b331-893b2b70a469]. In addition to that required choice, the Regulator has a separate discretionary power: it may, at its sole discretion, direct that a Captive Insurer which conducts Long-Term Insurance Business establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds for its Long-Term Insurance Business or any part of that business [#SRC:f6bf482b-33ba-4cf1-9375-26e6bfeb7ca7]. This means the Captive Insurer cannot treat the written notification option as guaranteed in all cases. Even where the Captive Insurer would otherwise comply by notifying the Regulator that it is deemed a single Long-Term Insurance Fund, the Regulator can still direct the establishment of one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds for the relevant business (or part of it), and the Captive Insurer must then align its actions with that direction.
source_text:
Residual discretion of the Regulator
Notwithstanding Rule 8.1.1 and 8.1.2, the Regulator may, at its sole discretion, direct that a Captive Insurer which conducts Long-Term Insurance Business establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds in respect of its Long-Term Insurance Business or any part of such business.
target_text:
Captive Insurer not a Cell Company
Where a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that, under the provisions of Rule ‎8.2, must be attributed to a Long-Term Insurance Fund, it must either:
(a)	establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds; or
(b)	notify the Regulator in writing that the Captive Insurer is deemed to constitute a single Long-Term Insurance Fund.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity publishes Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, what must it say about the Competent Person(s), and what consent must it have before publishing the information in that form?
gold_answer: The Mining Reporting Entity must do two things in parallel: include required Competent Person(s) statements in the disclosure and ensure the disclosure is issued only with the required written consent on how the information is presented. On the content side, the disclosure must state that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s). It must also state, for each Competent Person, whether they are an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party; if they are not, the disclosure must name the Competent Person’s employer. The disclosure must further state the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203]. On the permission side, where the disclosure includes Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves (and supporting information), it must only be made with the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) regarding the form and context in which the information is presented [#SRC:c30b96f6-edff-4774-b206-68a20fe00ba8].
source_text: Competent Persons . The disclosure made in Rule 11.12.1 must only be made with the prior written consent of the Competent Person(s) as to the form and context in which the Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, as the case may be, and the supporting information is presented in the disclosure.
target_text:
Competent Persons . Subject to Rule 11.12.2, a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity containing Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves must state:
(1)	that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s);
(2)	in each case, whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer; and
(3)	in each case, the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.

question: When applying the statement that Guidance is indicative and non-binding, how should a firm classify and treat this particular Guidance that is issued under section 15(2) of the Financial Services and Markets Regulations 2015 (FSMR) and is intended to be read together with FSMR and multiple FSRA guidance documents and rulebooks? In your answer, distinguish between Guidance issued as notations to the Rules and Guidance issued but not incorporated into the Rules.
gold_answer: A firm should treat this document as “Guidance” that is indicative and non-binding, while also classifying it within the Regulator’s two described forms of Guidance (notations to the Rules versus Guidance not incorporated into the Rules). [#TGT:9cba1e46-74c9-4276-9e69-6ed8746e30dd] This particular document is expressly described as Guidance issued under section 15(2) of the Financial Services and Markets Regulations 2015 (“FSMR”), and it is framed to be read alongside FSMR and a set of FSRA materials (relevant Rulebooks, the Guidance & Policies Manual, and specific guidance on ICOs/digital security offerings, virtual asset activities in ADGM, and the regulatory framework for private financing platforms). [#SRC:27924586-ba1b-4566-826f-92cba969d537] To apply the non-binding characterization correctly, the firm should (i) identify whether the Guidance has been made and issued as notations to the Rules or instead has been issued without being incorporated into the Rules, because both are recognized forms of Guidance. [#TGT:9cba1e46-74c9-4276-9e69-6ed8746e30dd] In doing so, the firm should keep the document’s stated context in view—namely that it is issued under FSMR section 15(2) and is intended to be read in conjunction with FSMR, FSRA Rulebooks, and the listed FSRA guidance documents—so that its indicative content is interpreted consistently across those referenced materials. [#SRC:27924586-ba1b-4566-826f-92cba969d537]
source_text:
INTRODUCTION
This Guidance is issued under section 15(2) of the Financial Services and Markets Regulations 2015 (“FSMR”).  It should be read in conjunction with FSMR, the relevant Rulebooks of the Financial Services Regulatory Authority (“FSRA”), the FSRA’s Guidance & Policies Manual, its ‘Guidance – Regulation of Digital Security Offerings (ICOs) and Virtual Assets under the FSMR’ (“ICO Guidance”),  its ‘Guidance – Regulation of Virtual Asset Activities in ADGM’ (“Virtual Asset Guidance”) , and its ‘Guidance – Regulatory Framework for Private Financing Platforms’.
target_text:
Guidance is indicative and non binding and may comprise—
(a)	Guidance made and issued by the Regulator as notations to the Rules; and
(b)	any Guidance issued by the Regulator which has not been incorporated into the Rules.

question: If an Authorised Person is allowed to do Managing a Collective Investment Fund and also does Dealing in Investments as Agent only as a small, wholly incidental part of that work, which category should it be in, and what would make it Category 2 instead?
gold_answer: It should be regarded as Category 3C if it carries out Dealing in Investments as Agent only in a manner that is wholly incidental to Managing an Investment Fund (or Managing Assets), and it otherwise fits the Category 3C definition. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] Category 3C covers an Authorised Person whose Financial Services Permission authorises one or more listed Regulated Activities, including Managing a Collective Investment Fund, provided it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B or 5. [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0] This means the incidental dealing-as-agent activity does not push the firm into Category 3A, because the text explicitly directs that such incidental Dealing in Investments as Agent is treated as Category 3C when it is tied to Managing an Investment Fund or Managing Assets. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] It would instead be Category 2 if its Financial Services Permission authorises Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal), its dealing activities are not limited in scope, and it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] So, the classification turns on (i) whether the firm meets the Category 3C activity-and-exclusion test and (ii) whether it meets the separate Category 2 principal-dealing/credit test. [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0]
target_text:
An Authorised Person is in Category 2 if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal);
(b)	its dealing activities are not limited in scope as provided in Rule 1.3.3(1)(a)(i); and
(c)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5.
Category 3A
Guidance
A Category 3A Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Agent and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1 and 1.3.2 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3A. Provided that an Authorised Person carries out the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Agent in a manner that is wholly incidental to the activity of Managing an Investment Fund or Managing Assets, the Authorised Person shall be regarded as falling within Category 3C.

question: When an Authorised Person calculates its Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital using its Total Risk Exposure Amount and a weighted average of applicable Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates, how must it determine which jurisdictions’ rates apply to its private sector credit exposures, and how does that jurisdiction identification feed into the buffer calculation?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must compute its Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by multiplying its Total Risk Exposure Amount by a weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to the jurisdictions where its private sector credit exposures are located. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] To determine which jurisdictions’ rates apply for that weighted average, the Authorised Person must, to the best of its ability, identify the geographical location of each private sector credit exposure as the jurisdiction where the underlying credit risk ultimately originates. [#TGT:ffc672ed-a781-4a71-bb0d-7fc38a2e0c7c] In practice, this means the “location” used to select the applicable jurisdictional buffer rate is not merely where an exposure is booked or administered, but the jurisdiction tied to the ultimate source of the credit risk, as identified by the Authorised Person. [#TGT:ffc672ed-a781-4a71-bb0d-7fc38a2e0c7c] Once those jurisdictions are identified on that basis, the Authorised Person uses the corresponding jurisdictional rates to form the weighted average that is then multiplied by the Total Risk Exposure Amount (as calculated under the referenced rule) to arrive at the required Countercyclical Capital Buffer amount. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]
source_text: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital equal to its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures are located, calculated in accordance with Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8.
target_text: Geographical location. For the purposes of the calculation of the weighted average of the applicable Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates an Authorised Person must identify, to the best of its ability, the geographical location of its private sector credit exposures as the jurisdiction where the underlying credit risk ultimately originates.

question: When the Regulator discloses Confidential Information to a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Regulator to facilitate the carrying out of a Public Function, what discretion does the Regulator have to impose conditions on the requesting authority and restrict how the information may be used, and how does that interact with the permitted disclosure pathway described?
gold_answer: The Regulator may disclose Confidential Information to a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Regulator where the disclosure is for the purpose of facilitating the carrying out of a Public Function and is made to one of the listed recipient categories, including a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Regulator. [#TGT:c143e65b-358c-4ac8-855c-546a1c91e4d1] In that scenario, the Regulator also has discretion, when disclosing Confidential Information under section 199(1), to require the requesting authority to comply with conditions or to agree to limits on the uses to which the Confidential Information may be put, to the extent the Regulator considers appropriate. [#SRC:6b15279a-ffe6-4bc9-961d-d8d4a305ef6f] Practically, this means the Regulator can both (i) rely on the Public Function facilitation basis and the specified recipient category to make the disclosure, and (ii) attach use-restrictions or other conditions directed at the requesting authority as part of the disclosure process. [#TGT:c143e65b-358c-4ac8-855c-546a1c91e4d1] [#SRC:6b15279a-ffe6-4bc9-961d-d8d4a305ef6f] The scope of any conditions or restrictions is determined by what the Regulator considers appropriate, rather than being fixed by the recipient category itself. [#SRC:6b15279a-ffe6-4bc9-961d-d8d4a305ef6f]
source_text: As set out in paragraphs 4.1.3 and 4.1.4 above, in disclosing any Confidential Information under section 199(1), the Regulator may require the requesting authority to comply with certain conditions or agree to restrict the uses to which the Confidential Information may be put, insofar as the Regulator considers appropriate.

question: If an Authorised Person has to subtract defined benefit pension fund assets when working out CET1 Capital, how can it lower that subtraction, and what must it do about risk weighting for the assets it uses to lower it?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must deduct defined benefit pension fund assets when it calculates its CET1 Capital, so the starting point is that these pension assets reduce CET1 Capital through a deduction. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] However, for that defined benefit pension fund asset deduction, the amount deducted can be reduced in two ways: first, by the amount of any associated deferred tax liability that could be extinguished if the pension assets became impaired or were derecognised under the International Financial Reporting Standards; and second, by the amount of pension fund assets that the Authorised Person has an unrestricted ability to use, but only where it has provided adequate advance notification to the Regulator that it intends to use those assets. [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada] If the Authorised Person uses pension fund assets to reduce the deduction, those assets must then be given a risk weight under Chapter 4 of these Rules, rather than being left without capital treatment. [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada] This sits alongside the wider list of required CET1 deductions (for example, goodwill and certain deferred tax assets), but the reduction and notification steps described here apply specifically to the defined benefit pension fund asset deduction. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]
source_text:
CET1 Deductions - defined benefit pension fund assets. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(d), the amount of defined benefit pension fund assets to be deducted from CET1 Capital must be reduced by the following:
(a)	the amount of any associated deferred tax liability which could be extinguished if the assets became impaired or were derecognised under the International Financial Reporting Standards; and
(b)	the amount of assets in the defined benefit pension fund which the Authorised Person has an unrestricted ability to use where the Authorised Person has provided adequate advance notification of its intention to use those assets to the Regulator. Those assets used to reduce the amount to be deducted must receive a risk weight in accordance with Chapter 4 of these Rules.

question: If a Listed Entity wants to issue Securities under an Employee Incentive Scheme and use the fact that Ordinary Security holders approved it (within the last three years) as an exception, what exactly must have been in the meeting notice, and when the entity later checks the 12‑month 20% issue limit formula, do those approved scheme issues count in “Relevant Issues” or not?
gold_answer: To use the Employee Incentive Scheme route that depends on Ordinary Security holder approval as an exception to Rule 9.7.1, the approval must have occurred within three years before the issue date and the meeting notice must have contained specific scheme disclosures. [#SRC:a2108df9-4a76-4d9c-8a4a-7e058e5e8113] The notice needs to include a summary of the scheme terms, the number of Securities already issued under the scheme since the Listed Entity’s Securities were admitted to the Official List (or since the last approval under the same rule), and the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme after the approval. [#SRC:a2108df9-4a76-4d9c-8a4a-7e058e5e8113] Separately, the 12‑month restriction on new issues says the Listed Entity must not issue (or agree to issue) more Equity Securities than (20% * Base Amount) minus Relevant Issues unless Ordinary Security holders approve. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] In that formula, “Relevant Issues” counts Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the prior 12 months, but it specifically excludes issues made with holder approval under Rule 9.7.1 (and certain other categories). [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] So, if the scheme issues were made under that Rule 9.7.1 approval, they are not included in “Relevant Issues” for the subtraction step. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]
source_text:
An issue of Securities under an Employee Incentive Scheme if within three years before the issue date:
(a)	in the case of a scheme established before the Listed Entity’s Securities were admitted to the Official List – a summary of the terms of the scheme and the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme were set out in in its Approved Prospectus or documents lodged with the Regulator under Rule 2.4.3; or
(b)	the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities have approved the issue of Equity Securities under the scheme as an exception to Rule 9.7.1.  The notice of meeting must have included:
(i)	a summary of the terms of the scheme;
(ii)	the number of Securities issued under the scheme since the Listed Entity’s Securities were admitted to the Official List, or the date of the last approval under this Rule; and
(iii)	the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme following the approval.
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: What does the PFP Operator have to review about a PFP Prospect and its financing proposal before publishing, and what information must it then publish to PFP Clients about the proposal and how it decides to accept proposals for publication?
gold_answer: Before publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence on the PFP Prospect. This includes reviewing the management’s details and background (including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers), reviewing the PFP Prospect’s background (including financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status if relevant), and reviewing the financing proposal to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, the proposal is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading [#SRC:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce]. After (and alongside) that work, the PFP Operator must ensure that information is published on the Private Financing Platform it operates and is available to PFP Clients. This published information must include the details of any financing proposal published on the platform, and it must also include the criteria and methodology for accepting a PFP Prospect’s financing proposal for publication on the platform [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f]. In combination, these requirements mean the PFP Operator must both do a substantive review before publication and clearly disclose to PFP Clients what proposal details are being shown and how the platform decides which PFP Prospect proposals are accepted for publication.
source_text:
Prior to publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence upon the PFP Prospect, in order to satisfy the disclosure requirements imposed on it by Rule 18.5.1. Such due diligence must include, but not be limited to, a review of the following information to be provided by the PFP Prospect:
(a)	details and background of management, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers;
(b)	background of the PFP Prospect, including its financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status, if relevant; and
(c)	the financing proposal, in order to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, its content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading.

question: How may the Investigator use a written notice to require a person to answer questions or otherwise provide information, and how should a regulated party assess whether the requested content qualifies as “information” rather than only “Documents”?
gold_answer: The Investigator may, by written notice, require the Person Under Investigation or any other person (even if not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to attend an interview at a specified time and place and answer questions, and may also require that person to provide such information as the Investigator may require [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. This sits alongside the Investigator’s power to require a person to give, or procure the giving of, information [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. In assessing whether a request is properly treated as “information” (as distinct from a request to “produce… Documents”), the key is that “information” is intended to be broad and not confined to documentary production. It can include knowledge about facts or circumstances, knowledge gained through professional or other activities, and computer-related data at any stage of processing (including stored or transmitted data) [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32]. It also includes explanations or statements, identification details, and responses to questions—meaning that oral or written answers, clarifications, and identifications can fall within “information” even where no specific document is being produced [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046].

question: How should an Authorised Person determine whether it falls within Category 1 or Category 3B when its Financial Services Permission includes both (i) Providing Custody for a Fund or Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust and (ii) Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, and what exclusion conditions must be checked for each category?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person should classify itself by identifying which category’s determinative permission it holds and then confirming it satisfies that category’s stated exclusions. For Category 1, the key trigger is that its Financial Services Permission authorises Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, and it must also not meet the criteria of Category 5. [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] For Category 3B, the key trigger is that its Financial Services Permission authorises Providing Custody (where it does so for a Fund) or Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust, and it must also not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5. [#SRC:c1ffeb55-d01d-48f4-b82b-88eb654acbbe] Where the firm holds permissions that could point to both categories (e.g., custody/trustee permissions and deposit/PSIAu permissions), the Category 3B test explicitly requires checking and excluding Category 1 status, while the Category 1 test requires checking and excluding Category 5 status. [#SRC:c1ffeb55-d01d-48f4-b82b-88eb654acbbe] [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] In applying these tests, note that each passage’s guidance indicates that other authorised Regulated Activities may exist, but the specified permissions are what determine category membership. [#SRC:c1ffeb55-d01d-48f4-b82b-88eb654acbbe] [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]
source_text:
Category 3B
An Authorised Person is in Category 3B if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of:
(i)	Providing Custody (where it does so for a Fund); or
(ii)	Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust; and
(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5.
Guidance
A Category 3B Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Providing Custody for a Fund or Acting as Trustee of a Fund, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1, 1.3.2 and 1.3.3 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3B.
target_text:
Category 1
An Authorised Person is in Category 1 if:
(a)		(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu; and
(b)		(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Category 5.
Guidance
A Category 1 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu that is determinative of its belonging to Category 1.
Category 2
Guidance
1.	A Category 2 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1, that are determinative of its belonging to Category 2.
