2.	Where the dealing activities of a firm are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the activities fall in the scope of Category 3A in accordance with Rule 1.3.3(1). A definition of "Matched Principal" is in Rule 1.3.3(2).

question: When an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and seeks to take that Collateral into account in measuring pre settlement Counterparty Exposure, what approach selection is permitted, and what mandatory constraints apply to approach choice and mixing for the Non Trading Book versus the Trading Book?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT is allowed to recognise the effect of that Collateral when measuring the relevant pre settlement Counterparty Exposure, provided the exposure is determined under the specified measurement basis and the recognition is done in accordance with the applicable recognition framework referenced in the permission [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778]. Once the firm elects to recognise collateral effects, the Target text imposes mandatory constraints on how that recognition must be performed depending on book classification. In the Non Trading Book, the Authorised Person must choose one of two approaches—either the FCSA or the FCCA—to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral, must apply that chosen approach consistently across the entire Non Trading Book, and must not use a combination of both approaches within that book [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412]. In contrast, for any pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT in the Trading Book, the Authorised Person is restricted to a single approach and must only use the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412].
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.
target_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person must use either the FCSA or the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral for any SFT in the Non Trading Book. The Authorised Person must apply the chosen approach consistently to the entire Non Trading Book and must not use a combination of both approaches. For a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from any SFT in the Trading Book, an Authorised Person must only use the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral.

question: For an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, which reconciliation and custody-check records must be maintained and included in the Resolution Pack, and what minimum frequencies apply to reconciling Client Accounts held with Third Party Agents, counting Safe Custody Assets, and reconciling Client ledger balances to Safe Custody Assets balances?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must ensure that its Resolution Pack includes the most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments, because the Resolution Pack is required to contain those reconciliation records as part of the specified record set [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. In parallel, the Authorised Person must perform (and therefore have records evidencing) three minimum-frequency controls: (i) at least every calendar month, reconcile its records of Client Accounts held with Third Party Agents against the monthly statements received from those Third Party Agents; (ii) at least every six months, count all Safe Custody Assets physically held by the Authorised Person or its Nominee Company and reconcile the count to the Authorised Person’s records; and (iii) at least every six months, reconcile individual Client ledger balances with the Authorised Person’s records of Safe Custody Assets balances held in Client Accounts [#TGT:99a621ce-b3ab-4dbc-a9c7-eac1065776e6]. Taken together, the Resolution Pack should contain the latest outputs of these reconciliation processes so that the Authorised Person can demonstrate both completion and recency of the required reconciliations and custody checks.
target_text:
An Authorised Person must:
(a)	at least every calendar month, reconcile its records of Client Accounts held with Third Party Agents with monthly statements received from those Third Party Agents;
(b)	at least every six months, count all Safe Custody Assets physically held by the Authorised Person, or its Nominee Company, and reconcile the result of that count to the records of the Authorised Person; and
(c)	at least every six months, reconcile individual Client ledger balances with the Authorised Person's records of Safe Custody Assets balances held in Client Accounts.

question: What must a Relevant Person do to assess and manage risks linked to NFTF business and the use of eKYC Systems as part of its overall money laundering risk assessment?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person must take appropriate steps to identify and assess the money laundering risks to which its business is exposed, taking into consideration the nature, size and complexity of its activities, and it must take into account that these risks include terrorist financing, proliferation financing, the financing of unlawful organisations, and sanctions non-compliance (including non-compliance with Targeted Financial Sanctions) [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. As part of that business-wide assessment, it should include an assessment of the risks associated with carrying on NFTF business, particularly where it uses eKYC Systems [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2]. When identifying and assessing risks, the Relevant Person must also consider (to the extent relevant) vulnerabilities tied to customers, countries/geographic areas, products and services, distribution channels and business partners, transaction complexity and volume, new products and business practices, and the use of new or developing technologies—areas that can be directly affected by eKYC and NFTF activity [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. It must then take appropriate measures to ensure any identified risk is reflected in day-to-day operations and mitigated, including for new products, new customers, and changes to its business profile [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. The assessment should also consider incorporating relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator and other relevant bodies [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2].
source_text: A business risk assessment under Rule ‎6.1.1(b) should include an assessment of the risks associated with the carrying on of NFTF business, particularly the use of eKYC Systems. The assessment should consider incorporating any relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and any other relevant bodies.

question: If an Authorised Person runs a Multilateral Trading Facility for Virtual Assets, what does it need to do with GEN Rule 5.2.14 (especially the word “Investment”), and which other rule sets does it have to follow for that activity (including what changes if it also provides custody)?
gold_answer: When an Authorised Person is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, GEN Rule 5.2.14 applies to that Authorised Person, and the rule must be read so that any mention of “Investment” is understood to mean “Virtual Asset”. [#TGT:726a7101-d094-4454-93b6-5e5561582705] This requirement is not standalone: it applies on top of the general requirements that already apply to an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets under Rules 17.1–17.6. [#SRC:24637efb-9ce5-40ee-bec4-7e5066d40d24] In addition, for the Multilateral Trading Facility activity, the Authorised Person must comply with the requirements in COBS, MIR and GEN as set out in Rules 17.7.2–17.7.6, which is the broader rulebook context that includes GEN Rule 5.2.14. [#SRC:24637efb-9ce5-40ee-bec4-7e5066d40d24] If the Authorised Person is also Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets, it must also comply with Rule 17.8, in addition to the Multilateral Trading Facility requirements and the GEN Rule 5.2.14 reading described above. [#SRC:24637efb-9ce5-40ee-bec4-7e5066d40d24]
source_text:
In addition to the general requirements applicable to an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets as set out in Rules 17.1 – 17.6, an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets must comply with the requirements set out in:
(a)	COBS, MIR and GEN, as set out in Rules 17.7.2 – 17.7.6; and
(b)	Rule 17.8 if also Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets.
target_text: GEN Rule 5.2.14 shall apply to an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, and all references to “Investment” shall be read as references to “Virtual Asset”.

question: When an Authorised Person has eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and is measuring the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure, can it recognise the Collateral’s effect, and if it does, how must it pick and apply FCSA or FCCA across the Non Trading Book and the Trading Book?
gold_answer: Yes. If an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined under the specified measurement basis, it may recognise the effect of that Collateral when measuring E, subject to following the recognition framework referenced in the permission [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778]. Once it recognises collateral effects, it must follow strict approach rules based on book classification. In the Non Trading Book, the Authorised Person must choose one approach—either the FCSA or the FCCA—to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral, must apply that chosen approach consistently to the entire Non Trading Book, and must not use a combination of both approaches within that book [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412]. For SFTs in the Trading Book, the rule is tighter: for any pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT in the Trading Book, the Authorised Person must only use the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412].
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.
target_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person must use either the FCSA or the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral for any SFT in the Non Trading Book. The Authorised Person must apply the chosen approach consistently to the entire Non Trading Book and must not use a combination of both approaches. For a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from any SFT in the Trading Book, an Authorised Person must only use the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral.

question: How must an Authorised Person determine and then continuously hold the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital, specifically where the buffer is the Countercyclical Capital Buffer derived from the Total Risk Exposure Amount and the weighted average of applicable jurisdictional buffer rates for private sector credit exposures?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person has two linked obligations: it must first compute the relevant buffer as a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital, and it must then ensure that the required buffer amount is actually maintained as CET1 Capital on an ongoing basis. The calculation step requires the Authorised Person to determine a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by taking its Total Risk Exposure Amount and multiplying it by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person’s private sector credit exposures are located [#TGT:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]. Once that required buffer amount has been calculated, the Authorised Person must maintain that required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times, meaning the obligation is continuous rather than point-in-time compliance [#SRC:97faadb3-289b-44a9-9f5c-3ea5c35e39cf]. Read together, the framework requires both a prescribed method to quantify the countercyclical buffer and a standing requirement to hold the resulting amount in CET1 Capital without interruption.
source_text: An Authorised Person must maintain the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times, as calculated in accordance with Rule 3.18.4.
target_text: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital equal to its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures are located, calculated in accordance with Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8.

question: When a person proposes to acquire or increase the level of control in a Domestic Firm and is also required to obtain the prior written approval of the Regulator, what written notice must be given, to whom, and in what form must it be submitted?
gold_answer: Where a person proposes either to acquire or increase the level of control in a Domestic Firm, the person must submit a written notice to us, and that notice must be in the form we shall set [#SRC:4068f5d7-33d4-473c-b314-4ee227d051bd]. In parallel, where a Person is required to obtain the prior written approval of the Regulator, that Person must provide written notice to the Regulator, and the notice must be in such form as the Regulator shall prescribe [#TGT:9b45a767-f8c2-493b-b0ae-d9f349767787]. Taken together, the obligation is not merely to notify, but to do so in the specific format mandated by the relevant authority (us for the Domestic Firm control change context, and the Regulator for the prior-approval context). The Source further indicates that the notice functions as an application that may be assessed for approval, objection, or conditions, and that incomplete or unclear submissions may trigger a written request for further information, affecting when the decision period starts [#SRC:4068f5d7-33d4-473c-b314-4ee227d051bd].
source_text: Controllers - Our approval. Under GEN 8.8.5(1), a person who proposes either to acquire or increase the level of control in a Domestic Firm must provide written notice to us in such form as we shall set. We may approve of, object to or impose conditions relating to the proposed acquisition or the proposed increase in the level of control of the firm. If the information in the written application lodged with us is incomplete or unclear, we may in writing request further clarification or information. We may do so at any time during the processing of such an application. The period of 90 days within which we will make a decision will not commence until such clarification or additional information is provided to our satisfaction. We may, in our absolute discretion, agree to a shorter period for processing an application where an applicant requests for such a period, provided all the information required is available to us.
target_text: A Person who is required to obtain the prior written approval of the Regulator pursuant to Rule ‎8.8.4(1) must provide written notice to the Regulator in such form as the Regulator shall prescribe.

question: When an Authorised Person is deducting holdings of CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities, does it use net positions or gross long positions to calculate the amount, and how does that fit with the list of CET1 deductions it must take?
gold_answer: The CET1 Deductions requirements state that an Authorised Person must deduct specified items from the calculation of its CET1 Capital, and that list includes the applicable amount of the Authorised Person’s direct and indirect holdings of CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities in the cases described for those holdings (including reciprocal cross holdings that artificially inflate the Authorised Person’s Capital Resources, and holdings where the Authorised Person has or does not have a significant investment in the Relevant Entities) [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]. For the purposes of the deductions tied to holdings of CET1 Capital instruments (and other capital instruments) of Relevant Entities, the amount of holdings to be deducted must be calculated on the basis of gross long positions, and this calculation is expressly subject to the referenced qualifying rule condition [#SRC:40c66431-d7b0-41ae-bc47-0ae63f4d9454]. That means the calculation is not described as a netting approach; instead, the required basis is gross long positions, and the resulting amount is then used to meet the obligation to deduct the applicable amount of those holdings from CET1 Capital.
source_text: CET1 Deductions - investments in CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(f), (g) and (h), the amount of holdings of CET1 Capital instruments and other capital instruments of Relevant Entities to be deducted, must be calculated, subject to Rule 3.10.15, on the basis of the gross long positions.

question: If a PFP Operator reviews a financing proposal to make sure it is clear and not misleading, what other due diligence items must it review, and what records must it keep for at least six years?
gold_answer: When the PFP Operator is preparing to publish a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, it must do due diligence on the PFP Prospect to satisfy its disclosure requirements. Beyond reviewing the financing proposal to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, it is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading, the due diligence must also include reviewing information provided by the PFP Prospect on management (including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers) and on the PFP Prospect’s background (including financial soundness, good standing and any relevant regulatory status) [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce]. The PFP Operator must then keep records to show what it did: for a minimum of six years it must maintain and keep a record of the due diligence undertaken, all disclosures made under the applicable disclosure rules, and all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7].
source_text:
A PFP Operator must, for a minimum of six years, maintain and keep a record of:
(a)	all disclosures made in accordance with Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2;
(b)	all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect; and
(c)	the due diligence undertaken in accordance with Rule 18.4.1.
target_text:
Prior to publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence upon the PFP Prospect, in order to satisfy the disclosure requirements imposed on it by Rule 18.5.1. Such due diligence must include, but not be limited to, a review of the following information to be provided by the PFP Prospect:
(a)	details and background of management, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers;
(b)	background of the PFP Prospect, including its financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status, if relevant; and
(c)	the financing proposal, in order to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, its content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading.

question: If a Reporting Entity needs to appoint an auditor, what does it have to do, and what process does it have to follow, based on section 82 of the FSMR and the Part 15/Rules requirement?
gold_answer: A Reporting Entity must both appoint an auditor and make that appointment using the specific appointment framework referenced for financial reports. [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] Section 82 of the FSMR creates the requirement for a Reporting Entity to appoint an auditor, so the entity has a clear duty to make an appointment rather than leaving the role unfilled. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] The financial reports provision adds that the Reporting Entity must have an auditor appointed in accordance with Part 15 and any Rules made for the purposes of that Part, so the appointment must be done through that Part 15 and Rules route. [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] Putting these together, the “what” is appointing an auditor (the obligation), and the “how” is that the appointment must be made in line with Part 15 and any Rules made for that Part (the required basis for the appointment). [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] This means a Reporting Entity should treat Part 15 and its Rules as the governing process for fulfilling the section 82 appointment duty. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb]
source_text: A Reporting Entity is required under section 82 of the FSMR to appoint an auditor.
target_text:
Financial reports. Appointment of auditors
A Reporting Entity shall have an auditor Appointed in accordance with ‎Part 15 and any Rules made for the purposes of that Part.

question: A Listed Entity must not issue too many Equity Securities without a vote by holders of Ordinary Securities. When working out how many Equity Securities it is issuing (including for the 12‑month lookback items in the cap), how should it count fully paid, partly paid, and convertible instruments, and when can the Regulator decide a different count?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the maximum allowed by the cap calculation unless it has the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]. To apply that limit, it must calculate how many Equity Securities it is issuing or agreeing to issue using the specified counting approach. Fully paid Ordinary Securities are counted one-for-one. Partly paid Securities are counted as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities they could become if fully paid up. Convertible Securities are counted as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities they could convert into [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f]. If the Security does not fit those categories, the Regulator may decide how it is counted, taking into account the need to ensure holders of Ordinary Securities have an opportunity to vote on issues that may dilute their holdings, or based on the Security’s characteristics [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f]. Using these counting rules helps ensure the Listed Entity’s total is measured consistently against the maximum number that, if exceeded, would require holder approval [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933].
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity is making its first disclosure of Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, what Competent Person details must it state, and what extra steps are required when it later repeats or refers to the same results or estimates so the first-time rule still applies?
gold_answer: On the first time a Mining Reporting Entity discloses Exploration Results or original or updated estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, it must include specific Competent Person information in the disclosure: it must say the disclosure is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s); it must identify, for each Competent Person, whether they are an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, name the Competent Person’s employer; and it must state the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203]. The “first-time only” scope is conditional: for later disclosures that refer to those same Exploration Results or estimates, the Mining Reporting Entity must (i) reference the earlier disclosure that complied, and (ii) confirm it is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects what was included earlier; where the later disclosure relates to Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, it must also confirm the earlier material assumptions and technical parameters still apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:9819bc20-c088-4225-b398-fd241c8b322d].
source_text:
Competent Persons . Rule 11.12.1 only applies the first time a Mining Reporting Entity discloses Exploration Results in accordance with Rule 11.4 or original or updated estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with Rules 11.5 or 11.6 provided that:
(1)	any subsequent disclosure that refers to those Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with Rule 11.12.1; and
(2)	the Mining Reporting Entity confirms in the subsequent disclosure that it is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects the information included in the earlier disclosure(s) and, in the case of estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, that all material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the estimates in the earlier disclosure(s) continue to apply and have not materially changed.
target_text:
Competent Persons . Subject to Rule 11.12.2, a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity containing Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves must state:
(1)	that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s);
(2)	in each case, whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer; and
(3)	in each case, the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.

question: When the Regulator is satisfied that doing so is in the interest of the ADGM/Abu Dhabi Global Market, may it direct a Reporting Entity to disclose specified information (including to the market) or take other steps, and on what basis can it set the terms and conditions for that direction?
gold_answer: Across both passages, the Regulator is permitted to issue a direction to a Reporting Entity when it has reached the satisfaction threshold that the action is in the interest of the ADGM/Abu Dhabi Global Market. In that circumstance, the direction may require the Reporting Entity to disclose specified information, and the Regulator may alternatively (or additionally) require the Reporting Entity to take other steps the Regulator considers appropriate, reflecting a broad discretionary power tied to the Regulator’s assessment of what serves the market’s interests [#SRC:b83c251c-65fd-4f1c-9225-20fa42145c35] and [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94]. The TARGET further clarifies that the disclosure may be to the market and that the Regulator may impose such a direction “on such terms and conditions as determined by the Regulator,” indicating that the Regulator controls the parameters and any conditions attached to compliance with the direction [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94]. Read together, the permission is triggered by the Regulator’s satisfaction as to the relevant market interest and then extends to both the content of the required disclosure and the ancillary steps and conditions the Regulator deems appropriate.
source_text: Section 84 of the FSMR gives the Regulator the power to direct a Reporting Entity to Disclose specified information or take such other steps as the Regulator considers appropriate where it is satisfied that it is in the interest of the ADGM to do so.
target_text:
Miscellaneous . Regulator's powers of Direction
The Regulator may, if it is satisfied that it is in the interests of the Abu Dhabi Global Market to do so—
(a)	direct a Reporting Entity to disclose specified information to the market or take such other steps as the Regulator considers appropriate; or
(b)	impose on a Reporting Entity any additional continuing obligations;
on such terms and conditions as determined by the Regulator.

question: How must an Authorised Person determine the amount of its Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital when it has private sector credit exposures in multiple jurisdictions, including how the weighted average of the applicable jurisdictional buffer rates is computed and then applied to the Total Risk Exposure Amount?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must set its Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital as a product of (i) its Total Risk Exposure Amount and (ii) a weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates applicable to the jurisdictions where its private sector credit exposures are located. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] The Total Risk Exposure Amount used in this calculation is the Total Risk Exposure Amount calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, and the weighted average rate must be calculated in accordance with the specified rules for determining that weighted average. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] To compute the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates across jurisdictions, the Authorised Person must: (1) for each jurisdiction in which it has private sector credit exposures, take the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the private sector credit exposures in that jurisdiction, divide it by the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the Authorised Person’s private sector credit exposures across all jurisdictions, and multiply the result by the applicable Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate in that jurisdiction; and then (2) sum these jurisdiction-level contributions across all jurisdictions. [#TGT:e71f9d6c-0033-443d-9ce0-aa873bdd8124] The resulting weighted average rate is then multiplied by the Total Risk Exposure Amount to yield the required Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]
source_text: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital equal to its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures are located, calculated in accordance with Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8.
target_text:
Weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates. The weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates shall be calculated by:
(a)	for each jurisdiction in which the Authorised Person has private sector credit exposures, dividing the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the private sector credit exposures in that jurisdiction by the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures across all jurisdictions and multiplying it by the applicable Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate in that jurisdiction; and
(b)	summing those contributions across all jurisdictions.

question: If a commodity deal is paid in cash and the goods are delivered promptly when it settles, what does the Regulator look at next to decide if it is an Accepted Spot Commodity, and what does the Authorised Person need to show about responsible and sustainable sourcing?
gold_answer: First, the commodity must fit the meaning of a Spot Commodity, including that it is a good sold for cash and promptly delivered when the transaction is settled, and that it is not a different type of arrangement such as delivery at a future date beyond the market’s standard delivery period for that commodity, a Financial Instrument involving conventional assets, or something that is not a good (for example, an intangible item). After that threshold is met, the Regulator decides whether, in its opinion, the Spot Commodity meets the requirements to be an Accepted Spot Commodity by applying its stated considerations. A key part of that review is the Authorised Person’s requirements for, and standards used, in relation to responsible and sustainable sourcing, including whether the Authorised Person adheres to internationally recognised certification standards where that is applicable to the relevant Spot Commodity. The Regulator also considers market fundamentals (including market practice and characteristics, liquidity and depth of demand and supply, number of active participants, transparency, and fair and orderly operation) and any other factors it considers relevant to whether the Spot Commodity is appropriate for the Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to it. [#SRC:34ccda9d-76c5-45f3-af56-56834f25f068] [#TGT:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338]

question: How does the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum, as a component used to calculate the Capital Requirement, affect when an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 must notify the Regulator and provide written confirmation if its Capital Resources drop below the required threshold?
gold_answer: The Expenditure Based Capital Minimum matters because it is expressly identified as a component used in calculating an entity’s Capital Requirement, and that Capital Requirement is the benchmark against which the notification trigger is measured [#SRC:596309d5-cc1a-4a45-9e6d-2042ff11da76]. For an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4, the obligation to notify is activated when its Capital Resources fall below 120% of its Capital Requirement; once that condition is met, the Authorised Person must notify the Regulator immediately and then confirm the notification in writing [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d]. Because the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum feeds into the calculation of the Capital Requirement, it is relevant to determining whether the 120% threshold has been breached and therefore whether the notification and written confirmation duties are triggered [#SRC:596309d5-cc1a-4a45-9e6d-2042ff11da76]. In practice, the Authorised Person should ensure it is using the correct Capital Requirement calculation (including this component) when assessing its Capital Resources against the 120% test, so it can meet the immediate notification and written follow-up requirements if the threshold is crossed [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d].
source_text: The Expenditure Based Capital Minimum is a component of the calculation of the Capital Requirement under Section 3.6 and is relevant in determining whether the Regulator has to be notified under Rule 3.20.2.
target_text: Notifications to the Regulator. An Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 must notify the Regulator immediately and confirm in writing if its Capital Resources fall below 120% of its Capital Requirement.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity already disclosed material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation with all required details, when can it make a later disclosure about those estimates without repeating all the details, and what does it still have to say clearly next to the estimates?
gold_answer: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, it must include specific information in the disclosure, including a clear statement placed prominently and close to the estimates explaining that they are Non-Equivalent Estimates, not reported under a Mining Reporting Standard, not yet classified by a Competent Person as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, and may never become reportable as such, plus other required supporting items (for example, sources/dates, relevance, reliability, summaries of work and assumptions, and verification work, timing and funding) [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]. But if the Mining Reporting Entity has already made an earlier disclosure of those Non-Equivalent Estimates that complied with those requirements, a later disclosure about the same estimates does not need to repeat the required information as long as it (1) points back to the earlier compliant disclosure, (2) confirms the earlier information still applies and that there is no new material information or data affecting reliability/interpretation or the entity’s ability to verify the estimates under a Mining Reporting Standard, and (3) still includes an equally prominent and proximate statement about the estimates covering the same key matters as the original prominent statement requirement [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4].
source_text:
If a Mining Reporting Entity has disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates that comply with the requirements of Rule 11.7.3, then any subsequent disclosure made in respect of the Non-Equivalent Estimates does not need to include the information in that Rule if the subsequent disclosure:
(1)	references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with that Rule;
(2)	contains a confirmation from the Mining Reporting Entity that:
(a)	the information provided in the earlier disclosure in compliance with that Rule continues to apply; and
(b)	there is no new material information or data relating to the Non-Equivalent Estimates that impacts on the:
(i)	reliability or interpretation of the Non-Equivalent Estimates; or
(ii)	Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify the Non-Equivalent Estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard; and
(3)	includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates addressing the matters contained in Rule 11.7.3(1).

question: If the Regulator sends a collateral notice, how can the Regulator decide the value limit for the assets a Captive Insurer must make available, and how is that limit worked out in the case of a Long-Term Insurance Fund?
gold_answer: The Regulator is allowed to require a Captive Insurer, by written collateral notice, to make available assets, but the value of those assets is not open-ended: it is set as the lower of (i) any amount stated in the notice and (ii) the amount calculated under the Rule 10.3.2(4) framework, with the value determined in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 6 [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7]. In the specific case of a Long-Term Insurance Fund, the Rule 10.3.2(4) amount is calculated as the sum of two components: (1) the Insurance Liabilities attributable to that Long-Term Insurance Fund and (2) the Minimum Fund Capital Requirement applicable to that Long-Term Insurance Fund, subject to the stated conditions that apply to that case [#SRC:9585f95e-ae97-44a1-966f-ec94cc458c39]. Practically, this means the collateral notice can require assets only up to the smaller of the notice’s stated amount (if any) and this liabilities-plus-capital-requirement total for the Long-Term Insurance Fund.
source_text:
The amount referred to in Rule ‎10.3.2(1)(b) is calculated as follows:
(a)	in the case of a Captive Cell of a Captive Insurer which is a Cell Company, the sum of the following two amounts:
(i)	the Insurance Liabilities attributable to that Captive Cell; and
(ii)	the Minimum Cellular Capital Requirement applicable to that Captive Cell.
(b)	in the case of a Long-Term Insurance Fund, subject to Rules ‎10.3.2(4)(c) and ‎10.3.2(4)(d), the sum of the following two amounts:
(i)	the Insurance Liabilities attributable to that Long-Term Insurance Fund; and
(ii)	the Minimum Fund Capital Requirement applicable to that Long-Term Insurance Fund;
(c)	in the case of a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company, the sum of the following two amounts:
(i)	the Captive Insurer's Insurance Liabilities; and
(ii)	the Captive Insurer's minimum capital requirement as provided for in Rule 2.2.
(d)	in the case of a Captive Insurer to which Rules ‎10.3.2(4)(a) and ‎10.3.2(4)(c) both apply, the amount set out in ‎10.3.2(4)(a); and
(e)	in the case of a Captive Insurer to which Rules ‎10.3.2(4)(c) and ‎10.3.2(4)(d) both apply, the amount set out in Rule ‎10.3.2(4)(d).
target_text:
The Regulator may, by written notice (referred to in this Chapter as a 'collateral notice'), require a Captive Insurer to make available assets:
(a)	of a type and in a manner described in Rule ‎10.3.2(5); and
(b)	having a value, determined in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 6, of the lower of:
(i)	the amount, if any, specified in the notice; and
(ii)	the amount determined in accordance with Rule ‎10.3.2(4).

question: When assessing whether it must disclose information that, if made generally available, would be likely to have a significant effect on the price of Financial Instruments, how should a Mining Reporting Entity apply the definition of Inside Information (including the requirements that it be precise, not generally available, and price-sensitive) while also taking into account the FSRA’s expectation regarding commercially sensitive ore-reserve-related details?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity should start by recognising that the FSRA does not expect it to disclose commercially sensitive information (such as pricing or volumes under long-term contractual commitments) merely to satisfy the specific ore reserves disclosure obligation, but it must still consider whether the same information is required to be disclosed under other disclosure requirements, including the obligation to disclose information that would, if generally available, be likely to have a significant effect on the price of Financial Instruments [#SRC:8597f744-9885-4eb3-9d70-e86ac02e5856]. To make that assessment, it should test the information against the definition of Inside Information: the information must be of a precise nature, not generally available, relate directly or indirectly to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers or to the relevant Financial Instruments (or other covered instruments), and be such that, if generally available, it would be likely to have a significant effect on price [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977]. If those definitional elements are met, the Mining Reporting Entity should treat the information as potentially within the scope of the price-sensitive disclosure obligation referenced by the FSRA, even if it is commercially sensitive, and document its analysis of each element (availability, precision, relationship, and price impact) in light of the disclosure triggers identified by the FSRA [#SRC:8597f744-9885-4eb3-9d70-e86ac02e5856] [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977].
source_text:
ORE RESERVES . The FSRA does expect a Mining Reporting Entity to have to disclose commercially sensitive information (e.g., pricing or volumes under long term contractual commitments) to meet this Rule obligation.  A Mining Reporting Entity (and other relevant entities) may, however, have to carefully consider whether this information needs to be disclosed to meet other disclosure requirements, including in reference to:

a)	where an Issuer is issuing a Prospectus within ADGM, and the requirement in section 62(1) of FSMR to include all information that investors would reasonably require and expect to find in a Prospectus for the purposes of making an informed investment decision; or

b)	the requirements in sections 95(2) of FSMR and Rule 7.2.1 to disclose information that ‘would, if generally available, be likely to have a significant effect on the price…’ of Financial Instruments.
target_text:
In relation to Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments which are not Commodity Derivatives, Inside Information is information of a Precise nature which—
(a)	is not generally available;
(b)	relates, directly or indirectly, to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers of the Financial Instruments or to one or more of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; and
(c)	would, if generally available, be likely to have a significant effect on the price of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments.

question: When an Authorised Person is onboarding a Retail Client for a trading account to buy and sell OTC Leveraged Products, what does the Authorised Person have to do about giving a separate risk disclosure statement, and what must that statement say about big losses, leverage, and stop-loss orders?
gold_answer: As part of onboarding and before opening a trading account that lets a Retail Client buy and sell OTC Leveraged Products, the Authorised Person must give the Retail Client a separate risk disclosure statement in good time before doing any business for that Retail Client [#SRC:3af19a86-294a-44cc-9abc-df79783033e8]. That statement must prominently warn that the Retail Client can lose substantially more than the initial margin they posted, and it must also set out additional required risk points, including that the statement may not cover every risk; the Retail Client could lose all capital outlay and any profits not redeemed; losses can build up quickly; and leverage amplifies losses when they happen [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955]. It must also explain that margin-trading limits, stop-loss limits, or other controls may not work or may fail, and where stop-loss orders are relevant, it must clearly say whether the stop-loss is “guaranteed”; if it is not guaranteed, it must explain that it may not limit losses in highly volatile market conditions [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955]. The statement must further cover slippage risk and note that most Retail Clients lose money in these products [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955].

question: In the annual report explanation mentioned in the SOURCE, what should a Reporting Entity say about its real governance practices so it covers the kinds of Rules the Regulator can set in TARGET (board of Directors and individual members, Controllers, employees or other persons, fair treatment of Shareholders, and conflicts of interests), and what overall long-term goal should it show?
gold_answer: In the annual report explanation, a Reporting Entity should focus on explaining how its day-to-day Corporate Governance practices actually deliver the outcomes expected under section 73 of the FSMR and the Principles, rather than treating the explanation as a purely formal statement. [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1] To make that explanation complete, it should be organized in a way that maps to the areas the Regulator may set by Rules for Corporate Governance: the principles and standards that apply to the Reporting Entity (including requirements that can apply to its board of Directors and individual members, Controllers, employees, or any other person as appropriate), requirements about fair treatment of Shareholders, and provisions that deal with conflicts of interests. [#TGT:d0183f42-1701-4885-9dcb-cb96c2d62d6d] This linkage helps show how the Reporting Entity’s actual practices are intended to achieve compliance with the outcomes behind the governance framework requirement. [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1][#TGT:d0183f42-1701-4885-9dcb-cb96c2d62d6d] The overall goal the explanation should demonstrate is that the governance framework supports prudent and sound management over the long term, in the interest of both the Reporting Entity and its Shareholders. [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1]
source_text: General. Section 73(2) of the FSMR provides that the Regulator is entitled to enact rules requiring a Reporting Entity to have a Corporate Governance framework which is adequate to promote prudent and sound management of the Reporting Entity in the long term interest of the Reporting Entity and its Shareholders. Accordingly, in providing its explanation in the annual report as noted in 2, a Reporting Entity should aim to illustrate how its actual practices achieve compliance with the outcomes intended by section 73 of the FSMR and the Principles, and thereby contribute to prudent and sound management of the Reporting Entity.
target_text:
For the purposes of the requirement in subsection ‎(1), the Regulator may by Rules prescribe—
(a)	Corporate Governance principles and standards that apply to a Reporting Entity, including any requirements applicable to its board of Directors and individual members, Controllers, employees or any other person as appropriate;
(b)	requirements relating to fair treatment of Shareholders; and
(c)	provisions to address conflicts of interests.

question: When an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and is measuring E for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure, how should the firm determine which collateral-recognition approach is permitted, including the distinction between exposures determined under Rule 4.9.15 and whether the SFT sits in the Trading Book or Non Trading Book?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral for an SFT only in the circumstances and using the methods specified for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures, and the permitted method depends on both how the exposure is determined and which book the SFT is in. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] Where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure for an SFT is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 and the Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral, the firm may recognise the effect of that collateral by applying the framework set out in Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] In addition, for any SFT in the Non Trading Book, the firm must choose either the FCSA or the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral, apply that single chosen approach consistently across the entire Non Trading Book, and avoid mixing the two approaches. [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412] By contrast, for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT in the Trading Book, the firm is restricted to using only the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral. [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412]
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.
target_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person must use either the FCSA or the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral for any SFT in the Non Trading Book. The Authorised Person must apply the chosen approach consistently to the entire Non Trading Book and must not use a combination of both approaches. For a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from any SFT in the Trading Book, an Authorised Person must only use the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral.

question: If a Fund Manager wants to remove a Trustee and appoint a new one, what paperwork must be sent to the Regulator, and what kinds of links between the Fund Manager and the new Trustee would mean the new Trustee is not independent?
gold_answer: The Fund Manager must give the Regulator a written notice saying it intends to remove the Trustee, and it must include either (i) a certification that the change will not negatively affect Unitholders’ interests and will not undermine the Fund Manager’s ability to comply with the Trust Deed, Prospectus, these Rules and the FSMR, or (ii) a Special Resolution of Unitholders approving the removal and the replacement with another Trustee. [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2] The Fund Manager must also provide the written consent of the person who will be the replacement Trustee and confirm that person meets the requirements for a Trustee in Section 114(2) of the FSMR to be able to act as replacement Trustee. [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2] Separately, the Trustee must be independent of the Fund Manager, so the Fund Manager should check that none of the listed relationships exist between it and the proposed replacement Trustee. [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c] The new Trustee would not be independent if either party holds or votes Shares of the other, they share a common holding company (or ultimate holding company), they have Directors who sit on both Governing Bodies, they share individuals performing Controlled Functions, or they have had professional or material business dealings in the last two years (other than acting as Fund Manager/Trustee for other funds). [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c]
source_text:
The Regulator may grant approval for the replacement of a Trustee only where it has received:
(a)	a written notice from the Fund Manager of its intention to remove the Trustee and either:
(i)	a certification that the removal of the Trustee will not adversely affect the interests of the Unitholders and the Fund Manager's ability to comply with its obligations under the Trust Deed, Prospectus, these Rules and the FSMR; or
(ii)	a Special Resolution of Unitholders approving the Fund Manager's proposal to remove the Trustee and its replacement with another Trustee; and
(b)	the written consent of the person who agrees to be the replacement Trustee, and that person meets the requirements for a Trustee in Section 114(2) of the FSMR to be able to act as the replacement Trustee.

question: When an Authorised Person is required to submit returns to the Regulator using EPRS, how must it proceed if the Regulator issues a written notice directing submission in a different form, manner, or frequency than otherwise prescribed, and for how long must that direction be followed?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person’s baseline obligation is to prepare its returns in accordance with the Rules in the relevant Chapter, the instructional guidelines in PRU and elsewhere, and the requirements of the Regulator’s Electronic Prudential Reporting System (EPRS), including the frequency of submission specified through those EPRS requirements, and then to submit the returns to the Regulator using EPRS [#SRC:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9]. However, this EPRS-based submission obligation operates subject to the Regulator’s power to vary how returns are submitted: the Regulator may, by written notice, direct an Authorised Person to submit its returns in a form, manner, or frequency other than the otherwise prescribed approach [#TGT:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b]. Where such a written direction is issued, the Authorised Person must continue submitting its returns in accordance with that direction, and it must keep doing so until the Regulator issues a further written notice directing otherwise [#TGT:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b].
source_text:
An Authorised Person must, subject to Rule 2.3.3:
(a)	prepare its returns in accordance with the Rules in this Chapter, the instructional guidelines in PRU and elsewhere, and the requirements of the Electronic Prudential Reporting System (EPRS) of the Regulator including the frequency of submission detailed therein; and
(b)	submit the returns to the Regulator using EPRS.
target_text: The Regulator may by way of a written notice direct an Authorised Person to submit its returns in a form, manner or frequency other than as prescribed in Rule 2.3.2.  An Authorised Person must continue to submit its returns in accordance with this direction until the Regulator by way of written notice directs otherwise.

question: When a person is required to attend an interview after receiving written notice to answer questions, what is prohibited as a basis for refusing to answer, and how does that prohibition align with the rule that a person must not treat self-incrimination or confidential communications as a reasonable excuse to refuse inspection/production obligations or to answer questions under an information-gathering requirement?
gold_answer: Where a person is required to attend an interview, they are first given written notice requiring attendance to answer questions, and the interviewee is not entitled to refuse or fail to answer merely because the answer may incriminate them, expose them to a penalty, or reveal a communication made in confidence (with the stated qualification regarding confidential communications) [#SRC:4d708250-cc2d-408e-9e2f-d77689864eda]. In parallel, the prohibition in the information-gathering context makes clear that, subject to the stated carve-out, it is not a reasonable excuse for a person to refuse or fail to permit inspection and copying of information or a Document, to give or produce (or procure the giving or production of) information or a Document, or to answer questions, on the grounds that the information, Document, or answer might tend to incriminate the person or might reveal a communication made in confidence (again with the stated qualification) [#TGT:4a2d4419-4e18-431a-9f52-59dae76a79ab]. Read together, the interview obligation and the broader prohibition both foreclose reliance on self-incrimination or confidentiality as a refusal rationale for answering questions, and the target text extends the same principle to inspection/copying and production duties when imposed under the relevant requirements.
source_text: Power to require a person to attend an interview . A person required to attend an interview will first be provided with written notice requiring their attendance at the interview to answer questions. Pursuant to section 206(5) of FSMR, an interviewee is not entitled to refuse or fail to answer a question on the basis that their answers may incriminate them, make them liable for a penalty or might reveal a communication made in confidence (subject to section 209(6) of FSMR).
target_text:
Subject to section ‎210‎(3), it is not a reasonable excuse for a person to refuse or fail to—
(a)	permit inspection and copying of any information or Document;
(b)	give or produce, or procure the giving or production of, any information or Document; or
(c)	answer questions;
pursuant to any requirement under sections ‎201, ‎203 and ‎206‎(1)‎(a), ‎(b), ‎(c) and ‎(e) on the grounds that any such information or Document or answer, as the case may be—
(d)	might tend to incriminate the person; or
(e)	is, or contains, or might reveal a communication made in confidence (subject to section ‎209‎(6)).

question: If an application is about Spot Commodities activities that a Recognised Body (a Recognised Investment Exchange or Recognised Clearing House) will carry out, what fee does the Applicant have to pay to the Regulator when applying to deal in investments as principal (not as a matched principal)?
gold_answer: When an application concerns activities relating to Spot Commodities that will be undertaken by a Recognised Body—meaning either a Recognised Investment Exchange or a Recognised Clearing House—the relevant application-fee regime is the one that applies to that Spot Commodities/Recognised Body scenario [#SRC:fb16bc56-352e-4a9e-82de-ebdb2b58ae49]. Under the obligation for the specific permission and activity described, an Applicant who applies for a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Principal, but not as a Matched Principal, must pay an application fee of $40,000 to the Regulator [#TGT:957c813c-93ef-4a38-aacd-a92bd99e168c]. So, if both conditions are met—(1) the application is tied to Spot Commodities activities undertaken by the specified type of Recognised Body, and (2) the Applicant is applying to deal as principal (excluding matched principal)—the required payment is $40,000, and it must be paid to the Regulator as part of the application.
source_text: Where an application concerns activities relating to Spot Commodities that will be undertaken by a Recognised Body, whether a Recognised Investment Exchange or Recognised Clearing House, the fees in Section 4.1 will apply.
target_text: An Applicant for a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Principal, but not as a Matched Principal, must pay to the Regulator an application fee of $40,000.

question: Where a Passported Fund remains materially prejudicial in ADGM despite measures taken by a Home Regulator, how does the Regulator’s ability to request urgent discussions with that Home Regulator connect to the Regulator’s subsequent power to take protective measures if those urgent discussions do not resolve the issues within a reasonable period?
gold_answer: In the Passported Fund context, if a Home Regulator has already taken measures (if any) but the Fund Manager’s activities in ADGM (or those of its Agent or any other Licensed Person promoting the Passported Fund) continue to be materially prejudicial to Unitholders situated in ADGM or to ADGM’s financial stability or integrity, the Regulator may initiate the process by requesting urgent discussions with the Home Regulator responsible for supervision and enforcement of the Passported Fund. [#TGT:722d2090-eec8-4ae1-8d98-db9a10f13e55] If those urgent discussions (as referenced in Rule 9.5.2) do not resolve the issues to the Regulator’s satisfaction within a period that is reasonable in the circumstances, the Regulator may then escalate by taking all appropriate measures needed to protect the interests of Unitholders domiciled in ADGM or to protect the financial stability and integrity of the ADGM market. [#SRC:6a79069b-b2b7-4349-9fa6-ae21f98b3a02] This linkage means the “urgent discussions” step functions as a precursor mechanism in the scenario where prejudice persists despite Home Regulator action, and the trigger for further intervention is the failure of those discussions to achieve a satisfactory resolution within a reasonable timeframe. [#TGT:722d2090-eec8-4ae1-8d98-db9a10f13e55] [#SRC:6a79069b-b2b7-4349-9fa6-ae21f98b3a02]
source_text: If the urgent discussions referred to in Rule 9.5.2 fail to resolve the issues to the satisfaction of the Regulator within a period that is reasonable in the circumstances, then the Regulator may take all appropriate measures needed in order to protect the interests of Unitholders domiciled in ADGM or the financial stability and integrity of the ADGM market.
target_text:
If, despite the measures (if any) taken by a Home Regulator in relation to a Passported Fund, a Fund Manager's activities (or the activities of its Agent or any other Licensed Person that is Promoting the Passported Fund) in ADGM continue to be materially prejudicial to either:
(a)	the Unitholders of the Passported Fund who are situated in ADGM; or
(b)	the financial stability or the integrity of ADGM,
the Regulator may request urgent discussions with the Home Regulator who has the supervision and enforcement responsibilities in respect of the Passported Fund.

question: When conducting periodic stress tests for its securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures, what must an Authorised Person do to ensure the testing reflects the firm-wide impact of those activities under stressed market conditions, including implications for other sources of risk and the risk that pipeline transactions may not complete, while also assessing its future ability to transact securitisation for CRM or liquidity purposes?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must conduct periodic stress tests covering its securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures, and those tests must include an assessment of its future ability to transact securitisation as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa]. In designing and performing those stress tests, the firm should ensure the scenarios and analysis consider the firm wide impact of securitisation activities and related Exposures in stressed market conditions, including the implications for other sources of risk across the firm [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97]. The scope of the stress testing should extend beyond current positions to include both existing securitisation Exposures and transactions in the pipeline, reflecting the specific risk that pipeline transactions may not be completed in a stressed market scenario [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97]. Taken together, the obligation is to run periodic, forward-looking stress tests that are comprehensive in coverage (on- and off-balance sheet, existing and pipeline) and that evaluate both firm-wide risk impacts and the firm’s capacity to continue using securitisation for risk mitigation or liquidity under stress [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97].
source_text: The periodic stress testing in relation to securitisation activities referred to in Rule 4.14.5 should consider the firm wide impact of those activities and Exposures in stressed market conditions and the implications for other sources of risk. Such stress tests should include both existing securitisation Exposures and transactions in the pipeline, as there is a risk of the pipeline transactions not being completed in a stressed market scenario.
target_text: Systems and controls for the use of securitisations. An Authorised Person must conduct periodic stress tests in relation to its securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures, including testing of future ability to transact securitisation as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes.

question: Before a PFP Operator publishes a financing proposal relating to a PFP Prospect, what due diligence must it perform on the PFP Prospect, and what platform disclosures must it ensure are made available to PFP Clients regarding both the risks of participating and the methodology and limitations of that due diligence?
gold_answer: Before publishing any financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence upon the PFP Prospect to support its disclosure obligations, and that due diligence must include (at a minimum) reviewing management details and background (including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers), the PFP Prospect’s background (including financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status where relevant), and the financing proposal itself to ensure, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, that the content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading [#SRC:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce]. In parallel, the PFP Operator must ensure that information available to PFP Clients is published on the Private Financing Platform it operates, including a statement identifying the risks involved in participating in financing proposals on the platform, details of any financing proposal published, the criteria and methodology for accepting a PFP Prospect’s financing proposal for publication, and the methodology of, and limitations to, the due diligence undertaken by the PFP Operator concerning each PFP Prospect identified on the platform [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f]. Together, these requirements link the pre-publication review of the PFP Prospect and proposal with transparent client-facing disclosure about risks and how the PFP Operator’s due diligence is conducted and bounded.
source_text:
Prior to publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence upon the PFP Prospect, in order to satisfy the disclosure requirements imposed on it by Rule 18.5.1. Such due diligence must include, but not be limited to, a review of the following information to be provided by the PFP Prospect:
(a)	details and background of management, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers;
(b)	background of the PFP Prospect, including its financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status, if relevant; and
(c)	the financing proposal, in order to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, its content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading.

question: When an Authorised Person must determine E for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT that is not covered by a qualifying cross product Netting agreement, how should E be measured for securities-lending/repurchase versus cash-lending/resale structures, and in what circumstances may the Authorised Person recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral taken for that SFT?
gold_answer: For a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT that is not covered by a qualifying cross product Netting agreement, an Authorised Person must determine E by reference to the structure of the SFT: where the Authorised Person has lent Securities or sold Securities with a commitment to repurchase at a specified price on a specified future date, E is the latest fair value of the Securities lent or sold; where the Authorised Person has lent cash through borrowing Securities or has paid cash to purchase Securities with a commitment to resell at a specified price on a specified future date, E is the amount of cash lent or paid [#TGT:9578677d-803d-4f27-b8f6-2e4bdf56805e]. In addition, if the Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT and the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure for that SFT is determined in accordance with the relevant measurement approach, the Authorised Person may recognise the effect of such Collateral when measuring the exposure, subject to applying the specified collateral-recognition framework referenced for that purpose [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778].
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.
target_text:
Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person must determine E, for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT which is not covered by a qualifying cross product Netting agreement as follows:
(a)	in the case where the Authorised Person has lent Securities to a Counterparty or sold Securities to a Counterparty with a commitment to repurchase those Securities at a specified price on a specified future date, the latest fair value of the Securities lent or sold; and
(b)	in the case where the Authorised Person has lent cash to a Counterparty through the borrowing of Securities from the Counterparty or paid cash for the purchase of Securities from a Counterparty with a commitment to resell those Securities at a specified price on a specified future date, the amount of cash lent or paid.

question: When an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 experiences a drop in its Capital Resources to below the specified buffer relative to its Capital Requirement, what notifications must it make to the Regulator, how quickly must it act, and what additional formality is required beyond the initial notification?
gold_answer: For an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4, the trigger event is its Capital Resources falling below 120% of its Capital Requirement. When that threshold is breached, it must notify the Regulator immediately, reflecting the urgency of the obligation and the expectation that the Regulator is informed without delay once the shortfall occurs [#SRC:c08e86ed-69f1-4d9f-81bf-af5206de7e41]. In addition to making the immediate notification, the Authorised Person must also confirm the notification in writing, meaning the communication is not complete with only an immediate alert and must be followed by a written confirmation to the Regulator [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d]. The combined requirements therefore impose both (i) a timing requirement (immediate notification upon the threshold breach) and (ii) a documentation/form requirement (written confirmation), each tied to the same capital-resources trigger and the same specified categories of Authorised Person.
source_text: An Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 must notify the Regulator immediately if its Capital Resources fall below 120% of its Capital Requirement, in accordance with Rule 3.20.2.
target_text: Notifications to the Regulator. An Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 must notify the Regulator immediately and confirm in writing if its Capital Resources fall below 120% of its Capital Requirement.

question: In the quarterly report, how often does a Mining Production Reporting Entity have to provide the Summary of Reserves and Resources (or where can it be included instead), and when that Summary is disclosed what table must a Mining Reporting Entity include and how recent must its date be?
gold_answer: In its quarterly reporting, a Mining Production Reporting Entity must include the Summary of Reserves and Resources at least once every 12 months, unless the Summary is included in the Mining Reporting Entity’s annual report instead; the quarterly report must also indicate when the prior and next such Summary disclosure was and will be made. This is a required element of the quarterly report that is disclosed for each quarter of the financial year and covers the Mining Production Reporting Entity and all controlled entities on a consolidated basis, if applicable [#SRC:a24b4f51-4c48-4846-bd22-d5f98dbad55b]. When the Summary of Reserves and Resources is actually disclosed, a Mining Reporting Entity must include a table in the form of MKT Form 11-1 within that Summary, and the table must be dated as of a point no earlier than one month before the Summary’s disclosure date [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd]. Practically, this means you must plan the annual cadence through the quarterly process (or the annual report alternative) and also ensure the Summary’s required table is prepared using a sufficiently recent “as of” date relative to when you publish the Summary.
target_text: A Mining Reporting Entity must include in its Summary of Reserves and Resources, a table in the form of MKT Form 11-1, as of a date no earlier than one month prior to the disclosure of the Summary of Reserves and Resources.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity says its economic assumptions are “commercially sensitive” in a Rule 11.9.1 forecast disclosure, what must it still explain, and when might it be hard to justify calling those assumptions sensitive? Also, what must it disclose about the Production Target used for the forecast?
gold_answer: Even where a Mining Reporting Entity believes its material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it must still include the material economic assumptions used for the forecast financial information and provide a statement that it considers them commercially sensitive together with an explanation of the methodology used to determine those assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] It must also disclose all other material assumptions used in preparing the forecast financial information. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] However, the Mining Reporting Entity should be cautious about asserting sensitivity where it is not warranted: if it has not yet entered into any commercially sensitive contracts that underpin assumptions such as commodity price, capital expenditure, or operational expenditure, it would be difficult to form a view that information about those assumptions is commercially sensitive. [#TGT:3b4ca4c9-5690-4bae-8c30-3d06642d6e95] In addition to assumptions, the disclosure must state the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, and it must include all information required for that Production Target (including the information contained in Rule 11.8.3). [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
