[#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] The monthly reconciliation obligation is framed as a systems-and-controls requirement aimed at ensuring reconciliations are accurate and performed at least every calendar month, so the firm should operate controls that reliably produce reconciliation outputs on that cadence (or more often where necessary). [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b] To align the Resolution Pack with that operational requirement, the Pack must include the most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments, which provides a concrete, current record demonstrating that reconciliation activity is being performed and documented. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] In practice, this means the firm should be able to point from its monthly (or more frequent) reconciliation process for Client Accounts to the latest completed reconciliation records for Client Money and Client Investments that are filed in the Resolution Pack. [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]
target_text: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must maintain adequate systems and controls to ensure that accurate reconciliations of Client Accounts are carried out as regularly as necessary but at least every calendar month.

question: Where a person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator is treated as liable for a Prospectus and an investor claims compensation for loss arising from an untrue or misleading statement or a material omission, what must that prescribed person demonstrate or have done to avoid incurring civil liability, including any steps required before the Securities were acquired in reliance on the Prospectus?
gold_answer: Under the compensation regime, any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to a person who acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and suffered loss or damage arising from an untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission of a material matter required to be included [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac]. However, that person does not incur civil liability if they can show one of the specified bases: that the statement was true and not false, misleading, or deceptive, or that the matter whose omission caused the loss was properly omitted; or that they made all enquiries that were reasonable in the circumstances and believed there was no false, misleading, or deceptive statement or omission in the Prospectus; or that, before the Securities were acquired by any person in reliance on the Prospectus, they took all steps reasonable for them to take to secure that a correction was promptly made and brought to the attention of persons likely to acquire the Securities [#SRC:4ce33793-6bb5-4bc3-a65f-675a4ac19554].
source_text:
A Person does not incur civil liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR if that Person can show that:
(a)	the statement was true and not false, misleading, or deceptive or that the matter the omission of which caused the loss was properly omitted;
(b)	he made all enquiries that were reasonable in the circumstances and believed that there was no false, misleading, or deceptive statement or omission in the Prospectus; or
(c)	before the Securities were acquired by any Person in reliance on the Prospectus, he had taken all such steps as were reasonable for him to have taken to secure that a correction was promptly made and brought to the attention of the Persons likely to acquire the Securities in question.
target_text: Any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to another person who has acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and who has suffered loss or damage arising from any untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission from it of any material matter required to have been included in the Prospectus by or under these Regulations.

question: During a period of financial or liquidity stress, when an Authorised Person liquidates part of its stock of HQLA to generate cash for outflows and this causes its HQLA level to fall below what is required under its LCR Requirement, what notification duty applies, including the trigger and timing, given that the notification rule expressly covers stress periods?
gold_answer: If, during a period of financial or liquidity stress, an Authorised Person liquidates part of its stock of HQLA to generate cash to cover cash outflows and, as a result, its HQLA level falls below the levels required under its LCR Requirement to the extent necessary to deal with those outflows, the Authorised Person is permitted to do so in that stress context. [#SRC:217110e1-e493-4282-8e36-277b891a0d4f] However, whenever the Authorised Person does not meet its LCR Requirement, or becomes aware of circumstances that may result in it not meeting its LCR Requirement at any time, it must notify the Regulator in writing immediately. [#TGT:d122a0f5-6de3-47a6-a4a6-e25cd93e7d8c] This notification obligation explicitly applies even where the potential or actual non-compliance occurs during a period of stress of the kind in which HQLA liquidation and temporary shortfall may occur. [#TGT:d122a0f5-6de3-47a6-a4a6-e25cd93e7d8c] Accordingly, the compliance approach is to (i) recognize that stress-driven HQLA liquidation may reduce HQLA below the LCR-required level to the extent necessary to address cash outflows, and (ii) treat any resulting failure to meet the LCR Requirement, or credible risk of such failure, as an immediate written notification trigger to the Regulator. [#SRC:217110e1-e493-4282-8e36-277b891a0d4f] [#TGT:d122a0f5-6de3-47a6-a4a6-e25cd93e7d8c]
source_text: Liquidation of assets during periods of stress . During a period of financial or liquidity stress, an Authorised Person may liquidate part of its stock of HQLA and use the cash generated to cover cash outflows. Subject to Rule 9.3.9, the Authorised Person's level of HQLA may fall below the levels required under its LCR Requirement to the extent necessary to deal with cash outflows during that period.
target_text: Notification if LCR Requirement is not met . An Authorised Person must notify the Regulator in writing immediately if it does not meet, or becomes aware of circumstances that may result in it not meeting, at any time, its LCR Requirement (including during a period of stress referred to in Rule 9.3.8).

question: If a Third Party Provider confirms a Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, how quickly must it refund, and what happens to the refund timing rule if it reasonably suspects the Customer is acting fraudulently?
gold_answer: Once the Third Party Provider has confirmed that a Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, it must provide a refund under Rule 20.12.1 as soon as practicable and no later than the end of the next day (the day after the confirmation day). [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] The key timing point is the Third Party Provider’s confirmation, because the “next-day” deadline is measured from that day. [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] There is also a specific exception tied to suspected fraud: the requirement to provide a refund within the timeframe set by Rule 20.12.2 does not apply if the Third Party Provider has reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behaviour by the Customer. [#SRC:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012] Put together, the general rule is a fast refund once unauthorised/incorrect execution is confirmed, but the Third Party Provider is not required to follow the Rule 20.12.2 timeframe when it has reasonable grounds for that fraud suspicion. [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] [#SRC:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012] This means your compliance check should identify (1) the confirmation date for the unauthorised/incorrect execution finding and (2) whether the fraud-suspicion condition is met, because that condition changes whether the Rule 20.12.2 timing requirement applies. [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] [#SRC:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012]
source_text: Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. The requirement to provide a refund within the timeframe prescribed in Rule 20.12.2 does not apply where the Third Party Provider has reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behaviour by the Customer.
target_text: Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. The Third Party Provider must provide a refund under Rule 20.12.1 as soon as practicable, and in any event no later than the end of the day following the day on which it has confirmed that the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed.

question: If an Exposure is only partly guaranteed by an Authorised Person’s Parent Financial Institution, can the Authorised Person exclude just the guaranteed part from the Large Exposure limit, and what extra requirements apply if the Authorised Person wants to exclude the Exposure based on a parental guarantee or parental Tier 1 support?
gold_answer: The Source allows relief only for the guaranteed slice: if an Exposure is partially guaranteed by an Authorised Person’s Parent Financial Institution and that guaranteed portion would receive a lower risk weight, only that part of the Exposure that is subject to the guarantee is exempt from the Large Exposure limit; the unguaranteed portion remains within the limit [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3]. The Target then provides a separate permission for excluding an Exposure from the Large Exposure limits where the Authorised Person’s Parent either (a) is set, under a legally binding agreement, to increase the Authorised Person’s Tier 1 promptly and on demand in an amount sufficient to reverse losses on the Exposure or to ensure compliance with the Capital Requirement, or (b) guarantees the Exposure to a Counterparty or group of Closely Related Counterparties not Connected to the Authorised Person, but only if detailed conditions are met (including CRM-aligned guarantee criteria, acceptable bank regulation, limits relative to the guarantor’s Tier 1, credit assessment, confirmations, annual enforceability confirmation, and Regulator notifications at specified thresholds) [#TGT:032faf55-93b1-4f6a-ab8f-56eea4f82cff]. Together, they mean partial guarantees drive partial relief, while full exclusion depends on meeting the Target’s parental-support conditions.
source_text: Exempt Exposures. If an Exposure is partially guaranteed by an Authorised Person's Parent Financial Institution, and would be assigned a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, only that part of the Exposure subject to the guarantee is exempt from the Large Exposure limit in Rule 4.15.5. When considering the treatment of this Rule an Authorised Person may also consider the exemptions permitted under Rule 4.15.18 relating to parental guarantees.

question: Where a FinTech Participant cannot meet the applicable criteria, when must it stop carrying on the Regulated Activity of Developing Financial Technology Services within the RegLab, and how does the Regulator’s ability to vary or cancel a Financial Services Permission affect that deadline under the framework addressing variation and cancellation on the Regulator’s initiative?
gold_answer: If a FinTech Participant is unable to satisfy the applicable criteria, it must stop carrying on the Regulated Activity of Developing Financial Technology Services within the RegLab. [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7] The default deadline for ceasing that Regulated Activity is the point when its RegLab FSP expires, reflecting the stated two-year validity period for that permission. [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7] However, that deadline is not fixed solely by expiry: it can be brought forward (or otherwise altered) if the Regulator varies or cancels the FSP, because the cessation deadline is also defined as “at such time as the Regulator varies or cancels the FSP” in accordance with the referenced mechanism. [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7] In applying this, the relevant framework is the regime concerning “Variation and cancellation of a Financial Services Permission,” specifically where variation or cancellation occurs on the initiative of the Regulator. [#TGT:445d41e7-27aa-41c1-84e4-194553261f8a] Accordingly, compliance planning should treat expiry as the baseline stop date, but also monitor for any Regulator-initiated variation or cancellation that would trigger an earlier (or otherwise revised) cessation point. [#SRC:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7] [#TGT:445d41e7-27aa-41c1-84e4-194553261f8a]
source_text: Two-year validity period. If the FinTech Participant is unable to satisfy the above criteria, it will be required to cease carrying on the Regulated Activity of Developing Financial Technology Services within the RegLab.  The deadline for ceasing the Regulated Activity will be upon the expiry of its RegLab FSP, or at such time as the Regulator varies or cancels the FSP in accordance with section 33 of the FSMR.  Please refer to section 8 below for more details.
target_text: Variation and cancellation of a Financial Services Permission. Variation or cancellation on initiative of the Regulator

question: If an Authorised Person has private sector credit exposures in more than one jurisdiction, what steps does it follow to work out the weighted average Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate and then calculate the Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person has private sector credit exposures in multiple jurisdictions, it must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by multiplying its Total Risk Exposure Amount by a weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply in the jurisdictions where those exposures are located. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] The Total Risk Exposure Amount used for this purpose is the Total Risk Exposure Amount calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, and the weighted average rate must be determined using the prescribed method for jurisdictional weighting. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] The weighted average rate is built up jurisdiction by jurisdiction. For each jurisdiction where the Authorised Person has private sector credit exposures, it must calculate that jurisdiction’s contribution by taking the Total Risk Exposure Amount related to private sector credit exposures in that jurisdiction, dividing it by the Total Risk Exposure Amount related to the Authorised Person’s private sector credit exposures across all jurisdictions, and multiplying by the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate applicable in that jurisdiction. [#TGT:e71f9d6c-0033-443d-9ce0-aa873bdd8124] It must then add together all of those jurisdiction contributions to get the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates. [#TGT:e71f9d6c-0033-443d-9ce0-aa873bdd8124] Finally, it applies that weighted average rate to the Total Risk Exposure Amount to arrive at the Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]
source_text: An Authorised Person must calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital equal to its Total Risk Exposure Amount, calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures are located, calculated in accordance with Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8.
target_text:
Weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates. The weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates shall be calculated by:
(a)	for each jurisdiction in which the Authorised Person has private sector credit exposures, dividing the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the private sector credit exposures in that jurisdiction by the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the Authorised Person's private sector credit exposures across all jurisdictions and multiplying it by the applicable Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate in that jurisdiction; and
(b)	summing those contributions across all jurisdictions.

question: When an MTF Operator chooses to list Exempt Offer Securities on the MTF so they can be traded among Professional Clients and a limited number of assessed Retail Clients, what systems and controls must the MTF have in place to admit those Securities to trading and manage who may trade them?
gold_answer: Where an MTF Operator elects to list Exempt Offer Securities on the MTF, the permission is conditioned by the trading model described in the source: the Securities may be traded among an unlimited number of Professional Clients and no more than 200 Retail Clients, but only where those Retail Clients have been assessed by the MTF Operator as having appropriate knowledge and experience of the relevant risks [#SRC:1afc74c9-338e-44c8-8b6b-bba509c5946f]. If the MTF admits to trading Securities offered by way of an Exempt Offer, it must also ensure it has effective systems and controls to operationalise that permission: it must admit only Securities of Exempt Offers made on its own platform, identify the Persons to whom the Exempt Offer was made, and restrict trading so that no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients can trade [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66]. In addition, the MTF must have controls to comply with the applicable admission-to-trading requirements and to allow users to obtain Inside Information, including relevant offer documents, so that trading access and information access align with the platform’s Exempt Offer admission framework [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66].
source_text: In respect of Securities offered by Exempt Offer, whether previously offered through a PFP or not, an MTF Operator may list Exempt Offer Securities on the MTF, enabling such Securities to be traded amongst an unlimited number of Professional Clients and not more than 200 Retail Clients which have been assessed by the MTF Operator to possess appropriate knowledge and experience of the relevant risks, in accordance with Market Infrastructure Rules (MIR) Rule 2.8.3. A description of the systems and controls required to be employed by a MTF Operator that seeks to admit Exempt Offer Securities to trading is set out in Conduct of Business Rules (COBS) Rule 8.2.2.

question: Where a Recognised Body has not taken action under its Default Rules but appears able to do so, what preconditions must the Regulator satisfy (including any consultation requirement and the grounds for being satisfied) before issuing a positive direction to take action?
gold_answer: In the scenario where a Recognised Body has not acted under its Default Rules but appears able to take action, the Regulator may issue a “positive” direction requiring action, but only after meeting additional preconditions. [#TGT:70b944a0-fca5-4266-8177-4fa3b31f8ea3] Before giving such a direction under Rule 6.5.4, the Regulator must consult the Recognised Body concerned. [#SRC:46b33967-ebbc-4f36-b86a-689930eb7a5a] Following that consultation, the Regulator is prohibited from giving the direction unless it is satisfied—based on the consultation—that at least one specified ground applies. [#SRC:46b33967-ebbc-4f36-b86a-689930eb7a5a] Those grounds are: (i) that not taking action would create an undue risk to investors or other market participants; or (ii) that the direction is necessary in light of the public interest in the financial stability of the Abu Dhabi Global Market; or (iii) that the direction is necessary to facilitate a proposed or possible use of a power under chapter 16 of COBS, or in connection with a particular exercise of a power under that chapter, or Rule 6.5.7(c). [#SRC:46b33967-ebbc-4f36-b86a-689930eb7a5a] Accordingly, the Regulator’s ability to issue the positive direction in this Default Rules context depends both on the appearance that the Recognised Body could act and on completing consultation and reaching satisfaction on one of the listed grounds. [#TGT:70b944a0-fca5-4266-8177-4fa3b31f8ea3] [#SRC:46b33967-ebbc-4f36-b86a-689930eb7a5a]
source_text:
Before giving such a direction under Rule 6.5.4, the Regulator shall consult the Recognised Body in question, and the Regulator shall not give a direction unless the Regulator is satisfied, in the light of that consultation that:
(a)	failure to take action would involve undue risk to investors or other participants in the market;
(b)	the direction is necessary having regard to the public interest in the financial stability of the Abu Dhabi Global Market; or
(c)	the direction is necessary to facilitate a proposed or possible use of a power under chapter 16 of COBS or in connection with a particular exercise of a power under that chapter, or Rule 6.5.7(c).
target_text: The Regulator may issue a "positive" direction (to take action) where in any case a Recognised Body has not taken action under its Default Rules, but it appears to the Regulator that the Recognised Body could take action.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a subsequent disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target after having already disclosed under Rule 11.9.1, under what conditions may it omit the assumption and Production Target information otherwise required in the initial Rule 11.9.1 disclosure, and what specific content must have been included in that earlier Rule 11.9.1 disclosure for the cross-reference to be valid?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity may omit the Rule 11.9.2 information in a subsequent disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target only if the subsequent disclosure is explicitly anchored to an earlier Rule 11.9.1 disclosure that itself contained the required assumption and Production Target content, and the subsequent disclosure includes the specified confirmations and warnings. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] For the earlier Rule 11.9.1 disclosure to be a valid reference point, it must have included all material economic assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, any commercially sensitive statement (if applicable) together with an explanation of the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions, and all other material assumptions utilised, as well as the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3). [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In the subsequent disclosure, the Mining Reporting Entity must (i) reference that earlier compliant disclosure, and (ii) confirm that all material assumptions from the initial disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] Additionally, if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, or is based in part on an Exploration Target, the subsequent disclosure must include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement about the forecast financial information corresponding to the relevant statement specified in Rule 11.8.3(5)(d) or Rule 11.8.3(7)(b), respectively. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: When an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM and therefore has an obligation to publish a Prospectus under Section 61 of FSMR, what consequence described in the Regulations may apply if the person making the Prospectus Offer fails to publish information they are required to publish, and how is that information published?
gold_answer: For an Issuer making an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, the offer is within the regime where publishing a Prospectus is an identified obligation (including under Section 61 of FSMR). [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] If, in that Prospectus Offer context, the person making the Prospectus Offer does not publish information that they are required to publish by or under the Regulations, the Regulator has a discretionary power to step in and publish the missing required information. [#TGT:cd1d6043-c316-4559-ad75-ad86cdaeaa9f] The mechanism for that intervention is that the Regulator may publish the information using the manner that is prescribed in the Rules, rather than leaving publication solely to the person making the Prospectus Offer. [#TGT:cd1d6043-c316-4559-ad75-ad86cdaeaa9f] This consequence is relevant to the Issuer’s ADGM public offer scenario because the Prospectus publication obligation is part of the requirements applicable to such Offers of Securities (including those under Sections 58 to 71 of FSMR and Chapter 4 of the Markets Rules ("MKT")), and a failure to publish required information can therefore trigger the Regulator’s publication power. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd]
source_text: Regulatory treatment of tokens deemed to be Securities. The requirements for Offers of Securities fall under Sections 58 to 71 of FSMR and Chapter 4 of the Markets Rules (“MKT”). When an Issuer wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, these requirements include, for example, the obligation to publish a Prospectus under Section 61 of FSMR.
target_text:
Prospectus requirement. Regulator power to publish information
Where a person making a Prospectus Offer fails to publish any information which that person is required to publish by or under these Regulations, the Regulator may publish such information in the manner prescribed in the Rules.

question: If someone is on the list in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, and a buyer of the Securities loses money because the Prospectus had a misleading statement or left out a required material matter, what can that liable person do (and by when) to avoid liability—especially if the problem is about an Expert’s competence or consent?
gold_answer: If a person is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, that person can have to pay compensation to someone who acquired the Securities covered by the Prospectus and suffered loss or damage because the Prospectus contained an untrue or misleading statement or omitted a material matter that was required to be included. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] Even in that setting, the person avoids incurring liability for the loss if, before the Securities were acquired, a correction is published in a way meant to bring it to the attention of people likely to buy those Securities. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] If the issue is a statement attributed to an Expert, the same timing and publication approach can be used by publishing that the Expert was not competent or did not consent to having the attributed statement included in the Prospectus. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] A second route is available: the person can avoid liability if they took all steps that were reasonable to secure that publication and reasonably believed it had happened before the Securities were acquired. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] In short, the compensation risk tied to misleading statements or required omissions is addressed by timely publication (or reasonable efforts and belief of publication) before acquisition. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b]
source_text:
Without prejudice to (2) and (3), a Person does not incur any liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR for any loss in respect of any Securities caused by any statement or omission as is mentioned in that Article if:
(a)	before the Securities were acquired by any Person, a correction or, where the statement was such as is mentioned in (2)(c), the fact that the Expert was not competent or had not consented to the inclusion of the statement attributed to that Expert in the Prospectus had been published in a manner designed to bring to the attention of Persons likely to acquire the Securities in question; or
(b)	he took all such steps as it was reasonable for him to take to secure such publication and believed on reasonable grounds that such a publication had taken place before the Securities were acquired.
target_text: Any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to another person who has acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and who has suffered loss or damage arising from any untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission from it of any material matter required to have been included in the Prospectus by or under these Regulations.

question: When an Authorised Person proposes to conduct a Regulated Activity in relation to a product it describes as a “Spot Commodity,” how should it frame its submission so the Regulator can determine whether the product is an Accepted Spot Commodity, including how the product’s defining features (e.g., prompt delivery and not being a Financial Instrument) connect to the Regulator’s assessment factors (e.g., sustainable sourcing standards and market fundamentals)?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person should present the product in a way that allows the Regulator to confirm it is a “Spot Commodity” and then assess whether it is an “Accepted Spot Commodity” for the intended Regulated Activity. [#TGT:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338] First, the submission should explain how the product fits the FSRA’s characteristics of a Spot Commodity, including that it is a good sold for cash with prompt delivery on settlement, and that it is not a future-dated delivery contract beyond the market’s standard delivery period. [#SRC:34ccda9d-76c5-45f3-af56-56834f25f068] It should also clarify that the product is not a Financial Instrument involving conventional assets (such as Securities or Derivatives) and is not a service or other non-good/intangible item (such as currencies or rights in real estate). [#SRC:34ccda9d-76c5-45f3-af56-56834f25f068] Building on that classification, the Authorised Person should provide information relevant to the Regulator’s acceptance assessment, including its responsible and sustainable sourcing requirements and standards (including adherence to internationally recognised certification standards where applicable), and market fundamentals such as market practice, liquidity, participant base, transparency, and fair and orderly operation. [#TGT:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338] Finally, it should address any other factors the Regulator may consider in deciding whether the Spot Commodity is appropriate for the Authorised Person’s proposed Regulated Activity. [#TGT:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338]

question: If a Listed Entity plans to issue Restricted Securities, does it always have to apply APP 7 restrictions, or can some APP 7 categories be switched off when it qualifies under Rule 2.3.15 or meets the Regulator’s profitability/revenue or tangible-asset test?
gold_answer: The starting point is that a Listed Entity that has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities must apply the restriction in APP 7, unless the Regulator uses its discretion to require different restrictions. [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f] But that baseline obligation is narrowed by a specific carve-out: unless the Regulator decides otherwise, the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply for certain Listed Entities. [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac] To decide what to apply, the entity should check whether it meets any of the carve-out conditions while still recognizing that APP 7 is the default restriction framework for Restricted Securities. [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f] The carve-out applies if the Listed Entity (1) qualifies for admission to the Official List under Rule 2.3.15, or (2) has a track record of profitability or revenue that the Regulator accepts, or (3) in the Regulator’s opinion has tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value that make up a substantial proportion of the total value of its assets—unless the Regulator decides otherwise. [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac] This means the entity may still need to apply other APP 7 restrictions (or other restrictions the Regulator sets), but the listed categories can be disapplied when the conditions are met. [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f] [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]
source_text: Entry into Restriction Agreements and Application of Restriction. Subject to Rule 9.6.2, a Listed Entity which has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities, must apply the restriction in APP 7 or such other restrictions as the Regulator, in its discretion, decides.
target_text:
Entry into Restriction Agreements and Application of Restriction. Unless the Regulator decides otherwise, the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply in relation to a Listed Entity that:
(1)	qualifies for admission to the Official List pursuant to Rule 2.3.15;
(2)	has a track record of profitability or revenue acceptable to the Regulator; or
(3)	in the opinion of the Regulator, has tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value which constitute a substantial proportion of the total value of its assets.

question: If a trader in bond futures buys or borrows a large amount of the bonds and then refuses to re-lend them (or only lends to people they think won’t re-lend), how does that connect to the rule about placing orders or doing trades that can mislead the market or keep prices at an abnormal level when it’s not for legitimate reasons and not in line with Accepted Market Practices?
gold_answer: This bond-futures pattern can fit the rule’s concern where the trader’s transactions or orders are used to influence market conditions in a way that produces a distorted price outcome, and the activity is not for legitimate reasons and not consistent with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] In the example, the trader holds a long position in bond futures, acquires a large quantity of the deliverable bonds by buying or borrowing, and then restricts re-lending (either refusing to re-lend or lending only to parties the trader believes will not re-lend to the market). [#SRC:350b6237-da6f-47c6-b04c-10caf56bf9d7] The stated purpose is to push the delivery price faced by short-position holders to a materially higher level, allowing the trader to profit on the long position. [#SRC:350b6237-da6f-47c6-b04c-10caf56bf9d7] That purpose-and-effect linkage is the “fusion” with the rule: using trading and related actions to secure the price of a Financial Instrument at an abnormal or artificial level is explicitly captured, provided the conduct is otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] Put simply, the example supplies the concrete mechanism (restricting bond availability to raise the delivery price), and the rule supplies the legal characterization test (abnormal/artificial price secured through non-legitimate, non-accepted-market-practice transactions or orders). [#SRC:350b6237-da6f-47c6-b04c-10caf56bf9d7] [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f]
source_text:
Abusive squeezes. The following are specific examples of an abusive squeeze that, in the Regulator's view, may contravene section 92 (4)(b):
(a)	during the course of a trading day on a Commodity Derivative Exchange, a trader rapidly builds up a position of more than 90% of the physical inventory underlying a crude oil contract.  The trader fails to Offer to lend the crude oil back to other market participants at a reasonable commercial rate.  The trader then unwinds his position in the Exchange's final settlement window  at rapidly increasing prices, thereby cornering/squeezing the crude oil market.  His conduct causes an abnormal movement in the price of crude oil contracts for forward month delivery; and
(b)	a trader with a long position in bond futures, buys or borrows a large amount of the bonds and either refuses to re-lend these bonds or will only lend them to parties he believes will not re-lend to the market.  His purpose is to position the price at which persons with short positions have to deliver to satisfy their obligations at a materially higher level, making him a profit on his position.
target_text:
The third is where the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade (otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market) which—
(a)	give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to the supply of, or demand for, or as to the price of, one or more Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; or
(b)	secure the price of one or more such instruments at an abnormal or artificial level.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity publishes forecast financial information and that forecast is based on a Production Target, what information must it include about the assumptions and the Production Target, especially if the economic assumptions are commercially sensitive or if the Production Target uses Inferred Mineral Resources or an Exploration Target?
gold_answer: If a Mining Reporting Entity’s forecast financial information is derived from a Production Target, its disclosure must include the Production Target that the forecast is derived from, and it must also include the required information that accompanies a Production Target disclosure [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. On assumptions, it must disclose all material economic assumptions and all other material assumptions used; if it considers the material economic assumptions commercially sensitive, it must say so and explain the methodology used to determine those assumptions [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] and [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. For the Production Target itself, it must state whether forecast commodity prices were used and, if they were, confirm those forecast prices were arrived at on reasonable grounds. It must also break down the proportions of the Production Target based on Ore Reserves, Mineral Resources (including Inferred Mineral Resources), and any Exploration Target, and include the required prominent cautionary statements and related explanations where the Production Target is wholly or partly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or partly based on an Exploration Target, including the additional support requirements when it is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a].
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: How should an Authorised Person determine whether its Financial Services Permission places it in Category 2 versus Category 3C, where it is authorised for Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal) and also has permissions that could include Managing Assets, Managing a Collective Investment Fund, Providing Custody (other than for a Fund), Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAr, Providing Trust Services as trustee of at least one express trust, or Providing Money Services? In particular, how do the respective exclusion tests against other Categories and the scope limitation condition for dealing affect the classification outcome?
gold_answer: To classify an Authorised Person, start with what its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on and then apply the category-specific conditions and exclusions. Category 2 applies where the permission authorises Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal), the dealing activities are not limited in scope in the specified way, and the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5 [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f]. By contrast, Category 3C applies where the permission authorises one or more of the listed activities (including Managing Assets, Managing a Collective Investment Fund, Providing Custody other than for a Fund, managing a PSIAr, Providing Trust Services as trustee of at least one express trust, or Providing Money Services) and the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B or 5 [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0]. Accordingly, if the firm satisfies the Category 2 conditions, it is excluded from Category 3C by Category 3C’s express “does not meet Category 2” requirement; if it does not satisfy Category 2 (including because the dealing scope condition is not met), it may fall within Category 3C if it meets the listed-activity limb and the broader exclusion set.
target_text:
An Authorised Person is in Category 2 if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal);
(b)	its dealing activities are not limited in scope as provided in Rule 1.3.3(1)(a)(i); and
(c)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5.
Category 3A
Guidance
A Category 3A Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Agent and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1 and 1.3.2 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3A. Provided that an Authorised Person carries out the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Agent in a manner that is wholly incidental to the activity of Managing an Investment Fund or Managing Assets, the Authorised Person shall be regarded as falling within Category 3C.

question: If an Authorised Person needs to work out RWA for both securitisation Exposures and Early Amortisation Exposures, what steps do they follow for each, and what do they add together at the end?
gold_answer: For securitisation Exposures, an Authorised Person must (1) calculate the Exposure value for each SE Exposure using the required exposure measurement methodology and taking into account any applicable CRM, (2) allocate an applicable Credit Quality Grade for that SE Exposure, and (3) calculate the RWA for each SE Exposure using the given formula (Exposure value times the applicable risk weight), except where the SE Exposure must be treated as a deduction from a component of Capital Resources rather than included in RWA [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646]. For Early Amortisation Exposures, it must (1) calculate the Exposure value (EAE) for each Early Amortisation Exposure using the same exposure measurement methodology and CRM recognition, (2) calculate RWA(EAE) using the formula EAE times CRW, where CRW is the risk weight for the underlying Exposure type as if it had not been securitised, and (3) add up the RWA(EAE) amounts across all Early Amortisation Exposures [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e]. At the end, it adds the SE Exposure RWA amounts (for those not deducted) to the Early Amortisation RWA amounts to reach the combined RWA figure.
target_text:
Calculation of RWA for securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures). To calculate its RWA for Early Amortisation Exposures, an Authorised Person must:
(a)	calculate the value of the Exposure (EAE) for each of its Early Amortisation Exposures in accordance with Exposure measurement methodology specified in Section 4.9 and recognising the effects of any applicable CRM;
(b)	calculate the risk weighted Exposure amount for each Early Amortisation Exposure using the following formula: RWA(EAE) = EAE x CRW
where:
(i)	"RWA(EAE)" refers to the risk weighted Exposure amount for that Early Amortisation Exposure;
(ii)	"EAE" refers to the Exposure value or amount, for that Early Amortisation Exposure calculated in accordance with (a); and
(iii)	"CRW" refers to the applicable risk weight for the underlying Exposure type as if the Exposure had not been securitised; and
(c)	add the RWA amounts calculated in accordance with (b) for all its Early Amortisation Exposures.

question: An Authorised Person must deduct defined benefit pension fund assets when working out CET1 Capital. How can the Authorised Person reduce the amount it deducts if there is a deferred tax liability linked to those assets, or if it can use some of the pension fund assets after giving advance notice to the Regulator?
gold_answer: In the CET1 Capital calculation, an Authorised Person is required to deduct defined benefit pension fund assets as one of the specified CET1 deductions [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]. But the amount of defined benefit pension fund assets that must be deducted is not necessarily the gross asset amount: it must be reduced by certain amounts that are directly tied to those pension fund assets [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada]. One reduction is for any associated deferred tax liability, but only to the extent that the liability could be extinguished if the pension fund assets became impaired or were derecognised under the International Financial Reporting Standards [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada]. A second reduction is available for assets in the defined benefit pension fund that the Authorised Person has an unrestricted ability to use, provided it has given the Regulator adequate advance notification of its intention to use those assets [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada]. Any assets used to reduce the deduction must then receive a risk weight in accordance with Chapter 4 [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada].
source_text:
CET1 Deductions - defined benefit pension fund assets. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(d), the amount of defined benefit pension fund assets to be deducted from CET1 Capital must be reduced by the following:
(a)	the amount of any associated deferred tax liability which could be extinguished if the assets became impaired or were derecognised under the International Financial Reporting Standards; and
(b)	the amount of assets in the defined benefit pension fund which the Authorised Person has an unrestricted ability to use where the Authorised Person has provided adequate advance notification of its intention to use those assets to the Regulator. Those assets used to reduce the amount to be deducted must receive a risk weight in accordance with Chapter 4 of these Rules.

question: If an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and wants to count that Collateral when measuring the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure, what must it do in the Non Trading Book and what must it do in the Trading Book?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined under the specified measurement basis, the firm is allowed to recognise the effect of that Collateral (so it can reflect the Collateral’s effect in the exposure measurement) in line with the recognition framework referenced in the permission [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778]. But the way it must recognise that effect depends on where the SFT sits. For any SFT in the Non Trading Book, the Authorised Person must use either the FCSA or the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral, must use the same chosen approach consistently across the entire Non Trading Book, and must not mix the two approaches in that book [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412]. For any pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT in the Trading Book, the Authorised Person must only use the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412].
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.
target_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person must use either the FCSA or the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral for any SFT in the Non Trading Book. The Authorised Person must apply the chosen approach consistently to the entire Non Trading Book and must not use a combination of both approaches. For a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from any SFT in the Trading Book, an Authorised Person must only use the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity’s forecast financial information for an operating mine comes from a Production Target that is wholly based on Ore Reserves (or Ore Reserves plus Measured Mineral Resources, and any Indicated Mineral Resources are not what makes the project viable), what does it still have to include in its disclosure about assumptions and the Production Target itself?
gold_answer: If the forecast financial information derived from a Production Target relating to an operating mine(s) is wholly based on Ore Reserves, or on the permitted combinations involving Measured Mineral Resources (and Indicated Mineral Resources only where they are not the determining factor in project viability), then the SOURCE states that a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity is not required to comply with the particular compliance requirement identified there [#SRC:bf5c6652-b4c7-4b61-8732-68aed56e52a7]. However, when the Mining Reporting Entity is making a disclosure pursuant to the TARGET provision, that disclosure must still contain specific content: it must include all material economic assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information; if the Mining Reporting Entity considers those material economic assumptions commercially sensitive, it must say so and explain the methodology used to determine them; and it must include all other material assumptions utilised [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. In addition, the disclosure must include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including the information referenced as being contained with it) [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489].
source_text:
A disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity is not required to comply with Rule 11.9.2 where the forecast financial information derived from a Production Target relating to an operating mine(s) is wholly based on:
(1)	Ore Reserves;
(2)	a combination of Ore Reserves and Measured Mineral Resources; or
(3)	a combination of Ore Reserves; and
(a)	Measured Mineral Resources; and/or
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources, provided that the Indicated Mineral Resources are not the determining factor in project viability.
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: When may the deferred publication of information about a transaction be authorised, and how is the applicable delay and minimum qualifying size determined by reference to the Financial Instrument’s average daily turnover classification?
gold_answer: Deferred publication of information in respect of a transaction may be authorised only where the transaction meets the eligibility criteria and the requested deferral does not exceed the maximum permitted delay applicable to the relevant Financial Instrument and transaction type [#SRC:d4233e73-f88e-4a70-8ab9-b5f982f14d48]. The transaction must be between a Member (or, if applicable, an Authorised Person) dealing on own account and a Client of that firm, and the transaction size must be equal to or exceed the relevant minimum qualifying size for the applicable delay [#SRC:d4233e73-f88e-4a70-8ab9-b5f982f14d48]. The relevant minimum qualifying size and the permitted delay are determined by classifying the Financial Instrument by its average daily turnover (ADT) and then applying the corresponding threshold for the chosen delay from the ADT-based table [#TGT:096764ad-3a3c-4347-9345-61ad740d7e27]. The table links each permitted delay (e.g., 60 minutes, 180 minutes, end of trading day, or later trading-day deferrals) to a minimum qualifying transaction size that varies by ADT band, including formula-based thresholds expressed as percentages of ADT with minimums or caps [#TGT:096764ad-3a3c-4347-9345-61ad740d7e27].
source_text:
Deferred publication of large transactions
The deferred publication of information in respect of transactions may be authorised, for a period no longer than the period specified in Rule ‎3.6.10 for the class of Financial Instrument and transaction concerned, provided the following criteria are satisfied:
(a)	the transaction is between a Member or if applicable, Authorised Person, dealing on own account and a Client of that firm; and
(b)	the size of that transaction is equal to or exceeds the relevant minimum qualifying size, as specified in Rule 3.6.10. In order to determine the relevant minimum qualifying size, all Financial Instruments admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange shall be classified in accordance with their average daily turnover to be calculated in accordance with Rule 3.6.10.
target_text:

The table below shows, for each permitted delay for publication and each class of Financial Instrument in terms of average daily turnover (ADT), the minimum qualifying size of transaction that will qualify for that delay in respect of a Financial Instrument of that type.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a subsequent disclosure that refers back to previously disclosed Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, what must it include to rely on the “first time only” application of Rule 11.12.1, and how does that interact with the Competent Person statement elements required in a disclosure containing those items?
gold_answer: To rely on Rule 11.12.1 applying only to the first disclosure, the Mining Reporting Entity’s later disclosure must (i) point readers to the earlier disclosure that complied with Rule 11.12.1 and (ii) include a confirmation that the entity is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects what was included previously; for Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves estimates, it must also confirm that the material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning those estimates still apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:9819bc20-c088-4225-b398-fd241c8b322d] In addition, where the later disclosure itself contains Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves (or Exploration Targets), it must include a Competent Person statement that the disclosure is based on and fairly represents information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s). [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] That statement must also specify, for each Competent Person, whether they are an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party, and if not, identify the Competent Person’s employer. [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] Finally, it must name the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member. [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] Together, the cross-reference/confirmation conditions support the “first time only” treatment, while the Competent Person statement elements govern what must be stated in any disclosure that contains the relevant technical content. [#SRC:9819bc20-c088-4225-b398-fd241c8b322d] [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203]
source_text:
Competent Persons . Rule 11.12.1 only applies the first time a Mining Reporting Entity discloses Exploration Results in accordance with Rule 11.4 or original or updated estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with Rules 11.5 or 11.6 provided that:
(1)	any subsequent disclosure that refers to those Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with Rule 11.12.1; and
(2)	the Mining Reporting Entity confirms in the subsequent disclosure that it is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects the information included in the earlier disclosure(s) and, in the case of estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, that all material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the estimates in the earlier disclosure(s) continue to apply and have not materially changed.
target_text:
Competent Persons . Subject to Rule 11.12.2, a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity containing Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves must state:
(1)	that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s);
(2)	in each case, whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer; and
(3)	in each case, the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.

question: When a Reporting Entity requests a Trading Halt or Suspension from the Listing Authority to obtain time to prepare and release a Disclosure of Inside Information, what information will the Listing Authority usually require the Reporting Entity to provide, and in what types of Disclosure-management circumstances might a Trading Halt or Suspension be considered necessary (including how the RIE’s trading status affects that assessment)?
gold_answer: A Reporting Entity seeking a Trading Halt or Suspension to gain time to prepare and release a Disclosure of Inside Information should expect the Listing Authority to require specific contextual details, and the Listing Authority will then decide whether the situation justifies the halt/suspension. [#SRC:22a51628-c5c0-43b8-b062-2c8145b3a2c6] In practice, the Listing Authority will usually ask the Reporting Entity to outline: the nature of the Inside Information, why the Trading Halt or Suspension is being requested, what event is expected to end it, and the intended scope and timing for releasing the Disclosure. [#SRC:22a51628-c5c0-43b8-b062-2c8145b3a2c6] Those inputs are assessed against circumstances where a Trading Halt or Suspension may be necessary to manage Disclosure issues, including where confidentiality appears to have been lost ahead of Disclosure and the information is having (or, if the RIE is not yet open, is likely to have when it opens) a significant price effect. [#TGT:4bdd6d36-6949-4aeb-9161-1eead5b4cfb9] It may also be necessary if the Listing Authority has asked the Reporting Entity to correct or prevent a false market, or if the Inside Information is particularly significant and likely to move the price materially (with examples such as a significant capital raising, a board decision to appoint an administrator, or winning approval for a one-off contract that substantially changes scale and activities). [#TGT:4bdd6d36-6949-4aeb-9161-1eead5b4cfb9] The RIE’s status matters: if the market is open and the Reporting Entity cannot disclose immediately, or if the market is not open and the Reporting Entity cannot disclose before the RIE opens, that timing constraint supports the need for a halt/suspension. [#TGT:4bdd6d36-6949-4aeb-9161-1eead5b4cfb9]
target_text:
IMMEDIATELY
Use of a Trading Halt or Suspension to manage Disclosure issues
A Trading Halt or Suspension may, however, be necessary in the following circumstances:

a)	there are indications that the Inside Information has lost its confidentiality ahead of a Disclosure (see Rule 7.2.2(2)), and it is having, or (where the RIE upon which the Listed Entity’s Securities are admitted to trading is not yet open for trading) is likely to have, when the RIE opens for trading, a significant effect on the price of the Listed Entity’s Securities;

b)	the Reporting Entity has been asked by the Listing Authority to correct or prevent a false market;  or

c)	the information is particularly significant Inside Information and likely to cause a significant movement in the price of the Listed Entity’s Securities (for example, Inside Information relating to a significant capital raising, the Board of the Listed Entity resolving to appoint an administrator, or that the Listed Entity is to win approval for a one-off contract that will substantially change the scale and activities of the Listed Entity);

and in circumstances where the RIE’s market is:

d)	open for trading in the Listed Entity’s Securities, the Reporting Entity is not in a position to make the Disclosure immediately; or

e)	not open for trading in the Listed Entity’s Securities, the Reporting Entity will not be in a position to make the Disclosure before the RIE opens for trading.

question: Where an Authorised Person is operating an MTF using Virtual Assets and wishes to also operate a Recognised Investment Exchange, how should the firm structure its authorisation/recognition so it can continue operating the MTF, and what is the compliance consequence for the MTF function once the Recognition Order includes the relevant stipulation?
gold_answer: To continue operating an MTF while also operating as a Recognised Investment Exchange, the firm must ensure that the Recognition Order expressly permits the additional MTF function, and it must manage the transition in status/permissions accordingly. An Authorised Person that is operating an MTF and seeks to also operate a Recognised Investment Exchange is required to relinquish its FSP upon obtaining the Recognition Order to operate as a Recognised Investment Exchange. [#SRC:16e6290e-4660-4e38-9618-89de6a251764] If the FSRA licenses the firm to carry out both activities (operating an MTF and operating a Recognised Investment Exchange), the Recognition Order should contain a stipulation reflecting that dual permission (referenced as being pursuant to MIR Rule 3.4.1). [#SRC:16e6290e-4660-4e38-9618-89de6a251764] In parallel, a Recognised Investment Exchange may only carry on the Regulated Activity of operating an MTF (or OTF) where its Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting it to do so. [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388] Once that stipulation is present, the specific COBS rules on MTFs and OTFs apply to the MTF/OTF function, and they apply only to that function rather than to the Recognised Investment Exchange’s other activities. [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388]
source_text:
MULTILATERAL TRADING FACILITIES AND VIRTUAL ASSETS
Recognised Investment Exchanges Operating an MTF using Virtual Assets
Authorised Persons that are operating an MTF wishing to also operate a Recognised Investment Exchange will be required to relinquish their FSP upon obtaining a Recognition Order (to operate a Recognised Investment Exchange).  If licensed by the FSRA to carry out both activities (e.g., operating an MTF and operating a Recognised Investment Exchange), the relevant Recognition Order will include a stipulation to that effect pursuant to MIR Rule 3.4.1 - see paragraph 135 above).
target_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange may carry on the Regulated Activity of operating an MTF or OTF provided that its Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting it to do so. If it does include such a stipulation, the specific rules on MTFs and OTFs in COBS will apply to that function, but that function only.

question: When the Regulator is considering issuing a “negative” direction to a Recognised Body that has not taken action under its Default Rules but appears to be proposing to take or may take action, what consultation step and satisfaction threshold must be met before the direction can be given, and what are the permissible bases for that satisfaction?
gold_answer: If the Regulator is contemplating a “negative” direction (i.e., a direction not to take action) in a situation where a Recognised Body has not acted under its Default Rules but seems to be proposing to act or may act, the Regulator must first consult the Recognised Body concerned before giving the direction. [#TGT:380d251f-0ce7-47ae-9d49-d8e2e45a9c8e] [#SRC:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3] Following that consultation, the Regulator is prohibited from giving the direction unless it is satisfied—based on the consultation—that at least one specified justification applies. [#SRC:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3] Those permissible bases are: (a) taking action would be premature or otherwise undesirable in the interests of investors or other market participants; (b) the direction is necessary in light of the public interest in the financial stability of the Abu Dhabi Global Market; or (c) the direction is necessary to facilitate a proposed or possible use of a power under chapter 16 of COBS, or in connection with a particular exercise of a power under that Part. [#SRC:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3] In practice, the “negative” direction scenario supplies the factual trigger (no Default Rules action yet, but potential action is contemplated), while the consultation and satisfaction tests govern whether the Regulator may proceed to issue the direction at all. [#TGT:380d251f-0ce7-47ae-9d49-d8e2e45a9c8e] [#SRC:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3]
source_text:
Before giving a direction under Rule 6.5.6, the Regulator shall consult the Recognised Body in question, and the Regulator shall not give a direction unless the Regulator is satisfied, in the light of that consultation that:
(a)	the taking of action would be premature or otherwise undesirable in the interests of investors or other participants in the market;
(b)	the direction is necessary having regard to the public interest in the financial stability of the Abu Dhabi Global Market; or
(c)	the direction is necessary to facilitate a proposed or possible use of a power under chapter 16 of COBS or in connection with a particular exercise of a power under that Part.
target_text: The Regulator may issue a "negative" direction (not to take action) where in any case a Recognised Body has not taken action under its Default Rules, but it appears to the Regulator that the Recognised Body is proposing to take or may take action.

question: When performing a business risk assessment that specifically covers the carrying on of NFTF business and the use of eKYC Systems, what must a Relevant Person do to identify and assess the full scope of money laundering-related risks and vulnerabilities, and how should it incorporate mitigation measures identified by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, or other relevant bodies into day-to-day operations?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person conducting a business risk assessment that addresses NFTF business and the use of eKYC Systems must both (i) identify and assess the money laundering risks its business faces and (ii) ensure the assessment is operationalised through mitigation in day-to-day activities, while considering relevant external mitigation measures. [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851] The assessment should explicitly cover risks associated with carrying on NFTF business, with particular attention to the use of eKYC Systems. [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2] In identifying and assessing risk, it must take appropriate steps that reflect the nature, size and complexity of its activities, and treat money laundering risk as including terrorist financing, proliferation financing, the financing of unlawful organisations, and sanctions non-compliance (including non-compliance with Targeted Financial Sanctions). [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851] It must also consider, to the extent relevant, vulnerabilities tied to customer types, geographies, products and services, distribution channels and partners, transaction complexity/volume, new products and practices, and the use of new or developing technologies—linking this technology lens to eKYC Systems used in NFTF business. [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851] The assessment should consider incorporating any relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and other relevant bodies, and the Relevant Person must take appropriate measures so identified risks are mitigated in operations, including for new products, new customers, and changes to its business profile. [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2] [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]
source_text: A business risk assessment under Rule ‎6.1.1(b) should include an assessment of the risks associated with the carrying on of NFTF business, particularly the use of eKYC Systems. The assessment should consider incorporating any relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and any other relevant bodies.

question: If someone managing a holding lock under Rule 9.6.9 wants the Regulator to let Restricted Securities holders take part in a Takeover (by accepting an offer or transferring/cancelling Securities), what does the offer have to cover, what level of acceptance is needed from non-Restricted Securities holders, and when do the parties have to agree in writing to put the holding lock back on?
gold_answer: A party managing a holding lock in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 can ask the Regulator to allow the holding lock to be released so holders of Restricted Securities can accept an offer, or transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover. [#TGT:12178c65-d1b6-440a-91e1-c670c7d9ab67] The Regulator will only provide consent if the applicable conditions are met for the way the Takeover is being done. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] If the Takeover involves an offer for Securities, the offer must be for all of the Ordinary Securities, or (if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities) for all Securities in the same class as the Restricted Securities. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] Also, at least half of the holders of the Securities that are not Restricted Securities (and that the offer relates to) must have accepted the offer. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] If the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder must agree in writing that the holding lock imposed under Rule 9.6.9 is immediately re-imposed for each Security the offeror does not buy. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] If the Takeover is done by a scheme, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity must agree in writing to immediately re-impose the holding lock if the Takeover does not take effect. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd]
source_text:
Regulator’s consent to sale of Restricted Securities in a Takeover or Merger. The Regulator will not provide its consent under Rule 9.6.11 unless, to the extent to which they are applicable, all the following requirements are met:
(1)	where there is an offer for Securities:
(a)	the offer is for all of the Ordinary Securities or, if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities, all the Securities in the same class as the Restricted Securities;
(b)	holders of at least half of the Securities that are not Restricted Securities, to which the offer relates, have accepted; and
(c)	if the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder agree in writing that the holding lock (imposed under Rule 9.6.9) be immediately re-imposed for each Security that is not bought by the offeror under the offer; and
(2)	where the offer is to be conducted by way of a ‘scheme’, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity in which the Restricted Securities are held agree in writing that the holding lock imposed under Rule 9.6.9 be immediately re-imposed if the Takeover does not take effect.
target_text: Regulator’s consent to sale of Restricted Securities in a Takeover or Merger. The Regulator may consent to a party that is managing a holding lock in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 releasing the holding lock, to enable holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer, or transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover.

question: Where an Issuer is seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF and intends to run a simultaneous Exempt Offer, how can it combine the 200-person limit for non-Professional Clients with an additional Exempt Offer category, and which Exempt Offer circumstance is expressly not available for that combined approach?
