gold_answer: An Issuer seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF can structure a simultaneous Exempt Offer by using the specific MTF-related circumstance that permits an offer to be directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients, and at the same time relying on another Exempt Offer circumstance for a different investor segment. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] The 200-person limb aligns with the prescribed Exempt Offer circumstance for an offer in or from the ADGM directed at no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients (and not Market Counterparties), where the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] In addition, the Issuer may pair that 200-person offer with an Exempt Offer made only to Professional Clients (i.e., an unlimited number of Professional Clients), thereby separating the non-Professional Client cap from the Professional Client tranche. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] However, when using the MTF admission pathway and combining Exempt Offer circumstances in this way, the Issuer is expressly not permitted to rely on the circumstance identified as MKT Rule 4.3.1(2), even though other Exempt Offer circumstances may be used. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]
source_text: MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) provides for the specific circumstance where an Exempt Offer can be directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients, where the Securities are to be admitted to trading on a MTF.  An Issuer seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF in accordance with MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) may also, pursuant to MKT Rule 4.3.3, utilise an Exempt Offer that relies on one or more of the circumstances within MKT Rule 4.3.1, with the exception of MKT Rule 4.3.1(2).  For example, an Issuer may make a simultaneous Exempt Offer to 200 Persons under MKT rule 4.3.1(13), and an unlimited number of Professional Clients under MKT Rule 4.3.1(1).

question: If a Recognised Body is not meeting the Recognition Requirements, when would the Regulator tell it to take steps (like letting the Regulator inspect its premises or pausing activities) instead of moving to revoke the Recognition Order, and what time-based business inactivity situations can also lead to revocation?
gold_answer: The Regulator can direct a Recognised Body to take specified steps to secure compliance with the Recognition Requirements, but it will usually consider revoking the Recognition Order in defined situations where directions are not enough or not suitable. [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500] Directions can require practical measures such as giving the Regulator access to the Recognised Body’s premises to inspect the premises or documents there, and suspending the carrying on of any activity for a period set out in the direction. [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500] However, revocation is usually considered if the Recognised Body is failing or has failed to satisfy one or more Recognition Requirements and that failure has or will have serious consequences. [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a] Revocation is also usually considered if it would not be possible for the Recognised Body to comply with a direction, or if (for some other reason) it would not be appropriate for the Regulator to give a direction. [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a] In addition, the Regulator will usually consider revocation where the Recognised Body has not carried on the business of a Recognised Body during the 12 months beginning when the Recognition Order took effect, or where it has not carried on that business at any time during the six months ending on the day the Recognition Order is revoked. [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a]
target_text: The Regulator has the power to give directions to a Recognised Body to take specified steps in order to secure its compliance with the Recognition Requirements. Those steps may include granting the Regulator access to the Recognised Body's premises for the purposes of inspecting those premises or any documents on the premises and the suspension of the carrying on of any activity by the Recognised Body for the period specified in the direction.

question: Can the Regulator choose to publish a decision notice or final notice (and details about the case), and what happens if a person takes the decision to the Appeals Panel?
gold_answer: Yes. The Regulator is permitted to publish a decision notice, final notice, or another notice linked to the exercise of the Regulator’s powers, along with details about the matter the notice relates to, as long as it is not a warning notice. This is described as a discretionary power: publication may occur at the Regulator’s discretion, rather than being automatic in every case. The SOURCE then explains how that discretion is expected to be applied in a particular situation: if a person uses their right to refer a decision to the Appeals Panel, the Regulator will publish appropriate information about that decision, and this publication will include the notice itself. Taken together, the TARGET provides the general permission and scope of what may be published (types of notices and related details), while the SOURCE adds the practical outcome for Appeals Panel referrals, indicating that publication will follow in that scenario and will cover both the notice and suitable information about the decision. [#SRC:9ddabd85-89c9-44a4-a291-0388531f1314] [#TGT:de87bb07-107e-4bc3-a834-8f7457702841]
source_text: Under section 252(3) of FSMR, we have the discretion to publish a decision notice, final notice or any other notice in relation to the exercise of our powers (other than a warning notice), and details about the matter to which the notice relates. Therefore, if a person exercises their right to refer a decision to the Appeals Panel, we will publish appropriate information about that decision, including the notice itself.
target_text: A decision notice, final notice or any other notice in relation to the exercise of the Regulator's powers (other than a warning notice), and details about the matter to which such notice relates, may be published by the Regulator at its discretion.

question: When an Authorised Person calculates RWA across its securitisation Exposures and its Early Amortisation Exposures, what is the required sequence of calculations for exposure value, risk weight selection, and aggregation, and how do the two calculation streams connect in the final RWA total?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must run two linked calculation streams and then aggregate them. For securitisation Exposures, it must first calculate the Exposure value for each SE Exposure using the specified exposure measurement methodology and recognising any applicable CRM, then allocate an applicable Credit Quality Grade for that SE Exposure, and then calculate the RWA amount for each SE Exposure using the stated formula (Exposure value multiplied by the applicable risk weight), except where an SE Exposure must instead be included as a deduction from a component of Capital Resources [#SRC:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646]. Separately, for Early Amortisation Exposures, it must calculate the Exposure value (EAE) for each Early Amortisation Exposure using the same exposure measurement methodology and CRM recognition, then compute RWA(EAE) as EAE multiplied by a CRW that is based on the underlying Exposure type as if it had not been securitised, and then add together the RWA(EAE) amounts for all such exposures [#TGT:c5c200a7-54bd-4b42-be55-48c29398129e]. The connection is that the SE Exposure RWAs (computed where not deducted) are added to the RWA amounts calculated for Early Amortisation Exposures to form the combined RWA total.
target_text:
Calculation of RWA for securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures). To calculate its RWA for Early Amortisation Exposures, an Authorised Person must:
(a)	calculate the value of the Exposure (EAE) for each of its Early Amortisation Exposures in accordance with Exposure measurement methodology specified in Section 4.9 and recognising the effects of any applicable CRM;
(b)	calculate the risk weighted Exposure amount for each Early Amortisation Exposure using the following formula: RWA(EAE) = EAE x CRW
where:
(i)	"RWA(EAE)" refers to the risk weighted Exposure amount for that Early Amortisation Exposure;
(ii)	"EAE" refers to the Exposure value or amount, for that Early Amortisation Exposure calculated in accordance with (a); and
(iii)	"CRW" refers to the applicable risk weight for the underlying Exposure type as if the Exposure had not been securitised; and
(c)	add the RWA amounts calculated in accordance with (b) for all its Early Amortisation Exposures.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses Exploration Results or original or updated estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves for the first time, what Competent Person statements must it include, and what must it do in later disclosures that refer back to those same results or estimates to remain within the limited first-time application?
gold_answer: For the first disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity of Exploration Results or original or updated estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, the disclosure must include the required Competent Person statements: it must state that the disclosure is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s); it must state for each Competent Person whether they are an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, identify the Competent Person’s employer; and it must state the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203]. The scope limitation is that this Competent Person compliance framework is intended to apply only the first time the Mining Reporting Entity makes such a disclosure, provided that any later disclosure that refers to those Exploration Results or estimates references the earlier compliant disclosure and confirms it is not aware of new information or data that materially affects the earlier disclosure; for Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, it must also confirm the material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the earlier estimates continue to apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:9819bc20-c088-4225-b398-fd241c8b322d].
source_text:
Competent Persons . Rule 11.12.1 only applies the first time a Mining Reporting Entity discloses Exploration Results in accordance with Rule 11.4 or original or updated estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with Rules 11.5 or 11.6 provided that:
(1)	any subsequent disclosure that refers to those Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with Rule 11.12.1; and
(2)	the Mining Reporting Entity confirms in the subsequent disclosure that it is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects the information included in the earlier disclosure(s) and, in the case of estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, that all material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the estimates in the earlier disclosure(s) continue to apply and have not materially changed.
target_text:
Competent Persons . Subject to Rule 11.12.2, a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity containing Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves must state:
(1)	that it is based on, and fairly represents, information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s);
(2)	in each case, whether the Competent Person is an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party and, if not, the name of the Competent Person’s employer; and
(3)	in each case, the name of the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member.

question: If a Listed Entity does not fully follow APP 4, what does it have to say in its annual financial report about the reasons and what it did instead, and what does the Regulator expect to be disclosed in the Prospectus and then later on?
gold_answer: When a Listed Entity has not fully adopted, or has only partially adopted, the best practice standards in APP 4, its annual financial report must clearly state whether APP 4 has been adopted and, if not fully, explain the reasons for the shortfall and describe what actions, if any, it has taken to achieve compliance to the extent the standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e]. The Regulator’s expectation complements this by focusing on disclosure continuity: if a Reporting Entity does not adopt APP 4 (or adopts it only partially), the Regulator expects the reasons and any alternative measures adopted to achieve the intended outcomes of the Corporate Governance Principles to be disclosed in the Prospectus and then continued thereafter through the applicable ongoing disclosure process [#SRC:ff5bac8d-3dc7-46dd-a9ce-b0c32a42422e]. Together, these requirements mean the entity should provide consistent explanations and descriptions of substitute measures across both the initial Prospectus disclosure and the later annual reporting cycle, so stakeholders can understand both why APP 4 was not fully followed and how the entity is still working toward the governance outcomes.
source_text: Generally, if a Reporting Entity does not adopt the best practice standards set out in APP 4, or adopts them only partially, the Regulator would expect the reasons for doing so and any alternative measures adopted to achieve the outcomes intended by the Corporate Governance Principles to be disclosed in the Prospectus and thereafter pursuant to the Disclosure required under Rule 9.2.10. Any inaccurate or false representations would lead to the imposition of civil liability in accordance with section 70 of the FSMR.
target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: When an Authorised Person conducts periodic stress tests for securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures, what specific scope elements must be covered to ensure the tests address both the firm-wide impact in stressed market conditions and the risk that pipeline transactions may not complete, including where securitisation is intended as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person’s periodic stress testing must be structured to cover both (i) the required activity/exposure perimeter and (ii) the stressed-scenario impacts and transaction-completion risks that arise across the firm. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] In scope, the stress tests must relate to the Authorised Person’s securitisation activities and its off balance sheet Exposures, and must also test the future ability to transact securitisation when it is used as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] Within that perimeter, the tests must consider the firm wide impact of securitisation activities and Exposures under stressed market conditions and assess the implications for other sources of risk, so the analysis is not limited to the securitisation book in isolation. [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97] The stress tests must include both existing securitisation Exposures and transactions in the pipeline, explicitly reflecting the risk that pipeline transactions may fail to complete in a stressed market scenario. [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97] Together, these elements ensure the stress testing addresses ongoing and prospective securitisation capacity (including CRM/liquidity use) while capturing firm-wide stressed impacts and pipeline execution risk. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97]
source_text: The periodic stress testing in relation to securitisation activities referred to in Rule 4.14.5 should consider the firm wide impact of those activities and Exposures in stressed market conditions and the implications for other sources of risk. Such stress tests should include both existing securitisation Exposures and transactions in the pipeline, as there is a risk of the pipeline transactions not being completed in a stressed market scenario.
target_text: Systems and controls for the use of securitisations. An Authorised Person must conduct periodic stress tests in relation to its securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures, including testing of future ability to transact securitisation as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes.

question: Where a Fund Manager identifies a material change, error, or omission after making the notification under Rule 3.1.2 but before Promotion begins in a Host Jurisdiction, what are the Fund Manager’s immediate notification duties, what must the Regulator do with that information, and how can that same type of issue lead to the Regulator taking measures up to de-registration if it results in non-compliance?
gold_answer: Between the notification under Rule 3.1.2 and the start of Promotion in a Host Jurisdiction, the Fund Manager must notify the Regulator in writing without delay if it becomes aware of any material change, error, or omission that is reasonably likely to be relevant to that notification. [#TGT:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6] After receiving that notice, the Regulator must promptly pass all relevant details of the material change, error, or omission to the relevant Host Regulator. [#TGT:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6] Separately, if a material change, error, or omission of the type referred to in Rule 3.1.9 results in the Fund Manager no longer complying with applicable legislation (including these Rules), the Regulator is required to take all due measures. [#SRC:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207] Those measures can include, where necessary, de-registering the Private Fund from the Register of Passported Funds in accordance with these Rules, and the Regulator may also act where it otherwise considers action necessary and appropriate in the circumstances. [#SRC:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207] In practice, the Fund Manager’s prompt written notice during the pre-Promotion window enables the Regulator’s onward communication to the Host Regulator while also informing whether the issue triggers due measures for non-compliance, potentially up to de-registration. [#TGT:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6] [#SRC:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207]
source_text: If, as a result of any material change, error, or omission referred to in Rule 3.1.9, the Fund Manager will no longer comply with applicable legislation, including these Rules, or if the Regulator otherwise considers it necessary and appropriate in the circumstances, the Regulator shall take all due measures, including, if necessary, the de-registration of the Private Fund from the Register of Passported Funds in accordance with these Rules.
target_text: If, at any time between the notification pursuant to Rule 3.1.2 and the commencement of Promotion in a Host Jurisdiction, the Fund Manager becomes aware of any material change, error, or omission reasonably likely to be relevant to such notification, the Fund Manager shall give written notice to the Regulator without delay. The Regulator will promptly provide the relevant Host Regulator with all relevant details of such material change, error or omission.

question: For a Listed Entity’s annual financial report that must report on adoption of the APP 4 best practice standards, how should the report operationalize the Regulator’s “comply or explain” approach reflected in Rule 9.2.10, including what must be stated when adoption is partial or not full and what additional Directors’ statement is required?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity’s annual financial report should implement the Regulator’s “comply or explain” approach by pairing a clear compliance position against the APP 4 best practice standards with an explanation and governance assessment where full adoption is not achieved. [#SRC:ff77ddf9-257f-4e32-960f-cd1e696b8c72] Specifically, the report must state whether the Listed Entity has adopted the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the “Corporate Governance Principles”). [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] If the standards have not been fully adopted or have been adopted only partially, the report must explain why full adoption did not occur (or why adoption was only partial, as relevant) and describe what actions, if any, have been taken to achieve compliance to the extent the relevant standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] In addition to this “explain” component, the annual financial report must include a statement by Directors on whether, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, supported by information and assumptions and including qualifications if necessary. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] This structure aligns the annual reporting content with the “comply or explain” approach referenced in Rule 9.2.10. [#SRC:ff77ddf9-257f-4e32-960f-cd1e696b8c72]
source_text: Rule 9.2.10 reflects the "comply or explain" approach adopted by the Regulator in respect of the Corporate Governance Principles.
target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: When an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, how must it determine the maximum distributable amount, including the required multiplication approach, the profit base to be used, and how the applicable factor is selected by reference to the Authorised Person’s CET1 Capital position within the Combined Buffer Requirement?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must calculate the maximum distributable amount before it can proceed with restricted distribution-related actions, and that calculation must follow the method that requires a multiplication of two components. First, the Authorised Person must identify the relevant profit base: the total of interim or year-end profits that were not included in CET1 Capital and that accrued after the most recent distribution of profits and after any relevant actions referenced in the calculation framework [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1]. Second, it must determine the applicable factor by assessing where its CET1 Capital (to the extent not used to meet the Capital Requirement, including any Individual Capital Requirement) falls within the quartiles of the Combined Buffer Requirement; the factor is 0, 0.2, 0.4, or 0.6 depending on whether it is in the first, second, third, or fourth quartile, respectively [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1]. This maximum distributable amount calculation is a required step when the Combined Buffer Requirement is not met [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e].
target_text:
Restrictions on distributions. Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must:
(a)	calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3.19.6; and
(b)	ensure that it does not undertake any of the following actions until such time as it has calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator under Rule 3.19.7:
(i)	make a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital, or create an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, or pay variable remuneration if the obligation to pay was created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement; or
(ii)	make payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments.

question: If the Investigator wants to get relevant information or documents during an investigation and chooses the compulsory route instead of asking voluntarily, what can the Investigator require by written notice from the Person Under Investigation or from someone else?
gold_answer: The Investigator may obtain relevant information and/or documents during an investigation either on a compulsory basis or on a voluntary basis, meaning the Investigator can choose between requiring material and requesting it cooperatively depending on the circumstances [#SRC:cf20c9eb-d551-42cd-87ce-691b75db72d4]. If the Investigator uses the compulsory approach, the TARGET explains that the Investigator may issue a written notice to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, even if that other person is not connected to the Person Under Investigation [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. The notice can require the person to attend an interview at a specified time and place and answer questions, to produce specified documents (or a specified type of documents) at a specified time and place, and to provide information or assistance that the Investigator requires. It can also require the person to allow the Investigator to enter the person’s business premises during normal business hours to inspect and copy documents kept there. Together, the SOURCE sets out the overall ability to obtain material compulsorily or voluntarily, and the TARGET lists what the compulsory written notice can demand.
source_text: Power to require documents or information . During an investigation, the Investigator may obtain relevant information and/or documents either on a compulsory basis, principally through the exercise of its powers under section 206(1)(b) and (c) of FSMR, or on a voluntary basis.

question: In defining eligible financial Collateral for an Authorised Person using the FCCA, how do the eligibility conditions for Units in a Collective Investment Fund interact with the rule-based instrument list, and what additional restriction applies where the Collateral is a T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by an entity in the Authorised Person’s Financial Group and held within that group as Collateral?
gold_answer: Eligible financial Collateral for an Authorised Person using the FCCA includes Units in a Collective Investment Fund only where the Fund invests in equity Securities that are traded on a regulated exchange, the Unit price is publicly quoted daily, and at least 90% of the Fund’s deposited property is invested in instruments that are within the FCCA eligibility rule and the referenced rule-based list. This means the Fund’s portfolio must be predominantly composed of instruments that meet the specified eligibility framework, including those drawn from the instrument list incorporated by reference. At the same time, the definition is constrained by an explicit exclusion that removes certain intra-group capital instruments from eligibility: any T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by any entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person is excluded where it is held by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities as Collateral. Accordingly, even if a capital instrument might otherwise appear to fit within the broader “instrument listed” concept that supports the Fund’s 90% test, it cannot be treated as eligible financial Collateral when it meets the intra-group issuance and holding conditions. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] [#SRC:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685]
source_text: For the purposes of Rule 4.13.5 and 4.13.6, eligible financial Collateral excludes any T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by any entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person, which is held by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities as Collateral.
target_text:
For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral comprises:
(a)	any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5;
(b)	any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and
(c)	any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund which invests in equity Securities referred to in (b), where:
(i)	a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily; and
(ii)	at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5.

question: When the Regulator is considering whether it may disqualify an auditor or actuary for a contravention, how should it apply the requirement to consider all circumstances to determine both whether to disqualify and the breadth of the disqualification across any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity (or a class of them)?
gold_answer: The Regulator’s permission to disqualify an auditor or actuary where it considers a contravention has occurred must be exercised through an assessment that takes into account all the circumstances of the case, both to decide whether disqualification is appropriate and to set the scope of any disqualification across any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity or any particular class thereof [#TGT:5cca9150-8e16-41b4-a5ef-74950916d06e]. In applying that “all circumstances” approach, the Regulator should consider, among other factors, the nature and seriousness of the contravention and its effects; whether the contravention or any failure to disclose information to the Regulator has resulted in or is likely to result in loss to customers, damage to the reputation of the ADGM, or an increased risk that a firm, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity may be used for financial crime; and what remedial action the auditor or actuary has taken [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22]. It should also weigh any relevant professional-body disciplinary action and whether it adequately addresses the contravention, as well as the auditor’s or actuary’s previous compliance record and any prior relevant sanctions, to calibrate the breadth and intensity of the disqualification [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22].
target_text: If the Regulator considers that an auditor or actuary has committed a contravention of these Regulations, it may disqualify the auditor or actuary from being the auditor of, or (as the case may be), from acting as an actuary for, any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity or any particular class thereof.

question: When the Investigator uses a written notice to require a person to “provide such information as the Investigator may require,” how broadly should “information” be understood, and how does that breadth affect what the person may need to supply in response to interview questions or other requests in the notice?
gold_answer: “Information” should be read expansively, so a written notice requiring a person to provide information can legitimately call for many different forms of content, not just formal documents. [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32] In practice, where the Investigator issues a written notice to the Person Under Investigation or any other person (even if not connected) requiring them to provide information, attend an interview and answer questions, or take other steps, the recipient should treat “information” as covering a wide range of material that can be supplied in response to those requirements. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] This broad scope includes, for example: knowledge communicated or received about a matter; knowledge gained through work or study; computer-processed data at any stage (input, output, storage, or transmission); explanations or statements; identification details about a person, matter, or thing; and direct responses to questions. [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32] Because the notice can also require attendance at an interview at a specified time and place to answer questions, the recipient should be prepared to provide “information” in the form of verbal answers and explanations, not only in written form. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] The key compliance takeaway is to map each notice requirement to this broad meaning so the response captures all requested knowledge, data, identifications, and statements. [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]

question: When implementing systems and controls for the use of securitisations, what must an Authorised Person do to ensure its periodic stress testing programme is appropriately calibrated, and how should the calibration relate to securitisation volumes and off balance sheet Exposures?
gold_answer: In implementing systems and controls for the use of securitisations, an Authorised Person must run periodic stress tests in relation to its securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures, and those tests must include testing its future ability to transact securitisation as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa]. To ensure the programme is appropriately calibrated, the Authorised Person should determine both the frequency (how often the tests are performed) and the extent (how comprehensive the scenarios and coverage are) based on the materiality of the Authorised Person’s securitisation volumes and its off balance sheet Exposures [#SRC:053ecf47-4501-4027-a994-9ada059b5e73]. This links the required periodic testing obligation to a proportionality driver: the more material the securitisation volumes and/or off balance sheet Exposures, the more robust the stress testing cadence and scope should be, so that the periodic tests meaningfully address the risks arising from those activities and positions and support the forward-looking assessment of continued ability to use securitisation for CRM or liquidity purposes [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] [#SRC:053ecf47-4501-4027-a994-9ada059b5e73].
source_text: The frequency and extent of stress testing to fulfil the requirements of Rule 4.14.5 should be determined on the basis of the materiality of the Authorised Person's securitisation volumes and its off balance sheet Exposures.
target_text: Systems and controls for the use of securitisations. An Authorised Person must conduct periodic stress tests in relation to its securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures, including testing of future ability to transact securitisation as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes.

question: Where the parties have agreed to disapply the individual Payment Transaction information requirements for a Low-Value Payment Instrument governed by a Framework Contract, what alternative transaction information must the Payment Service Provider provide or make available, and what is the fallback requirement when the instrument is used anonymously—particularly in light of the fact that Low-Value Payment Instruments under Rule 19.3.1 include instruments used for Stored Value?
gold_answer: If, for a Low-Value Payment Instrument governed by a Framework Contract, the parties agree that the usual information for individual Payment Transactions (as specified in Rules 19.2.13 and 19.2.14) will not apply, the Payment Service Provider must follow the alternative information approach set out for such instruments. [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21] Under that alternative approach, the Payment Service Provider must provide or make available a reference that enables the Payment Service User to identify the Payment Transaction, the amount of the Payment Transaction, and any charges payable for that Payment Transaction. [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21] If there are several Payment Transactions of the same kind made to the same Payee, the Payment Service Provider must instead provide or make available information about the total amount of those Payment Transactions and any charges for them. [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21] Where the Payment Instrument is used anonymously, or the Payment Service Provider is not technically able to provide or make available the information described above, the Payment Service Provider must enable the Payer to verify the amount of Money stored. [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21] This fallback is especially relevant because Low-Value Payment Instruments referred to under Rule 19.3.1 include instruments used in relation to Stored Value, making verification of stored Money a necessary substitute when transaction-level reporting cannot be delivered. [#SRC:9098e83a-9451-476e-8f4a-60bedc364e14]
source_text: Low-Value Payment Instruments referred to under Rule 19.3.1 encompass those used in relation to both Payment Accounts and Stored Value.

question: If the Regulator thinks an auditor or actuary has broken the Regulations and may disqualify them, what does it mean in practice to look at all the circumstances before deciding whether to disqualify and how wide the ban should be (for one entity, or a class of Authorised Persons, Recognised Bodies or Reporting Entities)?
gold_answer: If the Regulator considers an auditor or actuary has committed a contravention, it is permitted to disqualify that person from being the auditor of, or acting as an actuary for, any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity, or a particular class of them [#TGT:5cca9150-8e16-41b4-a5ef-74950916d06e]. Before deciding to use that power and before setting how wide the disqualification should be, the Regulator should take into account all the circumstances of the case [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22]. Practically, this includes looking at how serious the contravention is and what impact it had; whether the contravention (or any failure to disclose information to the Regulator) has caused or is likely to cause loss to customers, damage the reputation of the ADGM, or increase the risk that a firm, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity could be used for financial crime [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22]. The Regulator should also consider any steps the auditor or actuary took to remedy the issue, any relevant disciplinary action by a professional body (and whether it adequately addresses the contravention), and the person’s previous compliance record and prior sanctions, to decide whether a narrow or broader disqualification is justified [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22].
target_text: If the Regulator considers that an auditor or actuary has committed a contravention of these Regulations, it may disqualify the auditor or actuary from being the auditor of, or (as the case may be), from acting as an actuary for, any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity or any particular class thereof.

question: Where a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a compliant disclosure of Non-Equivalent Estimates, under what conditions may a later disclosure omit the detailed items normally required for material Non-Equivalent Estimates (such as source/date, reliability, and the Competent Person statement), and what specific statement must still be included in the later disclosure?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity may omit the detailed information otherwise required for a disclosure of material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation only if the later disclosure is structured as a true follow-on to an earlier disclosure that already met those detailed requirements. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] To do so, the later disclosure must (i) point back to the earlier compliant disclosure, and (ii) include the Mining Reporting Entity’s confirmation that the earlier information still applies and that there is no new material information or data affecting either how the Non-Equivalent Estimates should be relied on/interpreted or the Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard. [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] Even when relying on that omission pathway, the later disclosure must still carry an at least equally prominent and proximate statement about the Non-Equivalent Estimates that addresses the same core matters as the required prominent/proximate warning for Non-Equivalent Estimates (i.e., that they are not reported under a Mining Reporting Standard, have not been sufficiently worked by a Competent Person for classification, and may never become reportable as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves). [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]
source_text:
If a Mining Reporting Entity has disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates that comply with the requirements of Rule 11.7.3, then any subsequent disclosure made in respect of the Non-Equivalent Estimates does not need to include the information in that Rule if the subsequent disclosure:
(1)	references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with that Rule;
(2)	contains a confirmation from the Mining Reporting Entity that:
(a)	the information provided in the earlier disclosure in compliance with that Rule continues to apply; and
(b)	there is no new material information or data relating to the Non-Equivalent Estimates that impacts on the:
(i)	reliability or interpretation of the Non-Equivalent Estimates; or
(ii)	Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify the Non-Equivalent Estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard; and
(3)	includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates addressing the matters contained in Rule 11.7.3(1).

question: When a Prospectus has been filed with the Regulator and is intended to be treated as an “Approved Prospectus” for the purposes of subsection (1), what specific approval action must the Regulator take, and how does that action apply where the Prospectus comprises multiple documents under the Rules-based approval concept?
gold_answer: A filed Prospectus is treated as an “Approved Prospectus” only when the Regulator has taken an affirmative approval step, not merely because it has been filed. Under the Regulations’ framing, a Prospectus qualifies as an Approved Prospectus if it is approved by the Regulator in line with the requirements prescribed in the Rules, and references to a Prospectus in the Regulations are generally to an Approved Prospectus unless context indicates otherwise. [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1] In addition, for the filing to result in an Approved Prospectus for the stated statutory purpose, the Regulator must issue the Applicant a notice that states the Regulator’s approval. [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e] That notice must cover the Prospectus (or, where applicable, the Supplementary Prospectus). [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e] Where the Prospectus consists of multiple documents, the notice must expressly approve all of those multiple documents, aligning the practical evidence of approval (the notice) with the Rules-based approval concept used to define an Approved Prospectus. [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e] [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1]
source_text:
A Prospectus filed with the Regulator is not an Approved Prospectus for the purposes of section 61(2)(a) of the FSMR unless the Regulator has issued to the Applicant a notice stating its approval:
(a)	of the Prospectus or the Supplementary Prospectus as the case may be; and
(b)	in the case of a Prospectus in (a) comprising multiple documents, of all the multiple documents.
target_text:
For the purposes of subsection ‎(1)—
(a)	a Prospectus is an Approved Prospectus if it is approved by the Regulator in accordance with the requirements prescribed in the Rules; and
(b)	a reference to a Prospectus made by or under these Regulations is a reference to an Approved Prospectus, unless the context requires otherwise.

question: When the Regulator has exercised its discretion to approve an Offer document (including any conditions or restrictions it imposes), what must be done to ensure the approved document is made available to the public, and in what timing and format?
gold_answer: Where the Regulator has decided to approve an Offer document under its discretionary power, including on any conditions or restrictions it sees fit, the approval triggers a separate publication obligation. Specifically, once the Offer document has been approved in accordance with the applicable approval process, it must be made available to the public as soon as reasonably practicable, and it must be made available in the form approved by the Regulator. In practice, this means the party responsible for publication cannot treat approval as the final step: it must promptly take steps to publish or otherwise provide public access, and it must ensure that the version released matches the form the Regulator approved (including any changes needed to reflect conditions or restrictions attached to the approval). The Regulator’s ability to approve subject to conditions or restrictions frames what “the form approved” entails, while the obligation governs the timing and public availability following that approval. [#TGT:cff95a0c-cf4e-421f-aef9-c27588e13519] [#SRC:22b3eee4-acfd-4a8b-9dc9-e3c9ff07d5ca]
source_text:
Once an Offer document referred to in Rule 4.7.1 has been approved in accordance with 4.7.1(2), it must be made available to the public:

(a)	as soon as reasonably practicable; and
(b)	in the form approved by the Regulator.
target_text: The Regulator may, subject to (3), approve an Offer document referred to in (1) in accordance with the requirements and procedures set out in this Rule and, subject to such conditions or restrictions imposed by the Regulator as it sees fit.

question: If a Petroleum Reporting Entity comes up with new material estimates for Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources, or Petroleum Reserves that it has never disclosed before, how fast does it need to disclose them, and what details must it include about licences, the new data, and what changed compared with earlier disclosures?
gold_answer: The Petroleum Reporting Entity must disclose the new material estimates immediately when they have not previously been disclosed. [#TGT:1d41da19-7d47-42e7-baf3-28af0f6c1c12] When it makes that disclosure under Rule 12.6.1, it must also include enough detail to show what the estimates relate to and why they changed. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] The disclosure needs to include, at a minimum: - The types of permits or licences the Petroleum Reporting Entity holds that relate to the estimates. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] - A clear explanation of the new data and information. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] - An explanation of how the new data and information affected the estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources, or Petroleum Resources (which includes Petroleum Reserves). [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] - Any changes or additions to what it previously disclosed for Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources, and Petroleum Reserves, using the listed prior-disclosure groupings. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] So the rule is both “disclose right away” and “include the specified supporting explanations and updates to earlier information.” [#TGT:1d41da19-7d47-42e7-baf3-28af0f6c1c12] [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704]
target_text: A Petroleum Reporting Entity must immediately disclose any new material estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves that have not previously been disclosed.

question: If a Listed Entity is checking whether it needs holders of Ordinary Securities to approve a new issue because of the 20% limit, how should it count partly paid Securities and Convertible Securities when working out the number of Equity Securities for the calculation, including the “Relevant Issues” part?
gold_answer: To decide whether approval from holders of Ordinary Securities is needed, the Listed Entity must compare the proposed issue (or agreement to issue) against the maximum allowed under the formula: (20% × Base Amount) minus Relevant Issues; issuing above that maximum is not permitted without that approval. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] When determining the number of Equity Securities for this purpose (including the amount that contributes to “Relevant Issues”), the entity must apply the counting approach set for new issues unless the Regulator determines otherwise. [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f] Under that approach, a partly paid Security is treated as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities it could become if fully paid up, and a Convertible Security is treated as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities it could convert into. [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f] Those counted totals are then used when identifying “Relevant Issues,” which covers Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the prior 12 months, but excludes issues made with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5 and issues made under an exception in Rule 9.7.4. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] Using these counting rules ensures the cap test reflects potential dilution in fully paid Ordinary Securities terms. [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f]
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: If a Recognised Body is failing to meet Recognition Requirements and the consequences are or will be serious, can the Regulator still use its power to direct specified remedial steps (including inspection access or suspension), and what additional factors would lead it to usually consider revocation instead?
gold_answer: The Regulator can use its power to give directions to a Recognised Body to take specified steps to secure compliance with the Recognition Requirements, and those steps may include granting access to the Recognised Body’s premises for inspection of premises or documents and suspending the carrying on of any activity for a period specified in the direction [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500]. At the same time, where the Recognised Body is failing or has failed to satisfy one or more Recognition Requirements and that failure has or will have serious consequences, the Regulator will usually consider revoking the Recognition Order, indicating that revocation is a likely regulatory response in that scenario [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a]. Beyond seriousness of consequences, the Regulator will usually consider revocation if it would not be possible for the Recognised Body to comply with a direction, or if for some other reason it would not be appropriate to give a direction. Revocation is also usually considered where the Recognised Body has not carried on the business of a Recognised Body during the specified 12-month period after the Recognition Order took effect, or has not carried on that business at any time during the six months ending with the day the Recognition Order is revoked [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a].
target_text: The Regulator has the power to give directions to a Recognised Body to take specified steps in order to secure its compliance with the Recognition Requirements. Those steps may include granting the Regulator access to the Recognised Body's premises for the purposes of inspecting those premises or any documents on the premises and the suspension of the carrying on of any activity by the Recognised Body for the period specified in the direction.

question: When an Authorised Person seeks to apply the Standardised Approach or the Alternative Standardised Approach, what governance and documentation must it establish for mapping gross income across current business lines and activities, and how must it maintain those criteria as business activities change, including any prescribed reference framework?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person seeks to apply the Standardised Approach or the Alternative Standardised Approach, it must put in place a defined mapping framework that is both operationally embedded and auditable. Specifically, it must develop specific policies and maintain documented criteria that explain how gross income from its current business lines and activities is mapped into the relevant approach, ensuring the mapping is consistently applied and can be evidenced through documentation [#SRC:e55b981f-c5a0-41dd-ae9a-14f14a7b442d]. In addition, the mapping criteria are not static: the Authorised Person must review and adjust them as appropriate when there are new or changing business activities, so that the mapping remains aligned to the firm’s evolving business profile and continues to reflect current activities [#TGT:a1e9cb4f-8550-418a-b513-ff5763673aa3]. The required mapping documentation must also be prepared in line with the prescribed reference framework identified for this purpose, so that the criteria and policies correspond to the prescribed structure for mapping gross income into the Standardised Approach or the Alternative Standardised Approach [#TGT:a1e9cb4f-8550-418a-b513-ff5763673aa3].
source_text: In accordance with Rule 6.11.3, an Authorised Person seeking to apply the Standardised Approach or the Alternative Standardised Approach must develop specific policies and have documented criteria for mapping gross income for current business lines and activities into the Standardised Approach or the Alternative Standardised Approach. The criteria must be reviewed and adjusted for new or changing business activities as appropriate. The principles for business line mapping are set out below.
target_text: An Authorised Person seeking to apply the Standardised Approach or the Alternative Standardised Approach must develop specific policies and have documented criteria for mapping gross income for current business lines and activities into the Standardised Approach or the Alternative Standardised Approach, as prescribed in App7. The criteria must be reviewed and adjusted for new or changing business activities as appropriate.

question: For Derivatives (including written credit protection), how should a firm reconcile the SOURCE requirement to compute an Exposure value using an IFRS on-balance sheet amount plus an add-on for potential future Exposure with the TARGET SA-CCR requirement to calculate EAD per netting set using alpha, replacement cost (RC), and potential future exposure (PFE)?
gold_answer: For Derivatives (including written credit protection), the Exposure value framework in the SOURCE is built from two components: (i) an on-balance sheet amount determined under IFRS and (ii) an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated under specified App 4 rules. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] When the firm is applying the SA-CCR method described in the TARGET, it must calculate EAD separately for each netting set and determine it using the formula EAD = alpha * (RC + PFE), with alpha fixed at 1.4. [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] To reconcile the two, the firm should treat the TARGET’s PFE term as the structured “add-on for potential future Exposure” concept referenced in the SOURCE, because both are explicitly defined as potential future exposure amounts calculated under App 4 rule references. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] In addition, the TARGET requires RC (replacement cost) to be calculated under its specified rule set and combined with PFE before applying alpha, and this netting-set-by-netting-set EAD calculation provides the SA-CCR-specific way to operationalize the Exposure measurement for derivatives alongside the SOURCE’s IFRS-plus-add-on structure. [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007]
source_text:
In relation to on-balance sheet items:
a.	for SFTs, the Exposure value should be calculated in accordance with IFRS and the Netting requirements referred to in Rule 4.9.14;
b.	for Derivatives, including written credit protection, the Exposure value should be calculated as the sum of the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated in accordance with Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4; and
c.	for other on-balance sheet items, the Exposure value should be calculated based on their balance sheet values in accordance with Rule 4.9.3.
target_text:
Derivatives and long settlement transactions – Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR). EAD is to be calculated separately for each netting set. It is determined as follows:
EAD = alpha* (RC + PFE)
where:
alpha = 1.4
RC = the replacement cost calculated according to Rules A4.6.19 to A4.6.24
PFE = the amount for potential future exposure calculated according to Rule A4.6.26

question: If the Regulator anticipates substantial additional effort in handling a Person’s filing or on-going supervision, and the Person has also submitted a waiver or modification request that the Regulator considers novel, may the Regulator require a supplementary fee on either basis?
gold_answer: Yes. Both texts permit the Regulator to require a Person to pay a supplementary fee, and each provides an independent basis for doing so. The SOURCE authorises the Regulator to require a supplementary fee where the relevant matter is a request for a waiver or modification and, in the opinion of the Regulator, that request is particularly complex or novel [#SRC:ef45697b-2b10-450b-bacc-b9d501e87404]. Separately, the TARGET authorises the Regulator to require a Person to pay to the Regulator a supplementary fee where it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing, or when conducting on-going supervision [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]. In the scenario described, the Regulator could rely on the TARGET rationale for the filing or on-going supervision if it expects substantial additional cost or effort, and it could also rely on the SOURCE rationale if the waiver/modification request is, in its opinion, particularly complex or novel. Both are framed as permissions for the Regulator to require payment from the Person.
source_text: In accordance with Rule 1.2.4, the Regulator may require a Person to pay a supplementary fee where the request for a waiver or modification is particularly complex or novel in the opinion of the Regulator.
target_text:
Supplementary fees
The Regulator may require a Person to pay to the Regulator a supplementary fee in circumstances where it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing or when conducting on-going supervision.

question: If the protection seller on a credit derivative is an MDB, what do you need to check so you can count the credit risk mitigation, and what risk weights apply to an MDB asset class CR Exposure by Credit Quality Grade (including unrated)?
gold_answer: To be able to recognise the effects of CRM from a Credit Derivative where the protection provider is an MDB, the Authorised Person must ensure the provider is an MDB of the type referenced in Rules 4.12.7 to 4.12.9, because CRM recognition is only allowed when the provider is one of the listed eligible entity types (including those MDBs). [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] In parallel, if the exposure being assessed is a CR Exposure in the MDB asset class, the Authorised Person must risk weight that exposure using the MDB asset class table (and the table is stated to operate subject to Rules 4.12.8 and 4.12.9). [#TGT:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c] So you combine an eligibility check (is the protection provider an MDB within the referenced rule set) with the required risk-weighting approach for MDB asset class exposures. [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] [#TGT:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c] The table assigns: 0% for Credit Quality Grade 1; 50% for Grades 2 and 3; 100% for Grades 4 and 5; 150% for Grade 6; and 50% for unrated exposures. [#TGT:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c]
target_text:
Multilateral development bank (MDB) asset class. Subject to Rules 4.12.8 and 4.12.9, an Authorised Person must risk weight any CR Exposure in the MDB asset class in accordance with the following table:
Risk Weights for the MDB asset class
/Table Start
Credit Quality Grade	1	2	3	4	5	6	Unrated
Risk Weight	0%	50%	50%	100%	100%	150%	50%
/Table End

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation and uses the option that it does not have to follow the usual rule, what must it still put into the disclosure itself?
gold_answer: Even where a Mining Reporting Entity disclosing material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation can use the option that it does not need to comply with the usual disclosure rule (as long as it complies with the listed alternative rules) [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26], it still has to meet the disclosure-content requirements that apply to such disclosures [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]. The Mining Reporting Entity must include a clear, nearby statement that the estimates are Non-Equivalent Estimates, are not disclosed in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard, that a Competent Person has not done enough work to classify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard, and that it is uncertain whether further evaluation/exploration will ever allow that. It must also include the sources and dates of the estimates; explain any Mineralisation categories used (and whether they match or differ from a Mining Reporting Standard); and cover relevance and reliability. In addition, it must summarise the work and assumptions behind the estimates, provide any newer relevant estimates/data with sources/dates, describe what work is needed to verify them (plus timing and funding), state the classification/reporting standard used, and include a named Competent Person statement confirming the accuracy of specified parts of the disclosure.

question: When deciding whether to revoke a Recognition Order, how does the Regulator distinguish between using its power to give directions to secure compliance with the Recognition Requirements (including directions that may require premises access or suspension of activities) and proceeding to revocation, and what specific circumstances trigger the revocation approach?
gold_answer: The Regulator may use directions to require a Recognised Body to take specified steps to secure compliance with the Recognition Requirements, but it will usually consider revoking a Recognition Order where a direction is not suitable or the Recognised Body’s position warrants revocation. [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500] In particular, revocation is typically considered if the Recognised Body is failing or has failed to meet one or more Recognition Requirements and that failure has or will have serious consequences. [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a] Revocation is also the usual approach where it would not be possible for the Recognised Body to comply with a direction given under the Regulator’s direction power, or where (for another reason) it would not be appropriate for the Regulator to give such a direction. [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a] By contrast, where directions are used, the specified steps can include granting the Regulator access to the Recognised Body’s premises to inspect the premises or documents there, and requiring suspension of the carrying on of any activity for the period stated in the direction. [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500] Separately, revocation is usually considered if the Recognised Body has not carried on the business of a Recognised Body during the 12 months starting on the day the Recognition Order took effect, or has not carried on that business at any time during the six months ending on the day the Recognition Order is revoked. [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a]
target_text: The Regulator has the power to give directions to a Recognised Body to take specified steps in order to secure its compliance with the Recognition Requirements. Those steps may include granting the Regulator access to the Recognised Body's premises for the purposes of inspecting those premises or any documents on the premises and the suspension of the carrying on of any activity by the Recognised Body for the period specified in the direction.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes, or is required to make, a disclosure under the Rules that contains statements about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets (including in offering and periodic reporting materials and online communications), what preparation standards must it follow, and how does the scope of covered disclosures determine when those standards apply?
gold_answer: Where a disclosure is made or required to be made under the Rules and it includes a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets, the scope provision makes clear that the regime applies broadly across disclosure channels, including formal transaction documents and ongoing/public communications such as a Prospectus, Exempt Offer document, bidder’s and target’s statements, annual reports, financial statements, technical papers, presentations, and website content [#SRC:96612327-1f00-4faf-abc6-2c914cc73738]. Within that scope, the operative obligation is that a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity containing those types of statements must be prepared in accordance with both a Mining Reporting Standard and the chapter setting the disclosure requirements [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d]. Read together, the scope determines the trigger (any covered disclosure made or required under the Rules, regardless of medium), and the obligation determines the required method of preparation (alignment with the Mining Reporting Standard and the chapter). This means the Mining Reporting Entity should treat the preparation requirements as applying consistently whenever those statement types appear in any of the covered disclosure contexts.
source_text:
Rule 11.2.1 applies to all disclosures made or required to be made under the Rules which include a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets, including within a Prospectus, Exempt Offer document, bidder’s and target’s statements, annual reports, financial statements, technical papers, presentations, and website content and disclosures.
In order to ensure consistency of its disclosures, Issuers and Mining Reporting Entities should be mindful of the table format for disclosure of Ore Reserves and Mineral Resources set out in MKT Form-11-1.
target_text:
Requirements for all disclosures. A disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity that includes a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets must be prepared in accordance with:
(1)	a Mining Reporting Standard; and
(2)	this chapter.

question: When the Regulator receives a Host Regulator request to conduct an on-site inspection relating to a Passported Fund, is the Regulator permitted to decline to cooperate, and if so how does that interact with the requirement to allow the inspection and accompany it during the visit?
gold_answer: When the Regulator receives a request from a Host Regulator to carry out an on-site inspection in relation to a Passported Fund, the Regulator is required to permit the inspection and to accompany it during the on-site inspection [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6]. However, the Regulator also has discretion to refuse to act on a Host Regulator’s request for cooperation in relation to an inspection in specified circumstances [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c]. Those circumstances are limited to situations where the Regulator has already commenced or concluded enforcement action concerning the same conduct and the same Persons, or where judicial proceedings have already been initiated or concluded concerning the same conduct and the same Persons [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c]. Read together, the default position is that the Regulator must facilitate and attend the on-site inspection when requested, but it may decline to act on the cooperation request where one of the listed enforcement-action or judicial-proceedings conditions applies, because the refusal power is expressly tied to cooperation in relation to an inspection [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6] [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c].
source_text: Where the Regulator receives a request from a Host Regulator to carry out an on-site inspection in relation to a Passported Fund, the Regulator shall, subject to Rule 9.3.2, permit such inspection and accompany it during the on-site inspection.
target_text:
The Regulator may refuse to act on a request by a Host Regulator for cooperation in relation to an inspection in the following circumstances:
(a)	the Regulator has already commenced, or concluded, enforcement action in respect of the same conduct and the same Persons; or
(b)	judicial proceedings have already been initiated, or concluded, in respect of the same conduct and the same Persons.

question: When the Investigator asks for documents from the Person Under Investigation or another person, does the Investigator have the option to require either copies or originals, and can the Investigator keep any originals while they are needed, even if the person has to get the documents from someone else?
gold_answer: Yes. The Investigator may, by written notice, require the Person Under Investigation or any other person (whether or not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to produce specified documents or documents of a specified description at a specified time and place [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. The Investigator’s authority also covers requiring a person to produce documents or to procure the production of documents, which addresses cases where the person must arrange for documents to be produced rather than simply handing over what they already have [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3]. The Investigator can require production of original documents or copies, so the request can specify the form in which the documents must be provided [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3]. If originals are produced, the Investigator may retain possession of any original document for as long as is necessary for the purpose for which it was requested, meaning retention is allowed for the period needed to meet that purpose [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3].
source_text: Power to require documents or information . Section 206(1)(b) of FSMR empowers the Investigator to require a person to produce, or procure the production of, specified documents or documents of a specified description. It empowers the Investigator to require production of original documents or copies. The Investigator may retain possession of any original document for as long as is necessary for the purpose for which it was requested.

question: If a PFP Operator is about to post a financing proposal for a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, what checks must it do on the PFP Prospect, and what related records does it have to keep for six years (including any documents involving a Body Corporate it set up for the transaction)?
gold_answer: Before a PFP Operator publishes a financing proposal about a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, it must first carry out due diligence on the PFP Prospect to help it meet the disclosure requirements placed on it by Rule 18.5.1. [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce] That due diligence must include reviewing information the PFP Prospect provides about: (a) management details and background, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers; (b) the PFP Prospect’s background, including financial soundness, good standing, and (if relevant) regulatory status; and (c) the financing proposal, so that to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge the proposal is adequate, clear, fair, and not misleading. [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce] After doing this work (and making the related disclosures), the PFP Operator must keep records for at least six years. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] The six-year record set must cover: all disclosures made under Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2, all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect, and the due diligence undertaken under Rule 18.4.1. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] Taken together, this means the PFP Operator should be able to show both what it reviewed before publication and what it disclosed, and preserve that evidence for the required retention period. [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce] [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7]
source_text:
A PFP Operator must, for a minimum of six years, maintain and keep a record of:
(a)	all disclosures made in accordance with Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2;
(b)	all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect; and
(c)	the due diligence undertaken in accordance with Rule 18.4.1.
target_text:
Prior to publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence upon the PFP Prospect, in order to satisfy the disclosure requirements imposed on it by Rule 18.5.1. Such due diligence must include, but not be limited to, a review of the following information to be provided by the PFP Prospect:
(a)	details and background of management, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers;
(b)	background of the PFP Prospect, including its financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status, if relevant; and
(c)	the financing proposal, in order to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, its content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading.

question: If the Regulator decides to approve an Application for Listing, does it have to tell the Applicant in writing, and is this tied to the decision on admission of Securities to the Official List?
gold_answer: Yes. The Regulator has an obligation to notify the Applicant in writing of its decision in relation to the application for admission of Securities to the Official List [#SRC:c1f2bce6-f17b-456d-b187-9b5c3becc00e]. In addition, when the Regulator’s decision is to grant an Application for Listing, it must give the Applicant written notice of its decision [#TGT:f042ba18-df6f-45eb-92c9-0bd804f9ef7c]. Taken together, these requirements mean that once the Regulator has decided the outcome of the relevant application process, the Applicant must receive a written notice communicating that decision, and this includes the scenario where the application is granted. The key compliance point is that the communication must be in writing, must come from the Regulator, and must be provided to the Applicant as the formal notification of the decision connected to admission/listing on the Official List.
source_text: Under section 52(3) of the FSMR, the Regulator will notify the Applicant in writing of its decision in relation to the application for admission of Securities to the Official List.
target_text: If the Regulator decides to grant an Application for Listing, it must give the Applicant written notice of its decision.
