[#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] It also must have included the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In the later disclosure, the Mining Reporting Entity must reference that earlier compliant disclosure and state that the material assumptions from the first disclosure still apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] If the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, or partly based on an Exploration Target, the later disclosure must also include an equally prominent and nearby statement about the forecast financial information matching the relevant statement specified in Rule 11.8.3(5)(d) or Rule 11.8.3(7)(b). [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: If an Authorised Person is working out CET1 deductions for investments in CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities, what calculation basis must be used for Trading Book holdings (including any netting rules), and what is the general rule about using gross long positions?
gold_answer: The two texts together require the Authorised Person to apply a general calculation principle while also following a specific Trading Book method when it applies. The SOURCE states that, for the relevant purposes, the amount of holdings of CET1 Capital instruments and other capital instruments of Relevant Entities to be deducted must be calculated on the basis of gross long positions (and it notes this is subject to another rule) [#SRC:40c66431-d7b0-41ae-bc47-0ae63f4d9454]. The TARGET then explains that, for the relevant purposes, an Authorised Person must make the deductions by calculating holdings in the Trading Book on the basis of the net long position in the same underlying Exposure, but only if the short position’s maturity matches the long position’s maturity or the short has a residual maturity of at least one year [#TGT:f6640865-b279-44c1-941f-091a1619258c]. In practice, this means the gross long position basis is the general approach, while Trading Book holdings can be reduced to a net long position only where the offsetting short position meets the maturity conditions and relates to the same underlying Exposure.
source_text: CET1 Deductions - investments in CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(f), (g) and (h), the amount of holdings of CET1 Capital instruments and other capital instruments of Relevant Entities to be deducted, must be calculated, subject to Rule 3.10.15, on the basis of the gross long positions.
target_text:
CET1 Deductions - investments in CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(g) and (h), an Authorised Person must make the deductions in accordance with the following:
(a)	the holdings in the Trading Book of the capital instruments of Relevant Entities must be calculated on the basis of the net long position in the same underlying Exposure provided the maturity of the short position matches the maturity of the long position or has a residual maturity of at least one year; and
(b)	the amount to be deducted for indirect holdings in the Trading Book of the capital instruments of Relevant Entities that take the form of holdings of index Securities must be determined by calculating the underlying Exposure to the capital instruments of the Relevant Entities in the indices.

question: When a person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus would otherwise be required to pay compensation for loss arising from an untrue or misleading statement or a material omission in that Prospectus, how must the compensation obligation be assessed where the person incurring the loss acquired the Securities with knowledge of the falsity, the omitted matter or change, or the new matter or inaccuracy?
gold_answer: A person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is generally liable to pay compensation to a person who acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and suffered loss or damage because of an untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus, or because the Prospectus omitted a material matter required to be included [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac]. However, that compensation exposure must be assessed against the carve-out that a Person does not incur liability where the person incurring the loss acquired the relevant Securities with knowledge that the statement was false, misleading, or deceptive, or with knowledge of the omitted matter (or of the change), or with knowledge of the new matter or inaccuracy [#SRC:4ee654af-eec8-49f1-8813-6fb847d3eecb]. In practice, this means the compensation obligation described for Prospectus liability is not triggered against that Person in circumstances where the claimant’s acquisition was made with the specified knowledge, even if the loss is otherwise connected to the statement, omission, change, new matter, or inaccuracy.
source_text:
A Person does not incur any liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR if the Person incurring the loss acquired the Securities in question with knowledge:
(a)	that the statement was false, misleading, or deceptive;
(b)	of the omitted matter or of the change; or
(c)	of the new matter or inaccuracy.
target_text: Any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to another person who has acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and who has suffered loss or damage arising from any untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission from it of any material matter required to have been included in the Prospectus by or under these Regulations.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity has already disclosed a Production Target with all the required assumptions and related details, when can it make a later Production Target disclosure without repeating those details, and what does it still need to include in that later disclosure?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity’s first disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include specific content about how the Production Target was determined, including all material economic assumptions (or, if commercially sensitive, a statement and the methodology used), all other material assumptions, any statement that forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds, and the required breakdown of what proportions of the Production Target are based on reserves/resources, Inferred Mineral Resources, and any Exploration Target, together with the required statements for those categories [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]. After that, a later disclosure about the same Production Target may omit the information that would otherwise need to be repeated, but only if it points back to the earlier disclosure that was compliant and it confirms that the material assumptions used in the initial disclosure still apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef]. Also, if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, or if it is based in part on an Exploration Target, the later disclosure must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement for those situations, even though it can avoid re-stating the rest of the detailed required content [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a].
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed; or
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds.
(3)	the proportions of the Production Target based on:
(a)	Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves;
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources;
(c)	Inferred Mineral Resources; and
(d)	an Exploration Target.
(4)	a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan;
(5)	if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources:
(a)	an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources;
(b)	the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence;
(c)	a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and
(d)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.  The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.”
Guidance
Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement.  The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources.
(6)	if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.”
(7)	if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target:
(a)	a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and
(b)	an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that:
“The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: If the Customer is not a Natural Person, can the Customer and the Third Party Provider agree in writing to use a different time limit for reporting an unauthorised or incorrectly executed transaction, and what does the Customer still have to do to qualify for redress?
gold_answer: Yes. Where the Customer is not a Natural Person, the Customer and the Third Party Provider may agree in writing that certain rules do not apply, and they may also agree that a different time period applies for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the relevant refund-related purposes [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44]. Separately, the Customer’s entitlement to redress is tied to a notification requirement: the Customer is only entitled to redress if it notifies its Third Party Provider without undue delay and, in any event, no later than twelve months after the date of execution, once it becomes aware of an unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transaction [#TGT:d299e513-87d9-47de-9c0f-1f15cca91cbb]. Putting these together, the Customer must still act promptly when it becomes aware and must meet the applicable deadline for notifying the Third Party Provider. If the parties have agreed a different time period in writing, the Customer should follow that agreed period rather than relying on the default timing, because the agreement is expressly permitted for this scenario.
target_text: Subject to Rule 20.10.2, a Customer is only entitled to redress if it notifies its Third Party Provider without undue delay, and in any event no later than twelve months after the date of execution, on becoming aware of any unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transaction.

question: If a firm wants to give an Employee (who is a Related Person) better credit terms than non-Related Persons, what does the Credit Risk policy need to say about (1) the kind of employee credit policy it uses and (2) how it keeps conflicted people out of granting, managing, or approving that credit?
gold_answer: To allow better credit terms for a Related Person who is an Employee, the Credit Risk policy must be built around an Employee credit policy that is widely available to Employees of the Authorised Person and has been approved by the Authorised Person's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate. [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91] That employee policy must clearly describe the terms, conditions and limits for providing credit to those Employees, including limits at both individual and aggregate levels, and it must include mechanisms to ensure ongoing compliance. [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91] Those mechanisms must include immediate reporting to the Governing Body or its delegate if there is any deviation from or breach of the relevant terms, conditions, or procedures so action can be taken promptly. [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91] In parallel, the Credit Risk policy must include conflicts-of-interest procedures for granting and managing credit that prevent any Person who directly or indirectly benefits from the credit from taking part in the process of granting or managing it. [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496] Where the policy requires Governing Body (or delegate) approval for certain Related Person Exposures or write-offs, it must also exclude beneficiaries from the approval process. [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496]
source_text:
Credit Risk policy. In relation to conflicts of interest and Related Person transactions, the policy must:
(a)	set out adequate procedures for handling conflicts of interest relating to the provision and management of credit, including measures to prevent any Person directly or indirectly benefiting from the credit being part of the process of granting or managing the credit;
(b)	subject to Rule 4.4.5, prohibit Exposures to Related Persons on terms that are more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons; and
(c)	if Exposures to Related Persons are allowed on terms which are no more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons, set out procedures that:
(i)	require such Exposures, and any write off of such Exposures, exceeding specific amounts or otherwise posing special risks to the Authorised Person, to be made subject to the prior written approval of the firm's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate; and
(ii)	exclude Persons directly or indirectly benefiting from the grant or write off of such Exposures being part of the approval process.

question: If the Customer is not a Natural Person, what should you check to confirm whether the usual “tell the Third Party Provider without undue delay and within 12 months” rule for redress still applies, given the option to agree in writing on different rules and a different time period for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions?
gold_answer: Start from the standard position: the Customer only gets redress for an unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transaction if it informs its Third Party Provider without undue delay and no later than twelve months after the execution date, once it becomes aware of the issue. [#TGT:d299e513-87d9-47de-9c0f-1f15cca91cbb] Then confirm whether the Customer is not a Natural Person and whether there is a written agreement between the Customer and the Third Party Provider that changes what applies. [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] Specifically, for non-Natural Person Customers, the parties may agree in writing that certain listed Rules do not apply, and they may also agree that a different time period applies for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 20.10.1. [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] Because the redress entitlement is expressly tied to timely notification, your compliance check should (i) verify the existence and scope of any such written agreement and (ii) determine whether it alters the time period relevant to unauthorised/incorrectly executed transactions, while still ensuring notification is made without undue delay upon awareness. [#SRC:10510c2c-99d3-4cba-bac5-61cda5d00d44] [#TGT:d299e513-87d9-47de-9c0f-1f15cca91cbb]
target_text: Subject to Rule 20.10.2, a Customer is only entitled to redress if it notifies its Third Party Provider without undue delay, and in any event no later than twelve months after the date of execution, on becoming aware of any unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transaction.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation and relies on the carve-out that it is not required to follow the usual disclosure rule, what specific content must it still include in the disclosure to meet its mandatory requirements?
gold_answer: If a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, it may rely on a permission that it does not need to comply with the usual disclosure rule, but only on the condition that it complies with the specified alternative rules [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26]. Separately and in addition, the Mining Reporting Entity must ensure the disclosure itself contains a defined set of information and statements [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]. This includes a prominent statement explaining the estimates are Non-Equivalent Estimates, are not disclosed in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard, that a Competent Person has not done sufficient work to classify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard, and that it is uncertain whether they will ever be able to be disclosed as such. The disclosure must also provide the sources and dates of the estimates; explain any Mineralisation categories used (including whether they differ from those in a Mining Reporting Standard); address relevance and reliability; summarise the evaluation/exploration work and key assumptions/methods; identify more recent relevant estimates/data; describe verification work needed, its timing and funding source; state the classification/reporting standard used; and include a named Competent Person statement attesting to the accuracy of information provided for specified items.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure that does not follow a non-mandatory requirement in a Mining Reporting Standard (for example, a non-mandatory item in Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code), what must the Mining Reporting Entity include in the disclosure, and how does this relate to the Regulator’s expectation of compliance under Rule 11.2.1(1) and the explanation approach referenced in Rule 11.2.2?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is expected to comply fully with non-mandatory requirements in a Mining Reporting Standard, but if it does not, it must transparently explain the departure within the disclosure itself. [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124] Specifically, where a disclosure does not meet a non-mandatory requirement in the relevant Mining Reporting Standard, the Mining Reporting Entity must include a statement in that disclosure describing both how the disclosure differs and why it differs from the non-mandatory requirement. [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f] This disclosure-level statement operationalizes the Regulator’s expectation that non-mandatory requirements are followed unless the entity explains non-compliance, including in relation to non-mandatory items such as those found in Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code. [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124] In practical terms, the Mining Reporting Entity should (i) identify the specific non-mandatory requirement it did not meet, (ii) describe the nature of the difference, and (iii) provide the reason for that difference, all within the disclosure. [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f] This approach aligns with the referenced expectation to explain non-compliance in accordance with Rule 11.2.2 when non-mandatory requirements are not followed. [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124]
source_text: Rule 11.2.1(1) requires a Mining Reporting Entity to fully comply with all binding requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard. The Regulator also expects a Mining Reporting Entity to fully comply with all non-mandatory requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard, including, for example, Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code, or explain its non-compliance in accordance with Rule 11.2.2.
target_text: Requirements for all disclosures. Where a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity does not meet a non-mandatory requirement contained in a Mining Reporting Standard, the Mining Reporting Entity must provide in its disclosure a statement as to how and why its disclosure differs from the non-mandatory requirement contained in the relevant Mining Reporting Standard.

question: If an Insider has Inside Information about Issuer A’s Financial Instruments, does Section 92(2) stop them from trading only those Financial Instruments, or also things like derivatives or other group instruments—and where do you look for the definition of "Related Instrument"?
gold_answer: Section 92(2) is not limited to the Financial Instrument (or, where applicable, the Accepted Virtual Asset or Accepted Spot Commodity) that the Inside Information is about; it also blocks an Insider from dealing or trying to deal in a Related Instrument tied to that Inside Information. [#SRC:4d6d9fa5-5edd-4280-9d7b-90fca017f5d7] To decide what counts as a Related Instrument in this context, you apply the meaning that, for a Financial Instrument, it is an investment whose price or value depends on the price or value of that Financial Instrument. [#TGT:701dd6f2-183c-4150-a7ab-58ab24fc3f8f] Using the Issuer A example, the scope can include a derivative linked to A’s Financial Instruments, because its value depends on A’s Financial Instruments. [#TGT:701dd6f2-183c-4150-a7ab-58ab24fc3f8f] It can also include another Financial Instrument in a member of A’s Group, but only where that other instrument’s price or value depends (in whole or in part) on the price or value of A’s Financial Instruments. [#TGT:701dd6f2-183c-4150-a7ab-58ab24fc3f8f] For the formal source of the term, the definition of “Related Instrument” is set out at paragraph 1(9) of the CMC, which is the place to check when classifying an instrument for Section 92(2) purposes. [#SRC:4d6d9fa5-5edd-4280-9d7b-90fca017f5d7]
source_text: Related Instruments. Section 92(2) prohibits an Insider from dealing or attempting to deal in relation to either the Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity (i.e. to which the Inside Information relates) or a Related Instrument.  The definition of a "Related Instrument" is set out at paragraph 1(9) of the CMC.
target_text:
Application to Financial Instruments and Related Instruments. Section 92(2) (Insider Dealing) also applies to a "Related Instrument", which is defined as meaning:
"…in relation to a Financial Instrument, an investment whose price or value depends on the price or value of the Financial Instrument."
For example, if an Insider has Inside Information relating to an Issuer, A, of Financial Instruments, then a "Related Instrument" could include a Derivative relating to the Financial Instruments of A or another Financial Instrument in a member of A's Group, if the price or value of that other Financial Instrument depends, in whole or in part, on the price or value of Financial Instruments of A.

question: If an Authorised Person owns CET1 Capital instruments issued by a Relevant Entity, what facts make that ownership a “significant investment,” and how does that decision change which CET1 deduction bucket the holding goes into?
gold_answer: To place a holding into the correct CET1 deduction bucket, an Authorised Person must decide whether its holding in a Relevant Entity is a “significant investment,” because the CET1 rules distinguish between deductions for holdings where the Authorised Person has a significant investment and holdings where it does not. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] The holding is a significant investment if any one of these conditions applies: the Authorised Person owns more than 10% of the CET1 Capital instruments issued by the Relevant Entity; or the Authorised Person has Close Links with the entity and owns its CET1 Capital instruments; or the Authorised Person owns the entity’s CET1 Capital instruments and, while the entity is not consolidated under Chapter 8, it is included in the same IFRS accounting consolidation as the Authorised Person for financial reporting. [#SRC:c9f19d0b-d036-4cfe-88ba-7e2528a70c11] If the holding meets one of those tests, the Authorised Person must treat it as a holding where it has a significant investment and deduct the applicable amount under the significant-investment category. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] If none of the tests are met, the holding falls into the non-significant-investment category and the applicable amount must be deducted under that separate category. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]
source_text:
CET1 Deductions - significant investment in a Relevant Entity. For the purposes of Rules 3.10.7(g) and (h), an investment by an Authorised Person in a Relevant Entity must be considered as a significant investment if it meets any of the following conditions:
(a)	the Authorised Person owns more than 10% of the CET1 Capital instruments issued by that entity;
(b)	the Authorised Person has Close Links with that entity and owns CET1 Capital instruments issued by that entity; or
(c)	the Authorised Person owns CET1 Capital instruments issued by that entity and the entity is not included in consolidation pursuant to Chapter 8 of these Rules but is included in the same accounting consolidation as the Authorised Person for the purposes of financial reporting under the International Financial Reporting Standards.

question: If an ADGM Green Portfolio holds Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark, does the Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager still have to hire a third party to attest compliance at least every year, and which part of the assets does that attestation cover?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager of an ADGM Green Portfolio must appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually, but the obligation is expressly limited to the portion of the Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e]. At the same time, the scope statement provides that the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86]. Putting these together, the Investment Manager’s third-party attestation should not be required for the benchmark-tracking Eligible Green Portfolio Assets, even though the Investment Manager still has an attestation obligation for any remaining portion of Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy. The practical result is that the attestation engagement should be structured to cover only the in-scope portion and to exclude the EU Paris Aligned Benchmark-tracking portion.
source_text: Under Rule 3.8.6, the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets which are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark in accordance with Rule ‎3.8.4(b).
target_text: The Green Porftolio Attestation Requirement. The Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager of an ADGM Green Portfolio must appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually. This requirement only applies to that portion of the Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy in accordance with Rule ‎3.8.4(a). This requirement is referred to as the “Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement”.

question: When an Authorised Person is calculating Credit RWA amounts for an SE Exposure using the risk-weight tables, how may it treat a securitisation position that falls into a 1000% risk weight category, and what specific capital component and amount are referenced for the alternative treatment?
gold_answer: For a securitisation position that is in a 1000% risk weight category under the securitisation risk-weight tables used to calculate Credit RWA amounts, the Authorised Person has an alternative to including that position in its Credit RWA calculation. [#TGT:7ce52b92-cdc3-4168-9d40-23e520232638] Specifically, where the position is assigned a 1000% risk weighting pursuant to the tables in Rule 4.14.31, the Authorised Person may instead deduct an amount from capital rather than include the position in the Credit RWA amounts computation. [#SRC:88e1a05a-e874-4528-ba0a-6794021d9a88] The capital component identified for this alternative treatment is CET1 Capital, and the amount to be deducted is the Exposure value of the securitisation position. [#SRC:88e1a05a-e874-4528-ba0a-6794021d9a88] This linkage matters because the tables require assigning a risk weight to each SE Exposure for Credit RWA purposes and explicitly contemplate “1000% or deduction from Capital Resources” at the relevant rating categories, while the source text clarifies the operational alternative by specifying deduction from CET1 Capital of the Exposure value when the 1000% risk weight applies under the referenced tables. [#TGT:7ce52b92-cdc3-4168-9d40-23e520232638] [#SRC:88e1a05a-e874-4528-ba0a-6794021d9a88]
source_text: In respect of securitisation positions which are assigned a 1000% risk weighting pursuant to the tables in Rule 4.14.31, an Authorised Person may as an alternative to including the position in its calculation of Credit RWA amounts, deduct from its CET1 Capital the Exposure value of such positions.

question: For an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, how should the firm align the contents of its Resolution Pack with its broader obligation to maintain records for at least six years, specifically for Client classification and Client agreements?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business should treat the Resolution Pack as a defined subset of its wider recordkeeping population and ensure that the Client classification and Client agreement materials that must appear in the Resolution Pack are also maintained within the firm’s general records for at least six years. [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2] In practice, this means the Resolution Pack must include the records tied to Client classification and Client agreements identified for inclusion, and those same categories must be retained as part of the firm’s sufficient records maintained for the minimum six-year period. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2] Specifically, the Resolution Pack must contain the records of Client classification and Client agreements referenced for Investment Business, and the firm’s general recordkeeping must include documents regarding Client classification under Chapter 2 and a record of each Client Agreement (including later amendments agreed with the Client). [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2] Operationally, the firm should ensure its filing and retention approach allows the Resolution Pack copies (or pointers to them) to be preserved for the full six years as part of the sufficient records maintained for each activity and function. [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity is putting forecast financial information in its disclosure and that forecast comes from a Production Target, what must it say about its assumptions and the Production Target, and how does that fit with the FSRA’s expectation that the disclosure should be fair and balanced compared with the separate report that is attached as an annexure?
gold_answer: The disclosure needs to include a complete set of required assumption and Production Target information for the forecast, and it should be presented in a way that is fair and balanced when compared with the attached separate report, without trying to restate everything in that report. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:b8cb4fdb-f627-43ae-90bf-801a549f8d63] For the forecast financial information, the Mining Reporting Entity must include all material economic assumptions used to determine the forecast and also include all other material assumptions used. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If it believes the material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it must state that and explain the methodology it used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] It must also include the Production Target that the forecast is based on, and that Production Target must include all information required by Rule 11.8.3. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] Separately, where the disclosure includes information that comes from the separate report prepared under Rule 11.6.2 (which must be attached as an annexure), the information in the disclosure must be a fair and balanced representation of that report; however, the FSRA does not expect a full summary, only the material information needed to understand the estimates of Mineral Resources in the separate report that is not already in the body of the disclosure. [#TGT:b8cb4fdb-f627-43ae-90bf-801a549f8d63]
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text: ORE RESERVES . Pursuant to Rule 11.6.1, the information included in the disclosure must be a fair and balanced representation of the information contained in the separate report prepared in accordance with Rule 11.6.2 (which must be included as an annexure to the disclosure).  In complying with this obligation, the FSRA does not expect a Mining Reporting Entity to prepare a summary of all the information contained in the separate report.  Instead, it is expected that that only information which is material to understanding the estimates of Mineral Resources contained in the separate report, that is not otherwise included in the body of the disclosure, be included.

question: When the Regulator discloses Confidential Information, how may it structure the permission to disclose so that it both (i) imposes conditions tied to consents or equivalent confidentiality restrictions and (ii) limits what the recipient can do with the information, including in the context of a disclosure made pursuant to subsection (1)?
gold_answer: The Regulator may frame a disclosure of Confidential Information so that the permission to disclose is conditional and the downstream use of the information is limited, including where the disclosure is made pursuant to subsection (1). [#TGT:98d99b60-b14d-4468-becd-e2c79c8f8b4a] In doing so, the Regulator can impose conditions on the information disclosed, and those conditions may specifically address obtaining necessary consents and, where appropriate, requiring that information received is subject to restrictions on further disclosure that are at least equivalent to the restrictions described in section 198. [#SRC:5b971fba-9c2c-40a0-9b54-e38c1d4d3350] The same disclosure framework also allows the Regulator to restrict the uses to which the Confidential Information disclosed may be put, so that recipients are not free to use the information for unrestricted purposes. [#SRC:5b971fba-9c2c-40a0-9b54-e38c1d4d3350] Consistently, the provisions included in a subsection (1) disclosure may make any permission to disclose subject to conditions (including consents, equivalent section 198-style restrictions, or any other matter the Regulator considers appropriate) and may also restrict the uses of the Confidential Information disclosed. [#TGT:98d99b60-b14d-4468-becd-e2c79c8f8b4a] Together, these tools let the Regulator both control onward disclosure mechanics and constrain permitted uses within the same disclosure permission. [#SRC:5b971fba-9c2c-40a0-9b54-e38c1d4d3350] [#TGT:98d99b60-b14d-4468-becd-e2c79c8f8b4a]
source_text:
Section 199(3) of the FSMR enables the Regulator to, among other things:
(a)	impose conditions on the information disclosed, which may relate to, among other things, the obtaining of consents or, where appropriate, subjecting information received to restrictions on disclosure that are at least equivalent to those set out in section 198, per paragraph 199(3)(a); and
(b)	restrict the uses to which the Confidential Information disclosed may be put.
target_text:
Any disclosure by the Regulator pursuant to subsection  ‎(1) may include, insofar as the Regulator considers appropriate, provisions—
(a)	making any permission to disclose Confidential Information subject to conditions (which may relate to the obtaining of consents, subjecting information received to restrictions on disclosure of Confidential Information at least equivalent to those set out in section 198 or any other matter); and
(b)	restricting the uses to which Confidential Information disclosed may be put.

question: If an Authorised Person is allowed to Provide Custody for a Fund (or act as Trustee of an Investment Trust) and is also allowed to Accept Deposits (or manage a PSIAu), what checks decide whether it is Category 3B or Category 1?
gold_answer: To decide between Category 3B and Category 1, the Authorised Person should look at which permissions are treated as the deciding factor for each category and then apply the relevant “not in” checks. Category 1 applies where the Financial Services Permission authorises Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, and the firm must also not meet the criteria of Category 5. [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] Category 3B applies where the Financial Services Permission authorises Providing Custody (where it does so for a Fund) or Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust, and the firm must also not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5. [#SRC:c1ffeb55-d01d-48f4-b82b-88eb654acbbe] Because Category 3B expressly excludes firms that meet Category 1, a firm that has the Category 1-type permissions (Accepting Deposits or PSIAu management) would fail the Category 3B exclusion test unless it does not meet Category 1. [#SRC:c1ffeb55-d01d-48f4-b82b-88eb654acbbe] [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] In both categories, the guidance clarifies that the firm may have other Regulated Activities, but the listed permissions are what determine the category outcome. [#SRC:c1ffeb55-d01d-48f4-b82b-88eb654acbbe] [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]
source_text:
Category 3B
An Authorised Person is in Category 3B if:
(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of:
(i)	Providing Custody (where it does so for a Fund); or
(ii)	Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust; and
(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5.
Guidance
A Category 3B Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Providing Custody for a Fund or Acting as Trustee of a Fund, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1, 1.3.2 and 1.3.3 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3B.
target_text:
Category 1
An Authorised Person is in Category 1 if:
(a)		(a)	its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu; and
(b)		(b)	it does not meet the criteria of Category 5.
Guidance
A Category 1 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu that is determinative of its belonging to Category 1.
Category 2
Guidance
1.	A Category 2 Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not only as a Matched Principal) or Providing Credit, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1, that are determinative of its belonging to Category 2.
2.	Where the dealing activities of a firm are limited to acting only as Matched Principal, the activities fall in the scope of Category 3A in accordance with Rule 1.3.3(1). A definition of "Matched Principal" is in Rule 1.3.3(2).

question: When the Regulator decides it must not transmit a notice because it considers the Fund Manager or the Private Fund is not compliant (or may become non-compliant) with applicable legislation, or because refraining is necessary to further its objectives, what immediate notification duty does it owe to the Fund Manager regarding that decision?
gold_answer: Where the Regulator reaches a decision that it is prohibited from transmitting a notice—either because it considers the Fund Manager or the Private Fund does not comply with applicable legislation (or may in the future not comply), or because it considers refraining is necessary and appropriate to further one or more of its objectives—it must not proceed with transmitting the notice in those circumstances [#TGT:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c]. In parallel, once the Regulator has made the decision not to transmit a notice, it has an immediate obligation to notify the Fund Manager of that decision [#SRC:3d9f3de4-26a0-451d-8a89-3302fc516cca]. Read together, the prohibition governs the Regulator’s conduct (no transmission when the stated conditions are met), while the obligation governs the Regulator’s communications (promptly informing the Fund Manager that the Regulator has decided not to transmit). This means the Fund Manager should expect timely notice of the Regulator’s non-transmission decision whenever the Regulator relies on the specified compliance-related assessment or its objectives-based assessment as the basis for refraining.
source_text: The Regulator shall immediately notify the Fund Manager of its decision not to transmit a notice in accordance with Rule 3.1.5.
target_text:
The Regulator shall not transmit a notice under Rule 3.1.4‎(a):
(a)	if it considers that the Fund Manager or the Private Fund does not comply with, or it has reasonable grounds for determining that the Fund Manager or the Private Fund may in the future not comply with, applicable legislation including these Rules; or
(b)	if it considers that it is necessary and appropriate to refrain from doing so in order to further one or more of its objectives.

question: What does a Fund Manager have to tell its auditor to do about auditing the Fund’s financial statements, and what does the Fund Manager have to make sure the Auditor says in the Fund Auditor’s Report?
gold_answer: A Fund Manager must do more than simply appoint an auditor; it must set clear requirements for both the audit and the report. The Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to conduct an audit of the Fund’s financial statements in line with the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB), and it must require the auditor to produce a Fund Auditor’s Report on the audited financial statements [#SRC:8949f938-33e5-4393-a256-021917125579]. Then, when the Fund Manager is procuring the production of that Fund Auditor’s Report, it must ensure the Auditor includes specific statements. These cover whether the financial statements were properly prepared using the financial reporting standards adopted by the Fund, whether they give a true and fair view of the Fund’s (or Sub-Fund’s) financial position and results for the annual accounting period and at the end of that period, and whether there are problems such as missing accounting records, disagreement between the financial statements and accounting records/returns, or non-compliance with applicable financial reporting standards [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce]. The Auditor must also state whether it received all necessary information and explanations, whether the Directors’ report or the Fund Manager’s report is consistent with the financial statements, and any other matter required by FUNDS [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce].
source_text:
Function of the Auditor. A Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to:
(a)	conduct an audit of the Fund's financial statements in accordance with the requirements of the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB); and
(b)	produce a Fund Auditor's Report on the audited financial statements in accordance with GEN Rule 6.6.8.

question: When calculating regulatory capital, how must an Authorised Person treat (i) its own capital instruments that it holds or may be required to purchase under an existing contractual obligation, and (ii) Underwriting positions in the capital instruments of Relevant Entities where the Authorised Person has a significant investment—specifically distinguishing the AT1 Capital calculation from the T2 Capital calculation and the applicable five-working-day exclusion?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must apply parallel deduction approaches in AT1 Capital and T2 Capital calculations, but must keep the instrument type and the underwriting holding-period carve-out aligned to the relevant capital layer. [#SRC:3bd61854-86d4-427f-9af0-54918b0e84c8] [#TGT:5e7bdc23-7d1f-4fc2-8c33-dca7595021ab] For own-instrument positions, the Authorised Person must deduct direct and indirect holdings of its own AT1 Capital instruments from AT1 Capital, including cases where it has an actual or contingent obligation to purchase due to an existing contractual obligation. [#SRC:3bd61854-86d4-427f-9af0-54918b0e84c8] Separately, it must deduct direct and indirect holdings of its own T2 Capital instruments from T2 Capital, including own T2 instruments it could be obliged to purchase because of existing contractual obligations. [#TGT:5e7bdc23-7d1f-4fc2-8c33-dca7595021ab] For significant-investment holdings in Relevant Entities, the Authorised Person must deduct direct and indirect holdings of those entities’ AT1 instruments from AT1 Capital, but it does not deduct underwriting positions held for five working days or fewer. [#SRC:3bd61854-86d4-427f-9af0-54918b0e84c8] In the T2 Capital calculation, it must deduct direct and indirect holdings of those entities’ T2 instruments, excluding underwriting positions held for fewer than five working days. [#TGT:5e7bdc23-7d1f-4fc2-8c33-dca7595021ab]

question: When the Regulator holds Confidential Information that qualifies as CRD Information because it was received from an EEA Competent Authority under the Capital Requirements Directive, in what circumstances is the Regulator prohibited from disclosing it, and what consent and purpose limitations must be satisfied before any disclosure can occur?
gold_answer: CRD Information is a defined subset of Confidential Information: it is Confidential Information received or obtained by the Regulator from the EEA Competent Authority by virtue of the Capital Requirements Directive, and an EEA Competent Authority is a public authority or body officially recognised by national law in an EEA jurisdiction and empowered to supervise institutions as part of the supervisory system [#SRC:dc3f77a8-19bb-49c7-a2f8-f257642a9321]. Because of that origin, the Regulator is prohibited from disclosing such Confidential Information under the relevant disclosure gateways unless specific conditions are met [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c]. In particular, where the Confidential Information is CRD Information, the EEA Competent Authority that disclosed it to the Regulator must first give prior written consent to the disclosure. Further, if that consent is granted for a particular purpose, the Regulator may disclose the CRD Information only for that purpose and not for any other use or audience. These constraints operate as mandatory preconditions to any disclosure of CRD Information by the Regulator, notwithstanding other potential disclosure permissions.
source_text:
The exceptions under section 199(1) of FSMR. The provisions in section 199(2) relate specifically to Confidential Information originating in another governmental or regulatory authority, or Confidential Information that is CRD Information, and provide for and are consistent with the exchange of information and professional secrecy requirements in the European Union’s Capital Requirements Directive.  For the purposes of section 199(2):
(a)	‘CRD Information’ is defined as Confidential Information received or obtained by the Regulator from the EEA Competent Authority by virtue of the Capital Requirements Directive; and
(b)	‘EEA Competent Authority’ means a public authority or body officially recognised by national law of a jurisdiction within the EEA and empowered by that national law to supervise institutions as part of the supervisory system.
target_text:
Paragraphs (1)(b)(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (vi) and 1(c) do not permit the Regulator to disclose Confidential Information unless the conditions in paragraphs (a) and (b) are met –
(a)	where the Confidential Information (in whole or in part) originates in another governmental or regulatory authority, whether in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or otherwise, the authority that has disclosed the Confidential Information to the Regulator has given its prior written consent to the disclosure; and
(b)	where the Confidential Information is CRD Information –
(i)	EEA Competent Authority that has disclosed the Confidential Information to the Regulator has given its prior written consent to the disclosure; and
(ii)	if such consent was given for a particular purpose, the disclosure by the Regulator is solely for that purpose.

question: In what admission-related scenarios would the Regulator generally require a Reporting Entity to complete MKT Form 10-1 quarterly, and how do those scenarios align with the specific triggers that make quarterly completion mandatory?
gold_answer: A Reporting Entity must complete MKT Form 10-1 on a quarterly basis when the Regulator requires it, including where that requirement is imposed as a condition of admission to the Official List. [#TGT:67e6fb61-6313-4d10-b3bb-b9b99d81cb75] The Regulator will generally require this quarterly reporting in admission-related circumstances where the Listed Entity being admitted to the Official List is admitted under the assets eligibility test, has less than three years of audited financial statements, or is otherwise considered to need quarterly cash reporting (including where the admission involves a cash-box). [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8] Read together, these passages indicate that the “condition of admission” trigger for quarterly MKT Form 10-1 completion can be met in practice by the Regulator’s general approach to admissions that present heightened cash-reporting needs—such as assets-test admissions, shorter audited financial history, or cash-box admissions. [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8] [#TGT:67e6fb61-6313-4d10-b3bb-b9b99d81cb75] Separately, quarterly completion is also mandatory if the Regulator classifies the Reporting Entity as a Mining Exploration Reporting Entity or a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity, or if the Regulator requires it pursuant to section 84 of the FSMR. [#TGT:67e6fb61-6313-4d10-b3bb-b9b99d81cb75]
source_text: The Regulator will generally require a Reporting Entity to comply with Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i) in circumstances where the Listed Entity with Securities being admitted to the Official List is admitted under the assets eligibility test (see Rule 2.3.16), has less than three years of audited financial statements as prescribed in Rule 2.3.2(1), or is considered by the Regulator, for other reasons, to require quarterly cash reports, such as the admission of a cash-box.
target_text:
A Reporting Entity must complete MKT Form 10-1 on a quarterly basis if the Regulator:
(a)	requires it as a condition of admission to the Official List pursuant to section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR;
(b)	classifies the Reporting Entity as a Mining Exploration Reporting Entity or a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity; or
(c)	requires it pursuant to section 84 of the FSMR.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, how can it avoid having to comply with Rule 11.2.1(1), and what specific disclosure content must it still ensure is included (including the required prominent statement and the Competent Person-related elements)?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity that discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation may treat Rule 11.2.1(1) as not applicable only if it instead complies with the specified alternative rules (Rule 11.7.2, Rule 11.7.3, Rule 11.7.4, and Rule 11.7.6). [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] Even when relying on that carve-out, the entity must still ensure the disclosure contains the required Non-Equivalent Estimates content, including a prominent nearby statement that the estimates are Non-Equivalent Estimates not made under a Mining Reporting Standard, that a Competent Person has not done enough work to classify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard, and that it is uncertain whether further evaluation/exploration will ever allow such disclosure under a Mining Reporting Standard. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] The disclosure must also include the sources and dates of the estimates; explain whether any Mineralisation categories used differ from (or match) those in a Mining Reporting Standard; address relevance and reliability; summarise the work and key assumptions/parameters/methods used; provide any newer relevant estimates/data with sources and dates; and describe what work is needed to verify the estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, including proposed timing and funding source. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] Finally, it must state the classification/reporting standard used and include a statement by a named Competent Person(s) attesting that the information provided for items (3) to (9) accurately reflects available data and studies. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]

question: If the police ask for someone’s answers from an interview under section 206(1)(a) to use against that person in a criminal case, what usually happens first, and when can the statement still be shared?
gold_answer: The statement is not meant to be handed over for criminal proceedings against the same person unless one of two specific conditions applies, and the person is usually told about the request so they can respond. The Investigator must not disclose a statement made by a person in answer to questions asked under a section 206(1)(a) requirement to any law enforcement agency for that purpose unless the person consents or the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose it. [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff] When the Regulator receives a request from a law enforcement agency for those interview answers for criminal proceedings against the person, the Regulator will generally notify the person concerned. [#SRC:1e42ed63-f4af-4b44-9cb5-90fa843a8951] The point of that notice is to give the person a chance either to agree to the disclosure (which would satisfy the consent condition) or to challenge the request. [#SRC:1e42ed63-f4af-4b44-9cb5-90fa843a8951] Even without consent, the statement can still be disclosed if the Regulator is required by law or a court order to disclose it, and that same law/court-order situation is also a stated exception to the Investigator’s non-disclosure rule. [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff]
source_text: If the Regulator receives a request from a law enforcement agency for a person's answers in an interview conducted under section 206(1)(a) of the FSMR for the purpose of criminal proceedings against the person, the Regulator will, in accordance with section 207(2) of the FSMR, generally notify the person concerned of such request (so that the person has an opportunity to either consent to the disclosure or challenge the request), unless the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose the statement.
target_text:
The Investigator shall not disclose a statement made by a person in answer to any question asked pursuant to a requirement made of the person under section ‎206‎(1)‎(a) to any law enforcement agency for the purpose of criminal proceedings against the person unless—
(a)	the person consents to the disclosure; or
(b)	the Regulator is required by law or court order to disclose the statement.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity wants to publish forecast financial information derived from a Production Target again later, what is it allowed to link that forecast to (its holdings or a project), and what must it include so it can leave out the extra supporting details?
gold_answer: Forecast financial information derived from a Production Target may be disclosed in relation to a Mining Reporting Entity’s Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s) [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d]. If the Mining Reporting Entity has already made an earlier disclosure of that kind of forecast financial information that complied with the required content, then a later disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target does not need to repeat the otherwise required supporting information, but only if it meets the stated conditions [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]. The later disclosure must point back to the earlier compliant disclosure and must confirm that all the material assumptions used in the initial disclosure still apply and have not materially changed. Also, if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the later disclosure must include an at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement about the disclosed forecast financial information; and if the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, it must include a similarly prominent and proximate statement tailored to that situation [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4].
target_text:
Forecast financial information derived from a Production Target may be disclosed in relation to either a Mining Reporting Entity’s:
(1)	Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings; or
(2)	material Mining Project(s).

question: If the Fund Manager spots a relevant material change, error, or omission after it has sent the Rule 3.1.2 notification but before Promotion starts in a Host Jurisdiction, what should it do right away, what will the Regulator do next, and what could happen if that issue means the Fund Manager no longer complies with applicable legislation (including these Rules)?
gold_answer: In the period after the Rule 3.1.2 notification and before Promotion begins in a Host Jurisdiction, the Fund Manager must act quickly: once it becomes aware of a material change, error, or omission that is reasonably likely to matter to that notification, it must send written notice to the Regulator without delay. [#TGT:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6] The Regulator then has its own follow-on step: it will promptly give the relevant Host Regulator all relevant details about the material change, error, or omission. [#TGT:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6] Beyond that communication chain, the same kind of issue can have more serious consequences if it leads to non-compliance: where, because of a material change, error, or omission referred to in Rule 3.1.9, the Fund Manager would no longer comply with applicable legislation (including these Rules), the Regulator must take all due measures. [#SRC:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207] Those measures can go as far as de-registering the Private Fund from the Register of Passported Funds, and the Regulator may also take measures when it considers that necessary and appropriate in the circumstances. [#SRC:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207]
source_text: If, as a result of any material change, error, or omission referred to in Rule 3.1.9, the Fund Manager will no longer comply with applicable legislation, including these Rules, or if the Regulator otherwise considers it necessary and appropriate in the circumstances, the Regulator shall take all due measures, including, if necessary, the de-registration of the Private Fund from the Register of Passported Funds in accordance with these Rules.
target_text: If, at any time between the notification pursuant to Rule 3.1.2 and the commencement of Promotion in a Host Jurisdiction, the Fund Manager becomes aware of any material change, error, or omission reasonably likely to be relevant to such notification, the Fund Manager shall give written notice to the Regulator without delay. The Regulator will promptly provide the relevant Host Regulator with all relevant details of such material change, error or omission.

question: Can the Investigator go into a business to inspect and copy documents, and can the Investigator force someone to allow that by sending a written notice? If so, who can get the notice and when can the entry happen?
gold_answer: Yes. The source gives the Investigator permission to enter business premises to inspect and copy documents, but it ties that power to the investigation by limiting it to documents that are relevant for the purposes of the investigation [#SRC:6f288073-515c-4e53-9fa5-16c3700d2767]. The target adds how the Investigator can make that access happen in practice: the Investigator may, by written notice, require the Person Under Investigation or any other person (even if not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to permit the Investigator to enter that person’s business premises during normal business hours to inspect and copy documents on the premises [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. Putting both together, the Investigator can (1) enter premises to inspect/copy documents for the investigation, and (2) use a written notice to require permission to enter from a wide range of people, not just the Person Under Investigation. The timing condition in the target is that entry is during normal business hours, while the source condition is that the documents inspected and copied must be relevant to the investigation.
source_text: Power to enter premises and inspect and copy documents . Section 206(1)(e) of FSMR permits the Investigator to enter business premises for the purpose of inspecting and copying any documents where relevant for the purposes of the investigation.

question: If Restricted Securities are involved in a Takeover or Merger, what does the Listed Entity have to do within two Business Days after issue about the holding lock, and what conditions must be met before the Regulator will consent to selling those Restricted Securities under an offer or a scheme?
gold_answer: The Listed Entity has an early timing obligation tied to enforcement of the holding lock: within two Business Days after issuing Restricted Securities, it must obtain an undertaking from a suitable third party (for example a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD, or another entity the Regulator considers suitable) and submit it to the Regulator; that undertaking must require the third party to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities and not release it without the Regulator’s prior written consent [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76]. When a Takeover or Merger later involves a proposed sale of Restricted Securities, the Regulator will not give consent unless the applicable transaction conditions are satisfied [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd]. For an offer, the offer must be for all Ordinary Securities (or, if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities, all Securities in the same class), at least half of the Securities that are not Restricted Securities covered by the offer must have been accepted, and if the offer is conditional the offeror and the Security Holder must agree in writing that the holding lock is immediately re-imposed for each Security not bought. For a scheme, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity must agree in writing that the holding lock is immediately re-imposed if the Takeover does not take effect.
source_text:
Regulator’s consent to sale of Restricted Securities in a Takeover or Merger. The Regulator will not provide its consent under Rule 9.6.11 unless, to the extent to which they are applicable, all the following requirements are met:
(1)	where there is an offer for Securities:
(a)	the offer is for all of the Ordinary Securities or, if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities, all the Securities in the same class as the Restricted Securities;
(b)	holders of at least half of the Securities that are not Restricted Securities, to which the offer relates, have accepted; and
(c)	if the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder agree in writing that the holding lock (imposed under Rule 9.6.9) be immediately re-imposed for each Security that is not bought by the offeror under the offer; and
(2)	where the offer is to be conducted by way of a ‘scheme’, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity in which the Restricted Securities are held agree in writing that the holding lock imposed under Rule 9.6.9 be immediately re-imposed if the Takeover does not take effect.
target_text: Timing and Enforcement. A Listed Entity must obtain, and submit to the Regulator, within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD or other entity deemed suitable by the Regulator, to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities held by it, and not to release the holding lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity says its key economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, what does it have to add to its disclosure, and what warning applies if it has not signed any sensitive contracts supporting its price, capex, or opex assumptions?
gold_answer: If a Mining Reporting Entity considers its material economic assumptions (used to determine forecast financial information) to be commercially sensitive, it must still disclose all material economic assumptions employed, and it must add a statement that the assumptions are commercially sensitive plus an explanation of the methodology used to determine those assumptions; it must also disclose all other material assumptions utilised [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. At the same time, it needs to be careful not to label information as commercially sensitive when it is not: where the Entity has not yet entered into any commercially sensitive contracts that underpin its commodity price, capital expenditure, or operational expenditure assumptions, it would be difficult to justify treating information about those assumptions as commercially sensitive [#TGT:3b4ca4c9-5690-4bae-8c30-3d06642d6e95]. Practically, that means the Entity should only use the sensitivity statement when there is a real basis for it, and it should ensure the methodology explanation is consistent with the actual circumstances supporting (or not supporting) the sensitivity claim.
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text: ORE RESERVES . Mining Reporting Entities need to be careful not to claim that information is commercially sensitive when this is not the case.  If a Mining Reporting Entity, for example, has not yet entered into any commercially sensitive contracts that underpin its commodity price, capital expenditure or operational expenditure assumptions, it would be difficult to form a view that information about those assumptions would be commercially sensitive.

question: When can an Authorised Person give a Related Person credit on better terms than it gives to non-Related Persons, and what must the Credit Risk policy do to manage conflicts of interest and approvals in that situation?
gold_answer: The Credit Risk policy must manage conflicts of interest around providing and managing credit by setting out adequate procedures, including measures to prevent any Person who directly or indirectly benefits from the credit from being part of the process of granting or managing that credit [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496]. It must also address Related Person transactions by generally prohibiting Exposures to Related Persons on more favourable terms than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons, and by requiring that certain higher-risk or higher-amount Exposures (and any write-offs) be subject to prior written approval by the firm’s Governing Body or its delegate, with beneficiaries excluded from the approval process [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496]. However, the prohibition on more favourable terms does not apply if the credit is provided under an Employee credit policy that is widely available to Employees of the Authorised Person, is approved by the Governing Body or its delegate, and clearly sets out the terms, conditions, and limits for such credit [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91]. That Employee credit policy must also include mechanisms to ensure ongoing compliance and immediate reporting of deviations or breaches to the Governing Body or its delegate for timely action [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91].
source_text:
Credit Risk policy. In relation to conflicts of interest and Related Person transactions, the policy must:
(a)	set out adequate procedures for handling conflicts of interest relating to the provision and management of credit, including measures to prevent any Person directly or indirectly benefiting from the credit being part of the process of granting or managing the credit;
(b)	subject to Rule 4.4.5, prohibit Exposures to Related Persons on terms that are more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons; and
(c)	if Exposures to Related Persons are allowed on terms which are no more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons, set out procedures that:
(i)	require such Exposures, and any write off of such Exposures, exceeding specific amounts or otherwise posing special risks to the Authorised Person, to be made subject to the prior written approval of the firm's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate; and
(ii)	exclude Persons directly or indirectly benefiting from the grant or write off of such Exposures being part of the approval process.

question: If the Regulator decides it can refuse to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action (fully or partly) because one of the listed conditions applies, can it still use Resolution Tools or Resolution Powers to support that foreign action, and what approval limits apply?
gold_answer: The Regulator can only use Resolution Tools or Resolution Powers to support, or give full effect to, a foreign action where that action is a Recognised Foreign Resolution Action. Under the SOURCE, the Regulator may refuse to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action in whole or in part if it is satisfied that one or more specified conditions are met, such as an adverse effect on financial stability in the ADGM, the Resolution Conditions not being met for the relevant entity, Resolution Action in relation to an ADGM Branch not being necessary to achieve Resolution Objectives, unequal treatment or legal rights for creditors located or payable in the ADGM compared with creditors in the relevant non-ADGM jurisdiction, or material fiscal implications for the UAE or the ADGM [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba]. The TARGET then states that, for supporting or giving full effect to a Recognised Foreign Resolution Action, the Regulator may exercise one or more Resolution Tools or Resolution Powers, but this is subject to any requirement for ex-ante judicial approval [#TGT:5798f720-7021-4b63-9ebe-f1a30aebee29]. So if recognition is refused (or refused in part), the Regulator’s ability to take supporting action is correspondingly reduced, and any permitted action must still comply with any ex-ante judicial approval requirement.
target_text: For the purposes of supporting, or giving full effect to, a Recognised Foreign Resolution Action, the Regulator may exercise one or more Resolution Tools, or one or more Resolution Powers, subject to any requirement for ex-ante judicial approval in compliance with section 27.

question: If the Resolution Pack must include Third-Party Agent assessments and acknowledgements for Client Money and Client Investments, how does that fit with the rule that an Authorised Person must keep sufficient records for each activity and function for at least six years?
gold_answer: The Resolution Pack requirement and the six-year recordkeeping requirement work together: the Authorised Person must include certain Third-Party Agent documentation in the Resolution Pack, and it must also ensure those records are part of a broader, sufficiently complete record set retained for at least six years. The Resolution Pack must include the assessment of appropriateness of a Third-Party Agent and the acknowledgement by the Third-Party Agent in respect of Client Money, and similarly the assessment of appropriateness of a Third Party Agent and acknowledgement by the Third-Party Agent in respect of Client Investments [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. Separately, the Authorised Person must, for a minimum of six years, maintain sufficient records in relation to each activity and function, including (where applicable) records tied to Client-facing activities such as Financial Instruments provided to or Regulated Activities carried out for the benefit of a Client, advice or recommendations, and core client documentation like Client classification documents and Client Agreement records (including amendments) [#TGT:6d915e8a-721f-40a5-87a3-96f0c6727cd2]. So, Third-Party Agent records should be kept both as required Resolution Pack contents and within the longer-term, activity-based recordkeeping framework.

question: When the Regulator receives a request from a Host Regulator to conduct an on-site inspection relating to a Passported Fund, how should the Regulator determine whether it must permit and accompany the inspection versus when it may refuse to cooperate, particularly where enforcement action or judicial proceedings exist for the same conduct and the same Persons?
gold_answer: The Regulator’s default position, when it receives a Host Regulator request to carry out an on-site inspection connected to a Passported Fund, is to allow the inspection to proceed and to accompany the Host Regulator during the on-site visit.
