[#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6] However, the Regulator may decline to act on a Host Regulator’s cooperation request for an inspection if specific parallel actions already exist concerning the same conduct and the same Persons. [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c] In practice, the Regulator should (i) confirm that the request is for an on-site inspection and that it is in relation to a Passported Fund, because that is the trigger for the permit-and-accompany approach; and then (ii) assess whether either refusal circumstance applies. [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6] The refusal circumstances are limited to cases where the Regulator has already started or finished enforcement action about the same conduct and the same Persons, or where judicial proceedings have already been started or finished about the same conduct and the same Persons. [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c] If neither of those circumstances applies, the Regulator should permit the inspection and accompany it during the on-site inspection. [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6]
source_text: Where the Regulator receives a request from a Host Regulator to carry out an on-site inspection in relation to a Passported Fund, the Regulator shall, subject to Rule 9.3.2, permit such inspection and accompany it during the on-site inspection.
target_text:
The Regulator may refuse to act on a request by a Host Regulator for cooperation in relation to an inspection in the following circumstances:
(a)	the Regulator has already commenced, or concluded, enforcement action in respect of the same conduct and the same Persons; or
(b)	judicial proceedings have already been initiated, or concluded, in respect of the same conduct and the same Persons.

question: When preparing the annual report, what must the Board ensure regarding (i) a separate section on the audit committee’s work and (ii) explanations of safeguards for auditor independence in non-audit services, to evidence that Shareholders’ rights are effectively enabled and dialogue is promoted?
gold_answer: The Board must ensure that Shareholders’ rights are properly safeguarded through appropriate measures that enable Shareholders to exercise their rights effectively, promote effective dialogue with Shareholders and other key stakeholders as appropriate, and prevent any abuse or oppression of minority Shareholders [#TGT:07fe857d-d32b-4e85-a5b2-f6252690dd58]. In the annual report, this should be supported by transparency measures directed to Shareholders. Specifically, a separate section of the annual report should describe the work of the audit committee in discharging its responsibilities, giving Shareholders visibility into how the audit committee has performed its role and providing a concrete basis for engagement and scrutiny [#SRC:e6fc1de1-709b-4e05-b519-c6d344a0d34e]. In addition, the annual report should explain to Shareholders how auditor objectivity and independence is safeguarded where the auditor provides non-audit services, addressing a key area where Shareholders may have concerns and enabling more informed dialogue [#SRC:e6fc1de1-709b-4e05-b519-c6d344a0d34e]. These disclosures are not standalone; they should be treated as part of the Board’s overall measures to enable effective exercise of Shareholder rights and to reduce the risk of abuse or oppression, including of minority Shareholders [#TGT:07fe857d-d32b-4e85-a5b2-f6252690dd58].
source_text:
Audit committee. A separate section of the annual report should describe the work of the audit committee in discharging its responsibilities. The annual report should also explain to Shareholders how, if the auditor provides non audit services, auditor objectivity and independence is safeguarded.
Principle 5 – Shareholder rights and effective dialogue
Rule 9.2.7
"The Board must ensure that the rights of Shareholders are properly safeguarded through appropriate measures that enable the Shareholders to exercise their rights effectively, promote effective dialogue with Shareholders and other key stakeholders as appropriate, and prevent any abuse or oppression of minority Shareholders."
target_text: Principle 5 – Shareholder rights and effective dialogue. The Board must ensure that the rights of Shareholders are properly safeguarded through appropriate measures that enable the Shareholders to exercise their rights effectively, promote effective dialogue with Shareholders and other key stakeholders as appropriate, and prevent any abuse or oppression of minority Shareholders.

question: Does a Reporting Entity have to appoint an auditor, and if so, what rules must it follow when making that appointment?
gold_answer: Yes. A Reporting Entity is under a requirement to appoint an auditor, so it must take action to ensure an auditor is appointed rather than treating it as optional [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33]. In addition, the way the Reporting Entity fulfills that requirement is constrained by the applicable appointment framework: the Reporting Entity shall have an auditor appointed in accordance with Part 15 and any Rules made for the purposes of that Part [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb]. This means compliance is not achieved merely by selecting an auditor; the Reporting Entity must ensure the appointment process and outcome align with Part 15 and any related Rules. Taken together, the passages require both the appointment itself and adherence to the specified Part 15/Rules-based mechanism for making that appointment.
source_text: A Reporting Entity is required under section 82 of the FSMR to appoint an auditor.
target_text:
Financial reports. Appointment of auditors
A Reporting Entity shall have an auditor Appointed in accordance with ‎Part 15 and any Rules made for the purposes of that Part.

question: If an Issuer wants its Securities admitted to trading on an MTF and plans an Exempt Offer to up to 200 people who are not Professional Clients, what extra condition about the offer channel must be met, and can the Issuer also offer to Professional Clients at the same time?
gold_answer: For the “up to 200” route, the offer must fit the circumstance where an Offer in or from the ADGM is directed at no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients (and not Market Counterparties) and the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] In the MTF admission context described, an Issuer can also run a simultaneous Exempt Offer to an unlimited number of Professional Clients alongside the offer to up to 200 non‑Professional Clients. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] The Professional Client leg is consistent with the prescribed Exempt Offer circumstance for an Offer made to or directed at only Professional Clients. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] When structuring the combined approach for admission to trading on an MTF, the Issuer may rely on one or more Exempt Offer circumstances, but there is a specific carve-out: the circumstance identified as MKT Rule 4.3.1(2) cannot be used as part of that combination. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]
source_text: MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) provides for the specific circumstance where an Exempt Offer can be directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients, where the Securities are to be admitted to trading on a MTF.  An Issuer seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF in accordance with MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) may also, pursuant to MKT Rule 4.3.3, utilise an Exempt Offer that relies on one or more of the circumstances within MKT Rule 4.3.1, with the exception of MKT Rule 4.3.1(2).  For example, an Issuer may make a simultaneous Exempt Offer to 200 Persons under MKT rule 4.3.1(13), and an unlimited number of Professional Clients under MKT Rule 4.3.1(1).

question: If someone wants Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, do they have to avoid doing so unless there is an Approved Prospectus, or does that “shall not” rule not apply when the Securities are Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1 (as long as Rule 4.4.2 is met)?
gold_answer: Under the prohibition, a person shall not have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange unless there is an Approved Prospectus in relation to the relevant Securities, and this is framed as being “subject to subsection (3)” and uses the explicit prohibition term “shall not” [#TGT:82ade9b4-bba4-449c-815c-32d6ef292b54]. But the scope text narrows that outcome for a particular category: it states that the prohibition in section 61(1) of the FSMR does not apply to the admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange of Securities that are Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1, and it adds that this non-application is subject to the requirement in Rule 4.4.2 [#SRC:f70272ac-30bf-4e62-92d7-8b863f75cdf9]. Putting both together, the “shall not” restriction on admission to trading is not meant to bite where the Securities are Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1, but only if the Rule 4.4.2 requirement is satisfied. So the key checks are: (1) the Securities are Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1, and (2) Rule 4.4.2’s requirement is met; otherwise the Approved Prospectus condition remains the operative prohibition.
source_text: The prohibition in section 61(1) of the FSMR does not apply, subject to the requirement in Rule 4.4.2, to the admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange of Securities that are Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1.
target_text:
A person shall not, subject to subsection ‎(3)—
(a)	make an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market; or
(b)	have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange;
unless there is an Approved Prospectus in relation to the relevant Securities.

question: If an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 is checking whether it needs to tell the Regulator about low Capital Resources, how should it use the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum (as part of the Capital Requirement under Section 3.6), and what exactly must it do when Capital Resources drop too far?
gold_answer: To decide whether it must notify the Regulator, an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 needs to compare its Capital Resources to its Capital Requirement, and that Capital Requirement is calculated under Section 3.6 with the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum included as a component. [#SRC:596309d5-cc1a-4a45-9e6d-2042ff11da76] The notification trigger occurs when Capital Resources fall below 120% of the Capital Requirement (meaning the 120% test is applied to the Capital Requirement figure that includes the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum component). [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d] When that happens, the firm must notify the Regulator immediately and then confirm the notification in writing. [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d] Because the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum is specifically described as relevant to determining whether the Regulator has to be notified under Rule 3.20.2, the firm should ensure it is using the correct Capital Requirement calculation when applying the 120% threshold. [#SRC:596309d5-cc1a-4a45-9e6d-2042ff11da76] Put together, the compliance steps are: compute the Capital Requirement under Section 3.6 (including the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum), monitor Capital Resources against 120% of that amount, and if the firm falls below, notify immediately and follow up with written confirmation. [#SRC:596309d5-cc1a-4a45-9e6d-2042ff11da76] [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d]
source_text: The Expenditure Based Capital Minimum is a component of the calculation of the Capital Requirement under Section 3.6 and is relevant in determining whether the Regulator has to be notified under Rule 3.20.2.
target_text: Notifications to the Regulator. An Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 must notify the Regulator immediately and confirm in writing if its Capital Resources fall below 120% of its Capital Requirement.

question: Where an Issuer is seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF and intends to rely on the Exempt Offer circumstance that permits an Offer to no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients, can the Issuer simultaneously structure the same fundraising as an Exempt Offer to an unlimited number of Professional Clients, and what limitation applies to which Exempt Offer circumstances may be combined?
gold_answer: Yes. An Issuer seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF may run a simultaneous Exempt Offer that (i) is directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients and (ii) is also directed to an unlimited number of Professional Clients, provided the Issuer is relying on the relevant Exempt Offer circumstances in combination as permitted. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42] The “200 Persons” limb corresponds to the prescribed Exempt Offer circumstance for an Offer in or from the ADGM directed at no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients (and not Market Counterparties), where the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] The “unlimited Professional Clients” limb aligns with the prescribed Exempt Offer circumstance for an Offer made to or directed at only Professional Clients. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] When combining Exempt Offer circumstances for this MTF admission scenario, the Issuer may rely on one or more of the circumstances within the relevant Exempt Offer rule set, but it cannot use the circumstance identified as MKT Rule 4.3.1(2) as part of that combination. [#SRC:d2b137bd-19a4-4fb0-aaf3-0dddc7610d42]
source_text: MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) provides for the specific circumstance where an Exempt Offer can be directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients, where the Securities are to be admitted to trading on a MTF.  An Issuer seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF in accordance with MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) may also, pursuant to MKT Rule 4.3.3, utilise an Exempt Offer that relies on one or more of the circumstances within MKT Rule 4.3.1, with the exception of MKT Rule 4.3.1(2).  For example, an Issuer may make a simultaneous Exempt Offer to 200 Persons under MKT rule 4.3.1(13), and an unlimited number of Professional Clients under MKT Rule 4.3.1(1).

question: When the Investigator needs access to documents relevant to an investigation, how can the Investigator lawfully obtain inspection-and-copying access to Documents on a person’s business premises, and what procedural and timing conditions apply when the Investigator uses a written notice to secure that access?
gold_answer: The Investigator can obtain inspection-and-copying access to Documents on business premises in two complementary ways: (i) by exercising the statutory power to enter business premises to inspect and copy documents that are relevant to the investigation, and (ii) by issuing a written notice that requires a person to permit entry for that same inspection-and-copying purpose, subject to specified conditions. [#SRC:6f288073-515c-4e53-9fa5-16c3700d2767] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] Using the written-notice route, the Investigator may direct either the Person Under Investigation or any other person (even if not connected to the Person Under Investigation) to permit entry to that person’s business premises. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] The notice-based permission is constrained by timing and purpose: entry must be during normal business hours and must be for inspecting and copying Documents on the premises. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] Separately, the underlying entry-and-copying power is framed by relevance to the investigation: the Investigator’s entry to business premises is for inspecting and copying documents where those documents are relevant for the purposes of the investigation. [#SRC:6f288073-515c-4e53-9fa5-16c3700d2767] Read together, the written notice provides a procedural mechanism (including who may be required and the normal-business-hours condition) to facilitate the Investigator’s investigation-relevance-based inspection and copying on business premises. [#SRC:6f288073-515c-4e53-9fa5-16c3700d2767] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]
source_text: Power to enter premises and inspect and copy documents . Section 206(1)(e) of FSMR permits the Investigator to enter business premises for the purpose of inspecting and copying any documents where relevant for the purposes of the investigation.

question: If a Third Party Transaction wasn’t authorised under Rule 20.7 and it causes an unauthorised Payment Transaction, who does the Third Party Provider have to pay back (and how do you avoid paying the same amount twice), and what is the latest deadline after the Third Party Provider confirms the transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed?
gold_answer: When an executed Third Party Transaction was not authorised in line with Rule 20.7 and it leads to an unauthorised Payment Transaction, the Third Party Provider must make refunds to both the Primary Financial Institution and the Customer, with an offset to prevent double recovery. [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe] The Third Party Provider must refund the Primary Financial Institution for any amount the Primary Financial Institution may already have refunded to the Customer. [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe] It must also refund the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction, but it can subtract (i.e., pay “less”) any amount it has already refunded to the Primary Financial Institution, so the Customer is not effectively reimbursed twice for the same unauthorised amount. [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe] After the Third Party Provider has confirmed that the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, it must provide the refund promptly and no later than the end of the day following the day of that confirmation. [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] This creates a clear latest cut-off tied to the confirmation date, rather than the original execution date. [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]
source_text: Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. The Third Party Provider must provide a refund under Rule 20.12.1 as soon as practicable, and in any event no later than the end of the day following the day on which it has confirmed that the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed.
target_text:
Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions. Subject to Rules 20.10 and 20.11, where an executed Third Party Transaction was not authorised in accordance with Rule 20.7 and the Third Party Transaction leads to an unauthorised Payment Transaction, the Third Party Provider must:
(a)	refund the Primary Financial Institution for the amount that the Primary Financial Institution may have already refunded to the Customer; and
(b)	refund the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction, less any amount that the Third Party Provider has refunded to the Primary Financial Institution.

question: If someone is told they must come to an interview to answer questions, what kind of notice do they get first, and can they refuse to answer because it might incriminate them or reveal a confidential communication when the request is made under the listed sections?
gold_answer: Before the interview happens, the person must be given written notice telling them they are required to attend the interview to answer questions. [#SRC:4d708250-cc2d-408e-9e2f-d77689864eda] When the obligation to answer questions (and related obligations to allow inspection/copying, or to give/produce information or a Document) is imposed under sections 201, 203, or 206(1)(a), (b), (c) and (e), the person cannot rely on certain arguments as a valid reason to refuse or fail to comply. [#TGT:4a2d4419-4e18-431a-9f52-59dae76a79ab] Specifically for the interview context, the person is not entitled to refuse or fail to answer a question just because the answer might incriminate them, expose them to a penalty, or disclose a communication made in confidence, with the confidentiality aspect being subject to section 209(6). [#SRC:4d708250-cc2d-408e-9e2f-d77689864eda] The same “not a reasonable excuse” approach applies to refusing or failing to permit inspection/copying of information or a Document, or to give/produce (or procure the giving/production of) information or a Document, where the person’s reason is that it might incriminate them or reveal a confidential communication (again subject to section 209(6)). [#TGT:4a2d4419-4e18-431a-9f52-59dae76a79ab]
source_text: Power to require a person to attend an interview . A person required to attend an interview will first be provided with written notice requiring their attendance at the interview to answer questions. Pursuant to section 206(5) of FSMR, an interviewee is not entitled to refuse or fail to answer a question on the basis that their answers may incriminate them, make them liable for a penalty or might reveal a communication made in confidence (subject to section 209(6) of FSMR).
target_text:
Subject to section ‎210‎(3), it is not a reasonable excuse for a person to refuse or fail to—
(a)	permit inspection and copying of any information or Document;
(b)	give or produce, or procure the giving or production of, any information or Document; or
(c)	answer questions;
pursuant to any requirement under sections ‎201, ‎203 and ‎206‎(1)‎(a), ‎(b), ‎(c) and ‎(e) on the grounds that any such information or Document or answer, as the case may be—
(d)	might tend to incriminate the person; or
(e)	is, or contains, or might reveal a communication made in confidence (subject to section ‎209‎(6)).

question: When a Listed Entity/Reporting Entity writes its annual financial report, what does it need to say about adopting the Corporate Governance Principles, and how does that connect to the need to comply with Rule 9.2.10 on annual reporting of compliance?
gold_answer: In its annual financial report, a Listed Entity to which the annual reporting section applies must make specific statements about its Corporate Governance Principles position, and this reporting should be handled with awareness that Listed Entities/Reporting Entities also have to comply with Rule 9.2.10 on annual reporting of their compliance with those principles. [#SRC:88ccc385-cfe8-4e4e-afd3-80026e74b4dd] The annual financial report must state whether the best practice standards in APP 4 (the Corporate Governance Principles) have been adopted. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] If the standards have not been fully adopted or have only been partially adopted, the report must explain why that is the case and describe what actions (if any) have been taken to achieve compliance to the extent the standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] The report must also include a Directors’ statement on whether the Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, and that statement must be supported by information and assumptions and may include qualifications if needed. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] Preparing these disclosures in the annual financial report helps align the entity’s annual reporting with the separate Rule 9.2.10 compliance-reporting obligation. [#SRC:88ccc385-cfe8-4e4e-afd3-80026e74b4dd]
source_text: Note that Listed Entities/Reporting Entities are also required to comply with Rule 9.2.10 on annual reporting of their compliance with Corporate Governance Principles.
target_text:
Annual reporting on compliance. The annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which this section applies must:
(1)	state whether the best practice standards specified in APP 4 (the "Corporate Governance Principles") have been adopted by the Listed Entity;
(2)	if the best practice standards in APP 4 have not been fully adopted or have been only partially adopted explain:
(a)	why the best practice standards were not adopted fully or adopted only partially, as is relevant; and
(b)	what actions, if any, have been taken by the Listed Entity to achieve compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles to the extent the relevant best practice standards were not adopted, or were only partially adopted; and
(3)	include a statement by Directors whether or not, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework of the Listed Entity is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, with supporting information and assumptions, and qualifications if necessary.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity shares material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, when does it not have to follow Rule 11.2.1(1), and what information still has to be put into the disclosure (especially what must be said about the Mining Reporting Standard and the Competent Person)?
gold_answer: Rule 11.2.1(1) does not need to be followed for a Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure of material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation only where the Mining Reporting Entity instead complies with Rule 11.7.2, Rule 11.7.3, Rule 11.7.4, and Rule 11.7.6. [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] However, the disclosure must still contain a defined set of information about the Non-Equivalent Estimates. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] This includes a clear, nearby statement that the estimates are Non-Equivalent Estimates and are not disclosed under a Mining Reporting Standard, that a Competent Person has not done enough work to classify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard, and that it is uncertain whether further evaluation and/or Exploration work will ever allow them to be disclosed that way. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] The Mining Reporting Entity must also provide the sources and dates of the estimates; explain whether any Mineralisation categories used are different from, or the same as, those in a Mining Reporting Standard; and cover relevance, reliability, the work done and key assumptions/methods, and any newer relevant estimates or data with their sources and dates. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] It must also describe what verification work is needed, the proposed timing and funding for that work, identify the classification/reporting standard used, and include a statement by a named Competent Person(s) confirming the accuracy of the information provided for items (3) to (9). [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]

question: When the FSRA expects a "substantial additional" regulatory burden or costs/effort in dealing with an application or ongoing supervision, what should the Applicant/Authorised Person do regarding fee implications, and how does this relate to the Regulator’s ability to require a supplementary fee (including in the example of migrating an MTF to become a conventional "Securities" Recognised Investment Exchange)?
gold_answer: Where a matter creates a “substantial additional” burden for the FSRA/Regulator, the fee outcome can extend beyond standard charges, and the Applicant/Authorised Person should proactively engage early on fee implications. [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc] Specifically, the FSRA indicates it retains the ability to impose additional fees when a “substantial additional” regulatory burden is placed on it, and it highlights migration of an MTF into a conventional “Securities” Recognised Investment Exchange as an example of such a circumstance. [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc] In parallel, the Regulator’s supplementary-fee power is framed around situations where it expects to incur substantial additional costs or to expend substantial additional effort in handling an application, authorisation, filing, or in conducting on-going supervision. [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080] Taken together, the practical compliance step is that, when the Applicant/Authorised Person anticipates a scenario like an MTF migration (or any application/supervision activity likely to drive substantial additional effort), they should discuss fee implications with the FSRA as early as practicable, because the Regulator may respond by requiring a supplementary fee reflecting that additional cost/effort. [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc] [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]
source_text:
FEES
Cumulative application of Fees
Pursuant to FEES Rule 1.2.4, the FSRA reserves its right to impose additional fees in circumstances where a ‘substantial additional’ regulatory burden is imposed on FSRA. In such circumstances, including the migration of an MTF to become a conventional ‘Securities’ Recognised Investment Exchange, the FSRA recommends that the Applicant/Authorised Person discuss FEE implications with the FSRA as early as practicable.
target_text:
Supplementary fees
The Regulator may require a Person to pay to the Regulator a supplementary fee in circumstances where it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort in dealing with an application, authorisation, filing or when conducting on-going supervision.

question: If an Authorised Person has an SFT pre settlement Counterparty Exposure that is not covered by a qualifying cross product Netting agreement, what number do they use for E in the two SFT cases listed, and when can they take eligible financial Collateral into account if the exposure is determined under Rule 4.9.15?
gold_answer: For an SFT pre settlement Counterparty Exposure that is not covered by a qualifying cross product Netting agreement, the Authorised Person must calculate E using the rule that matches the SFT type, and eligible financial Collateral can only be reflected when the exposure is determined under Rule 4.9.15 and the collateral is eligible financial Collateral taken for that SFT. [#TGT:9578677d-803d-4f27-b8f6-2e4bdf56805e] [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] Specifically, if the Authorised Person lends Securities to a Counterparty or sells Securities to a Counterparty and agrees to buy back those Securities later at a set price and date, E is the latest fair value of the Securities that were lent or sold. [#TGT:9578677d-803d-4f27-b8f6-2e4bdf56805e] If instead the Authorised Person lends cash (by borrowing Securities from the Counterparty) or pays cash to buy Securities and agrees to sell those Securities back later at a set price and date, E is the amount of cash lent or paid. [#TGT:9578677d-803d-4f27-b8f6-2e4bdf56805e] When the Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and the exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15, the effect of that collateral may be recognised, but only by applying Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778]
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.
target_text:
Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person must determine E, for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT which is not covered by a qualifying cross product Netting agreement as follows:
(a)	in the case where the Authorised Person has lent Securities to a Counterparty or sold Securities to a Counterparty with a commitment to repurchase those Securities at a specified price on a specified future date, the latest fair value of the Securities lent or sold; and
(b)	in the case where the Authorised Person has lent cash to a Counterparty through the borrowing of Securities from the Counterparty or paid cash for the purchase of Securities from a Counterparty with a commitment to resell those Securities at a specified price on a specified future date, the amount of cash lent or paid.

question: Where Eligible Green Portfolio Assets in an ADGM Green Portfolio are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark, must the Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager still appoint a third party to provide ongoing and at least annual attestation of compliance, and how does this interact with the limitation that the attestation obligation applies only to the portion invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy?
gold_answer: The Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager of an ADGM Green Portfolio is generally required to appoint a third party to attest, on an ongoing basis and at least annually, to the Investment Manager’s compliance with the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement, but that obligation is scoped to apply only to the portion of the Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy [#TGT:8c92c1b5-2b0d-41a3-b4f4-1b590557042e]. Separately, the scope provision states that the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark [#SRC:9c6ac3b6-ffca-4e6e-a0d2-7252f3e4be86]. Read together, the Investment Manager must apply the attestation obligation only to the relevant portion of Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that falls within the stated applicability, and must exclude from that attestation any Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that meet the EU Paris Aligned Benchmark condition. In practice, this means the third-party appointment and attestation coverage should be calibrated to the portfolio’s composition so that only in-scope assets are attested and the benchmark-tracking assets are carved out.
source_text: Under Rule 3.8.6, the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement does not apply to Eligible Green Portfolio Assets which are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark in accordance with Rule ‎3.8.4(b).
target_text: The Green Porftolio Attestation Requirement. The Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager of an ADGM Green Portfolio must appoint a third party to attest to its compliance with the Green Portfolio Investment Requirement on an ongoing basis and at least annually. This requirement only applies to that portion of the Eligible Green Portfolio Assets that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy in accordance with Rule ‎3.8.4(a). This requirement is referred to as the “Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement”.

question: When the Regulator discloses Confidential Information, may it make the permission to disclose subject to conditions, including requirements around obtaining consents and ensuring the recipient applies disclosure restrictions that are at least equivalent to the relevant confidentiality restrictions?
gold_answer: Yes. The framework permits the Regulator, when making a disclosure of Confidential Information, to attach conditions to the permission to disclose, to the extent the Regulator considers appropriate. Those conditions may address how the disclosure is managed, including requiring the obtaining of consents and, where appropriate, requiring that information received is subjected to restrictions on further disclosure that are at least equivalent to the relevant confidentiality restrictions. This means the Regulator can structure the permission so that disclosure is not unconditional, but instead is controlled through specified safeguards that govern the handling of the Confidential Information by the recipient. The same permission also allows the Regulator to restrict the uses to which the disclosed Confidential Information may be put, reinforcing that both onward disclosure and downstream use can be constrained as part of the disclosure arrangement. These powers are described as enabling the Regulator to impose conditions on the information disclosed and to restrict uses [#SRC:5b971fba-9c2c-40a0-9b54-e38c1d4d3350], and are reflected in the permission to disclose being made subject to conditions (including consents and equivalent restrictions) insofar as the Regulator considers appropriate [#TGT:98d99b60-b14d-4468-becd-e2c79c8f8b4a].
source_text:
Section 199(3) of the FSMR enables the Regulator to, among other things:
(a)	impose conditions on the information disclosed, which may relate to, among other things, the obtaining of consents or, where appropriate, subjecting information received to restrictions on disclosure that are at least equivalent to those set out in section 198, per paragraph 199(3)(a); and
(b)	restrict the uses to which the Confidential Information disclosed may be put.
target_text:
Any disclosure by the Regulator pursuant to subsection  ‎(1) may include, insofar as the Regulator considers appropriate, provisions—
(a)	making any permission to disclose Confidential Information subject to conditions (which may relate to the obtaining of consents, subjecting information received to restrictions on disclosure of Confidential Information at least equivalent to those set out in section 198 or any other matter); and
(b)	restricting the uses to which Confidential Information disclosed may be put.

question: If Restricted Securities are issued and then a Takeover happens, what must a Listed Entity do within two Business Days to set up the holding lock, and when can the Regulator allow the party managing the holding lock to release it?
gold_answer: The Listed Entity has a timing and submission obligation tied to the holding lock: within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, it must obtain an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD or another entity the Regulator considers suitable, and it must submit that undertaking to the Regulator [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76]. That undertaking must cover two key points: the entity will place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities it holds, and it will not release the holding lock unless it first has the Regulator’s prior written consent [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76]. Separately, in a Takeover or Merger scenario, the Regulator may consent to the party that is managing the holding lock releasing it, but only to enable holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer or to transfer or cancel Securities under a Takeover [#SRC:12178c65-d1b6-440a-91e1-c670c7d9ab67]. This means the lock can be lifted only through the Regulator’s consent pathway, even when a corporate transaction creates a need to act.
source_text: Regulator’s consent to sale of Restricted Securities in a Takeover or Merger. The Regulator may consent to a party that is managing a holding lock in accordance with Rule 9.6.9 releasing the holding lock, to enable holders of Restricted Securities to accept an offer, or transfer or cancel Securities, under a Takeover.
target_text: Timing and Enforcement. A Listed Entity must obtain, and submit to the Regulator, within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD or other entity deemed suitable by the Regulator, to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities held by it, and not to release the holding lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent.

question: When does a message count as an Offer of Securities because it is a communication to any person (in any form) that helps an investor decide to buy or subscribe, and when is it not treated as an offer because it is linked to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, ongoing reporting to the Regulator or a Recognised Investment Exchange, or another exempt communication in Rules?
gold_answer: Both passages describe an Offer of Securities as a very broad category of message: it covers any communication to any person, in any form or by any means, that presents information about the Offer and the Securities offered (including the terms of the Offer) in a way that enables an investor to decide to buy or subscribe to those Securities [#SRC:b3c9bf5b-e0ac-4be7-badf-15646cde6e09] [#TGT:35fa228f-ac9c-4d5f-82af-61d001921310]. So you look at what the message does: does it give enough information about the Offer and the Securities for an investor to make a buy/subscribe decision, regardless of whether it is an email, website, presentation, or other medium? The TARGET then adds important carve-outs: even if a communication looks like it could influence an investor, it is excluded if it is in connection with trading of Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, if it is made to comply with the on going reporting requirements of the Regulator or a Recognised Investment Exchange, or if it is another type of communication that Rules prescribe as exempt [#TGT:35fa228f-ac9c-4d5f-82af-61d001921310].
source_text:
MARKETS RULES – OFFERS OF SECURITIES TO THE PUBLIC
Offers of Securities
As set out in section 59 of FSMR, an Offer of Securities to the Public is “a communication to any person in any form or by any means presenting information on the Offer and the Securities offered so as to enable an investor to decide to buy or subscribe to those Securities”.
target_text:
General prohibitions and definitions. Definition of an Offer of Securities
An Offer of Securities means a communication to any person in any form or by any means, presenting information on the terms of the Offer and the Securities offered, so as to enable an investor to decide to buy or subscribe to those Securities but excluding—
(a)	any communication in connection with the trading of Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange;
(b)	any communication made for the purposes of complying with the on going reporting requirements of the Regulator or a Recognised Investment Exchange; or
(c)	any other communication prescribed in Rules as an exempt communication.

question: When a Relevant Person proposes to rely on a Person in (1) for elements of CDD, how must it determine and evidence that the third party is regulated in a country with AML/TFS rules equivalent to FATF standards, and what immediate CDD-information and document-availability steps must be taken as part of that reliance?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person may rely on a Person in (1) for relevant elements of CDD only if it both (i) meets the operational conditions for third-party reliance and (ii) is satisfied that the third party is regulated and supervised in a country whose AML/TFS regulations are equivalent to FATF standards. [#TGT:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275] To support the equivalence determination, the Relevant Person must take into account a range of jurisdictional indicators, including published mutual evaluations or assessment/follow-up reports by bodies such as FATF, the IMF, the World Bank, the OECD or other International Organisations, as well as whether the jurisdiction is a member of FATF or regional groups (e.g., MENAFATF or the Gulf Co-operation Council). [#SRC:06794d47-81ee-49d0-bf3a-58e87a031da4] It must also consider contextual risk factors like political stability and corruption levels, and any recent criticism (including FATF advisory notices or public assessments by the listed organisations, or reports from relevant NGOs or specialist commercial organisations). [#SRC:06794d47-81ee-49d0-bf3a-58e87a031da4] In parallel, it must immediately obtain the necessary CDD information from the third party and take adequate steps to ensure certified copies of the documents used for the relied-on CDD elements will be available on request without delay. [#TGT:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275] Finally, it must confirm the third party did not use an exception for any CDD element being relied on and that any information relied on is up to date. [#TGT:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275]

question: How must a firm and an Authorised Person ensure their risk management arrangements are designed and maintained so they provide the practical capability to identify, assess, mitigate, control, and monitor risks, including in a way that can be evaluated through internal self-assessment and supervisory review?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure its risk management systems provide it with the means to identify, assess, mitigate, monitor, and control its risks, and it should be able to evidence this capability through its own internal risk self-assessment and the controls and mitigation programmes it has in place, which may be reviewed as part of an external assessment of how those risks impact supervisory objectives and the likelihood of occurrence [#SRC:f5c0b126-6b54-4fe9-9522-52952b6adad1]. In parallel, an Authorised Person must establish and maintain risk management systems and controls that enable it to identify, assess, mitigate, control, and monitor its risks, meaning the arrangements must be operationally effective and kept current rather than being a one-off design exercise [#TGT:6f83c3c2-989d-47c2-952e-b1d8c7fb6c21]. Read together, the obligations require both the existence and ongoing maintenance of systems and controls, and that those systems demonstrably provide the tools and processes needed to manage risks across the full lifecycle from identification and assessment through mitigation, control, and monitoring, with documentation and self-assessment supporting reviewability.
source_text: Review of risk management systems. Under GEN 3.3.4, a firm must ensure that its risk management systems provide the firm with the means to identify, assess, mitigate, monitor and control its risks. In addition to undertaking our own assessment of the firm, we may review the firm's internal risk self-assessment and determine the extent to which each of the firm's risks impact our objectives, the likelihood of the risk occurring, and the controls and mitigation programmes the firm has in place.
target_text: Risk management: An Authorised Person must establish and maintain risk management systems and controls to enable it to identify, assess, mitigate, control and monitor its risks.

question: If the Regulator shares Confidential Information, can it put conditions on that permission—like requiring consents or requiring the receiver to follow confidentiality limits that are at least equivalent to the usual restrictions?
gold_answer: Yes. When the Regulator discloses Confidential Information, it is permitted to include conditions as part of the permission to disclose, to the extent the Regulator considers appropriate. Those conditions can cover practical safeguards around the disclosure, including requiring that consents are obtained and, where appropriate, requiring that the recipient treats the information under restrictions on further disclosure that are at least equivalent to the relevant confidentiality restrictions. In other words, the Regulator can allow disclosure but only on terms that control how the information is handled after it is shared, rather than granting an unrestricted permission. In addition, the same permission allows the Regulator to restrict the uses to which the disclosed Confidential Information may be put, so the recipient may be limited not only in whether it can re-disclose the information but also in what it can do with it. This aligns with the statement that the Regulator may impose conditions on the information disclosed (including consents and equivalent restrictions) and may restrict uses [#SRC:5b971fba-9c2c-40a0-9b54-e38c1d4d3350], and with the permission being expressly subject to such conditions insofar as the Regulator considers appropriate [#TGT:98d99b60-b14d-4468-becd-e2c79c8f8b4a].
source_text:
Section 199(3) of the FSMR enables the Regulator to, among other things:
(a)	impose conditions on the information disclosed, which may relate to, among other things, the obtaining of consents or, where appropriate, subjecting information received to restrictions on disclosure that are at least equivalent to those set out in section 198, per paragraph 199(3)(a); and
(b)	restrict the uses to which the Confidential Information disclosed may be put.
target_text:
Any disclosure by the Regulator pursuant to subsection  ‎(1) may include, insofar as the Regulator considers appropriate, provisions—
(a)	making any permission to disclose Confidential Information subject to conditions (which may relate to the obtaining of consents, subjecting information received to restrictions on disclosure of Confidential Information at least equivalent to those set out in section 198 or any other matter); and
(b)	restricting the uses to which Confidential Information disclosed may be put.

question: When an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and is using the FCCA, and the transaction is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, what must the Authorised Person do to determine the adjusted exposure value and how must that value be used in the credit risk exposure calculation, taking into account the required haircut-based methodology and the exclusion of OTC Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions?
gold_answer: Where an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and is using the FCCA, it must calculate an adjusted exposure value (E*) in accordance with the applicable Rules and then use that E* in place of the unadjusted exposure (E) when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for the relevant CR Exposure [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de]. For collateralised transactions within scope of the haircut approach—i.e., transactions not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement or a qualifying cross product Netting agreement, and excluding OTC Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions—the Authorised Person must compute E* using the specified formula that applies supervisory or own-estimate haircuts under the FCCA [#TGT:bfe1d138-bbe5-4cfd-b804-a89cccbf6949]. This requires determining E as the fair value of the Exposure, applying the appropriate Exposure haircut (HE), valuing the eligible financial Collateral received (C), applying the appropriate Collateral haircut (HC, including weighted treatment for baskets), and applying any currency mismatch haircut (HFX), with E* floored at zero. The resulting E* is the exposure value after risk mitigation and is the value substituted into the credit risk exposure calculation.
source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT that is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and using the FCCA, must calculate E* in accordance with Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4, and substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for that CR Exposure under Section 4.8.

question: If an Applicant has less than three years of audited financial statements and the Regulator generally expects quarterly cash reports in that situation, what audited accounts must the Applicant have published or filed, and what key requirements must those accounts satisfy?
gold_answer: If an Applicant has less than three years of audited financial statements, the Regulator will generally require a Reporting Entity to comply with the quarterly cash reporting expectation in that circumstance, including where the Listed Entity is admitted under the assets eligibility test or where the Regulator considers quarterly cash reports necessary for other reasons such as a cash-box admission [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8]. Separately, the Applicant must have published or filed audited accounts that cover three years, unless the Regulator accepts a shorter period, which is the built-in flexibility for Applicants that do not have a full three-year audited track record [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1]. The audited accounts must be consolidated for the Applicant and any subsidiary undertakings, prepared under IFRS or other standards acceptable to the Regulator, and audited and reported on by auditors using IAASB auditing standards or other standards acceptable to the Regulator [#TGT:fa97161e-1e4a-4a6b-b09a-bf0989e66ff1]. In practice, this means the Applicant must both (i) ensure its audited accounts meet these content and audit-quality conditions (even if for a shorter period accepted by the Regulator) and (ii) be prepared for the Regulator’s general expectation of quarterly cash reporting triggered by having less than three years of audited financial statements [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8].
source_text: The Regulator will generally require a Reporting Entity to comply with Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i) in circumstances where the Listed Entity with Securities being admitted to the Official List is admitted under the assets eligibility test (see Rule 2.3.16), has less than three years of audited financial statements as prescribed in Rule 2.3.2(1), or is considered by the Regulator, for other reasons, to require quarterly cash reports, such as the admission of a cash-box.

question: When a Relevant Person performs its business-wide risk assessment, how must it address risks arising from carrying on NFTF business and the use of eKYC Systems, and how must those considerations be integrated into the identification, assessment, and mitigation of money laundering risks across the firm’s activities?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person must take appropriate steps to identify and assess the money laundering risks to which its business is exposed, taking into consideration the nature, size and complexity of its activities, and it must recognise that those risks include terrorist financing, proliferation financing, the financing of unlawful organisations, and sanctions non-compliance (including non-compliance with Targeted Financial Sanctions) [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. In doing so, its business risk assessment should include an assessment of the risks associated with carrying on NFTF business, particularly where it uses eKYC Systems [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2]. The Relevant Person must also, to the extent relevant, take into account vulnerabilities relating to its customers, geographies, products and services, distribution channels and business partners, transaction complexity and volume, new products and business practices, and the use of new or developing technologies, which would encompass eKYC-enabled processes and NFTF-related activity profiles [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. Finally, it must take appropriate measures to ensure identified risks are reflected in day-to-day operations and mitigated, and the assessment should consider incorporating relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator and other relevant bodies [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2] [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851].
source_text: A business risk assessment under Rule ‎6.1.1(b) should include an assessment of the risks associated with the carrying on of NFTF business, particularly the use of eKYC Systems. The assessment should consider incorporating any relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and any other relevant bodies.

question: In the context of an investigation, when may the Investigator compel attendance at an interview and questioning, and does that authority extend beyond the Person Under Investigation to other individuals regardless of any connection to that person, provided the requirement is issued by written notice?
gold_answer: Across the two provisions, the Investigator is permitted to compel a person to attend an interview and answer questions as part of an investigation, and the mechanism and scope are clarified. The SOURCE establishes the core investigative permission: the Investigator has the power to require a person (described as the interviewee) to attend an interview and answer questions for the purposes of an investigation [#SRC:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf]. The TARGET then specifies how and to whom that power may be directed: the Investigator may do so by written notice, and the notice may be addressed either to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, expressly including persons who are not connected to the Person Under Investigation [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]. Read together, the Investigator’s permission is not limited to the subject of the investigation; it can reach third parties, and it is exercisable through a written notice that can require attendance at a specified time and place and answering questions. This combined reading supports compliance planning for both primary subjects and potential third-party interviewees.
source_text: Power to require a person to attend an interview . Under section 206(1)(a) of FSMR, the Investigator has the power to require a person (the interviewee) to attend an interview and answer questions for the purposes of an investigation.

question: If a rated short term corporate CR Exposure gets a 150% risk weight, what risk weight must an Authorised Person apply to any unrated exposure to the same corporate (short term or long term), and how is that different from the table’s unrated corporate risk weight?
gold_answer: If the Authorised Person has a short term CR Exposure in the corporate asset class with an issue-specific external credit assessment that attracts a 150% risk weight, they must apply a 150% risk weight to any unrated CR Exposure to the same corporate, whether that unrated exposure is long term or short term [#SRC:f80ad0a8-f280-43e0-a71b-74b00c8175ad]. This is different from the corporate asset class table’s general unrated treatment, which assigns 100% to “Unrated” corporate exposures (subject to the stated rule cross-references) [#TGT:ee286214-80b1-480f-8be1-055c442795e4]. In other words, the table provides a baseline for unrated corporate exposures, but the specific rule for the same corporate requires a higher risk weight when there is a related rated short term issue at 150%. The Authorised Person should therefore use 150% for the unrated exposure to that corporate, even though the table’s unrated column would otherwise suggest 100%.
source_text:
Corporate asset class. The risk weight for any CR Exposure in the corporate asset class that does not have an external credit assessment by a recognised external credit rating agency must be the risk weight determined in accordance with the table under Rule 4.12.13 or the risk weight that is applicable to an CR Exposure to the central government of the jurisdiction in which the corporate is incorporated or established, whichever is higher. If a short term CR Exposure in the corporate asset class with an issue specific external credit assessment:
(a)	attracts a risk weight of 50% or 100%, then the Authorised Person must apply a risk weight of not lower than 100% to any unrated short term CR Exposure to the same corporate; or
(b)	attracts a risk weight of 150%, then the Authorised Person must apply a risk weight of 150% to any unrated CR Exposure (whether long term or short term) to the same corporate.
target_text:
Corporate asset class. Subject to Rules 4.12.14 and 4.12.15, an Authorised Person must risk weight any CR Exposure in the corporate asset class in accordance with the following table:
Risk Weights for the corporate asset class
/Table Start

Credit Quality Grade	1	2	3	4	5	6	Unrated
Risk Weight	20%	50%	100%	100%	150%	150%	100%

/Table End

question: When the Regulator is considering disqualifying an auditor or actuary for a contravention, how should it determine both whether to disqualify and the scope of the disqualification (e.g., across any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity or a particular class), and what case-specific factors must be weighed?
gold_answer: Where the Regulator considers an auditor or actuary has contravened these Regulations, it has discretion to disqualify that person from acting for any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity, or for a particular class of them; the scope decision is therefore part of the same assessment as whether to disqualify at all. [#TGT:5cca9150-8e16-41b4-a5ef-74950916d06e] In deciding whether to exercise the disqualification power and what the scope of any disqualification will be, the Regulator must evaluate all the circumstances of the case, rather than relying on a single trigger. [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22] The factors to be weighed include the nature and seriousness of the contravention and its effects, and whether the contravention (or any failure to disclose information to the Regulator) has resulted in or is likely to result in customer loss, reputational damage to the ADGM, or increased financial-crime risk involving a firm, Recognised Body, or Reporting Entity. [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22] The Regulator should also consider remedial actions taken by the auditor or actuary, any professional-body disciplinary action (and whether it adequately addresses the contravention), and the auditor’s or actuary’s prior compliance record including relevant prior sanctions. [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22]
target_text: If the Regulator considers that an auditor or actuary has committed a contravention of these Regulations, it may disqualify the auditor or actuary from being the auditor of, or (as the case may be), from acting as an actuary for, any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity or any particular class thereof.

question: If an Authorised Person finds it does not meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, and later wants to do the kinds of actions listed in Rule 3.19.3(b)(i) and (ii), what are the two main things it has to do: (1) how must it cap what it distributes after telling the Regulator, and (2) what must be in the capital conservation plan and when must it be sent?
gold_answer: In this situation, the Authorised Person has two linked duties: it must keep any later distributions within a calculated cap (after notifying the Regulator) and it must produce a detailed capital conservation plan for the Regulator within a short deadline. [#SRC:27f9bf56-82e3-4122-9d99-41e44b5fee9e] [#TGT:7a946965-716a-431a-b643-57f91e0ff92e] On distributions, when it subsequently takes any of the actions described in Rule 3.19.3(b)(i) and (ii), it must first calculate the maximum distributable amount and notify the Regulator, and then ensure it distributes no more than that calculated maximum distributable amount. [#SRC:27f9bf56-82e3-4122-9d99-41e44b5fee9e] On the plan, once it has identified that it fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must prepare a capital conservation plan and submit it to the Regulator no later than five business days after that identification. [#TGT:7a946965-716a-431a-b643-57f91e0ff92e] The plan must cover financial projections (income/expenditure estimates and a forecast balance sheet), steps to increase CET1 Capital, and a plan and timeframe to raise CET1 Capital with the aim of restoring the Combined Buffer, plus any other information the Regulator might need for its considerations referred to in Rule 3.19.10. [#TGT:7a946965-716a-431a-b643-57f91e0ff92e]
source_text:
Restrictions on distributions. An Authorised Person must:
(a)	in subsequently taking any of the actions described in Rule 3.19.3(b)(i) and (ii), after having calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator, ensure that it distributes no more than its calculated maximum distributable amount; and
(b)	prepare and submit a capital conservation plan pursuant to Rule 3.19.9.

question: When a Listed Entity is determining whether it is prohibited from issuing or agreeing to issue Equity Securities above its calculated maximum without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities, how must it count fully paid Ordinary Securities, partly paid Securities, and Convertible Securities in the calculation, and what discretion does the Regulator have to alter that counting?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity is prohibited from issuing, or agreeing to issue, more Equity Securities than the maximum number produced by the prescribed calculation unless it first obtains the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]. To apply that prohibition correctly, the Listed Entity must calculate the number of Equity Securities it “may issue or agree to issue” by applying the counting rules for different instruments: each fully paid Ordinary Security counts as one; each partly paid Security counts as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities into which it can be paid up; and each Convertible Security counts as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities into which it can be converted [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f]. For any other type of Security, the count is determined as the Regulator may decide, with regard to ensuring holders of Ordinary Securities have an opportunity to vote on issues that may dilute their holdings or based on the Security’s characteristics [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f]. These counting steps feed into the maximum-cap framework (including the “Relevant Issues” concept) that triggers the approval requirement when exceeded [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933].
target_text:
Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities:
Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues),
where:
Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of:
(1)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16);
(2)	fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was:
(i)	entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or
(ii)	approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and
(3)	any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5;
Guidance
The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1.
(4)	partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement,
but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement.
Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than:
(a)	with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or
(b)	under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a compliant disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, what does it still have to include in that first disclosure, and what does it need to do in a later update so it can avoid repeating the same detailed information?
gold_answer: In the first disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, the Mining Reporting Entity must include the required elements for a disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1: all material economic assumptions employed, plus (if it considers those assumptions commercially sensitive) a statement that they are commercially sensitive and an explanation of the methodology used to determine them, as well as all other material assumptions utilised [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. It must also include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3 [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. Once that compliant disclosure has been made, a later disclosure about forecast financial information derived from a Production Target does not need to repeat the information in Rule 11.9.2, but only if it references the earlier disclosure that complied with Rule 11.9.2 and includes a confirmation that all material assumptions from the initial disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]. Depending on whether the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or partly on an Exploration Target, the later disclosure must also include an equally prominent and proximate statement of the specified type [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4].
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure does not follow a non-mandatory requirement in a Mining Reporting Standard, what must it say in the disclosure, given the Regulator’s expectation about complying with those non-mandatory requirements?
gold_answer: The Mining Reporting Entity should approach non-mandatory requirements in a Mining Reporting Standard as requirements it is expected to fully comply with, even though they are not described as binding, because the Regulator expects full compliance with those non-mandatory requirements (in addition to full compliance with binding requirements) [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124]. When the Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure does not meet a non-mandatory requirement contained in the relevant Mining Reporting Standard, it must address that gap directly in the disclosure itself by providing a statement that explains both (1) how the disclosure differs from the non-mandatory requirement and (2) why it differs [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f]. This means the disclosure should not merely note that the requirement is “non-mandatory”; it must describe the nature of the non-compliance and the reason for it, so the reader can understand the deviation against the relevant Mining Reporting Standard [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f]. This disclosure statement also aligns with the Regulator’s expectation that the Mining Reporting Entity either fully complies with non-mandatory requirements or explains its non-compliance [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124].
source_text: Rule 11.2.1(1) requires a Mining Reporting Entity to fully comply with all binding requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard. The Regulator also expects a Mining Reporting Entity to fully comply with all non-mandatory requirements set out in a Mining Reporting Standard, including, for example, Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code, or explain its non-compliance in accordance with Rule 11.2.2.
target_text: Requirements for all disclosures. Where a disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity does not meet a non-mandatory requirement contained in a Mining Reporting Standard, the Mining Reporting Entity must provide in its disclosure a statement as to how and why its disclosure differs from the non-mandatory requirement contained in the relevant Mining Reporting Standard.

question: When an Authorised Person wants to provide credit to a Related Person on terms more favourable than those offered to Persons who are not Related Persons, what must its Credit Risk policy include to rely on the employee-credit-policy carve-out while still meeting the conflicts/approval-process controls for Related Person transactions?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person may only treat more-favourable credit to a Related Person as permissible if it is delivered under an Employee credit policy that is widely available to Employees and is approved by the Authorised Person's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate. [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91] To rely on that approach within its Credit Risk policy framework, the policy must also include adequate conflicts-of-interest procedures for the provision and management of credit, including measures to prevent any Person who directly or indirectly benefits from the credit from being involved in granting or managing it. [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496] The employee policy must clearly specify the terms, conditions and limits for providing credit to those Employees, including limits at both individual and aggregate levels, and it must include mechanisms to ensure ongoing compliance. [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91] Those mechanisms must include immediate reporting to the Governing Body or its delegate if there is any deviation from, or breach of, the applicable terms, conditions, or procedures so timely and appropriate action can be taken. [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91] Separately, where the policy allows Exposures to Related Persons (on no-more-favourable terms), it must require prior written approval by the Governing Body or its delegate for Exposures (and any write-off) exceeding specified amounts or otherwise posing special risks, and it must exclude beneficiaries from the approval process. [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496]
source_text:
Credit Risk policy. In relation to conflicts of interest and Related Person transactions, the policy must:
(a)	set out adequate procedures for handling conflicts of interest relating to the provision and management of credit, including measures to prevent any Person directly or indirectly benefiting from the credit being part of the process of granting or managing the credit;
(b)	subject to Rule 4.4.5, prohibit Exposures to Related Persons on terms that are more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons; and
(c)	if Exposures to Related Persons are allowed on terms which are no more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons, set out procedures that:
(i)	require such Exposures, and any write off of such Exposures, exceeding specific amounts or otherwise posing special risks to the Authorised Person, to be made subject to the prior written approval of the firm's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate; and
(ii)	exclude Persons directly or indirectly benefiting from the grant or write off of such Exposures being part of the approval process.

question: When a Fund Manager appoints an auditor for a Fund, what must the Fund Manager require the auditor to do in relation to auditing the Fund’s financial statements, and what specific statements must the Fund Manager ensure the Auditor includes when producing the Fund Auditor’s Report?
gold_answer: A Fund Manager must take two linked steps that span both the audit work and the resulting reporting. First, the Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to conduct an audit of the Fund’s financial statements in accordance with the requirements of the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB), and to produce a Fund Auditor’s Report on the audited financial statements [#SRC:8949f938-33e5-4393-a256-021917125579]. Second, when procuring the production of that Fund Auditor’s Report, the Fund Manager must ensure that an Auditor states a defined set of matters in the report, including whether the financial statements were properly prepared in accordance with the financial reporting standards adopted by the Fund, whether they give a true and fair view of the Fund’s (or Sub-Fund’s) financial position and results for the annual accounting period, whether proper accounting records have not been kept or the statements are not in agreement with records/returns or do not comply with applicable standards, whether the Auditor received all necessary information and explanations, whether the Directors’ report or the Fund Manager’s report is consistent with the financial statements, and any other matter required by FUNDS [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce].
source_text:
Function of the Auditor. A Fund Manager must, in writing, require its auditor to:
(a)	conduct an audit of the Fund's financial statements in accordance with the requirements of the relevant standards published by the International Auditing and Assurance Standards Board (IAASB); and
(b)	produce a Fund Auditor's Report on the audited financial statements in accordance with GEN Rule 6.6.8.

question: When a Relevant Person looks at risks from new or developing technologies, how should it treat eKYC Systems used in NFTF business, and what must it do with any risks it finds?
gold_answer: A Relevant Person must identify and assess the money laundering risks to which its business is exposed, and when doing that work it must take into account, to the extent relevant, vulnerabilities relating to the use of new or developing technologies for both new and pre-existing products and services [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. In that context, its business risk assessment should include an assessment of the risks associated with carrying on NFTF business, particularly the use of eKYC Systems, because eKYC is a technology-driven mechanism that can affect how customers are onboarded and how services are delivered [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2]. The Relevant Person must also keep in view that money laundering risks include terrorist financing, proliferation financing, the financing of unlawful organisations, and sanctions non-compliance, so the technology/NFTF analysis should be aligned to those risk types [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851]. The assessment should consider incorporating any relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and any other relevant bodies [#SRC:31f0a7bd-a9fa-4aab-a4b4-32d0a6fb51b2]. After identifying risks, the Relevant Person must take appropriate measures to ensure they are taken into account in day-to-day operations and mitigated, including in relation to new products, new customers, and changes to its business profile [#TGT:e86229e2-4422-4a87-a0f6-ff61d6a28851].
source_text: A business risk assessment under Rule ‎6.1.1(b) should include an assessment of the risks associated with the carrying on of NFTF business, particularly the use of eKYC Systems. The assessment should consider incorporating any relevant mitigation measures identified by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and any other relevant bodies.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information and also discloses the key underlying assumptions and outcomes of a relevant Technical Study used to support an Ore Reserves estimate, what must it include regarding the economic assumptions, and how should it address any claim that those assumptions are commercially sensitive?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity must ensure its disclosure is complete across both the forecast financial information assumptions and the Technical Study disclosures supporting an Ore Reserves estimate. For the forecast financial information, it must include all material economic assumptions employed, and it must also include all other material assumptions utilised. If it considers the material economic assumptions commercially sensitive, it must provide a statement that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions, rather than omitting them without context [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]. In parallel, where the entity has carried out a relevant Technical Study (a preliminary feasibility study or feasibility study) to achieve the required level of confidence in the modifying factors used to determine an estimate of Ore Reserves, it must disclose the key underlying assumptions and outcomes of that Technical Study [#TGT:30cf9cda-951e-48ba-9be2-61a889a87464]. Taken together, the disclosures should allow users to understand both the economic basis of the forecast financial information and the principal assumptions/outcomes underpinning the Ore Reserves estimate.
source_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
target_text: ORE RESERVES . Pursuant to Rule 11.6.1(1)(a), in order to achieve the required level of confidence in the modifying factors to determine an estimate of Ore Reserves, a Mining Reporting Entity will need to have carried out a relevant Technical Study (preliminary feasibility study or feasibility study ).  The key underlying assumptions and outcomes of the Technical Study are also to be disclosed.
